SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1172 words

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Tale of Bad Timing at AMF: Silk Stockings and Bowling Shows

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
When Goldman, Sachs led a buyout of AMF Bowling in 1996, some analysts wondered why a silk-stocking investment bank would risk sullying its image in such a pedestrian pursuit. But, after four years under Goldman's control, it is AMF's image that has suffered as the company has racked up losses and its stock price has sunk to 75 cents a share.
Having traded for less than $1 a share for more than 30 consecutive days, AMF -- arguably the biggest name in bowling -- is in danger of being delisted from the New York Stock Exchange and investors are wondering if the company will have to sort out its financial troubles in bankruptcy court. People close to the company, which is based in Richmond, Va., said that AMF's board discussed a range of revamping options, including a prepackaged bankruptcy filing, last week in New York. 
 AMF is saddled with about $1.2 billion in debt. Its bonds have been trading for 20 percent to 30 percent of their face value.
When the company releases its second-quarter earnings within the next two weeks, those investors who still are paying attention will focus less on what happened in the traditionally slower spring season than on what the company has to say about its future plans. After all, the earnings cannot surprise analysts because nobody on Wall Street follows AMF's stock any more.
Ronald Baron, chief executive of Baron Capital, once was one of AMF's biggest boosters, predicting that the stock price would soar to $100 by 2003. Now, with his company and its mutual funds holding more than 11 million shares of AMF, Mr. Baron will not discuss AMF. Through a spokesman, he denied that his funds, the biggest investor in the company after Goldman, were among the sellers when AMF shares dropped to a record low of 18.75 cents on June 30.
Stephen E. Hare, AMF's chief financial officer, said in an interview that "the capital structure needs to be fixed" but the company has not settled on a solution. He declined to discuss the possibility of a voluntary bankruptcy filing and said that the company had not started negotiating with its creditors. But it is clear that changes must be made before AMF has to start making much bigger payments to bondholders in about a year.
"The meter is running," Mr. Hare said "It's fair for the markets to say, 'Show us the plan.' When we have a plan that we're comfortable with, you'll see us announce it."
In the meantime, Mr. Hare acknowledged, the company, its industry and its employees are all suffering. "Just the fact that the stock has not been successful in the last year, I don't think speaks well for the industry," he said, "We feel a certain obligation to be successful for the industry at large."
Goldman officials declined to comment.
Mr. Hare said that company officials have talked to representatives of the New York Stock Exchange about how to get back into compliance with the exchange's listing standards. AMF has less than 30 days to come up with a plan. One possibility: a reverse stock split that would reduce the number of shares outstanding to push up their price and buy management more time to realign the company.
How AMF, under Goldman's control, got into such a bind is a complicated story that involves Asian economics, American social trends and the ways of Wall Street.
In 1996, Goldman led a leveraged buyout of AMF. A year later, the firm took the company public again, raising $263 million by selling shares for $19.50 each.
The pitch for the 1997 initial offering was that AMF would buy bowling alleys around the United States and would capitalize on a growing craze for bowling in China and other parts of Asia. AMF would make money two ways: by operating a chain of bowling centers and by selling the equipment to outfit new ones overseas.
But while AMF was gobbling up alleys and trying to run them more efficiently, league bowling -- the lifeblood of the bowling business -- was dying. Leagues, which represent a predictable stream of revenue from September through March, once accounted for as much as 80 percent of a bowling center's business, said Sandy Hansell, a bowling consultant in Southfield, Mich. That share has dropped to about 50 percent, he said.
Then in the summer of 1998, an economic crisis swept across Asia, wiping out demand for capital-intensive leisure activities like bowling.
Suddenly, Goldman was the majority owner of a heavily indebted company in a slow-growth business. The bowling products business, which had generated about $70 million in cash flow in 1997, produced less than $10 million in cash flow last year, Mr. Hare said. He said demand for bowling is still growing in some countries, including England, but "what we don't see right now are any markets that have that boom potential."
AMF's board -- which has Richard A. Friedman, who runs Goldman's merchant-banking operations, as chairman -- removed the company's management. Last year, the directors hired Roland Smith, who formerly ran the Arby's fast-food chain, as chief executive.
Mr. Smith is slowing the pace of acquisitions while the company devises a strategy for marketing its 417 United States bowling centers as a national chain, Mr. Hare said. The company is spending about $10 million to gear all of its centers for what it calls Xtreme bowling, a nighttime activity aimed at teenagers and other recreational bowlers, and is considering an extensive ad campaign, he said.
Without a big increase in revenue, the bowling centers are quite profitable on an operating basis, Mr. Hansell, the consultant, said. And, despite its slower growth, the bowling business is healthy, with most lane operators making more money than they ever have, he said.
The tough question for AMF and Goldman is how they can relieve the company of some of its debt burden before it snuffs the life out of bowling-center operations. It is a rare problem for Mr. Friedman and Goldman's other merchant bankers, who have rolled their share of strikes, most recently in having a big stake in VoiceStream Wireless when Deutsche Telekom agreed to buy that company for a huge premium.
In May 1996, Goldman and its merchant-banking funds put up $260 million for a majority stake in the buyout of AMF. Two other investment banks, Blackstone Group and Kelso & Company, bought smaller stakes, and the company borrowed about $1 billion through bank loans and bond sales.
Along the way, Goldman received about $50 million in fees for advising the company and underwriting securities, including its initial public offering of stock. Now its 45 million shares are worth less than that, about $34 million. Goldman officials will not say how much the firm has lost on its AMF investment, but a person close to the matter said the firm is feeling "a lot of pain."
No matter what happens to AMF, Mr. Hansell said, the bowling business will survive.
"If AMF went belly up, would it be a problem?" he said. "It would hurt, but it wouldn't be cataclysmic. The other 5,000 bowling centers in this country would roll along."

HEADLINE: President Opens Attack On the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By CARL H. LAVIN 

DATELINE: PALM BEACH, Fla., July 31

 BODY:
President Clinton took on the Republicans and their platform today in a series of Florida appearances that raised more than $1.2 million for his party and rallied support for his plan to expand Medicare to provide prescription drug insurance.
Speaking to Medicare beneficiaries at a community center in Tampa, the president continued his attack on the host of tax cuts being passed by the Republican-controlled Congress. 
 "You may hear, if you turn on the television, the Republicans, when they meet in Philadelphia in convention, talking about all their tax-cut bills and how wonderful they'd be for you," Mr. Clinton said. "But what they don't say is that if you take all their tax-cut proposals in total, it spends the entire projected surplus of the country for the next 10 years."
He compared tax-cut legislation being sent to him by Congress to the choices a diner faces at a well-stocked restaurant: "When I go to a cafeteria, everything I see looks good. But if I eat it all, I'll get sick."
Accompanied by Bill Nelson, the Florida insurance commissioner, who is running for the Senate, Mr. Clinton also told Democratic donors in Tampa and later in Palm Beach that the Republican goal was to blur the differences between the parties on health care, the economy, gun control, the environment and other issues that matter to voters.
"Their strategy is to talk about compassion," and "it's a brilliant strategy," Mr. Clinton said. "It's a pretty package, and they're hoping if they wrap it tight enough, nobody will open it before Christmas."
At a fund-raising reception here for Mr. Nelson, the president emphasized that the Democratic strategy should be to stay positive -- "you don't have to say a bad word about our opponents," he said -- but to explain to voters how the parties differ.

HEADLINE: Image and Reality on Education

 BODY:
The first of four theme nights at the Republican Party's meticulously planned national convention focused on what has become George W. Bush's signature issue -- education, particularly education for young, poor children. In terms of giving this convention a softer and more inclusive feel, this was a wise choice. Yet it also illuminated the central paradox of a conclave marking Mr. Bush's emergence as the party's trend-setter. On the one hand, the vast convention hall was positively awash in soaring language and inspiring individual success stories designed to highlight Mr. Bush's signature promise that no child, no matter how disadvantaged, would be left behind. On the other hand, the same delegates who cheered this vision in prime time had earlier ratified a platform that defines a narrower, less generous world in which the federal government has virtually no role to play in shaping the country's educational future.
This paradox revolves around a fundamental question about Mr. Bush's candidacy, a question he can go a long way toward answering in his acceptance speech Thursday night. Does his noble rhetoric about compassionate conservatism spring from a genuine determination to lead his party toward a more activist role in education, or is it just empty salesmanship? Based on the numbers, the rank-and-file seems willing to be led. In a New York Times survey of delegates to this convention, 26 percent ranked education the No. 1 issue in their states, whereas four years ago the economy was No. 1 for the same number and education received a measly 2 percent. Yet it was not clear whether they were prepared to spend more money on the problem than their leaders in Congress, who for the last eight years have often tried to cut education spending. 
 True to Mr. Bush's desire to convey optimism on even the most difficult issues, last night's menu of speeches and visuals was relentlessly upbeat and demographically inclusive -- a fourth-grade teacher from North Carolina discussing math and science, a video from a largely Hispanic school in El Paso, brief testimonials to the virtues of parental involvement and after-school enrichment, and a speech by his wife, Laura, about her experience as a teacher and their joint commitment to education. The evening was topped off by an inspirational testimonial to racial fairness and educational opportunity from probably the most popular Republican in America, Gen. Colin Powell.
The reality of the platform was quite different. At Governor Bush's insistence, the committee dropped a harsh and longstanding provision calling for the abolition of the Department of Education. The document also quoted lofty pledges that under a Bush presidency no American child would be "segregated by low expectations, imprisoned by illiteracy, abandoned to frustration and the darkness of self-doubt." Yet when the document turned to substance, it pointed in a direction opposite to that proclaimed in Mr. Bush's oratory. The platform insisted that "the role of the federal government must be progressively limited as we return control to parents, teachers and local school boards." The platform then goes on to extol remedies like those celebrated in last night's displays -- charter schools, parental involvement and the like -- while writing off Title I, the main federal program aimed at disadvantaged children, as a $120 billion failure.
Governor Bush is the only person in Philadelphia who can fix this disconnect. This is a nation in which a lot of children are in trouble -- 11 million with no health insurance and nearly 13 million, one in five, living in poverty, untouched by the present prosperity. Head Start could handle a million more eligible children with more generous financing. It may be too much to expect Mr. Bush to redesign his proposed $1.3 trillion in tax cuts in order to pay for these and similarly worthy ventures. But even those who no longer doubt the sincerity of his belief that no child should be left behind have a perfect right to ask him how he means to balance the scales.

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS;
Excerpts From General Powell's Address to Republicans

 BODY:

Following are excerpts from Retired Gen. Colin Powell's speech at the Republican National Convention yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
During the almost seven years since I retired from the Army I've traveled all across America. I've seen people hard at work providing for their families, giving of themselves, taking care of each other. I've seen them creating wealth for the nation, I've seen an economy transforming itself to seize the promise of the information revolution. . . . 
 I've been moved yet again to stand in awe of the American dream, which was given birth in this city over 200 years ago. A dream that I have been privileged to live. I've met so many young people who believe in the dream. They're on a road to success. . . .
There is so much that is so good and right in America tonight my friends that we ought to be very, very proud of this wonderful country of ours. And yet I cannot ignore and we cannot ignore other things I've seen in my travels. I've seen poverty. I've seen failing communities. I've seen people who've lost hope. Tragically, I've seen too many young Americans who were overwhelmed by the daily struggle just to survive. I've seen kids destroying themselves with drugs. Kids who see violence and crime as the answer to their hopelessness. Kids who no longer believe in themselves and who don't see a reason to believe in America. I've seen kids in utter despair. I've visited kids in jail doing adult time for the crimes they've committed. They are part of a growing population of over two million Americans behind bars. . . . Most of them are men and the majority of those men are minorities.
The issue of race still casts a shadow over our society. Despite the impressive progress we have made over the last 40 years to overcome this legacy of our troubled past, it is still with us.
So with all the success we have enjoyed and with all the wealth we have created we have much more work to do and a long way to go to bring the promise of America to every single American.
And with all we have to do in our national agenda, I am convinced that to deliver on that promise we must begin with our children. So many of the problems we worry about go back to how we raised our children. The problem is as simple and as direct as this: we either get back to the task of building our children the way we know how or we're going to keep building jails in America. And it's time to stop building jails in America and get back to the task of building our children.
Listen. Listen. And listen, listen, listen very carefully. Our children are not the problem. They are our future. They are America's promise. The problem is us if we've failed to give them what they need to be successful in life. The burden is on us, not on our children.
That mission of providing for our children has become the passion of my life. Because what I've seen over the last several years convinces me of the following truths:
That if you want to solve our drug problem, you won't do it by trying to cut off supply and arresting pushers on the street corners alone. It will only be solved when we place into the heart of every child growing up in America the moral strength never to fall for the destructive lure of drugs, the strength -- only -- we will only solve and cure this plague of drugs is when we have given to each and every one of our children the strength to just say, and you've heard it before, just say no, not me, I won't do it, I've got too much to live for, I'll never do drugs. . . .
Tonight we focus on education, the keystone to it all. Governor Bush has rightly made children and education the centerpiece of his campaign for president. . . . Every child deserves and must receive a quality education. Because when you give a quality education to a child who believes in himself or herself then even with the bleakest beginning in life that child can make it. And once that child makes it and gets out into the work place and is earning a decent living, you have broken the cycle of poverty and failure for that family forever. Education is the key to breaking that cycle of poverty and failure.
So many, many of our public schools are doing a fine job preparing our youngsters. . . . But I've also seen too many schools that are failing. They are trapped in fossilized bureaucracies. Bureaucracies that have low expectations for children and consequently set low standards for them. These schools are failing our children and they must be fixed and they must be fixed now.
Governor Bush has shown in Texas in just a few short years what can be done for education. As governor, he ended social promotions for kids, he increased state funding by $8 billion, he put new text books in every school in the state of Texas, he strengthened standardized testing in all Texas public schools, he insisted on teacher competency and he expanded the charter school movement. Seventeen thousand Texas kids are now in charter school. Seventy-eight percent of those kids are minorities. Their parents had a choice and they decided what was best for their children. And the results, the results in Texas have been dramatic. . . .
He hasn't stopped there. To ensure a diverse college population with the loss of affirmative action, Governor Bush has guaranteed acceptance at public universities for the top 10 percent of every high school graduating class in the state. . . .
Governor Bush now offers the leadership that he has demonstrated in Texas to the nation. In pursuing educational reform as well as in all other parts of his agenda for Texas, Governor Bush as reached out to all Texans -- white, black, Latino, Asian, Native American. He has been successful in bringing more and more minorities into the tent by responding to their deepest needs. Some call it compassionate conservatism, to me it's just caring about people.
I believe he can do the same thing as president. I am convinced he will bring to the White House that same passion for inclusion. I know that he can help bridge our racial divides. I know that.
Recently, Governor Bush addressed the annual meeting of the N.A.A.C.P. He spoke to the delegates about his plans for housing and health and educational programs to help all Americans. He also spoke the truth to the delegates when he said that the party of Lincoln has not always carried the mantle of Lincoln. I talked with him again today and I know that with all his heart, Governor Bush welcomes the challenge. He wants the Republican party to wear that mantle again.
But he knows and I know and all of you must know that it's going to take hard work. He knows that that mantle will not simply be handed over. That it will have to be earned. The party must follow the governor's lead in reaching out to minority communities. And particularly the African-American community. And not just during an election year campaign. My friends, if we're serious about this, it has to be a sustained effort. It must be every day and it must be for real. The party must listen to and speak with all leaders of the black community regardless of political affiliation or philosophy.
We must understand, my friends, we must understand that there is a problem for us out there. We must understand the cynicism that exists in the black community. The kind of cynicism that is created when, for example, some in our party miss no opportunity to roundly and loudly condemn affirmative action that helped a few thousand black kids get an education. But you hardly hear a whimper when it's affirmative action for lobbyists who load our federal tax code with preferences for special interests. It doesn't work. It doesn't work. You can't make that case.
Overcoming the cynicism and mistrust that exists and raising up that mantle of Lincoln is about more, it's much more about than just winning votes. It is about giving all minorities a competitive choice. They deserve that choice. And if we give them that choice it will be good for our party but above all it will be good for America. And we need to work to give them that choice.
Good for America, that must be the measure for all that we do. I believe that's the measure that Governor Bush will use to guide his actions as president. Whether it's economic policy or military strategy or seeing what we can do to make our American family more inclusive, he will always try to do that which is good and right for America.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
U.S. Is Investigating New York Job Data

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The federal government is investigating New York State's robust 1999 job growth numbers after complaints that the statistics might have been inflated.
In March, the state revised its 1999 job growth rate to 2.9 percent from 1.8 percent, an increase that "looked a little bit unusual," Patricia Getz, division chief for monthly industrial employment statistics at the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said yesterday. "We're just trying to make sure there are not any errors or any problems." 
 The federal Labor Department relies on monthly and yearly job-growth data from states for nationwide reports. The inquiry into the statistics was first reported on Sunday by The Buffalo News.
The state has acknowledged that some jobs were counted twice, saying that the mistakes came in the first quarter of 1999 when the method of processing unemployment insurance forms was changed.
Thomas Rodick, director of research and statistics for the State Department of Labor, described the problems as minimal. The department may be off by about 9,000 jobs, or about "one-tenth of 1 percent" of the statewide total, he said.
In March, Gov. George A. Pataki said that just under 200,000 jobs were created in New York last year, the most in 15 years. A spokesman for Mr. Pataki, Michael McKeon, said yesterday that the governor was "confident with our numbers." Mr. McKeon said the federal investigation could be a move by the Clinton administration to aid Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign, and called it "just an outrage."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Bond Sale to Aid Hospital

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
Seeking to ensure the salvation of a Suffolk County hospital that was nearly shut down early this year, the New York State Dormitory Authority plans to sell up to $118.5 million in tax exempt bonds whose proceeds would be used to put the St. Catherine of Siena Medical Center on a sound, long-term financial footing.
The center, in Smithtown, includes a 311-bed hospital that was previously St. John's Episcopal Hospital. Its former owner, Episcopal Health Services, declared bankruptcy last fall and said it would sell the hospital to Catholic Health Services of Long Island for nearly $100 million. 
 But a labor dispute with the hospital's nurses in January nearly doomed the sale and brought the hospital to the brink of closing. The dispute was resolved, and the sale was completed in February. Officials said then that the hospital employed 1,700 people and that about 400 doctors regularly practiced there.
Also sold was a 240-bed nursing home in the medical complex and a subsidized housing development next to the complex whose 298 apartments are largely occupied by the elderly. Most of the bond proceeds would be used to replace bank financing, which was used in making the purchases, with 30-year fixed-rate bonds whose tax exempt status would permit a lower interest rate. The rest of the bond money would be used for renovations and other costs.
The authority hopes to sell the bonds late next month, a spokeswoman, Claudia Hutton, said yesterday. A hearing on the proposed sale is to be held on Aug. 15 at the agency's Manhattan offices at 1 Pennsylvania Plaza. Joseph P. Fried

HEADLINE: Canadian TV Makes a Move Into Papers

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: MONTREAL, July 31

 BODY:
Making a bold bet on the future braiding of television, newspapers and the Internet, Canada's second-largest private television network said today that it would buy about half of the country's larger daily newspapers from Conrad Black, the international press magnate.
In the largest media deal in Canadian history, CanWest Global Communications, a company that started 20 years ago with a North Dakota television station, is to pay $2.36 billion for dominant dailies in 8 of Canada's 10 provinces. Mr. Black is to gain a seat on the CanWest board and is to become the second-largest shareholder, after the family of the company founder, Israel H. Asper. 
 "The borders are gone, we have to grow," Mr. Asper, Global's chairman, told a news conference in Toronto today, comparing his acquisition to Tribune Media's recent purchase of The Los Angeles Times. "We don't intend to be one of the corpses lying beside the information highway."
Mr. Black said in a statement that his company, Hollinger International, "believes this intimate association with a highly successful telecaster built by an entrepreneurial spirit compatible with Hollinger is the best possible assurance of the strength of the newspaper franchises."
In the political realm, the newspaper ownership change could affect Canada's growing conservative movement. Mr. Black has placed his free-market stamp on some of the nation's most influential editorial pages. During the recent leadership race of the new conservative party, the Canadian Alliance, his National Post newspaper seemed, to some readers, to be the movement's official newspaper.
In contrast, Mr. Asper, who runs his national television network from his hometown of Winnipeg, Manitoba, has long been seen as a low-profile social democrat, running the provincial branch of the Liberal Party for five years in the 1970's. Canada does not have laws barring the ownership of newspapers and television stations in the same media market, and the Liberal government of Jean Chretien is not expected to place regulatory barriers in the way of this merger.
"It looks as if the unapologetic conservative, Conrad Black, has surrendered the reins," Chris Dornan, director of Carleton University's journalism school, said today from Ottawa.
Mr. Black's sale seemed to be motivated at least in part by his large debt load, $1.6 billion. Under the deal, CanWest will assume responsibility for about $460 million in Hollinger debt.
In the first half of this year, Canada's print media suffered a psychological body blow as most of the nation's newspapers were put up for sale, either by Mr. Black or by Kenneth R. Thomson. Mr. Thomson, chairman of the Thomson Corporation, clearly said that he wanted to invest deeper in electronic information services. Two weeks ago, Mr. Thomson completed the sale of his 49 American newspapers, for $2.44 billion. Mr. Thomson is trying to sell five of his Canadian newspapers and has said he will retain ownership of The Globe and Mail of Toronto.
Mr. Black has sent mixed signals about newspapers. In April, he said he wanted to sell his Canadian weeklies and smaller dailies. But with today's announcement, he is selling newspapers that dominate some of Canada's most important markets, including The Ottawa Citizen, The Gazette of Montreal, The Calgary Herald, The Edmonton Sun and The Vancouver Province.
If the sale goes through as expected in late September, Mr. Black, 55, will have tailored his press fief to ownership of newspapers in prestige cities that he cares about: The Daily Telegraph in London, The Jerusalem Post and The Chicago Sun-Times. As for his pet Canadian project, The National Post, a Toronto-based newspaper that in less than two years of existence has added a muscular conservative voice to Canada's intellectual debate, Mr. Black is to become the newspaper's chairman for five years and Hollinger is to retain management control. CanWest will own 50 percent of this newspaper.
Mr. Black was on vacation in Europe and did not return telephone calls left at his Toronto and New York offices. But in his press statement, he seemed to expect criticism.
"There continues to be an audible body of opinion that holds that the newspaper industry has entered a period of stagnation or even decline," said Mr. Black, who is Hollinger's chairman. "We strenuously disagree with this and look forward to demonstrating both the fallacy of this view and the enduring vitality of quality newspaper assets intelligently managed and imaginatively linked with other media."
Don Babick, The Post publisher, declined in an interview to predict how the marriage of electronic and print media would happen, saying only, "We are blending ourselves with a first-class national telecaster."
The deal would strengthen the news-gathering capacity of CanWest, making it "far and away the leading Canadian media operation," said Mr. Dornan, a former television journalist. "These guys are going to have the most robust news rooms in every single market in the country."
CanWest estimated that the combined strengths of the merged operations could save the company up to $100 million a year.
Little known in the United States, CanWest Global emerged in recent years as Canada's third-largest television network, after CBC, the government-owned network, and CTV, a privately owned network. BCE, a major telecommications holding company, wants to buy CTV, largely with the idea of piping TV and Internet programs over Bell lines.
From the small station imported 20 years ago from North Dakota, CanWest grew by calling its collection of separately licensed stations a "system" rather than a "network." Under Canadian laws at the time, networks had to show a higher percentage of Canadian-made programs than systems. American programs can be bought for one-tenth the cost of producing Canadian programs.
"Global has been as studiously nonpolitical as possible, producing as little Canadian content as possible and making as much money as possible," said Vincent A. Carlin, chairman of the journalism school of Ryerson Polytechnic University, in Toronto. "They were always failing the government guidelines, and always getting a break."
After succeeding in Canada, Mr. Asper methodically expanded in the industrialized English-speaking world, buying television stations in Australia, Ireland and New Zealand.
"He has taken some of the economics of a big-box retailer and applied them to small-market media, where you buy American programming in bulk and pass the savings along," said Paul W. Taylor, who worked for Mr. Asper's first television station before studying the company for a doctorate in communications. He said CanWest Global was one of the largest buyers of American television programming.
Dr. Taylor predicted that with the merger, the newspapers would strengthen TV news programs, the newspapers would promote the TV entertainment shows and advertisers would get larger audiences. "If you are a national advertiser, with a single buy," he said, "you will be able to reach the eyeballs you want to move your goods."
A few years ago, CanWest Global became a full network. Now, Mr. Asper and his son, Leonard, the president of CanWest, may have decided that Canadian news is the Canadian content that Canadians most want to see. By this reasoning, Californians want to see California news, but not necessarily California movies. Mr. Dornan said, "News about ourselves, journalism, current affairs programming, documentaries -- that's what Canadians want to see."
At first glance, the deal today suggested that Mr. Black might eventually play a bigger role in Global. He has repeatedly entered companies by holding a minority position, then ended up wresting control. He is to get 15 percent of the equity of CanWest, making him the largest shareholder after the Asper family.
But this time, Mr. Black may have to settle for what the deal offers: a seat on the CanWest board for himself and for another Hollinger representative.
"The Asper family's control of the corporation is beyond his reach," Richard Siklos, author of "Shades of Black: Conrad Black and the World's Fastest Growing Press Empire" (McClelland & Stewart, 1995 ), said today. "It's an exit strategy for Black and these newspapers. I wouldn't expect it to be a lasting partnership."

HEADLINE: Laser Eye Surgery's Turf War

BYLINE: By KENNETH CHANG 

 BODY:
Harriet Bass lay on a table at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, her right eye propped open by a metal ring, staring up at a red dot of light.
"You're going to feel a little pressure," Dr. John A. Seedor told Ms. Bass, a 49-year-old casting director, as he was about to slice into her cornea. Using a motorized blade known as a keratome, Dr. Seedor cut a circular flap around the cornea, about one-third of an inch wide and one-150th of an inch thick, and peeled it back. 
 Switching to a computer-controlled laser, Dr. Seedor trained an invisible beam of cool ultraviolet light on the exposed soft underlayers. The lenses within Ms. Bass's nearsighted eyes bent light too sharply, making her vision fuzzy. The laser vaporized bits of cornea in a way that flattened the curvature at the front of Ms. Bass's eye to bring images at the back of the eye, on the retina, into focus.
"All right, Harriet. It looks beautiful," Dr. Seedor said. He placed the flap back down, caressing it with a brush back into place. "Ready for the other eye?"
Dr. Seedor repeated the procedure. The operation took about 15 minutes.
Although the Food and Drug Administration approved the procedure only last year, Lasik, short for laser in-situ keratomileusis, has quickly grown into a $3 billion-a-year industry, with 750,000 Americans expected to choose the surgery this year. Intended to correct nearsightedness, the procedure can now treat farsightedness as well.
With 1.2 million American customers expected next year, Lasik is becoming the issue in a financial turf war between ophthalmologists and optometrists, between top-dollar surgeons and low-cost, high-volume centers.
Ophthalmologists are the eye surgeons with medical degrees who perform the surgery. Optometrists are specialists in measuring vision who prescribe eyeglasses and contact lenses, and, increasingly, handle the care before and after Lasik surgery.
Lasik's popularity is easily explained: for the vast majority of patients, it is safe, effective and, increasingly, affordable.
"It's a simple procedure," said Dr. Richard S. Koplin, medical director of LaserOne in Manhattan. "It's not brain surgery."
With so many people willing to pay out of pocket -- most insurance companies do not pay for the procedure, because they regard it as "cosmetic" -- to be rid of contacts or glasses, Lasik surgeons have turned to the familiar marketing tools: celebrity testimonials, billboards, radio and television advertisements, telemarketing.
For would-be patients, the choices -- LaserOne, Lasik Vision, the Laser Center, Insight Laser Center, Infinity Laser Center, among others -- can bewilder.
Three general business models have evolved. Dr. Seedor is in the mode of a traditional practice: a patient pays for the attention and experience of the surgeon, $2,650 an eye in Ms. Bass's case.
Centers like Lasik Vision and LaserOne are decidedly corporate and mass market; Carmine Asparro of Bellmore, taking advantage of the grand opening special at Lasik Vision in Garden City, N.Y., paid just $500 for Lasik on his right eye. (His left already had 20/20 vision.)
The third is an increasingly popular arrangement known as "co-management" in which a patient's optometrist handles the initial evaluation and postoperative care in exchange for part of the fee. The Laser Center in Manhattan, for example, works with about 75 optometrists who send a stream of patients. The optometrists make money from a procedure that eliminates the need for their services.
At the Laser Center, Evan Mason of Irvington paid more than Ms. Bass: $5,500 for two eyes. Yet she never met her surgeon, Dr. Mark G. Speaker, before the surgery and has not seen him since. No studies have showed which approach yields better results, and all three have their critics and defenders.
Marketing materials from the traditional Lasik surgeons often darkly hint that their cheaper competitors might be skimping to make a profit.
Dr. Joseph Dello Russo of the New Jersey Eye Institute in Bergenfield charges $2,800 per eye. "I know what I'm worth," he said. "You're not going to get an experienced surgeon for $1,000 an eye."
Michael R. Henderson, president and chief executive of Lasik Vision Corporation, which runs centers in North America, is similarly emphatic. "If you pay $5,000," he said, "you're simply being gouged."
But Dr. Susan Fromer, an ophthalmologist at Garden City Lasik Vision, says higher-cost surgeons can coexist with the high-volume centers. In addition to her work at Lasik Vision, Dr. Fromer also performs the surgery in her private practice in Manhattan, charging $3,600 for two eyes.
In her practice, Dr. Fromer handles the evaluation and postoperation visits herself. At Lasik Vision -- which now charges $999 an eye after 1,000 people quickly signed up for the introductory special -- an optometrist on the staff handles those duties, although Dr. Fromer says she reviews the optometrists' data.
"I believe in both models," Dr. Fromer said. "It's an issue of handholding. The level of care is the same."
In the co-management debates, some ophthalmologists are concerned about the appearance of optometrists' steering patients their way.
Others fear that optometrists may be slow to recognize complications after operations. The Laser Center is "an economic model," said Dr. Joseph Evitar, a surgeon at Chelsea Eye Associates in Manhattan. "You can't know what is really going on. You're relying on someone else's judgment."
Dr. Speaker, on the other hand, says he carefully chooses his co-managing optometrists. "It wouldn't reflect well on me if I were associated with someone who wasn't knowledgeable," he said. The payment, 20 percent, is simply for the visits before and after. "They are entitled to be paid for their services," he said, "just like any other profession."
Ms. Mason said she was not aware that $1,000 of the $5,000 she paid Dr. Speaker was going to her optometrist, Arkady Selenow, but that did not bother her. "I trust Dr. Selenow," she said.
Optometrists say they know their patients better and that results in better care.
"It's not just a prescription," said Mr. Selenow, who practices in Manhattan and Queens and co-manages about 1,000 Lasik cases a year. "It's knowing their complete lifestyle. You know if they're going to be happy. It's not just a science. There's an art to it, too."
For example, he said, a person who spends lots of time reading or staring at a computer screen might be dissatisfied with 20/20 vision, because up-close viewing might be uncomfortable. Leaving the vision slightly nearsighted might be a better option.
With Ms. Mason, 44, Mr. Selenow steered her toward monovision, where her right eye was corrected to 20/20 vision, while her left eye was intentionally left a slightly nearsighted 20/40. That creates a sort of bifocal vision, with the right eye to focus on distant objects and the left eye for close-up reading.
The sparring over co-management has escalated to the professional societies of ophthalmologists and optometrists.
This year, the American Academy of Ophthalmology and the American Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgery released a paper declaring that co-management should be "an exceptional, rather than a routine, occurrence," applicable, say, to someone who lives far from the surgeon.
"If the co-management of patients is done on a routine basis for predominantly financial reasons," the two organizations said, "it represents unethical behavior and may be illegal."
The American Optometric Association countered, "This conclusion is not grounded in law, regulation, or the American Academy of Ophthalmology's own Code of Ethics."
Two weeks ago, the International Society of Refractive Surgeons, which includes ophthalmologists and optometrists, also said that co-management was acceptable and that it was developing guidelines for it.
"Properly structured, legal co-management arrangements should not be cast under a pall just because they're co-management," said Dr. Jeffrey B. Robin, the society's executive vice president.
While no study offers a comprehensive picture, anecdotes point to potential pitfalls.
Dr. Marc Odrich, director of refractive surgery at Columbia and medical director of VISX, a laser manufacturer, tells of one co-managed Lasik patient referred to him.
The woman's eyesight was worsening, and an exam quickly showed why: cataracts were clouding her lenses. Her optometrist had not spotted the problem. The ophthalmologist did not check and, relying on the optometrist, performed the operation. It went smoothly, but the cataracts render it useless.
"I don't fault the optometrist," Dr. Odrich said. "I fault the doctor who is operating on someone else's exam. You've got to do the exam. This doesn't absolve you from being a doctor."
Most Lasik patients encounter no problems at all, although 1 percent to 10 percent require a second Lasik operation to fine-tune their prescriptions.
Still, complications do occasionally occur, some serious.
During surgery, the flap-cutting keratome might jam or create a wrinkle in the cornea, in perhaps 1 in 500 eyes, said Dr. Jonathan Carr, director of medical services for the Lasik Vision chain.
After surgery, a range of problems can arise, although most can be easily treated if caught promptly. And, about 1 in 500 will experience an inflammation under the eye, Dr. Carr said. The odds of an infection are about 1 in 10,000. And, there is one reported case of a 35-year-old man who had one eye removed after a Lasik-induced infection.
The operation also cuts down on production of tears, leading to eyes that need drops. Almost always, the condition improves after a few months.
For some, particularly those with large pupils, Lasik can result in nighttime glare and blurry halos around street lamps. Only rarely does bothersome glare persist longer than a few months, Dr. Carr said.
Other surgical alternatives exist, including corrective lenses implanted in the cornea. That procedure costs about the same and is reversible.
And, in June the F.D.A. approved a new procedure called laser thermal keratoplasty for treatment of mild to moderate farsightedness in people over 40. The condition affects an estimated 60 million Americans. The procedure takes less than three seconds: the thermal laser fires 16 bursts in two concentric rings, causing cornea tissue to shrink and steepening the edges.
Improvements with Lasik are expected to help extremely nearsighted people and those with oddly shaped corneas. For most, Lasik already produces the results as promised.
"I'm seeing perfect," Evan Mason said a couple of weeks after her surgery. "It was perfect that night." Monovision, which she tested with contact lenses before her surgery, was also no problem. "I adapted immediately."
Mr. Asparro, who took advantage of the special offered by Lasik Vision, is also a satisfied patient. "I'm so happy I did it," he said. "Love it. Would recommend it to anyone."
A couple of months after her surgery, Ms. Bass's vision is 20/50, not the intended 20/25. She has bought reading glasses.
She has a second operation scheduled -- an "enhancement" in industry parlance and included in the original cost.
"They think they have to do me again at the beginning of August," she said. "It's not as easy as I thought it would be. I am not a disgruntled patient by any means. I'm still satisfied with the work because it's greatly improved over what I used to see."

Chart: "Eyes Wide Open"
 
Lasik surgery, or laser in-situ keratomileusis, can correct a number of common problems that cause blurry vision.
 
COMMON FOCUSING PROBLEMS
 
NEARSIGHTEDNESS
If the eyeball is too long or the cornea too curved, light does not focus on the retina, but in front of it.
 
FARSIGHTEDNESS
If the eyeball is too short or the cornea too flat, light from nearby objects focuses on a point beyond the retina.
 
ASTIGMATISM
An irregularly shaped cornea results in light rays focusing on more than one point on the
retina, causing distortion. viewed.
 
How Lasik Works
After a protective flap is lifted, a laser reshapes the cornea, the transparent layer of tissue in the front of the eye.
 
CUTTING THE CORNEA
 
1. Opening
The eye is held open and anesthetic is administered. The surgeon marks the cornea with soluble ink to guide how the flap will be repositioned at the end of the surgery.
 
2. Cutting
A suction ring is used to increase pressure in the eye so that it is firm enough to be cut cleanly. Next a motorized blade, guided along a threaded track, slices the cornea.
 
3. Exposing
The surgeon lifts the flap carefully, exposing the layers of the cornea that will be vaporized by the laser.
 
RESHAPING THE CORNEA
 
4. Correcting
 
NEARSIGHTEDNESS is corrected by vaporizing the center of the internal cornea to flatten it.
 
FARSIGHTEDNESS is fixed by removing a ring of tissue around the center, making the cornea steeper.
 
ASTIGMATISM -- An irregularly shaped cornea is corrected by vaporizing more tissue on one side.
 
Pulses of ultraviolet light break the molecular bonds between cells, vaporizing tissue.
 
LASER EYE SURGERY IN THE U.S.
 
Graph shows numbers of surgeries for Lasik and surgeries displaced by Lasik from 1996-2001 projected.

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
No Decisions, No Drama

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 31

 BODY:
Ronald Reagan used to preach what he called the 11th commandment: Speak no evil of other Republicans.
But now his party, and the other one, too, have gone him one better, appropriating the physician's Hippocratic oath as the unspoken guiding principle for their quadrennial gatherings: First, do no harm. 
 It is that thought, more than anything, that has drained all of the drama and much of the meaning from modern political conventions. No surprises are wanted these days. No sore losers. No floor fights. So long, eccentricity. Farewell, spontaneity; hello, choreography. No more smoke-filled rooms -- unless you count the convention hall, which is to be filled with artificial, politically correct smoke as part of the entertainment here.
The Republicans, who began their national convention this morning, and the Democrats, who meet in Los Angeles next month, have been reading the polls and reflecting on the past. Partisans all, they are confronted with the uncomfortable finding that Americans, a few of whom may actually be watching on television, hate partisanship and discord.
Perhaps it is the times. Perhaps it is because most people are happy with their lot, with the economy and with the course of the ship of state. If that is the reason for voters' aversion to conflict, feel-good conventions could be a passing phase. Hard times pose hard questions, and those questions get thrashed out not only in campaigns but also in the conventions preceding them.
This year, though, it is pablum for breakfast, lunch and dinner.
The original raison d'etre of conventions -- nominating candidates -- vanished a quarter-century ago. Not since the Republican gathering in Kansas City in 1976, when Gerald R. Ford barely held off Ronald Reagan, has there been a genuine contest for the presidential nomination at a convention of a major party. It was well past midnight when West Virginia finally gave Mr. Ford the votes he needed to go over the top.
Not since 1940 has an outsider captured the nomination. At the Republican convention that year, Wendell L. Willkie finished third on the first ballot; it took his handlers many hours to put together the deals that gave him the nomination on the sixth.
There will probably never again be a spectacle even remotely resembling the epic struggle between rural and urban interests at the 1924 Democratic convention in the first Madison Square Garden. John W. Davis of New York was chosen by exhausted delegates on the 103rd ballot, but the party had next to nothing left for the fall campaign, and Davis was trounced by Calvin Coolidge.
The new reality is the consequence of the 1968 Democratic convention in Chicago, which was so rowdy, with spiteful oral combat inside the hall and a police riot outside, that the parties tore up their old rule books.
Today almost all the delegates are chosen by voters in primaries and caucuses, not, as of old, by the political bosses. The delegates know months before they come to town whom they will vote for. They are bit players now, with no power.
George W. Bush, the man they have come here to nominate, told The National Journal the other day that conventions have become an anachronism. But that, he insisted, does not -- should not -- mean they are on the way out.
"The convention provides a system of rewards for hardworking, grass-roots people who end up being delegates," Mr. Bush said. "I view it as an opportunity for these people to go back home, energized to help me get elected."
Fair enough. It also provides an excuse for a lot of parties, mostly paid for by big corporations, and yet another setting to raise money.
Mr. Bush also said that the convention has become "a place to showcase ideas more than in the past." Not exactly. To be precise, it has become a place to talk in muted terms about ideas that the nominee wishes to be heard. If there are abortion rights supporters at the podium this week, for example, they will talk about something else, thanks to what Mr. Bush calls his "iron-fist" control of the proceedings. But there will be no oratorical fire on the other side of the issue, either, and few attacks on the Democrats.
That was the lesson that politicians drew from the contrasting conventions of 1992. The Republicans, nominating George Bush the elder, permitted the clergyman who delivered the opening-night invocation to compare abortion to the Holocaust and allowed Patrick J. Buchanan to issue a shrill call to arms for the "religious war going on in our country for the soul of America."
Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania said this week, "I felt absolutely terrible that night." Just like a lot of other people in the hall and out across the country.
The Democrats, on the other hand, staged a pageant of unity behind Bill Clinton, denying Robert J. Casey, then the governor of Pennsylvania, a chance to state his anti-abortion position from the podium. Mr. Clinton won, of course, and a new bit of conventional political wisdom was born: Trouble in August means trouble in November.
So there will be no echoes here of Barry Goldwater's belligerence in accepting the Republican presidential nomination in 1964.
Quoting Cicero, Mr. Goldwater, senator from Arizona, told the delegates that "extremism in defense of liberty is no vice," and that "moderation in pursuit of justice is no virtue." He lost, as did William Jennings Bryan of Nebraska in 1896 after perhaps the most spellbinding of convention speeches. Siding with the Western populists against Eastern bankers, Bryan cried out, "You shall not crucify mankind upon a cross of gold!"
Nor will there be a surprise vice-presidential nominee. In 1956, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois left the choice to the delegates at the Democratic convention, and a youngster named John F. Kennedy, then a senator from Massachusetts, though narrowly defeated by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, set himself up for 1960. Kennedy, in turn, stunned the country by choosing Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas as a running mate. And George Bush chose Dan Quayle, a senator from Indiana.
Now a new tradition is emerging: choose the running mate before the convention, so as to eliminate that, too, as a potential disruption.
Sometimes the drama of conventions has lain in credentials disputes. At Chicago in 1952, Dwight D. Eisenhower's managers mounted a campaign of dubious legitimacy under the slogan "Fair Play" and succeeded in stripping Robert A. Taft of enough delegates to assure the general's nomination.
Sometimes the drama has lain in the rules. At Miami Beach in 1972, the brain trust of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota deftly manipulated the rules to guarantee his victory.
And sometimes -- often, in fact -- the drama has lain in the platform debate, where conflicting ideas on major issues were thrashed out.
Here in Philadelphia 52 years ago this summer, Hubert H. Humphrey led a passionate campaign for civil rights. He told the delegates, assembled to nominate Harry S. Truman: "There are those who say we are rushing this issue of civil rights. I say we are 172 years too late."
The Dixiecrats walked out, nominated Strom Thurmond for president and carried five states. But Truman won -- a reminder that it has by no means always been politically suicidal to stage a contentious and divisive convention.
This year, neither convention is likely to tackle such important issues as drugs, campaign finance and the gulf between the rich and the poor. The Republicans, deeply divided on the issue of abortion, will display no prime time dissent; abortion-rights forces, who had enough votes in the platform committee to take a minority plank to the floor, decided to pass up that chance in the name of unity.
"It's all propaganda," the chairman of the Republican National Committee in the 1996 convention, Haley Barbour, said. "It's all a TV show. It's not news, but it's hugely important information for the American people."
Yet the question remains whether these carefully packaged four-day Republican and Democratic infomercials will influence the unaligned, uncommitted voters whom both parties say they want to reach. With dissent muffled, with debate defunct, will they be stirred? The low turnouts in recent presidential elections suggest that all the staging in the world will not do the trick.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: August 17, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page news analysis article on Aug. 1 about the effect of the Republican Party's efforts to keep its national convention free of discord misstated the source of the phrase "do no harm." It is from Hippocrates' work "Epidemics," not from the Hippocratic oath.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
A Ranch in the Rockies for Famed Artists and Novices

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Heilman Brooke 

DATELINE: SNOWMASS VILLAGE, Colo.

 BODY:
Sheep dung once was up to the windows of what artists now call the seminar room. The seminar room's floor is far from level, and its walls are chinked spruce and fir logs, remnants of a late-19th-century forest fire. But this summer William Christenberry, a photographer, used this former sheep shed to show slides for his course called Interaction of Media: Photography, Painting and Sculpture.
Cattle barns and sheep sheds that until 1966 were the heart of an active ranch here now draw acclaimed and aspiring artists from around the world. The Anderson Ranch Arts Center, a four-and-a-half-acre campus eight miles west of Aspen, is a bucolic center for potters, photographers, painters, printmakers, woodworkers, sculptors, art historians and critics. From early June through late September the studios have more than a thousand professional and novice artists in workshops of one to two weeks on topics as basic as Making Stuff in Clay and as lofty as The Meaning of Mountains. 
 Internationally renowned artists come to learn from one another and from experts in technologically new fields yet to be fully explored.
New York has Chautauqua, New Hampshire has the MacDowell Colony, and North Carolina has the Penland School of Crafts. With its Rocky Mountain backdrop, its heady 8,200-foot altitude and its proximity to Aspen, Anderson Ranch has in three decades acquired a reputation for corralling curious artists in search of creative synergy.
The ranch's course catalog is available in January, and half its courses were full by mid-March. Most workshops are limited to about a dozen participants, but because of the extensive pottery equipment, which include a kiln yard with five gas kilns, a wood kiln, a Japanese Anagama kiln and several electric kilns, ceramics workshops can enroll as many as 16.
For 15 years Doug Casebeer, a former ceramics consultant to the United Nations, has directed the ceramics program at the ranch. Mr. Casebeer said that artists generally recognize that their profession can require a selfish self-absorption, but that Anderson Ranch is an "arena where we can all come together, leave the egos at the door, appreciate that everybody has something to say."
This summer Paul Soldner, the center's first artistic director, and a fellow ceramic artist, Peter Voulkos, will again teach A Lifetime of Clay, a workshop that encourages "mentorship and an exchange of ideas." Late in July, Ah Leon, a Taiwanese ceramic artist specializing in Yixing-style teapots and sculpture, will lead The Language of Tea: Dissecting the Teapot, which the catalog calls "a total immersion in the tea experience."
Most workshops meet from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Friday, with a break for lunch. Studios are open 24 hours a day. Tuition ranges from $250 for a one-week course called Art and Mud: A Course for Teachers, to $550 for a two-week sculpture class taught by the sculptor Laura Thorne, to $1,295 for two weeks of John Sexton's lab intensive photography course.
At the cafe these days, which serves breakfast, lunch and dinner al fresco and cappuccino and biscotti late into the night, the Texas sculptor James Surls can often be found sitting beside a 60-year-old lawyer, accountant or business executive who has come to try a first studio art course.
Seven years ago at age 67, Lloyd Schermer, then chairman of Lee Enterprises, a media company, decided to take his first drawing course. "Taking a course in art, for Pete's sake. I was terrified," Mr. Schermer said. Since then he has taken classes in watercolor, figure drawing, oil, acrylic, collage and monotype (single print) and has become an enthusiastic monotype artist.
Relying sometimes on wood type he salvaged from one of his newspapers in Missoula, Mont., Mr. Schermer has painted and sculptured and sold more than 100 of his works, which are in the collections of the National Museum of American Art at the Smithsonian Institution, the Aspen Institute, the Tribune Company and the Hearst Corporation.
Mr. Schermer and his wife, Betty, have been donors to the ranch and served on its board; the meeting hall dedicated in 1999 was named for them.
In August performers from Jazz Aspen will fill the ranch with music. In past years B. B. King stopped by for an impromptu performance. Larry Rivers, the painter, once picked up his saxophone and surprised students with an unexpected riff.
Artists come from as far away as Nepal, Jamaica and Japan. There are children's workshops for ages 6 through 15.
Artists can apply for short or long residencies. Past visiting artists have included the Japanese ceramist Takashi Nakazato, the performance artist Laurie Anderson and the painters Red Grooms and Jim Dine.
The ranch, with an annual budget of $2.8 million, has 55,000 square feet of studios and housing and offers as many as 150 scholarships a year. Full-time art students and art teachers are offered a 50 percent discount on tuition for courses in which space is available.
Mr. Surls, the sculptor, who has been an invited artist in residence for two years, said that the ranch center had given him "a midcareer jump, a new lease on life, a second wind."
"We are not in the same West of Remington and Russell," he said. "Today there is an incredibly complex set of references. I think everybody conjures from his environment. The landscape here is beautiful. The weather is great. My work has totally opened up. This terrain change has created a head change."
James Baker, a photographer and 14-year veteran of the ranch who has been its executive director for five years, said it offered the "gift of time and space, an opportunity to blend idealism with pragmatism."
Mr. Baker added: "At a time when our economy is so strong, we've got everything we want except what we really need. You can see that yearning. Society needs this type of fulfillment. To be human is to create, and people need opportunities to create."

HEADLINE: To Appreciate Cheney, Come to Wyoming

BYLINE: By Alan K. Simpson; Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican, served in the Senate from 1979 to 1997.

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
Since he became the Republican vice presidential nominee, Dick Cheney has been depicted as some kind of right-wing kook. His detractors have scoured his record in Congress and plucked out a few votes with no reference to their context. They toss out conclusions about him that have no relation to his splendid reputation among his former colleagues, Republican and Democrat alike. But if his detractors continue to focus on only a few of his thousands of votes, let's at least be upfront with the facts.
South Africa sanctions. Dick Cheney opposed sanctions against South Africa under apartheid and voted against a resolution calling for the release of Nelson Mandela. But the issues then were not so simple. 
 In the 1980's, there was a consensus to end apartheid. The debate was whether sanctions should be imposed or whether we should follow President Ronald Reagan's policy of free trade and open dialogue. Mr. Reagan believed the American companies could best help black South Africans by giving them jobs. Sanctions, the thinking went, would only hurt black South Africans, because these companies would have to pull out.
Moreover, the resolution to free Mr. Mandela contained language requiring official recognition of the African National Congress as the legitimate representative of the black majority. But the South African government was then our ally in stemming communism in Africa, particularly in Angola, and the leaders of the A.N.C. included admitted communists.
When Dick Cheney cast his votes, neither he nor anyone else knew when the cold war would end. Nor could we know that sanctions would ultimately help create a free South Africa. Members of the House are issued voting cards, not crystal balls.
Equal rights amendment. It is not easy being a minority member of the House. The majority party can use procedures that deprive the minority of offering amendments. That's what happened when Democrats brought the equal rights amendment to the House for consideration under "Suspension of the Rules," which doesn't allow debate or amendments -- even though this legislation would have amended the Constitution.
Mr. Cheney has always supported the equal rights amendment. He voted no because he believed that a proposed amendment to the Constitution should be subject to full debate. But this vote was not about equal rights for women. This was about the Democrats' hardball efforts to create an issue during a campaign year.
Head Start. If Dick Cheney were voting today on whether to expand this program, or any other social program, he would first ask whether it was worthwhile. If the answer was yes, the next question would be, "Can we afford it?" The answer today, with the surpluses piling up, is likely yes. But Mr. Cheney served in Congress during the days of huge deficits. It's never easy for politicians to say no to worthwhile programs, but if we hadn't had members of Congress like him to cast these tough votes, we might not have the luxury of surpluses we wallow in today.
Gun control. In Wyoming, gun control means holding your rifle steady. We have a different lifestyle; we learn to use firearms for hunting or target practice responsibly at an early age. The way for a guy to be "outside the mainstream" -- or out of office -- is to vote for gun control. The last time I checked, members of Congress are encouraged to represent their constituency. But things change, and the Columbine shootings and other tragedies have haunted us all. I personally know that Dick Cheney would almost surely support tough laws to keep guns out of the hands of juveniles and criminals. He would also support child safety locks and raising the age of handgun possession to 21.
The environment. Mr. Cheney is an avid outdoorsman, committed to conservation and a clean environment. I remember his steady efforts on behalf of an act that set aside thousands of acres of Wyoming for special protection. No one fought harder for it than he did, despite the powerful economic interests and many Republicans fighting against the designation.
To evaluate his record fairly, one must look at the 1980's, with its deficits and cold war antagonisms. And one must remember that he represented a very conservative state, and ask whether these votes are relevant to judging his qualifications. As vice president, he would take a broader view than his role of congressman from Wyoming required. After all, we know that as defense secretary during the gulf war, Mr. Cheney was calm and cool under pressure -- thoughtful, competent and trustworthy. What he is not is an extremist. Those who know him will tell you this, including honest Democrats. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Mixed Signals In 3 Reports On Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The first drop in orders in 19 months restrained manufacturing in July but consumer spending rebounded in June, two reports showed today.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said that its factory index was unchanged last month at 51.8, the lowest level since January 1999. The index for new orders fell below 50 -- meaning that more companies reported a drop than reported an increase -- for the first time since December 1998, when recessions in many Asian countries held down demand for American products. 
 A separate report from the Commerce Department showed consumer spending rose 0.5 percent in June after rising 0.3 percent in May. While that was the largest gain in three months, higher energy costs accounted for most of the rise, analysts said. Incomes rose 0.4 percent after an increase of 0.3 percent in May.
In another Commerce Department report, spending on construction of houses and apartments in June registered the largest drop in five years.
The statistics add to evidence that six interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve since June 1999 have begun to cool demand for expensive items like cars and homes. The overnight bank lending rate, at 6.5 percent, is the highest it has been in nine years and has pushed up the cost of consumer borrowing.
The purchasing association's index of prices paid -- which measures whether manufacturers are paying more or less for raw materials -- rose to 61.9 in July from 61.2 in June. The index peaked at 79.8 in March, and last month's reading was the second lowest since August 1999.
A reading of 50 or higher in the factory index suggests expansion, while a lower reading suggests contraction. July's overall factory index showed the 18th consecutive month of growth.
Two indexes dropped into negative territory last month. The new-orders index fell to 49.9 from 50.6 in June, and the import index declined to 49.8 from 56 -- the first reading below 50 since January 1999.
Should consumer spending continue to slow and result in further increases in inventories, that may suggest "slower production growth ahead," said Peter Kretzmer, an economist at Banc of America Securities in New York.
A slowdown in home building is one reason consumer spending could slow, as people buy less furniture and fewer appliances, he said. Spending on residential construction fell 1.39 percent in June, the biggest drop since May 1995. Over all, construction spending fell 1.7 percent in June after declines of 0.2 percent in May and 1.7 percent in April.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: PLEA TO END DRUG CERTIFICATION -- President-elect Vicente Fox will propose ending Washington's certification of Latin American countries' anti-drug efforts when he meets with President Clinton on Aug 24, said Aguilar Zinser, a foreign relations adviser to Mr. Fox. The certification program has been criticized as a symbol of American domination, and countries that refuse to take part risk losing economic benefits. Mr. Zinser argued that the United States should instead help set up a regional anti-narcotics group made up of countries fighting the drug trade. (AP)
 
VENEZUELA: ELECTION UNREST -- President Hugo Chavez sent troops to quell disturbances over disputed regional election results as several opposition candidates refused to accept defeat in general elections last Sunday. Tensions were particularly high in the state of Merida, where the latest results showed a pro-Chavez candidate, Florencio Porras, edging out the incumbent, Gov. William Davila, by less than 1 percent. (Reuters) 

EUROPE
 
YUGOSLAVIA: ABDUCTION ACCUSATION -- The police said they had arrested eight people suspected of abducting Stevan Todorovic, a former Bosnian Serb police chief indicted by the United Nations for war crimes, from inside Serbia and handing him over to NATO troops in 1998. On Monday, Yugoslav authorities said they had detained four Dutch citizens who were trying to kidnap and possibly kill Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, who was indicted last year on charges of ordering war crimes in Kosovo. (Reuters)
 
BRITAIN: GAS PRICE STRIKE -- Motorists enraged by gasoline prices exceeding $4.80 a gallon staged a rare protest by refusing to fill their gas tanks. Organizers said they hoped to stage regular protests to urge the government to lower taxes, which account for three-quarters of the pump price of gasoline. Alan Cowell (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: ALERT IN CHECHNYA -- Russian troops sealed off Chechnya's second-largest city, Gudermes, in anticipation of a possible surge in rebel attacks in coming days to mark the first anniversary of the conflict in the separatist republic. An armed incursion by Islamic militants a year ago into the neighboring republic of Dagestan led to the current Russian military crackdown in Chechnya. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
PHILIPPINES: TRASH SURVIVORS SUE -- Survivors of the collapse of a mountain of garbage in the capital, Manila, filed a class-action suit against local officials and private waste contractors, accusing them of negligence. At least 218 people -- and possibly hundreds more -- died when a rain-soaked wall of garbage buried their shanties on July 10. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: BOMB KILLS 3 -- A powerful bomb at the residence of the Philippine ambassador in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, killed 3 people and injured at least 21, including the ambassador. Muslim separatists in the Philippines denied responsibility. A number of bombs linked to the separatists have exploded recently in the Philippines. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
INDIA: ATTEMPTS TO FREE ACTOR -- A 10-year manhunt against the nation's most feared bandit was suspended as authorities tried to negotiate the release of a kidnapped movie icon, Rajkumar, taken prisoner by Veerappan, a notorious murderer, poacher and smuggler who operates in the forests of southern India. S. M. Krishna, chief minister of the state of Karnataka, said the police do not want to do anything that might further endanger Mr. Rajkumar. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
LAOS: NEW TERROR SCARE -- Residents reported that a bomb was found and defused at the Vietnamese embassy in the Laotian capital, Vientiane. The report was the latest in a series about bombings or attempted bombings. The discovery of the bomb came on Sunday, the same day that an explosive device was removed from the Vientiane airport and one day before a bomb killed several people at the central post office. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
KUWAIT: NO CLOSER TO IRAQ -- Kuwait's Foreign Minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, ruled out a resumption of ties with its former occupier, Iraq, in the near future and said his country intends to renew defense pacts with Western countries. He spoke in an interview published 10 years after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. (Reuters)
 
IRAN: WOMEN ALLOWED TO LEAD PRAYERS -- Muslim authorities have lifted the prohibition on women leading congregational prayers by members of their own sex, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The religious decree solves a longstanding problem in all-girl schools, where women had not been allowed to lead prayers. Muslims are required by their faith to pray five times a day and, if possible, to pray with a group of other Muslims. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
NIGERIA: 5TH STATE ADOPTS ISLAMIC LAW -- The northern state of Katsina began enforcing strict Islamic law, becoming the fifth state to bring in the code since Nigeria returned to civilian rule last year. Secular area courts were replaced with Islamic Shariah courts. Christians in the state are opposed, saying it is a violation of the 1999 Constitution. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ZIMBABWE: STRIKE PLANNED -- The country's main labor movement called for a one-day strike today, to demand an end to what it terms intimidation and violence against government critics. The strike has been backed by labor, some businesses, farmers and the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, making it the most broadly based challenge to President Robert Mugabe since the country's independence from Britain in 1980. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Prices End Mixed, as Investors Migrate From Tech Shares

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday as investors switched out of technology companies on fears that their earnings growth might slow and moved into more traditional and cheaper sectors, like consumer products.
Concerns that more than a year of interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve will hurt profitability, particularly in the technology sector, continued to dog Wall Street, analysts said. Expectations of strong earnings growth are priced into many semiconductor and Internet-related equipment stocks, leaving little room for disappointment. 
 "Slowing growth means -- unless you have phenomenal productivity -- slowing profits growth, and these stocks aren't priced for any slowdown in growth," said Edgar Peters, chief investment officer at Pan-Agora Asset Management in Boston.
Old-economy manufacturing companies, like General Motors and Coca-Cola, gained as investors breathed a sigh of relief over benign economic data and took refuge in companies they saw as less vulnerable to market volatility.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 84.97 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,606.95.
The technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index, however, dropped 81.47 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,685.52.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a broader measure of the market, finished up 7.27 points, or 0.5 percent, at 1,438.10.
"It's really a continuation of the selling that we saw last week," said Tony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Kirlin Holdings. "Sentiment was negative going into yesterday, so a lot of people are using the strength in yesterday's prices to cut losses."
Among the larger technology issues to drop was Intel, which lost 2 1/8, to 64 5/8. Indeed, semiconductor shares led the high-technology sector's descent. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor Index fell 3.83 percent.
The most heavily traded stock on the Nasdaq for the second consecutive day was Cisco Systems, which slipped 2 1/4, to 63 3/16, after the company, a data networking giant, said it would buy a wireless communications software maker, IPmobile for $425 million in stock.
Procter & Gamble advanced 2 3/16, to 59 1/16, after reporting fourth-quarter earnings of 55 cents a share, which met analysts' estimates.
Coca-Cola gained 113 9/16, to 62 7/8, and General Motors added 1 7/8, to 58 13/16, while Walt Disney rose 17 15/16, to 40.
The pharmaceuticals company Merck rose 27 3/32, to 73 3/4, amid a broad rally in drug and biotechnology stocks.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Rise on Data
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasuries rose as reports suggested that the economy was not growing fast enough to prompt more increases in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Slower-than-expected manufacturing growth last month, coupled with a decline in construction spending in June and slower growth in personal income, bolstered confidence among investors who had bet that the economy was cooling enough for the Fed to hold steady on rates.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 1 2/32, to a price of 103 24/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.98 percent from 6.03 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 2 8/32, to 1071 6/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.72 percent from 5.78 percent on Monday.
