HEADLINE: A Parade That's a Tradition

BYLINE: By Jonathan Chait; Jonathan Chait is an associate editor of The New Republic.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
You might mistake the Republican convention for an ethnic festival or a forum on women's rights," The New York Times said in a news story that seems to capture the scene in Philadelphia this week. Except this dispatch, reported by Maureen Dowd, didn't come from the convention that is nominating George W. Bush, but the one that nominated his father 12 years ago.
The image of diverse Republican speakers is so at odds with the usual portrayal of the party that some people have concluded that something radical and significant must be going on. Last week, a Times story said the convention would "showcase women and people from minority groups, faces that are not usually highlighted at Republican conventions." Actually, the last convention, in 1996, gave prominent roles to Susan Molinari, Colin Powell and Elizabeth Dole. And G.O.P. conventions have been showcasing women and minorities since at least the time of Ronald Reagan. 
 The Republicans held their 1980 convention in Detroit, a city with a majority of black residents. In Dallas in 1984, women received the two longest speakers' slots. Trying to close the gender gap in 1988, Republicans gave over their podium to a parade of women and members of minority groups. Even the 1992 convention, now often characterized as a right-wing hate fest, featured an event called "Black America Salutes the First Family" and forced white male luminaries like Alfonse D'Amato and Howard Baker to surrender their credentials to make room for more female delegates.
A convention is a television commercial, and the decision to feature black or female faces has barely any deeper philosophical import than the decision to feature balloons or confetti. In February, when Mr. Bush needed the support of conservative whites in South Carolina, he visited Bob Jones University and refused to denounce the Confederate flag. This doesn't mean that Mr. Bush is a secret racist; it simply reflected expediency in the choice of racial symbolism at that moment. Now the moment and the symbolism have changed.
The best evidence that Mr. Bush has not fundamentally altered the direction of his party is the acquiescence of the G.O.P.'s right wing. Conservatives are so vigilant against creeping moderation that they have denounced Newt Gingrich and Trent Lott for ideological deviation. Not only is this group not barking out any complaints now, but it is nuzzled lovingly in Mr. Bush's lap. And no wonder. His positions on economics and judicial appointments hew firmly to the conservative line.
Party diehards understand that it doesn't much matter if a blind mountain climber speaks in prime time while Mr. Lott is shunted to 11 a.m. Come next year, Mr. Lott, not the mountain climber, will be helping to set the G.O.P. legislative agenda.

HEADLINE: Car Sales Rise, Except at G.M. And Chrysler

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 1

 BODY:
General Motors and DaimlerChrysler said today that their sales fell in July, leaving both automakers unable to reduce their bloated inventories of unsold minivans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. But Ford and foreign automakers announced strong sales last month and balanced inventories.
Overall industry sales were very strong. While they did not quite match the torrid pace early this year, they were still brisk enough to suggest that consumer spending remained a powerful force in the American economy during July. 
 "There are some signs of moderation, although the industry is running at a healthy pace," said Bill Lovejoy, G.M.'s group vice president for North American vehicle sales, service and marketing.
Mark M. Cornelius, an auto statistician in West Olive, Mich., calculated this evening that sales rose 2.1 percent from a year ago, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17.2 million cars and light trucks. He used estimates for sales of Mazda, the only automaker not reporting today. The auto industry sold 17 million vehicles last year, its best ever.
General Motors posted a 2.6 percent drop in sales for July from its record level a year earlier, as a 22.8 percent jump in sales of small Saturn cars failed to offset weak sales of minivans, small pickup trucks and large sport utility vehicles. Paul Ballew, G.M.'s sales analysis director, blamed inadequate factory production for the weaker sales of large sport utilities.
The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler said sales fell 12.2 percent in July, dragged heavily by a 29 percent plunge in sales of minivans, a market segment that Chrysler essentially invented in 1983 and has dominated since. Chrysler will introduce redesigned minivans later this month and in early September, and customers have proved loath to buy the older models, despite increasingly lavish rebates.
Jeep sales dropped 15 percent and sales of Dodge Durango large sport utility trucks fell 3 percent. But Americans continued to snap up Chrysler PT Cruiser small vans as fast as the company could build them.
During most of the year, automakers seek to keep a 60-day inventory of vehicles at dealerships and on the way to dealerships. But at the end of July, when they are phasing out old models, they would prefer somewhat smaller inventories of 55 to 58 days.
G.M. said late this afternoon that its supply of unsold cars and light trucks equaled 68 days of sales; Chrysler said that it had a 78-day supply. Both automakers said that they did not have separate inventory figures today for cars and for light trucks, which encompasses minivans, sport utilities and pickups.
G.M. and Chrysler both had very large inventories of light trucks and small numbers of cars at the end of June. Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto analyst at Lehman Brothers, said that the two companies' sales and production figures in July suggested that this pattern had persisted, particularly at G.M., and that the companies' overall inventory figures masked huge backlogs of minivans, sport utilities and pickups.
"Their car inventory is too low, but you don't make any money on cars, and their light truck inventory is too high, and you make money on light trucks," he said. "You just can't go forever building more than you sell."
Chrysler officials acknowledged that their large inventories reflected an enormous supply of minivans. That situation stems at least partly from the company's determination not to run out of minivans this year as it did in 1995 when it shut its two minivan factories for nearly three months to retool them for a new generation. Chrysler ran short of minivans, posted a huge quarterly loss and watched as many loyal customers deserted to rival brands.
This time, Chrysler built lots of extra minivans in the spring and figured out a way to convert one factory over to the new model in two weeks this summer and the other in seven weeks.
The first factory is now in production and cranking out the new minivans quickly, but the old models are selling slowly. James Holden, Chrysler's chief executive, said last week that discounts would be needed to dispose of the older models.
G.M.'s situation is more complicated. In a telephone conference call with reporters this afternoon, Mr. Ballew, the sales analysis director, dismissed widespread rumors in Detroit that G.M. was about to slow output at some factories because of excessive inventories. The automaker's supply of vehicles looks large only in comparison with last summer, when the company was short of many models, he said. He added that the industry's sales might slow slightly next year with weaker economic growth. Gas prices have had little effect on sales, Mr. Ballew said.
Ford announced today that its sales inched up 0.6 percent from an extremely strong performance a year ago. The company had roughly a 50-day supply of cars and about a 60-day supply of light trucks at the end of July, said George Pipas, a market analyst at Ford.
Some foreign automakers fared better in July. Honda had its best month ever in the American market as sales rose 11.6 percent, led by strong results for the Civic compact car, the Odyssey minivan and the CR-V small sport utility vehicle. Mitsubishi's sales jumped 28.5 percent.
Volkswagen's sales climbed 4.8 percent, while Toyota's sales crept up 1 percent and Nissan's sales edged up 0.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Chavez Says He Will Crush Political Foes In Venezuela

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 1

 BODY:
President Hugo Chavez said today that he would use troops to crush street protests and to remove an opposition party governor who has accused the governing party of fraudulently altering the outcome of elections last weekend.
"This is going to be nothing more than a little spat, but we are obliged to guarantee order and prevent these groups from spoiling the beautiful process that we have concluded," Mr. Chavez said this afternoon, referring to the vote held across Venezuela on Sunday. "If they lost, they lost," he added dismissively. 
 Preliminary results from the national and local balloting, in which Mr. Chavez and 165 members of a new National Assembly were also elected, gave victory to the incumbent governor in the western state of Merida, William Davila, a leading opposition figure. But 6,000 ballots, most cast for Mr. Davila, were declared invalid for reasons that are still not clear, and the pro-Chavez candidate was declared the winner today, by a margin of less than 1,800 votes.
"It is clear that there was a fraud, which the people of Merida reject," Mr. Davila said in remarks broadcast on national television today.
Opposition candidates in five other states also made similar accusations about fraud in their races. Preliminary results had given Mr. Chavez's leftist Patriotic Pole coalition 12 of the 23 governorships at stake in the election in this oil-rich nation of 23 million people, but this afternoon Mr. Chavez said that his candidates had actually triumphed in 16 states and warned that he would not tolerate "anarchy."
"We are consolidating our victory, and as in any battle, you have to fight for every inch of territory," he said. He minimized the protests as "a mob with a few rocks and sticks" and said that "four or five canisters of tear gas ought to get them out of there," referring to the government offices where Mr. Davila has taken refuge.
On Monday, two international observer groups, one led by former President Jimmy Carter and the other sent by the Organization of American States, had pronounced the balloting here clean and fair. Sustained opposition complaints of fraud in the tabulation of votes began in earnest only today, though, after the observer groups had begun to close down operations here.
Mr. Chavez, a former army colonel who led an unsuccesful coup attempt in 1992, announced the dispatch of troops this afternoon during a three-hour news conference at which he also discussed issues ranging from his government's foreign policy to his plans to reactivate the Venezuelan economy. His most significant comments, though, came in a response to a question about oil prices, which have recently soared to near-record highs.
In recent years, Venezuela has been the leading supplier of the oil imported by the United States, and the country's energy minister, Ali Rodriguez Araque, was designated president of the Organization of Oil Exporting Countries, or OPEC, this spring. Mr. Chavez made it clear that he was delighted with the jump in oil prices and reiterated his position that he sees no reason to take any action to bring them down.
"We are just defending our position," Mr. Chavez said. "It's not that prices are high. They are fair and just."
Despite the oil bonanza, Venezuela's economy contracted by more than 7 percent last year, and now that the election is over, Mr. Chavez is under pressure to take steps to end that recession.
He also reiterated his admiration for the Cuban and Chinese revolutions, saying those countries' economies "have good things" and have produced social benefits. But he then added that it is not his intention to "try to import models from abroad," and said that his own revolutionary government welcomes foreign investment, so long as it is "productive, not speculative."
Long a skeptic about American policies in the region, Mr. Chavez expressed concern about the $1.3 billion emergency aid package for neighboring Colombia that President Clinton approved last month. He said that while his government is "willing to cooperate" with Colombia and the United States, he hoped that the military aid would "not be used to Vietnamize the Colombia conflict" or contribute to an increase in the fighting there.
"Let's hope this doesn't happen," he said. "We are paying close attention."
But Mr. Chavez reserved his most critical comments for his domestic opposition, saying that some of his adversaries "refuse to recognize Chavez as president" and warning that he will not hesitate to use his expanded powers to bring them to heel. "If they don't understand that or don't cooperate, we will apply the Constitution to them," he warned.

HEADLINE: Heat Wave Nearly Causes Rolling Blackouts in California

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1

 BODY:
A lingering heat wave throughout the West drove demand for electric power in California to near-record levels today and brought the state close to a full-scale power emergency. Such an emergency would have prompted rolling blackouts, in order for power administrators to keep the state's giant, overburdened electricity grid from crashing completely.
For the second straight day, the California Independent System Operator, which controls about 75 percent of the state's electric power grid on behalf of private utilities, declared a statewide Stage 2 emergency at midday. In a Stage 2 emergency, power is curtailed to commercial and industrial users that receive power-rate discounts in exchange for agreeing to shut down when asked to do so in times of high demand. 
 Officials warned that a Stage 3 emergency, which has never been declared, was possible because a stubborn high-pressure system stretching from Mexico to Canada had kept temperatures so high that air-conditioning systems were working harder and longer throughout the entire region. In a Stage 3 alert, "rotating blackouts" to small parts of communities are imposed to keep the larger system up and running.
In California, which began deregulating the electric power industry four years ago, and around the nation, a decade of economic growth and under-investment in new power plants has left power reserves at the lowest levels in decades. And because the current heat wave is so widespread, California has been unable to import enough power from other states.
This morning officials warned that overall demand in California today was expected to exceed 46,245 megawatts, breaking a record of 45,884 megawatts, set just last year.
But at 3:30 p.m., the system, handling 43,400 megawatts, had already cut off about 1,800 megawatts to industrial users as a result of the Stage 2 alert. That left the system with about 3 percent more power than the demands on it. A Stage 3 alert is automatically called if reserves fall below 1.5 percent.
If a Stage 3 event worked as planned, "we'd have to impose rotating outages to small portions of communities across all our service area," said Tom Boyd, a spokesman for Southern California Edison, which supplies power over 50,000 square miles in Central and Southern California, including much of suburban Los Angeles.
In Los Angeles itself, the city's municipal utility, the venerable Department of Water and Power, controls its own, independent electric power source and would not be expected to be affected by a Stage 3 alert.
Doug Kline, spokesman for San Diego Gas and Electric, which serves 1.2 million homes and businesses in the San Diego area, a total of about three million people, said the utility would treat any blackout caused by shortages as it treats a natural disaster.
For customers on life support who cannot have their power interrupted, "we encourage them to have some backup generation in the case of something like this," Mr. Kline said.
"But obviously they're in a different category of customers," Mr. Kline said, adding that "we work with those customers when we know where they are."

HEADLINE: For Mrs. Clinton, G.O.P. Theme Is Like Old Times

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: WESTBURY, N.Y., Aug. 1

 BODY:
The day after the Republican National Convention opened with a call to "leave no child behind," Hillary Rodham Clinton marveled at how familiar it all seemed.
"I thought it sounded like the convention theme was 'It Takes a Village,' " Mrs. Clinton said with a smirk, referring to the title of her book, which was ridiculed by conservatives when it was published in 1995. 
 The official theme at the Philadelphia convention on Monday was actually "Opportunity With a Purpose: Leave No Child Behind." The phrase ran through the remarks of many speakers, from experts on adoption and literacy to Gen. Colin L. Powell.
"Many of the issues that were discussed and the way they were discussed were very much in line with what I've written about and talked about for 30 years," Mrs. Clinton said today on the first day of a three-day campaign trip on Long Island. "I'm happy to have even rhetorical support for our mutual obligation to care for children."
The first lady's remarks came on the home turf of her Republican opponent for the United States Senate, Representative Rick A. Lazio. Mrs. Clinton is likely to have a much harder time winning votes on Republican-dominated Long Island, where the congressman was born and raised.
"Underneath all of that soothing rhetoric are very different ideas about what we should do as a country," she told reporters after a lunch meeting of the Nassau County Village Officials Association here.
"I'm glad we've moved the Republican Party rhetorically," Mrs. Clinton said. "But if you look at their Congressional agenda, if you look at their platform, if you look at what their nominee said when he started to run during the primary and the positions he signed onto, there are huge differences. And if the people of New York know the differences, the Democrats will do very well."
Mrs. Clinton was accompanied by her daughter, Chelsea, for the first time since it was announced that Chelsea would take a leave from Stanford University to help her mother's campaign. Small crowds gathered around Ms. Clinton as she greeted well-wishers and posed for pictures with babies and elderly people.
Just as Mrs. Clinton had stressed economic development in struggling upstate towns, she tailored her remarks today to the crowds of largely white, middle-aged and elderly Long Islanders, emphasizing issues like lowering taxes and her support for using the federal surplus to preserve Social Security and introduce prescription drug benefits for Medicare patients. She again mentioned a proposal, first outlined in Albany last month, that would change the formula to determine the state's share of federal Medicaid dollars.
Absent from today's remarks were the issues she has stressed before black audiences over the last couple of days, like the 1986 vote in Congress by Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, against a resolution urging freedom for Nelson Mandela from a South African prison.
While toning down what had been sharp criticism of Mr. Lazio, Mr. Cheney and Gov. George W. Bush, Mrs. Clinton said she had merely been pointing out facts.
"I don't think it's an attack to say Governor Bush went to Bob Jones University, Governor Bush supports the Republican platform and Supreme Court nominees who are dedicated to doing away with a woman's right to choose," she said. "I don't think it's negative or an attack to say here are the facts and let people make their own judgment."
Mrs. Clinton seemed downright earnest, even returning, for the first time in months, to the slogan of her book. "It takes a village to provide parks," she said earlier in the day during a campaign stop at a neighborhood park in Great Neck. "It takes a village to keep the streets safe. It takes a village to provide teachers and resources necessary to educate our children."
"It takes a lot of villages," Mrs. Clinton observed, "to help elect someone to the United States Senate."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow and S.& P. 500 Gain, But Nasdaq Slumps 2.2%
Stocks were mixed as investors switched out of technology companies on fears that their earnings growth might slow and moved into more traditional and cheaper sectors, like consumer products.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 84.97 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,606.95, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.27 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,438.10. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 81.47 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,685.52. Page C9. 

P.& G. Meets Lowered Estimates
Procter & Gamble, troubled by rising costs, management turmoil and credibility problems on Wall Street, reported fourth-quarter results that were in line with lowered forecasts but said that earnings growth in the first half of its new fiscal year would be sluggish. C2.
 
Ex-Coke Manager Gives Suit Advice
A former Coca-Cola benefits manager who has criticized the company's treatment of black workers said that he would urge those workers to retain lawyers to help them determine whether they should accept a settlement reached in June between Coke and four black employees or file their own suits. C3.
 
Three Labels to Sell Music Online
In a potentially fundamental change to the way music has been packaged, at least three major record labels -- EMI, Universal and Sony -- plan to begin selling songs over the Internet by the end of the year, enabling users to listen to or download songs for a flat fee. C5.
 
Ad Server Attracts Big Investors
Advertising.com, which develops systems that send ads to Web sites to be shown to computer users, is hoping to help accelerate its growth with investments totaling $57 million from sources that include major agency and media companies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.
 
Business Lessons From a Full House
"You can learn a lot about management from managing 18 kids." So says Pat Williams, senior vice president of the Orlando Magic. He should know, for he has reared almost enough children for a basketball league of their own. And he has done it despite his demanding professional life, the challenge of keeping such a large family afloat financially and, not least, the decision by his first wife to seek a divorce after 23 years of marriage. The Boss. C6.
 
Softbank Won't Sell Shares in Units
Softbank abandoned a plan to sell shares in five subsidiaries, citing potentially costly tax consequences. But there was speculation that Softbank abandoned the plan partly because a spinoff might have made the company less attractive to shareholders. C4.
 
Mixed Signals in Economic Reports
The National Association of Purchasing Management said that its factory index was unchanged in July at 51.8, the lowest level since January 1999, but government figures showed consumer spending rose 0.5 percent in June after rising 0.3 percent in May. C2.
 
Sales Offset Payouts on Air Delays
Hal Rosenbluth, whose travel management company offered in May to pay cash refunds to customers whose flights were delayed, has paid out more than he expected during this summer of delays and cancellations. But he isn't complaining because ticket sales on the company's Web site are up 40 percent. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C8.

HEADLINE: South Korea's Leader Deplores Anti-Americanism

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 1

 BODY:
President Kim Dae Jung issued a warning today against anti-Americanism as displayed by a small group of protesters, reminding South Koreans that the United States remained the country's "biggest supporter."
The warning came as the United States and South Korea prepared for talks Wednesday on revising a defense agreement that critics say infringes on Seoul's sovereignty. 
 Meanwhile, 50 protesters engaged in shoving matches with the police trying to prevent them from rallying near the American Embassy today.
Waving pickets and shouting slogans, the protesters demanded that Washington revise the defense treaty -- called the Status of Forces Agreement -- to allow South Korea greater jurisdiction over American soldiers in criminal cases.
"We must criticize wrong American policies but that should not lead to anti-Americanism," Mr. Kim was quoted by his office as saying during a cabinet meeting. "Cooperative relations with the United States should remain strong. Anti-Americanism does not help our national interests."
His warning was aimed at protesters who have demanded that Washington withdraw 37,000 troops stationed in South Korea as a deterrent against Communist North Korea. The group has stepped up activities since relations between North and South Korea began thawing in June, as a result of a summit meeting.
Despite the improving relations with North Korea, Mr. Kim reconfirmed that South Korea needed the American military presence for its security and for regional stability.
"The United States remains our biggest supporter," he said, "not only in security and international relations but also in economic relations."
Demands to revise the defense treaty increased last month after the United States military apologized for having dumped 20 gallons of formaldehyde into the Han River, a main source of drinking water for Seoul's 12 million people.
Protesters used public criticism of the American forces to demand their withdrawal.
Under the defense agreement, signed in 1966 and revised in 1991, American soldiers stationed in South Korea and involved in crimes remain under the custody of the United States military until all appeals are exhausted.

HEADLINE: College Takes to Street to Drum Up Enrollment

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Call it the big sell.
The Borough of Manhattan Community College is plastering its name all over New York City -- in 350 buses, 1,000 subway cars and 24 movie theaters, to be exact -- to attract students, and is sending current students out on the streets to recruit. Ronald Spalter, the college's vice president for administration and planning, is even planning to send students to Jones Beach to collar prospects for this fall's class right on the sands. 
 Last Friday, on a sultry afternoon that threatened rain, three students positioned themselves between vendors hawking wireless telephones and health insurance at the bustling Fordham Plaza shopping center in the Bronx to sell the virtues of the college. They were looking for high school students, immigrants and other men and women from poor and working-class neighborhoods who may not have thought of college as a possibility.
"Interested in college? B.M.C.C. is where you want to be," Theodore McNeil called as he trotted alongside likely-looking candidates.
"If you can't afford the tuition there," he said, pointing to the nearby Fordham University campus, "you can come to B.M.C.C." (B.M.C.C. tuition is $2,500 a year for state residents; Fordham's tuition is about $20,000.)
The campaign is part of a wider push by the City University of New York to attract more students to its six community colleges after the number of applicants in the late spring fell more than 10 percent below the year before.
Why the numbers slipped is unclear. Some CUNY professors suggest that students feel unwelcome because of the university's new policies limiting remedial classes. CUNY administrators disagree, saying that the changes affect the senior colleges, not the community colleges. They say the cause is the booming economy, which makes work more attractive than school.
Whatever the cause, the university did not want to take a chance that enrollments would remain weak -- even though community college students often wait to enroll until classes begin and there could still be a last-minute surge. A decline in students means a decline in tuition revenues and could force the colleges to cut back.
In June, Matthew Goldstein, CUNY's chancellor, leaned on the community colleges to mount recruiting campaigns, putting up about $250,000 to aid the effort. Last month, he took to the airwaves himself to promote CUNY, with 30- and 60-second radio spots advising listeners that "It takes more than a high school diploma to get a good job," and inviting them to call 290-5678 for "on-the-spot admission."
All of CUNY's community colleges now have their own recruiting and publicity programs. But none is as far-reaching as the one at B.M.C.C., which is probably less well known than the other CUNY community colleges, which draw most of their students from their own neighborhoods. B.M.C.C. draws only about a quarter of its students from Manhattan. Many of the rest come from the other boroughs and from Long Island and Westchester. Foreign students account for nearly 10 percent of its enrollment.
Based in a sprawling modern building on Chambers Street near the Hudson River, the college has seen its enrollment slip to fewer than 15,000 from about 17,000 a few years ago.
"We knew we had to correct the slide," said Antonio Perez, B.M.C.C.'s president.
Another reason for the big publicity splash, he said, was that the college needs greater name recognition before it begins a multimillion-dollar fund-raising campaign.
The publicity is costly. B.M.C.C. put the cost of the advertisements at more than $150,000. But Dr. Perez said an increase in students and a successful capital campaign would more than make up for the spending.
At Fordham Plaza last week, Chanel Wray and Antoinette Daniels, members of B.M.C.C.'s women's basketball team (which took third place nationally among community colleges) laid out brochures for more than a dozen B.M.C.C. programs, including science, nursing, accounting and computer programming, as well as a pile of information on student aid.
The students also mounted a large satellite dish with the college's name on it between their two tables.
"It's a decoy, but it draws people's attention," said Ms. Wray, an 18-year-old liberal arts major at the college who is earning $8.46 an hour to recruit students.
Business was brisk.
Six young women decked out in multiple gold chains and earrings crowded around the college's table and chatted about the basketball team. After asking where the college was (on Chambers Street, near the Hudson River) and how they could get there (the 1, 2, 3, 9, A and C subway trains stop close by), two of them filled out short forms requesting more information.
A gum-chewing woman with neon-pink toenails grabbed brochures on the college's nursing and early childhood programs.
The driver of a shiny black Town Car limousine pulled over to the curb and leaned out the window to ask Mr. McNeil about the college. Mr. McNeil handed the driver a form, and he filled it out, passed it back and sped away.
Several mothers stopped to fill out forms requesting more information for their children.
"Parents don't take the time to invest in helping their children," commented Stephanie Fields, a tall woman with an assured manner. She said she just graduated from college herself and was now trying to find a place for her daughter, Arlene, who is a senior in high school.
Some of the most serious candidates appeared to be immigrants hoping to move up to better jobs, a group that accounts for a sizable share of the students at all of CUNY's community colleges.
Lanning Diaz, a medical school graduate from the Dominican Republic, looked carefully through the B.M.C.C. brochures, especially the ones about computer science. A tall man with a grizzled beard, he said that he had been thinking about returning to school to learn about computer applications in health care since his medical license is not valid here.
He said he had already asked for his transcripts to be sent from the Dominican Republic to CUNY, but did not know which college he would attend. "I barely know the names and locations of the colleges," he said.
Sunday Alao, a Bronx resident from Ghana, also looked slowly through the college brochures. He said that although he had studied college-level accounting and management in Ghana, he was working in a kitchen now and wanted to go back to school to enter nursing. What college he chooses, he said, depends on whether he can afford it and whether he can schedule classes around his job.
Not everyone was interested.
Sharon Brown, a chatty woman in a bright turban who described herself as an entrepreneur, stopped briefly. She said she did not have a college degree but did not want one, though she might consider a computer course.
"Do they have Wealth Creation 101?" she asked. "That's what I'm interested in."
Mr. McNeil, who is 33 years old and has three children, was philosophic. "With the Clinton administration and prosperity, a lot of people are focused on putting food on the table now," he said after several people passed by without stopping.
"They don't want to think about what happens down the road. We're trying to get them to think about it."
B.M.C.C. officials are pleased with the response so far. As of mid-July, they say, the number of CUNY applicants requesting B.M.C.C. was nearly 2,800 -- more than 20 percent above last year.
But Mr. McNeil said that whether the number of new students rose or fell, he was convinced that the recruiting effort was worthwhile.
"On the off-chance it doesn't work," said Mr. McNeil, "they can't say CUNY didn't reach out."

HEADLINE: Liberties;
New Century, Old Grudges

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
O.K. Now we're in business.
After an icky evening of Republican kissy-face and blaxploitation ("Affirmative Action, the Musical"), Poppy unleashed Chiang! 
 Unleashing Chiang, in the loopy Bush family patois used in golf and tennis, means giving the ball a good whack.
After a week of President Clinton taunting W., saying that the Republican candidate's message was merely "My Daddy was president," Daddy lost it.
"And if he continues that, then I'm going to tell the nation what I think about him as a human being and a person," the former president threatened on NBC's "Today."
Our summer of torpid politics suddenly came alive with the freaky spectacle of two presidents trash-talking. The race turns out to be what we thought it was all along: President Bush vs. President Clinton.
George Senior is determined to prove once and for all that Bill Clinton is a tacky hick who defiled the presidency. Bill Clinton is determined to prove once and for all that George Senior is an irrelevant aristocrat who thinks the presidency is a family heirloom.
Two intensely competitive chief executives, who had been trying not to meddle too much in the campaigns of their proteges, bolting off the reservation in a bid for vindication.
George Senior is fighting for the second term he feels he was gypped out of by Bill Clinton. And Bill Clinton is fighting for the third term he needs to launder his legacy.
W. and Al are alternately bystanders and stand-ins in the big rematch.
It is as though the tape of the '92 election, on pause all these years, has started rolling again.
The presidential hissy fit is driven by class rage. Edith Wharton would have savored this drama of manners.
The Bushes have been privately steaming that Gore/Clinton have not abided by Marquess of Queensberry rules, allowing the Republicans to enjoy their nomination party without any Democrats throwing a punch.
Bush Pere believes his manners toward his successor have been impeccable, and that he has been discreet out of loyalty to the office.
"Who's been more gracious and charitable to Bill Clinton, even during Lewinsky?" asked the former president's old friend Alan Simpson, the former Wyoming senator.
So the Bushes felt the gentlemanly rules of order were broken over the last week when the Democrats put out an ad attacking Dick Cheney's conservative record and two more attacking W. on health care and the environment, and when Bill Clinton repeatedly mocked W. as a coddled daddy's boy at fund-raisers.
"The country was in the ditch," Mr. Clinton said in Boston last Friday, talking about '92, comparing the Bush White House to a ditzy "Wayne's World."
Nobody gave Mr. Clinton, who never knew his own father and who had to stand up to an abusive, alcoholic stepfather, a solid gold key to success. And he clearly thinks Al Gore, another regent raised to be president by a famous political father, is not up to the challenge of gutting the Bushes on the entitlement issue.
It has to be galling to Mr. Clinton that Americans don't seem inclined to reward his vice president for the purring economy. And he is surely fed up with the Republicans acting as if his two terms were merely Bushus Interruptus.
The remarkable thing is that this class war has caused everyone to reverse roles. In '92, W. was the vindictive one who lashed out when his father was criticized. Now dad has taken junior's role. And while it is usually vice presidents who serve as hatchet men, now Bill Clinton does that for his vice president.
Even though Mr. Simpson says that the Bushes avoided publicly criticizing Mr. Clinton about Monica Lewinsky, that is in fact the subtext of W.'s campaign -- restoring "honor and dignity" to the White House. Mr. Clinton thinks a rejection of Mr. Gore would be a ratification of the Bushes' contention that he sullied the White House. The president can also see that it is hard for Al Gore to attack, because even people who agree with Mr. Gore find him insufferable on the attack. W. and Mr. Gore will probably keep campaigning, but we all know it's not about them anymore. Maybe it never was.

PUB-DATE: August 2, 2000

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1660 words

HEADLINE: Columbia Sets Pace In Profiting Off Research

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
When Fredric D. Price, the president of a nutritional-supplements company, sought a partner to create an online information company, NutritionU.com, he approached a Columbia University professor, Dr. Richard J. Deckelbaum.
He hit pay dirt. 
 Some academics might have run the other way, concerned about the motives and standards in the emerging commercial market for cybereducation. But Dr. Deckelbaum, director of Columbia's Institute of Human Nutrition, viewed the Internet as a way to reach a wider population.
Columbia was interested, too. The venture fit its strategy of turning more of its intellectual capital -- its professors' knowledge, research and teaching -- into financial capital. It quickly forged an agreement with Mr. Price for fees and a share of the company.
Columbia's eagerness to join forces with a start-up Internet venture reflects a shift in an academic culture that once saw itself driven only by intellectual curiosity and far removed from commerce. While the change is occurring throughout the academic world, few universities have tried to cash in as aggressively as Columbia, which has a research capacity similar to that of Harvard and Yale but without their endowments.
As Columbia ventures further and faster than its peers -- it is collecting more in patents and royalties than any other university -- it is the focus of concern and envy.
"There's been a paradigm shift," said Cornelius W. Sullivan, vice provost for research at the University of Southern California, who is trying to point his university in a similar direction. "There was a time that this kind of work -- and the idea of making money from your research -- was not acceptable at universities, including ours."
Last year, Columbia earned nearly $100 million of its $1.5 billion budget from patents and royalties. This year it will collect more than $144 million from patents, like one on a technique that allows animal cells to be used to manufacture proteins used as drugs, and one on a discovery that paved the way for eye drops used in treating glaucoma.
The University of California, among the universities that has earned the most patent income in recent years, earned $89 million for the fiscal year that ended in June. Stanford University, another leader in patent income, expects to earn $35 million for the fiscal year that ends this month.
Columbia is reinvesting much of its money in further research to expand scientific discoveries and the money it makes from them.
Generally, the faculty has not raised a fuss. The benefits of collecting more money from research and other academic activities are clear: more money to advance their work and less dependence on the government. But there are concerns.
Dimitris Anastassiou, a professor of electrical engineering at Columbia, said he worried about the perception among some faculty members that the university increasingly "appears to be a for-profit enterprise." He would like it to put more of a wall between decisions about how the campus can make money, and decisions about what research the university should support. Currently, both sets of decisions are vested in the executive vice provost, Michael M. Crow, who receives the university's income from patents and royalties and decides how to spend it.
Sheldon Krimsky, a science policy specialist at Tufts University, said he was concerned about the impact on research when professors or universities have a stake in the outcome of their work. "It is a question not just of how many relationships you have with business, but the nature of those relationships," he said.
Eli M. Noam, a Columbia business professor who said he thought that generating more revenue from intellectual property was legitimate, said he still worried that "long term, it will reduce the credibility of universities and will probably reduce the willingness of society to take care of these institutions."
"Universities have benefited from the perception that they are outside the marketplace and have credibility because they are seen as disinterested parties," Mr. Noam said.
Columbia's provost, Jonathan R. Cole, acknowledges that there is a revolution taking place in what he calls the "means and modes" of producing knowledge, but argues that it will be possible to safeguard the underlying values of the university.
"I think the dominant values are predominantly the same as they used to be," he said. "The income is only a means to continue to pursue our mission."
"Our motivation is to be entrepreneurial," Mr. Cole said. "We've been giving it away for generations. Now we want to get a fair return, always so we can reinvest it."
The change began two decades ago. To spur technological progress, the Bayh-Dole Act of 1980 encouraged universities to commercialize the research they conducted with support from the federal government. Columbia, like other research universities, set up a technology licensing office.
Spinning academic discoveries into commercial riches, however, turned out to be a slow, uncertain process. Even if a university can find a company willing to license its discoveries, the odds are only one in 20 that the company will make it pay off commercially, said Lita Nelsen, director of the Technology Licensing Office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She said that M.I.T. typically earned $15 million to $20 million a year in patent and royalty fees, and that most university licensing offices did not break even.
But the Internet, which traffics in information, has jolted university officials into action. They see the Internet as a gold mine -- providing a faster, larger payback than traditional research in areas like biology -- if only they can figure out how to package what their professors know.
Internet companies with deep pockets are already buzzing around campuses, eager to enlist professors like Dr. Deckelbaum or Arthur R. Miller, a widely known Harvard law professor who agreed to work with a new online law school while he remained at Harvard.
Mindful of the competition, universities are trying to create their own opportunities that will allow professors to expand their reach and their incomes, and permit the universities to share in the bounty.
Columbia has been well ahead of the pack. The partnership with NutritionU.com is just one of the deals it has announced in recent months. In April, it announced the creation of Fathom.com, a commercial online partnership with other prestigious institutions, including the New York Public Library, the British Library and the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History; those institutions and others will offer information and classes on the Web site. In May, the university announced that it was teaming up with Cognitive Arts, a software designer, to offer continuing education on the World Wide Web.
Columbia was the first university to join forces with UNext.com, a start-up backed by Michael Milken, the former junk-bond king, that is offering Internet college courses created by elite universities. Columbia has already collected $2 million.
Dr. Crow, Columbia's executive vice provost, has been directing the university's efforts to cash in on its intellectual property. He has easy access to the provost and the president. And he has a hefty bankroll: more than $40 million this year, money not subject to the normal budget process or any faculty oversight.
One sign of the university's seriousness was its decision seven years ago to give Dr. Crow the income from the university's research royalties as his budget, rather than contribute it to the university's general fund. At the time, the amount was small, about $1 million. Today, it is about $42 million.
Dr. Crow thinks of the money, he said, as venture capital to be spent both on academically promising projects and economically promising ones. In recent years, his office has contributed $800,000 in seed money for a child and family policy center, and $600,000 into the development of an urban extension service.
This year, he said, about $10 million went into various academic initiatives. Another $20 million went into building new institutions, like a campus connected with Biosphere 2 in Arizona, and the rest into various projects, including digital media.
The university has created Columbia Media Enterprises to nurture digital projects. Although modeled on Columbia's technology licensing office, Columbia Innovation Enterprise, there is a key difference: it is a profit-making company, albeit one wholly owned by Columbia. Columbia Media Enterprises started last fall with one employee; today there are 15, including 7 student "sweepers" who comb the university for content to put on the Web.
In anticipation of increased activity over the Internet, Columbia pushed its faculty to consider how their interests should be treated. Professors traditionally own the rights to the books and articles they write, and their royalties represent perhaps 10 to 15 percent of book sales. Universities typically own patents from research, and professors may get a quarter of the revenue. (Each university's policy differs.)
Columbia's Senate approved a new intellectual property policy in June that gives the university rights to Internet projects that are supported by university money or commissioned by the university, or that make "substantial" use of university equipment and labor. In these cases, professors share in the revenue, receiving anywhere from a quarter to a half of the revenue after expenses.
Columbia says it has no plans to compel faculty members to cooperate with its own ventures, but hopes to offer them as an alternative to working with outside companies.
"The faculty are independent spirits, and we can't make them do anything," Dr. Crow said. "Their primary benefit is to create new knowledge. The secondary benefit is to collect licensing income. But it's a wondrous secondary benefit."

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS: THE NEW YORK SENATE RACE;
Lazio Drops In on Philadelphia, Saying His Job Is in New York

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Representative Rick A. Lazio stopped by his party's convention for a few brief hours today, seizing the chance to raise money for his Senate campaign and to rally supporters.
Mr. Lazio, Republican of Long Island, also tried to increase his visibility against his high-profile opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, by giving several television interviews. 
 Early, he seemed unrestrained by national Republican efforts to avoid criticism of the Clintons. Instead, Mr. Lazio told New York delegates at a brunch, "We've been here about a day, probably longer than Hillary Clinton has been in New York."
Later, Mr. Lazio was far more guarded, telling a mass of journalists that he was taking the high road, compared with what he considered the negativity of his opponent.
He attracted people curious to see the man in political combat with the first lady, though more than a smattering were unsure who he was.
Mr. Lazio ventured inside the hall, though far from the podium, where some Republicans felt he belonged.
Asked about the Republican Party's platform, which, among other points that differ from Mr. Lazio's positions, opposes abortion, Mr. Lazio said, "I think the platform, frankly, has become largely obsolete." But he cited only the abortion plank as problematic, adding, "I think the party platform is going to be determined by Governor Bush." (Mr. Lazio does oppose public financing for abortions and late-term procedures.)
Dan McLagan, a spokesman for Mr. Lazio, later explained that Mr. Lazio considered the concept of platforms obsolete, not the content.
Mr. Lazio faced numerous questions about his brief visit, and he restated that he would not be here on Thursday for Gov. George W. Bush's acceptance speech. Some have suggested that the Lazio campaign was irritated that he was not offered a greater role. But Mr. Lazio said: "My job is to get back to New York. That's where the votes are. I'm not running for national office here."
Some of his prominent Republican allies, including Dick Armey, the House majority leader, said they were disappointed in Mr. Lazio's limited role. Mr. Armey hugged Mr. Lazio and called him "one of my one or two best friends in the House."
Organizers "tried to allocate spots to guys who needed the exposure," Mr. Armey said of the schedule. "Rick doesn't really need it."
On Wednesday, Mr. Lazio is scheduled to appear on a WWOR program led by Bob Grant, who has drawn controversy over remarks he has made about blacks.
His opponent's staff regarded Mr. Lazio's convention appearance as a sign of his ties to what they consider the conservative party leadership.
"Which part of the Bush-Cheney ticket does he support?" asked Howard Wolfson, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman. "Does he support a risky tax scheme that would make a U-turn for our economy?"

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Courting of Voting Bloc Poses Question of Motive

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Tonight, for the second night in a row, one of the principal speakers at the Republican National Convention was a black person. Tonight, it was Condoleezza Rice, the chief national security adviser to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas; on Monday night, it was Colin L. Powell, who may be secretary of state if Mr. Bush is elected president.
Amazing stuff. 
 Obviously, this was no happenstance. In this convention, whose sole mission is to glorify Mr. Bush, happenstance just doesn't happen.
Equally obviously, neither Ms. Rice nor General Powell was on the dais as window-dressing. Both are eminent figures, whose success in the academic and military worlds speaks volumes about the achievements of black Americans in the last couple of decades. But there was window-dressing as well -- black singers, black choirs, black candidates for lesser offices and black children seated at school desks in the backdrop to the speech of the prospective nominee's wife, Laura, a former schoolteacher.
The question occurs, what is all this about? Granting that Mr. Bush has demonstrated in his brief political career a much greater sensitivity to minority concerns than the average Republican, what political purpose lies behind the image-making?
Does he really think he can do better among blacks than his father, who took 12 percent and 10 percent of the black vote in 1988 and 1992, respectively, and better than Bob Dole, who took 12 percent in 1996? Or is it a three-cushion shot, a subtle play for the votes of white suburbanites, a pivotal voting block that includes many voters for whom civil rights remains a high priority?
"He has no chance of getting any significant African-American vote," said David Bositis of the nonpartisan Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies. "This is not even about that. It's about the suburbs, and about moderate swing voters all across the country."
At the moment, the cold facts are these: The Democrats are a multiracial party, with large numbers of blacks in leadership positions. The Republicans are largely a mono-racial party. Since World War II, only three African-American Republicans have been elected to Congress.
General Powell said bluntly that there was widespread "cynicism in the black community" toward the Republican party, based in part on its opposition to affirmative action. He challenged the Republicans to reach out to blacks and other minority communities.
"And not just during an election-year campaign," he continued. "It must be a sustained effort."
Mr. Bush acknowledged that "we have a lot of work to do."
But Democrats expressed skepticism that it would ever get done. Speaking at the alternative convention here, the Rev. Jesse Jackson praised General Powell but said that his speech was part of a "sham." Noting that this is a largely white convention -- only 4 percent of the delegates are black, about the same as in 1972 -- Mr. Jackson added, "You got Powell making speeches but you got Trent Lott making policy" -- a reference to the Senate majority leader, a conservative from Mississippi.
According to exit polls conducted by Voter News Service, a consortium of television networks and The Associated Press, Mr. Bush took 27 percent of the black vote in his re-election contest in 1998. That may have been an exaggeration of his true strength, because his Democratic opponent, Tony Mauro, was never seen as a viable alternative. Mr. Bush did much less well against Ann Richards in 1994, winning 15 percent of the black vote then.
During this year's campaign, he made a point of appearing before the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. But in South Carolina, when Senator John McCain of Arizona was pressing him hard, Mr. Bush was unwilling to condemn the flying of the Confederate battle flag on the statehouse, and he campaigned at Bob Jones University in Greenville, which banned interracial dating at the time of his speech.
Mr. Bush has also described Clarence Thomas and Antonin Scalia, dyed-in-the-wool conservatives whose very names are anathema to many blacks -- even though Mr. Thomas is himself black -- as model Supreme Court justices.
To many African-Americans, those actions seemed of a piece with Richard M. Nixon's southern strategy, which built a lasting base for the Republicans among Southern white voters. It was not explicitly anti-black, but it was grounded in racial apprehensions. Ever since, the Republican Party has had, to a greater or lesser degree, a white southern core, and its leadership on Capitol Hill has been largely southern.
President Clinton, meanwhile, has emerged as the most popular president among African-Americans since Lyndon B. Johnson, who signed the Voting Rights Act, and Franklin D. Roosevelt, who espoused their cause during the Depression, when many of them had trouble finding enough to eat.
"Most of my friends see him as a kind of god," said a black Republican delegate here, who asked that his name not be used. "Some of that rubs off on Al Gore, and it makes Bush's job in November terribly difficult."
The latest New York Times/CBS News poll, taken between July 20 and 22, suggested how difficult a job Mr. Bush faces in courting black votes. In a two-way race, Mr. Gore won the support of 84 percent of African-Americans to Mr. Bush's 6 percent.
At a first glance, blacks would seem to be ripe for conversion to Republicanism. In nationwide telephone surveys conducted by The Times and CBS News since 1976, between a quarter and a third of black voters have described themselves as conservatives, but only 6 percent to 11 percent have described themselves as Republicans. Even making allowances for those who use the word "conservative" in its social rather than political sense, and apply it to themselves because they are regular churchgoers, for example, the Republicans should have an opportunity.
In recent years, moreover, more and more blacks have reached the middle class, have moved into prosperous suburbs and have joined the professions. According to a new study called Black America 2000, the income levels of black households have tripled in the past 24 years, and the number of black-owned businesses more than doubled in number between 1987 and 1997.
When other groups have undergone such changes, significant numbers among them have migrated to the Republican party. But so far, that pattern has not held for blacks.
In any event, things are going well for Mr. Bush among white suburbanites. The same Times/CBS poll showed him ahead of the Mr. Gore among that group, 52 percent to 34.
If, as Mr. Bositis and a number of Republican tacticians suggested, Mr. Bush's real aim in appealing to blacks is to solidify his support among white moderates, he would not be the first Republican nominee to try that ploy. In 1980, Ronald Reagan made much of his endorsement by the civil rights leaders Ralph David Abernathy and Hosea Williams. His black support barely budged; but that was not the point, a strategist, Richard Wirthlin, later explained. The target, Mr. Wirthlin said, was white suburbanites.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Gooden's Bronx Revival Continues

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
Dwight Gooden's revival continued last night, which meant that one of the most surprising developments of a long season continued for the Yankees. Gooden pitched seven competent innings for one of the best teams in baseball and made it difficult to fathom how he was unemployed before George Steinbrenner offered him one more chance.
Of course, Gooden has devoured the chance, has helped stabilize the Yankees and has made them look shrewd for believing in him again. While Gooden was impeccable last night at Yankee Stadium, the bullpen was not, so Gooden lost his chance for a victory when Mike Stanton frittered away a two-run bulge in the eighth and the Kansas City Royals rallied to tie the score. 
 But Scott Brosius saved Stanton by hammering a homer off Ricky Bottalico to lead off the bottom of the eighth and vault the Yankees to a dramatic 5-4 victory. Since Brosius had stranded six runners in his first three at-bats and had not homered in 14 games, he tossed the bat aside, raised his arms in the air like Rocky Balboa and scampered around the bases.
"It was one of those times where you could walk away with a smile after struggling a bit," Brosius said.
Gooden could definitely smile after continuing to do something that was supposed to be a surprise, and is now looking more and more like a routine. He had a sturdy fastball, precise control and enormous confidence, allowing one earned run and four hits in his longest outing of the season. He gave Manager Joe Torre enough evidence to prove that the 35-year-old Gooden should stay in the rotation.
Torre admitted that he never expected Gooden to be in a pivotal position. But Gooden, who signed a minor league contract in June, is 3-0 with a 1.86 earned run average for the Yankees after adding a changeup and being more aggressive. It will be difficult for Torre to remove him from the rotation, even if David Cone is excellent in his next start.
"You can't top what he did tonight," Torre said about Gooden. "It's fun for me to watch. I know he has to be thrilled about it."
After abominable stints with the Houston Astros and Tampa Bay Devil Rays and a near retirement, Gooden thought about what he had accomplished and said, "It might sound crazy, but I'm more relaxed now."
Despite his superb pitching, Gooden knows that Orlando Hernandez, who is recovering from an injury, will return to the rotation and he would like to see Cone do so as well. If Cone is in the five-man rotation, Gooden will not be.
"I think that's their decision," Gooden said. "I still feel we're a better team with me in the bullpen. That would mean that El Duque is healthy and Coney is back on track. I have no problem going to the bullpen."
With the Yankees trailing by 2-1 in the seventh, Chuck Knoblauch walked and stole second, and Royals starter Dan Reichert followed by walking Derek Jeter. After the left-hander Tim Byrdak struck out Paul O'Neill, Bernie Williams smashed a two-run double to left. David Justice followed with a double to make it 4-2, a refreshing change for the Yankees, who had stranded two in the fifth and three in the sixth after Brosius whiffed.
Gooden was six outs from his fourth victory with the Yankees and he had thrown only 79 pitches, but Torre turned to Stanton in the eighth. A one-out single, a walk and Johnny Damon's booming double off the fence in right-center field, which was a few feet from being a three-run homer, tied the score, 4-4. The Royals later loaded the bases against Jeff Nelson, but Nelson fanned Joe Randa and pumped his fist as he returned to the dugout. All of the Yankees were celebrating a few moments later when Brosius belted Bottalico's 1-0 fastball over the left-field fence.
The homer climaxed a long day for Brosius. His 8-year-old daughter, Allison, developed the concept for a fund-raiser called Yankees' Kids for Kids, which was introduced yesterday. The Yankees put canisters at more than 50 locations throughout the Stadium for donations to buy toys for local children who are in the hospital. Allison and her father videotaped a message describing the effort that was shown on the scoreboard during the game.
"People definitely got enough of the Brosius family tonight with all that was going on," Brosius said. "From here on out, we'll be less visible."
Even though Gooden did not get the victory, the Yankees were giddy because a reclamation project from the Devil Rays was pitching as well as anyone else on their staff. Gooden was dejected when the Royals took a 2-0 lead in the fifth, a sign of how much he expects of himself now. Gooden's revival continued, but will he stay in the rotation?
"I like tough decisions," Torre said. "There are other clubs struggling to know who they'll start next week. If we have a lot of choices, I like that. It's going to be tough. Right now, I don't know what I'm going to do."

INSIDE PITCH
ORLANDO HERNANDEZ (sprained elbow and back spasms) pitched four shutout innings in a Class A game yesterday and felt no pain. Hernandez struck out five and walked one in a 49-pitch effort, and his fastball reached 92 miles an hour. The Yankees will decide today if he should rejoin the team or make another rehab start. . . . RYAN THOMPSON was relieved that the Yankees did not acquire a left fielder. "You know how they say you have a monkey on your back?" Thompson said. "I had a gorilla. But I still have to show these guys. I have to impress them."

LENGTH: 996 words

HEADLINE: U.S. IS PROPOSING NEW WAY TO FIGHT GLOBAL WARMING

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Preparing for renewed international negotiations on cutting levels of heat-trapping gases that may be warming the climate, the United States is proposing that countries get just as much credit for using forests and farmers' fields to sop up carbon dioxide, the chief warming gas, as they would for cutting emissions from smokestacks and tail pipes.
Scientists have known for decades that trees and other plants absorb carbon dioxide as they grow and some soils do as well. In theory, pulling carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere would allow countries to emit some heat-trapping, or greenhouse, gases without adding to the overall problem. 
 Clinton administration officials and some scientists said last night that incentives to plant trees and to farm in ways that lock away carbon were essential for stabilizing the climate. In addition, they said, bringing farmers and foresters into the battle is likely to be crucial if the Senate, which has so far firmly opposed ratifying any international climate treaty, is to change its view.
But the position is being criticized by some private environmental groups, which have pressed to cut the burning of coal and oil, which caused most of the carbon dioxide buildup in the first place. They point to uncertainties about how long plants and soils could continue to absorb carbon.
And the proposal is at odds with the stance of the European Union which, given its relative lack of open land for tree-planting, would be at a disadvantage.
The State Department laid out the United States' approach in documents filed last night with a United Nations office that is overseeing talks aimed at carrying out the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, an international agreement aimed at averting any dangerous climate warming. Thirty-eight other industrialized countries were scheduled to file their proposals last night, as well.
The Kyoto agreement has been signed by the United States and more than 100 other countries but has not yet been ratified, and many details remain to be ironed out, with two rounds of negotiations coming in September and again in November.
If the agreement is ratified, the United States would commit itself to cutting its emissions of carbon dioxide by 2010 to 7 percent below the emissions in 1990. Given the growth in the economy and fuel use since 1990, administration officials say, the only way to come anywhere near that target is by adopting every possible strategy, including the agricultural approach.
Vice President Al Gore was deeply involved in crafting the Kyoto treaty and any deadlock in talks would be a blow to him. On the other hand, although Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has said he believes global warming is a significant problem, he opposes ratification of the Kyoto Protocol, saying it would unfairly burden the United States.
White House officials said Mr. Gore was being apprised of the proposed strategy.
Michael Oppenheimer, chief scientist of Environmental Defense, a private group, said that whatever program finally emerges in the next rounds of talks, it must not allow any country to get too much credit for things it is already doing, like, for example, planting trees on land that was clearcut several years ago.
"Done well, credit for forests and farming could help jumpstart a solution to the global warming problem," Dr. Oppenheimer said. "Done poorly, it could undermine the credibility of the whole Kyoto agreement."
David B. Sandalow, the assistant secretary of state for oceans and environmental affairs, said the United States would not want any final climate plan to permit loopholes allowing clearcutting or other bad land practices to get credit.
But, taking a position at odds with some environmental groups, he added that the country's position would be to try to get credit for most of the carbon dioxide being absorbed by the country's trees and crops -- about 300 million metric tons a year is the projection for that tally by 2010.
That compares to the projected total emissions of more than 2.1 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide a year from industry, cars and other sources if current energy trends continue, he said.
He added that keeping some focus on farming and trees would keep the cost of fighting global warming down. Estimates are that it will be much cheaper for a country to absorb pollution than to reduce the output of these gases.
"We need strong incentives for parties to adopt practices that protect the atmosphere at low cost," Mr. Sandalow said last night.
Canada, Russia, Australia and other countries with lots of forests and farming are all tending to align with the American position. Also, according to several Japanese news services, Japan last night submitted similar plans, anticipating a large role for tree planting. Its focus is probably not so much on current events but on an anticipated round of talks extending actions on global warming to the third world, where Japan and other rich countries could get credit for investing in forest projects.
Some private environmental groups are vigorously opposing this approach.
Jennifer Morgan, the director of the climate change campaign at the World Wildlife Fund, an international group, said that forests and soils are, at best, a temporary storehouse for carbon, and one that can be broken open by later changes in practices or by unforseen forces like wildfire, droughts, or insect infestations -- all of which could abruptly unlock millions of tons of banked carbon.
"Soil can be a great absorber of carbon, but if you plow too deeply two years in a row you can release it all back into the air," she said. "We need to find the most secure way of reaching these goals, and that is to focus on cutting emissions from things like power plants."
Last night, a White House official said that some environmental groups -- historically focused on cleaning pollution -- were being too inflexible on the issue. "Carbon is carbon, right?" said the official.

HEADLINE: Levy Offers Higher Salaries To Staff the Worst Schools

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
With pressure mounting to rid New York City's most troubled schools of uncertified teachers by September, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced a plan yesterday to lure experienced instructors from private and parochial schools by increasing the starting salaries they can earn if they transfer into the city's poorest schools.
Mr. Levy's announcement came as a state judge temporarily barred him from allowing unlicensed teachers to work in 99 troubled schools in the coming school year, which begins Sept. 7. The judge, Gloria C. Aronin of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, issued the temporary restraining order yesterday after Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, sued the Board of Education. 
 In court papers, Mr. Mills charged that the board had violated a new state law by hiring nearly 600 unlicensed teachers to work in the 99 underperforming schools, mostly in Brooklyn and the Bronx, last year. Also, he argued, the board did not provide any guarantee that those teachers would be replaced this fall, and that any extra vacancies would be filled with certified teachers.
Mr. Levy said he was surprised by the suit but his new effort to recruit parochial and private school teachers would "go a long way toward solving the problem." The plan, which Mr. Levy negotiated this week with the United Federation of Teachers and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, changes a longtime cap on starting salaries for experienced teachers who transfer into the city schools.
Because of the cap, all certified teachers transferring into the system started out earning a salary commensurate with only five years of experience -- about $39,000 -- no matter how much experience they had. But now, teachers with more than seven years of experience who transfer into the 99 underperforming schools will start out with a higher salary, earning $48,000.
"I think there are a significant number of teachers who would long ago have transferred to the public school system if the economic gain was larger," Mr. Levy said. "Teachers at Dalton, Trinity and Regis who want to help children in need will see this higher-pay package as a way to do the work they love without having to make a financial sacrifice."
Richard Blumenthal, the headmaster at the Dalton School, was out of town yesterday and could not be reached for comment. But other private schools leaders said they did not think that the new salary incentive would be enough to draw private-school teachers into the city's failing schools. "The failing schools that the chancellor needs teachers for are such a different world that I don't think they'd be an attractive option for our teachers," said Dorothy A. Hutcheson, head of Nightingale-Bamford, a private school for girls on the Upper East Side.
Ms. Hutcheson said she was more concerned about losing teachers to suburban public schools, which offer not only much higher salaries but also comfortable working conditions.
Nora Murphy, a spokeswoman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York's education office, responded angrily to Mr. Levy's plan. Teachers at Catholic schools sign contracts in the spring promising to return the following fall, she said, so the plan is effectively urging them to break those contracts.
Told of Ms. Murphy's comments, Mr. Levy said, "The last I looked it was a free market, and people have the ability to decide where they want to work."
Of the 577 uncertified teachers hired last year to work in the 99 underperforming schools, roughly 250 have been reassigned. The Board of Education has urged the remaining teachers to apply to a new alternative certification program that the state approved last month. But to participate, they would have to pass two state certification exams by the start of the school year.
Many of these teachers have repeatedly failed the certification exams, and state education officials say the alternative certification program will not begin to solve the problem. Besides ordering Mr. Levy to replace uncertified teachers who were hired for the 99 troubled schools last year, Mr. Mills is also ordering Mr. Levy to fill any new vacancies in those schools with certified teachers. Board officials said yesterday that they did not know how many vacancies they would have to fill in September. But last year, there were 1,400 vacancies in those schools, out of a total 6,000 teaching positions.
A spokesman for Mr. Mills praised Mr. Levy's incentive plan for parochial and private-school teachers yesterday, but added that Mr. Levy should consider transferring experienced teachers from other city schools into the 99 troubled schools -- even if they did not want to go.
Board officials say the teachers' contract prevents them from forcing transfers. But Chris Carpenter, the spokesman for Mr. Mills, said the commissioner believed that they could find a way to do it.
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, the teachers' union, warned that forcing teachers to transfer to troubled schools would "outrage" parents and compel the teachers to abandon New York City schools altogether. She praised Mr. Levy's plan, but said a better solution would be to significantly raise salaries for all 75,000 of the city's teachers.
