HEADLINE: War on Diamonds

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Diamonds have become unfashionable as never before among Western powers struggling to snuff out civil wars in Africa. Appalled by pictures of children with limbs hacked off by diamond-smuggling rebels in Sierra Leone and humiliated when those rebels kidnapped international peacekeepers in May, the United States, Britain and several other countries are making control of the diamond trade a foreign policy priority.
The United Nations recently imposed an embargo on diamonds from Sierra Leone, and the United States is threatening sanctions against other West African countries accused of trading guns for gems. And a consensus has emerged for a strict certification regime to keep the stones that have been used to fuel Africa's civil wars out of the world's jewelry shops. 
 What has been conspicuously missing from all this is international support in the form of money, arms or troops -- to force the rebels in Sierra Leone out of their lucrative diamond mining turf.
"The real critical thing is that someone has got to go in there and get the rebels out," said Ralph Hazleton, a Canadian expert on diamonds who testified today at a United Nations hearing on the diamond embargo in Sierra Leone. "No matter what the international community does, the rebels will always find ways to sell their diamonds. There are a lot of not-so-honest people around."
Evidence of the existence of unscrupulous diamond traders can be found by looking south in Africa to Angola, where the Unita rebel movement, despite a United Nations diamond embargo, has made hundreds of millions of dollars a year by selling stones into the international market.
Robert R. Fowler, the Canadian ambassador to the United Nations and chairman of a committee that investigated violations of the embargo in Angola, has said the embargo did little to put Unita out of the diamond business. Rather, he said, it was a military offensive last year by Angolan government forces that chased Unita away from diamond mines and finally crippled its smuggling operation.
In Sierra Leone, though, military analysts say the government cannot hope to push rebels out of diamond mining areas without substantial help from United Nations peacekeepers or a major injection of military aid from the West.
But American and British diplomats made clear in interviews here today that there was neither the political will nor the money to rout the rebels from Sierra Leone's diamond country.
"We are not working to militarily defeat the rebels," said Jeremy Greenstock, the British ambassador to the United Nations. "It is unrealistic in the short or medium term to expect that either the Sierra Leone government or the United Nations peacekeepers will be capable of taking over the whole of the country."
Britain, the former colonial power in Sierra Leone, is spending $40 million to train security forces in the country and has plans to supply them with some weapons, Mr. Greenstock said. But he added that British help was not intended to make the government able to go on the offensive.
What the British, the Americans and the United Nations hope to do, then, is to make rebels in Sierra Leone say uncle by applying an economic and political squeeze.
Diplomats said they expect that strict enforcement of the embargo, which has won broad public support from diamond traders, will make smuggling much less easy and profitable than it has been in the past. In recent years the rebels have been making $30 million to $50 million a year from smuggled diamonds, an American official said.
Cracking down on the diamond trade is particularly difficult.
Millions of dollars worth of the stones can be smuggled in a sock, and it is often impossible for experts to determine the country of origin for small parcels of diamonds.
In Sierra Leone the problem is compounded by a long open border with Liberia. American and British diplomats say the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, is a principal player in diamond smuggling. Officials accused Mr. Taylor of formulating military strategy for the Sierra Leone rebels and personally profiting from the sale of illicit stones.
The United States sent an envoy last month to Monrovia, the Liberian capital, to warn Mr. Taylor that unless he immediately halted the trade, he would be subject to American and international sanctions.
But Liberia may have little to lose from sanctions. Its economy is already in ruins from a savage civil war prosecuted by Mr. Taylor. Although it was once the largest per capita recipient of American aid in Africa, Liberia now receives little money from the United States and the World Bank.
Diamonds, in fact, may be more valuable in Liberia than international good will.
An American official said the tiny country exported about $290 million in smuggled diamonds last year, a huge windfall for a near-bankrupt state.
"We have seen no diminution yet between the almost daily contracts between senior leaders in Monrovia and senior leader of the R.U.F.," said Mr. Greenstock, using the acronym for the rebels of the Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone.
Echoing views of American diplomats, Mr. Greenstock predicted that strict enforcement of the diamond embargo would, over time, impoverish the rebels and make them willing to discuss a political settlement.
"You are lowering the price of diamonds going out and therefore de-motivating the R.U.F.," Mr. Greenstock said, adding that there was evidence that the price of smuggled diamonds had fallen 30 percent since the United Nations imposed an embargo on stones from Sierra Leone six weeks ago.
The British ambassador dismissed a comparison to the largely ineffectual diamond embargo in Angola. He said other nations and the world diamond trade were now much more motivated and united in their desire to halt violence in Africa.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 21, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article on Aug. 2 about diamond smuggling in Africa that finances guerrilla wars included an outdated account of the views of Robert R. Fowler, Canadian ambassador to the United Nations. It was in an interview last February that Ambassador Fowler, chairman of a committee investigating sanctions violations in Angola, said that a diamond embargo against the Unita rebel movement there was having little effect. At that time, he said it was a government military offensive that was crippling the rebel smuggling operation. But in a statement to The Times last week, the Ambassador said the international sanctions had since begun to have a significant effect.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Anarchists of the World, Unite in Your Literary Roots!

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman 

 BODY:
The appearance of some self-proclaimed anarchists among the protesters at the Republican convention is tantalizing but perplexing. With radical effusions so out of style, what are we to make of these figures from beyond the fringe? They summon us back to a time and place when anarchists were taken seriously, Russia in the 19th century, and to the great novelists who grappled with the phenomenon.
As the eruptions on the streets of Seattle and Washington demonstrated a few months ago, any organization that calls itself the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund is a natural target for a radical's abiding animosity toward rich and powerful institutions that impose their will on entire societies. But since the anarchist by definition opposes every sort of system, the word has become identified more with wishful dreams of destroying what exists than with workable schemes to achieve what ought to exist. 
 In his 1964 history, "The Anarchists," (Atlantic, Little Brown), James Joll concluded that while anarchist doctrine draws on political ideas of the Enlightenment, anarchist actions, which are often meant to startle, can be explained "only in terms of the psychology of religious belief." The confrontations, slogans, costumes (black garb enlivened by red bandanas) of today's American-style street anarchists invite a novelist's scrutiny of a temperament that had its most spectacular heyday in 19th-century Russia yet pops up periodically even on these relatively placid shores.
In their literary incarnations anarchists range from murderers to flower children. Dostoyevsky, the pre-eminent psychologist of Russian radicalism, found inspiration for his novel "The Possessed," (renamed "Demons" by its latest translators, Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky) in the 1869 murder of a student by a group led by a 22-year-old nihilist, Sergei G. Nechayev. (My dictionary reports that the anarchist believes that all political institutions and existing social arrangements should be abolished; the nihilist, a word that has gone out of fashion, calls for their destruction by terrorism.) The Nechayev trial in 1871, the first public political trial in Russia, supplied Dostoyevsky with many of the characters and elements of his novel, published the following year.
Be they anarchists or nihilists, the radicals do not come off very well in "Demons." Shigalyov, the movement's theoretician in the book, is candid about the dead end of anarchism: "Starting from unlimited freedom, I conclude with unlimited despotism." The Nechayev-like character, Pyotr Verkhovensky, represents the transformation of the ideal of unlimited freedom into anarchic destruction.
The translators sum up Dostoyevsky's take on his characters' radicalism: "Everything is inverted here: freedom ends in despotism, adoration turns to hatred, lucidity increases blindness, the first real act of the liberator of mankind -- Nechayev or Verkhovensky -- is the murder of his human brother. Seeking the greatest good, we do the greatest evil."
Although Dostoyevsky and his foremost competitor, Turgenev, had little in common politically, they shared a mistrust and distaste for the anarchic atrocities and fancies of their time.
Turgenev provided an enduring specimen of what might be called Anarchy Light in Bazarov, who came to personify nihilism, which had a vogue in mid-19th-century Russia. Although Bazarov willingly accepts being labeled a nihilist, he is far too disdainful of any hope for improvement of any sort to become part of any movement.
As he puts it in a running quarrel with Pavel Petrovich, the older-generation liberal, "At the present time the most useful thing is negation." When pressed on what is to be done after the destruction of "everything," he says: "That already goes beyond our task. The first thing is to clear the field."
Call it anarchy or nihilism or just desperation, that is the terrorism of the mind; the payoff is all internal. The politics of Bazarov, by far the most dynamic character in "Fathers and Sons" (or "Fathers and Children," as a newer translation has it), grows out of his sense of his own intellectual superiority. Or, as some psychologist would surely deduce, it is a shield for his insecurity.
Bazarov wins all the arguments with the elderly liberal, but they are essentially rhetorical victories. He patronizes his loving parents, mocks the ignorant peasantry and scorns almost everyone he meets until, in a contrived ending for an otherwise glowingly honest novel, Turgenev has him morally redeemed by love and death.
Still, when it comes to probing the radicalism of his time, Bazarov remains the enduring figure of the self-absorbed radical whose bark is fierce but who has no bite, a specimen not absent among radicals today. It is temperament, not ideology, that holds him back from true anarchy. Although he is politically useless, his heart, to borrow this campaign season's favorite organ, is good. At least you would never find him donning a mask or breaking a window in a demonstration.
There seems to be something about the greatest novelists that is put off by anarchism, whatever its form. In part it may be their own politically conservative inclinations. More important perhaps, for all their differences, writers like Dostoyevsky, Turgenev and Conrad, who inspected the psyche of a bomb thrower in "The Secret Agent," share a need for intellectual organization, which is threatened by ideological chaos. Moreover, they mistrust movements that would force art and politics into utopian abstractions in the name of an illusory freedom. They have history on their side and might make for rewarding reading by today's theatrically inclined protesters.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Detroit's Use of Steel

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Ford Said to Plan Improved Mileage in Sport Utilities" (front page, July 27), you report that "lighter auto parts are usually more expensive, because they need to be made from aluminum instead of steel."
Over the last six years, the global steel industry has demonstrated the untapped potential of steel to reduce the weight of auto components at no cost premium through its series of "ultralight steel auto body" initiatives. Ford and other vehicle makers have been increasing their use of advanced high-strength steels and processing technologies to save weight, improve performance and safety, and reduce cost. 
 We support the Ford Motor Company in its effort, as we have been supporting Ford and the other vehicle manufacturers in their work to improve fuel economy and lower tailpipe emissions of their cars and trucks.
 
ANDREW G. SHARKEY III
President and Chief Executive
American Iron and Steel Institute
Washington, Aug. 1, 2000

HEADLINE: On Avenue C, Renewal and Regret

BYLINE: By JOHN LELAND 

 BODY:
WHEN the Scottish movie "Trainspotting," about young heroin addicts, hit theaters in 1996, some critics called it an advertisement for drug use. But for the residents of 713 East Ninth Street, just east of Avenue C, the film was an opportunity.
The residents, calling themselves Dos Blockos, were a close-knit group of squatters inhabiting an abandoned six-story tenement that had been stripped of wires, pipes, anything neighborhood addicts could convert to quick cash. When a glossy magazine wanted an appropriately derelict backdrop for a "Trainspotting" photo shoot, the squatters volunteered their homes -- for a location fee of $500 a day. "We used that money to put plumbing in the building," said Dan, who had lived in the squat at the time, and declined to give his last name. 
 It was a funny transaction, the squatters marketing their picturesque squalor in order to inch their building closer to gentility. But such was life on Avenue C in 1996: a push and pull between urban entropy and bootstrap self-improvement, with money conspicuous primarily for its scarcity. While other parts of the East Village were becoming playgrounds for gentrification, Avenue C was still a frontier. "Avenue C was pretty crazy," said Dan, who is no longer a squatter. "But it was also beautiful. People were living outside the rules of society."
Four years since "Trainspotting," that frontier has been redrawn. On a drizzly evening last week, Mark Edio returned to his home at 713 East Ninth Street, the former site of the Dos Blockos squat. But Mr. Edio, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, was returning to a different sort of home: new sheetrock walls, videophone security and key-card entry to the front door. The floors glistened and the common hallways smelled faintly of renovation. The squatters were gone.
"It's the perfect apartment," Mr. Edio said. As he saw it, the new place was big, it was cheap and it was in a great neighborhood.
He was speaking the new language of Avenue C. Decoded: For roughly 1,000 square feet, on a site until recently deemed not worth maintaining, Mr. Edio and three roommates have just signed a lease for $3,000 a month. It is, they feel, a find.
The story of the Dos Blockos squat and the new, high-priced rentals that are replacing it mirrors the story of Avenue C, a prosaic stretch that once seemed impervious to change. After decades of disregard, the avenue is in a state of rapid, some say rabid, churn. As crime rates have fallen and fortunes risen citywide, the tide of gentrification has pushed eastward, into the shoe-box tenements and worn street life that long resisted its seep. The newcomers are lured not by fixer-upper lofts or brownstones but by the night life and a social swank, and by the diversity they threaten to upset. "Here you've got students, you've got professional people, you've got bums," said Mr. Edio, who moved from Brooklyn's Park Slope. "It's more real."
In storefronts that once housed drug dens, a handful of entrepreneurs are opening smart bistros, bars and cafes. Neat row house co-ops have risen in place of crumbling squats and community gardens. Gone, too, are the cinder blocks that sealed abandoned buildings; behind the new, double-pane windows are tiny one-bedroom apartments renting for $2,000 a month, surprising even real estate agents.
"We started to see people get $500-plus per square foot about a year ago" for co-ops, said Stephen Kliegerman of the Halstead Property Company, or nearly triple what co-ops sold for in the mid-1990's. "This isn't a fringe neighborhood anymore, it's a mainstream neighborhood," he said.
Blocks that long vibrated with the colors and flavors of working-class Latino families are increasingly drawing dot-comers and students, many of whom, like Mr. Edio, rely on family money to pay the new rents, which have doubled in the last five years.
"I have my parents for now," said Meegan Thompson, 22, who moved into a newly renovated building on East Fifth Street between Avenue B and Avenue C in early July. Ms. Thompson, who graduated from Lewis & Clark College in Portland, Ore., in May, is looking for a job in publishing. "I've worked out the math," she said. To make her half of the $2,050 rent, she figured, she needs to find a job paying $26,000 a year.
Here is another sign of the times: the Lower East Side Harm Reduction Center, which provides clean needles and services to drug users, wants to leave the area. "We're looking for a place where our participants won't have to walk past haute couture clothing stores on their way to us," said Drew Kramer, the center's executive director.
Like many long-term residents, Richard Hell, a musician and novelist, has watched with resignation and sadness as more affluent waves of newcomers have moved east. He came to the neighborhood in the early 1970's, attracted by its cheap rents and invitation to creative dishabille. As a member of the bands Television and the Voidoids, he helped draw punk rockers to the East Village, bringing along a swell of anti-gentrification resentment.
"I'm sorry to see my neighborhood turned into a Coney Island boardwalk, Bleecker Street tourist trap, but it is kind of the cycle," said Mr. Hell, whose real surname is Myers. "The kids come in, then the young artists, and they displace the poor. Then they get displaced. To me it's just like the weather by now."
The neighborhood has a history of resisting gentrification, sometimes violently. Twelve years ago this month, locals clashed with police in riot gear over a proposed curfew in Tompkins Square Park. Thirteen police officers and 40 civilians were injured over two days of conflict. Since then, protesters have skirmished with police over the eviction of squatters or the bulldozing of gardens to make room for mixed-income co-ops, some distributed by lottery. The unofficial greeting remains "Yuppie Go Home"
But as the new gentry have pushed east to Avenue C, known locally as Loisaida Avenue, the voices of protest have been uncharacteristically quiet. "A lot of people just accepted that this is like trying to stop a Mack truck," said Lesley Heathcote, a gardener and painter who has lived in the neighborhood for 20 years. Ms. Heathcote added, "A lot of people who have come in aren't part of this latest wave but want a more middle-class lifestyle, so aren't going to fight the gentrification in the same way."
Still, locals say the economic gap between new and old residents has never been greater.
Last week, Maizie Torres, 33, reflected on the sweep of transformation along the avenue. Ms. Torres has lived in the neighborhood all her life, and now works for the tenant advocacy group Good Old Lower East Side, or Goles. When she was a teenager, her parents would not let her leave the apartment by herself, she said, because the neighborhood was too dangerous and drug-infested. Now, as a single mother of four, Ms. Torres is relieved that she can let her children go to the store alone.
Though she cannot afford the new cafes, she welcomes her new neighbors. The co-op owners she has met, she said, have adopted the local ethos of community self-improvement.
But Ms. Torres is at best ambivalent about the broader changes in the neighborhood. Her apartment, on East Tenth Street between Avenue B and Avenue C, has for the last 20 years been subsidized under a federal Housing and Urban Development Department program that allows low-income tenants to keep their rents at 30 percent of their incomes; HUD picks up the rest. Ms. Torres currently pays $203 a month.
DURING lean times, when the neighborhood was racked by drugs and neglect, such subsidies were profitable for landlords. But as rents around Avenue C began climbing, they lost their luster.
This year, along with 150 of her neighbors, Ms. Torres received a chilling notice: at the end of October, her landlord, the Center Development Corporation, has the option to drop out of the HUD program. This change would allow it to bring rents up to market rate -- or way beyond the reach of most tenants.
William Hubbard, a general partner at the corporation, says it will probably stay with the HUD program, negotiating higher, so-called mark-up-to-market subsidies from the government. But this possibility offers small comfort to Ms. Torres.
"I don't mind the new people in the neighborhood," she said. "I just have a problem that our landlord made money off this contract for 20 years, and now he thinks it's time for us to get out. Now that the community's cleaned up, we should be able to live in a neighborhood that's cleaned up."
Even where subsidies are not an issue, some landlords are eager to evict low-income tenants in order to raise the rent, said Margaret Hughes, the executive director of Goles. Five to ten families come to the organization daily, "at the precipice" of losing their apartments, she said. The organization can no longer help out families who want to move into low-income housing; it can barely see all the people who are about to lose their apartments.
"There's a lot of animosity toward the new people coming in," Ms. Torres said. "I try to explain that it's not the new people. You can't blame them because they can afford it. We direct animosity more toward the landlords and politicians and the developers."
The changes on the avenue become most striking after dark. A few years back, come evening, the strip was deserted save for the drug traffic and the Latino social clubs. Now, the same sidewalks bustle with well-dressed young people promenading among a handful of new bars and restaurants: C-Note, 9C, Baraza, Esperanto, Alphabet Lounge. Though not the Saturnalian theme park that Avenue B or Ludlow Street have become, the strip of the avenue between Seventh Street and Eleventh Street is evolving into a night life destination.
"I like the ambience over here," said Monica Bhambhani, a New York University graduate student, who was finishing a Pan-Latin dinner at Esperanto. Ms. Bhambhani, who lives near Union Square, found the restaurant through Citysearch.com and thought it might make a good spot for her coming birthday party. "The people here are more eclectic" than uptown, she said. On a Saturday night out with a woman friend, Ms. Bhambhani said, she felt safer on Avenue C than in Midtown.
Dimitri Vlahakis, 34, and Stephan Gerville-Reache, 33, the owners of Esperanto and Baraza, are among the avenue's agents of change. Mr. Vlahakis grew up and still lives in Bensonhurst; Mr. Gerville-Reache grew up in the banlieues of Paris,the blocks of housing projects, built for immigrant laborers, that ring the city.
They were drawn to Avenue C three years ago by the cheap rents and limited competition, but also by the character of the neighborhood: the gardens reclaimed from sites of devastation, the mix of artists, working Latino families and squatters. "It's a real neighborhood, with families and old people," Mr. Gerville-Reache said. "Not like a fake neighborhood like SoHo, where everyone is between 20 and 40."
When they first opened Baraza, they found a sign at a flea market that read, "No Cocaine Peddling." It seemed perfect for the bar. The location, as they understood it, had once been a base for coke dealers. In their first weeks, squatters scrawled anti-yuppie graffiti on the bar's gate. But soon after, the two men noticed the same people coming in to drink, listening as Mr. Gerville-Reache spun salsa music on the turntables. The squatters "were testing us," he said.
The current night life pickings on the strip are just a small sample of what's to come. By fall, at least five bars or restaurants are planning to open, including a spinoff of the popular First Avenue bar D.B.A., which specializes in single-malt whiskeys, and a combination cafe and furniture design studio, which will showcase high-end pieces beyond the means even of the new local swells.
On a recent afternoon, Sylvester Schneider set to work on a mission that seems idiosyncratic even for this neighborhood: Zum Schneider, a traditional Bavarian beer garden, complete with plaster trees. If this is gentrification, it is from within as much as from without. Most of the new entrepreneurs, like Mr. Schneider, live in the area, and struggle under budgets as taut as those of the neighboring households. Ray Deter, a co-owner of D.B.A., lives with his wife and two kids in a one-bedroom apartment off Avenue B and sends the children to the local public school. He said he cannot afford a bigger apartment in the neighborhood. "I'm stupid," Mr. Deter said. "I should have taken a place on Avenue C a couple years ago," before the rents took helium.
The gentrification, though, may be reaching its natural limits. Janet Abu-Lughod, a professor emerita at the New School for Social Research and the author of "From Urban Village to East Village: The Battle for New York's Lower East Side" (Blackwell), has studied the slum properties of the area and feels that the conditions for gentrification -- undervalued properties in a desirable location -- have been overtaken by all the new arrivals. The bargains are now in Harlem, she said.
Even the current veneer of snazz runs shallow, a thing of Sheetrock rather than bedrock, warned Councilwoman Margarita Lopez, a longtime housing advocate in the neighborhood. Business on Avenue C has a rocky track record. Ms. Lopez ticked off the names of several establishments that came and went in the last year. "Turnover continues to create an environment of instability and speculation," she said. "Developers and speculators are getting rich, that's it. It's not the residents, not the small business community."
As for the Dos Blockos squatters, after several losing court battles, they awoke on the morning of April 27, 1999, to a police helicopter and officers in riot helmets coming to remove them from their homes. The encounter was noisy but nonviolent. Dan and several other squatters ultimately ended up in Bushwick, Brooklyn, renovating a loft in another poor, long-neglected neighborhood.
More recently, he decided to leave Bushwick for Harlem, where another wave of pioneers, black and white, are riding another neighborhood through transition.
For Dan, Harlem offers a fresh renewal, but also the start of a familiar cycle -- like Avenue C before it. "I have some contradictions," he said. "I see that my person, my culture, my lifestyle facilitates gentrification. It's like I'm a tool of the system. I don't know what to do. I just live my life the way I live it."
Under his nest of sandy brown dreadlocks, Dan now tends bar at Baraza and Esperanto, where the new gentry of the neighborhood come to make merry. He has become a student of the neighborhood's change. The new apartments at 713 East Ninth, he pointed out, are smaller than those of the squat.
On Avenue C, the cultural mix continues its rock and its roll, listing toward an equilibrium it never quite finds. Mr. Edio and his roommates represent one element, trying to make a home amid the swirl.
The other night, one of the roommates watched someone stealing a bicycle on the street below, but this hardly shook Mr. Edio's regard for his new home. He is planning a trip to Ikea, soon.

HEADLINE: Once-Towering Figure Is Focus of Irish Inquiry

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, July 26

 BODY:
Each weekday morning, he is chauffeured in a pale blue Mercedes to the doors of Dublin Castle. It would seem a fitting mode of travel for a former prime minister of Ireland, a man of regal bearing whose very face, with those hooded eyelids and that dramatic sweep of silvery hair, is as identifiable in this country as the castle itself.
But Charles J. Haughey comes to discuss the state of his financial affairs rather than affairs of state -- from the witness stand, at a tribunal that is exploring the relationship between this once-dominant political figure and various businessmen who, over the years, handed him and his subordinates hundreds of thousands of dollars in checks and cash. 
 The tribunal has estimated that Mr. Haughey (pronounced HAW-hee) received as much as $10 million in contributions to cover his huge debts and expensive tastes, and it is poring over his personal banking records to determine whether he used his public office to benefit his benefactors. Mr. Haughey and his lawyers have not yet addressed the central thrust of the inquiry, but they are expected to maintain that he did nothing untoward for the money, which they will argue totaled no more than $7.5 million.
The seamiest allegations center on a fund that Mr. Haughey established in 1989 to send his political ally and close friend, Brian Lenihan, who has since died, to the United States for a liver transplant. About $100,000 from the fund covered the transplant and related costs, but the whereabouts of at least another $125,000 is unclear -- although there is evidence that some was spent on Mr. Haughey's personal expenses.
The tribunal will ultimately present a report to Parliament that probably will join other efforts to tighten relatively new public ethics laws. Michael Moran, a government spokesman, said that revelations regarding Mr. Haughey and other politicians have already contributed to legislation seeking further reform.
In the meantime, the daily proceedings of the tribunal which began a summer recess on July 28 and will reconvene in September feed a growing list of allegations of public corruption. There are 9 sitting tribunals and 11 other inquiries, investigating everything from the contamination of blood products to decades-old allegations of child abuse in public institutions.
But the most prominent investigation centers on offshore bank accounts, cozy public-private relationships and blurred lines between political donations and personal gifts -- all of which lead inexorably back to this 74-year-old man twirling his gold-rimmed glasses as he ponders embarrassing questions posed in public.
"He is a Nixon figure in Irish public life," said Dermot Keogh, an author and professor of Irish history at National University of Ireland in Cork. "He is a flawed talent."
An accountant from Dublin and the son-in-law of former Prime Minister Sean Lemass, Mr. Haughey rose quickly within the dominant political party, Fianna Fail (FEE-na FALL) to serve in various ministerial capacities in the 1960's. He is credited with several progressive measures, from ensuring that widows and children were included in estate matters to providing free electricity and public transportation to the elderly.
He spent several years in political isolation -- charged with, and then acquitted of, conspiring to import guns to be used in Northern Ireland. But in 1979 he returned, gaining control of Fianna Fail and emerging as prime minister, a position he held, on and off, for nine years. He was both blamed and praised for economic ebbs and flows and is generally credited with jump-starting the Northern Ireland peace efforts.
He seemed larger than life, with a stiletto-sharp intellect, a ruthless political instinct and an imperious nature. While visiting Galway one day in the early 1980's, he tried to scrape a campaign sticker from his shoe. When he failed, one of his ranking cabinet ministers bent down low to remove the annoyance.
"He has this Napoleonic thing; he fancies himself as quite a bit of an emperor," said Ryle Dwyer, a historian who has written several books about Mr. Haughey. "But I would argue that he had this real charisma in the true sense of the word, used for politicians who seem capable of superhuman feats. In Haughey's case, he kept escaping."
Throughout, the matter of his wealth vexed and amused the nation. Mr. Haughey earned a modest salary as a member of the Parliament, yet lived on a Dublin estate, owned a small island off the southern coast, and relaxed on a yacht called the "Celtic Mist."
By 1992, various controversies had become too much for even Mr. Haughey's allies to countenance, and he was forced to step down as prime minister. With characteristic flourish, he said farewell to public life with a quote from "Othello": "I have done the state some service, they know't; no more of that."
But just as Mr. Haughey was settling into his role as elder statesman, the Dunne family, owners of the country's largest department-store chain, became concerned with the spending habits of the company's chief executive, Ben Dunne. Inquiries led to the discovery that over the years Mr. Dunne had given Mr. Haughey a sum now estimated at $2.5 million.
At first Mr. Haughey told an investigating tribunal in 1997 that he knew nothing of the matter and that a close adviser had handled his financial affairs to free him "to devote my time and ability to public life." But the accumulated evidence forced Mr. Haughey to concede that he had misled the tribunal.
Mr. Dunne's testimony of an incident in 1991 was particularly damaging. He said he visited the prime minister and found him looking depressed. To cheer the leader up, he said, he handed him checks totaling $260,000. His recollection of Mr. Haughey's response has since entered national lore: "Thank you, big fella."
Although the tribunal found no evidence that Mr. Haughey had assisted Mr. Dunne in exchange for the gifts, it expressed great doubt about the former leader's testimony. "It is quite unacceptable," the tribunal said in its final report, for an elected official -- particularly a prime minister -- to be "supported in his personal lifestyle by gifts made to him personally."
A criminal charge of obstruction was lodged against Mr. Haughey, and he was forced to pay more than $1 million in back taxes and penalties.
Now another panel is digging deeper into his murky finances to determine whether the showers of money influenced the performance of his public duties.
And so, for the last 18 months, some of Ireland's best-known public figures -- from multimillionaire businessmen to Bertie Ahern, a former Haughey lieutenant and current prime minister -- have made their way up the cobblestone path to Dublin Castle to share their tantalizing pieces of the puzzle.
Even the Haughey faithful have found the revelations unsettling. Testimony has shown that when he was elected prime minister in late 1979, Mr. Haughey and his aides spread the word that he needed money, fast: he owed more than $1.3 million to Allied Irish Bank. Within weeks, he was able to give more than $930,000 to the bank, which charged off most of what was still owed.
A property developer, in typical testimony, testified that he contributed $475,000 to the cause after being summoned by the prime minister to his estate. Another developer testified that in 1989 he handed Mr. Haughey four checks for about $31,000 each -- one for the Lenihan transplant fund and the three others for Fianna Fail. But according to the tribunal, the party received only a portion of the money, and none of it was deposited in the transplant fund.
In fact, testimony has shown that contributions to the Lenihan fund went into a so-called leader's account that Mr. Haughey used for such personal needs as tailor-made shirts from Paris and dinners at an exclusive French restaurant in Dublin. Evidence that Mr. Lenihan's medical costs were fully covered has not created a groundswell of support for Mr. Haughey, no more than have reports that he has prostate cancer.
Professor Keogh, who has written several books on modern Ireland, said the revelations of the tribunal demonstrate the extent to which Mr. Haughey and his allies corrupted the values of a government founded a generation earlier by people who believed in a "communitarian democracy." The country needed to be modernized, he said, "but he did it in a way that weakened and undermined the state of governance, and the citizens' confidence in the government."
Professor Dwyer said, though, that Mr. Haughey is not the first leader to believe that he should focus on public affairs while others tend to his finances. Mr. Dwyer also said that, given the many other cases of political scandal, Mr. Haughey's indiscretions are more symptomatic than causal -- and that Irish politicians have long had the power to enact reform.
"If he has done wrong he should be nailed and, I rightly feel, jailed," Mr. Dwyer said. "I just don't like the hypocrisy."
As others contemplate his legacy, Mr. Haughey comes daily to Dublin Castle and tries when possible to contain the harm already done. At times he has claimed to be overwhelmed by all the paperwork. At other times he demonstrates the acumen for which he was once famous, quibbling with the nuances of certain words -- even the nuances of punctuation -- that appear in old bank memoranda portraying him as an unrepentant debtor who was not above mentioning his station in national politics.
Then, when two hours have elapsed -- a time limit established in deference to his age and illness -- Mr. Haughey is excused. A few minutes later, the blue Mercedes carrying a small man in the passenger seat pulls away from Dublin Castle, whose refurbishment he oversaw when once in power.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Fell in June; Other Economic Signs Mixed

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell in June to the lowest level in two and a half years as a rise in borrowing costs engineered by the Federal Reserve made it more expensive for people to buy, government figures showed today.
Single-family home sales -- which declined in all regions except the western United States -- fell 3.7 percent in June, to an annual rate of 829,000 units, after falling to 861,000 units in May, the Commerce Department said. 
 In a separate report, the Conference Board said its index of leading economic indicators -- a gauge of economic performance over the next six to nine months -- was unchanged in June, the third consecutive month without an increase. The index fell 0.1 percent in May and was unchanged in April.
In the housing sector, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in June was 8.23 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which buys mortgages. While down from the recent peak of 8.64 percent in mid-May, rates are still above the average 7.55 percent of June 1999. One-year adjustable rates breached 7 percent in June and reached 7.32 percent in mid-July, the highest since 1991.
The June pace of new-home sales was the slowest since an annual rate of 793,000 units in December 1997, the data showed.
Slow sales pushed the median price of a new home down 1.4 percent, to $159,000 in June, from $161,200 in May. The June price was the lowest since $154,900 last August. The supply of new homes for sale rose to 4.9 months, the highest since December 1996, when it was 5 months.
Even with three months of declines, new-home sales are on track to finish the year at 885,000 units, close to the 886,000 sold in 1998, the second-best year on record. The highest was last year's 907,000.
Consumer confidence in July was close to the record reached in May and January. The unemployment rate in June was 4 percent, close to a 30-year low, and a Commerce Department report on Tuesday showed June incomes grew 0.4 percent.
Fed policy makers have raised the overnight bank lending rate six times since June 1999 in an effort to slow the economy and keep inflation from rising. They will next meet on Aug. 22 and with housing and manufacturing showing signs of slowing, policy makers could opt to leave rates alone.

HEADLINE: Jorge Flores, 88; Influenced a Coup in Brazil

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Jorge Oscar de Mello Flores, a businessman who worked behind the scenes to influence important political events in Brazil, died on Monday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 88.
Mr. Flores was known for getting business interests to support the military coup that deposed President Joao Goulart in 1964. He later formed close ties with Humberto Castelo Branco, the army general who took control of Brazil's central government. 
 Through a lobby called the Brazilian Institute of Democratic Action, which he formed, Mr. Flores continued after the coup to organize the support of private companies and wealthy individuals for authoritarian rule. The institute is believed to have collected millions of dollars against Communism.
"He was unapologetic in his belief that Communism was a threat to the economic well-being of Brazil," said Maria Celina D'Araujo, a political scientist at the Fundacao Getulio Vargas, an economics institute in Rio de Janeiro. "He took a certain pride in being one of the coup's top conspirators."
Mr. Flores stayed close to General Castelo Branco but fell out with his successor, Gen. Artur da Costa e Silva, in the middle to late 60's. But though Mr. Flores's political influence waned, his economic power did not.
In 1969 he became president of Chase Manhattan's banking operations in Brazil, a position he held until 1992, six years after civilian rule was re-established. He then became president of the Fundacao Getulio Vargas.
Wielding political influence came naturally to Mr. Flores. He was born into an upper-class family in Rio, then Brazil's capital, in 1912. Part of his family descended from Portuguese nobility who arrived in Brazil in 1808.
As a civil servant in Rio in the 1930's, Mr. Flores wove a formidable network of connections, which he later used as a director of the Sul America insurance group. He eventually invested in industrial manufacturing and financial services businesses.
In 1959 he founded Consultec, an economic consulting company, together with Roberto Campos, a leading diplomat and right-wing politician. Mario Henrique Simonsen, perhaps Brazil's most influential economist, became a partner of Consultec at Mr. Flores's urging.
In some ways Mr. Flores was a precursor to the bankers and economists who today shuttle between high-level jobs in Brazil's private and public sectors, said Guilherme Fiuza, an editor of No., an online political and cultural newspaper in Rio.
He was one of the eminences grises who are central to deciphering the workings of Brazilian politics.
For example in the 1970's Mr. Flores, having strengthened his ties with the military government, smoothed Mr. Simonsen's path to the Finance Ministry. He described a 1974 discussion with Gen. Golbery do Couto e Silva, chief political strategist to President Ernesto Geisel: "We discussed the matter and we both decided it would be a great solution for the country," Mr. Flores said of Mr. Simonsen's appointment.
Mr. Flores is survived by his wife, Wanda Dias Flores, a daughter and a grandson.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Gives 30-Year Bond a Reprieve, and Price Falls

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The 30-year bond received a reprieve yesterday, and its fate is now probably in the hands of the next administration.
In its announcement of the details of its quarterly auction of Treasury notes and bonds, the government did not put the 30-year bond, the onetime benchmark for Treasury interest rates, on the endangered species list, a development that surprised some investors. 
 But some longtime bond market analysts, who have been reluctant to believe that a president and Congress could keep government surpluses running long enough to pay down most of the government's $3 trillion of publicly held debt, now think that the demise of the 30-year bond is nigh.
It is now possible, said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, to say that the public debt will shrink so much in the next few years that the only bonds that might be left will be those hoarded by investors unwilling to sell them back to the Treasury.
The reason for this is the sheer size of the government surplus, which is now forecast to be $211 billion in the 2000 fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, and $228 billion in the 2001 fiscal year.
About a month ago, President Clinton announced that the projected surplus for the 2001 through 2010 fiscal years would be slightly less than $4.2 trillion. Of that, $2.3 trillion is expected to come from the Social Security system and the rest, almost $1.9 trillion, from general tax receipts. Both Democrats and Republicans consider the Social Security surplus off limits for tax cuts or spending programs. So that leaves $1.9 trillion to finance the tax cuts and spending increases that the two parties will fight over.
What makes the demise of the 30-year bonds more plausible is that it is not practical to sell them when the publicly held debt could be eliminated in just more than a decade.
So the pressure on the 30-year bond has been growing since last August, when the Treasury first announced it was considering buying back some of its longer-term debt and would reduce the amount of 30-year bonds it issued.
The actual buybacks began early this year, and so far the Treasury has repurchased $17.5 billion of bonds with remaining maturities of 15 to 25 years. By the end of this year, the total should approach $30 billion, with two buybacks of $1 billion to $3 billion each month.
And some investors apparently thought that the Clinton Treasury, in an effort to highlight its success in wiping out government deficits and starting to pay off the public debt, would have announced the next step for the 30-year bond yesterday. When they were disappointed, the price of the 30-year bond dropped a full point as its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 5.79 percent, from 5.72 percent on Tuesday. The bond rallied late in the day and finished down 18/32, to 106 30/32, with the yield at 5.76 percent. The 10-year note rose 2/32, to 103 26/32; its yield fell to 5.97 percent from 5.98 percent on Tuesday.
The announcement these investors were waiting for was that the Treasury would actively consider no longer issuing 30-year bonds, similar to the announcement it made in May about one-year bills.
Gary Gensler, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, said there was no need for any significant change either in the Treasury's reduced pace of issuing new Treasury bills, notes and bonds, or in its plan for buying back existing debt. He said the reason was the large amount of government debt that the Treasury had paid off so far -- $360 billion over three years -- and the fact that the amount of maturing Treasury debt was still high next year, $464 billion, and the year after, $382 billion.
One small change announced was that the Treasury would now include callable Treasury securities in its buyback program. A callable security can be repurchased on demand by the Treasury at a certain date before its maturity. The Treasury also said it would buy back securities with remaining maturities of 10 years or more.
With the 30-year bond down to new issuance of just $15 billion a year -- $5 billion of that next week -- a decision on its fate cannot be far.
Mr. Gensler, however, said yesterday that it was Treasury policy "to give the market ample notice should we decide to eliminate or curtail a particular issue."
We will continue to follow that practice," he said.
So it is likely that the next administration will decide the fate of the 30-year bond. The current one has one more chance, at the next quarterly news conference announcing Treasury intentions, on Nov. 1, the Wednesday before Election Day.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Standard Chartered, Short of Forecasts, Will Cut Staff by 20%

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Standard Chartered P.L.C., a London-based bank with most of its operations in Asia, announced a severe global cutback today that will eliminate 5,000 positions, or about 20 percent of the staff, to help lower costs.
Such cuts, which tend to increase a company's stock price, have been made by other big banks worldwide. But Standard Chartered's cutback was coupled with an announcement that its earnings in the first half of the year had been lower than expected, and the bank's shares fell here today by more than 10 percent, losing 98 pence to close at 8.52, or $12.71. 
 Standard Chartered said the cost-cutting, to include a streamlining of its data-processing centers, would itself cost $715 million in severance and other expenses. It is projected to produce savings around $105 million next year and $255 million annually from 2003 onward.
The bank said 6,000 jobs would be eliminated and 1,000 others created. Of the special expenses, about $150 million will be used to integrate Grindlays Bank, which Standard Chartered bought for $1.3 billion in April as part of a planned Asian expansion. The company said the purchase made it the leading international bank in southern Asia.
Though it does relatively little business in Britain, Standard Chartered has operations in Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, India and other parts of Asia, where recovery from the financial crisis of 1997-98 has benefited banks there, such as the rival HSBC, by making it easier for individuals and companies to repay loans.
But while HSBC reported a better-than-expected increase of 31 percent in its first-half profit this week, Standard Chartered's profit increase seemed less robust. Investors compare the two banks because of their similar emphasis on emerging markets -- shielding them somewhat from the rough-and-tumble competition of retail banking in Britain.
Standard Chartered said the Asian recovery had allowed it to set aside less money for potential bad debts -- equivalent to $246 million compared with $360 million in the period last year. This saving increased first- half profit 25 percent above the level of a year earlier, to the equivalent of $346 million. Analysts, though, had forecast a 31 percent increase.
Rana Talwar, the bank's chief executive, maintained that the job cuts had been under consideration for 18 months and would affect personnel throughout the bank's operations. The reductions matched job cuts by banks in the United States, Britain and Germany, reflecting competitive pressure that make traditional banking operations less profitable.
In the United States, the Bank of America has said that it will reduce its work force by 9,000 to 10,000, and Dresdner Bank of Germany is eliminating 5,000 jobs, or about 10 percent of its work force. Barclays Bank recently stirred protests from British customers and politicians with plans to close scores of small branches.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: By Jeanne Moore

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
CROATIA: MISSION TO WASHINGTON
The new, democratic leaders of Croatia have been granted the official visit to Washington that the late president, Franjo Tudjman, was never allowed. President Stipe Mesic and Prime Minister Ivica Racan, opposition leaders elected this year, arrive on Monday for meetings with President Clinton and other administration officials. They have moved Croatia away from Mr. Tudjman's strident nationalism and closer to Western aims in the Balkans, but face huge fiscal problems and unemployment. Steven Erlanger (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: GOOD NEWS FOR PETS
Fifteen rabies-free islands -- including Australia, Japan and Hawaii -- will be added to the "pet passport" program that allows cats and dogs to enter Britain without being quarantined for six months. The program got under way in February, beginning with 22 rabies-free European countries. Each passport certifies the pet has a microchip implant verifying its identity and that it has been vaccinated and tested. Other regions will be considered for inclusion in the program in the near future, including the continental United States. (AP) 

POLAND: WALESA UNDER SCRUTINY
Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity movement that toppled Polish Communism, was in court for the second time in a week fighting allegations by a political opponent that he lied about past ties with the secret police. Mr. Walesa is among a dozen contenders in presidential elections who, under a new law, must file statements disclosing whether they collaborated with the Communist-era police. Anyone caught lying can be barred from running. Mr. Walesa has repeatedly denied the allegations. (AP)
 
FRANCE: CONCORDE INQUIRY
Transport Minister Claude Gayssot called a meeting for today to update all parties involved in examining last week's Concorde crash on progress of the investigation and to look at new safety measures that might enable Air France Concorde flights to resume. French Concordes have been grounded since the July 25 crash, which killed 113 people, but British flights have continued. (Agence France-Presse)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
VENEZUELA: PROTESTS EASE
Disturbances over disputed regional election results died down despite continued vote-rigging allegations by candidates opposed to President Hugo Chavez. Mr. Chavez, who won re-election in Sunday's vote, sent troops to quell protests after his alliance won governorship races in most of the country's states. But there was no sign of a repetition of the violent clashes between pro- and anti-Chavez groups that left one person dead and nine injured on Tuesday. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: REBEL CLASHES
Two Iranian soldiers were killed in clashes with the outlawed opposition People's Mujahedeen, which also left several rebels dead and wounded, the official IRNA news agency said. It said the Iraq-based rebels mounted a mortar attack along the region of Dehloran bordering Iraq and tried to send fighters into Iranian territory. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
CHINA: U.S. PORT CALL
A United States Navy cruiser arrived in Qingdao for the first port call by an American warship in China since NATO bombed the Chinese Embassy in Yugoslavia last year. The visit by the cruiser Chancellorsville is part of a gradual revival of military ties, which has included a visit to Beijing last month by William S. Cohen, the U.S. defense secretary. (AP)
 
HONG KONG: MIGRANT PROTEST
Angry migrants from mainland China set a fire inside Hong Kong's immigration headquarters after being refused papers that would have allowed them to remain in the former British colony. Forty-six people were injured in the blaze, which erupted after the migrants doused the 13th floor with a flammable liquid. The right of mainland Chinese to live in Hong Kong has been a volatile issue since Beijing overturned a local court ruling that granted residency to some migrants. Mark Landler (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
NIGERIA: HOSTAGE DEAL
Royal Dutch/Shell officials said that armed youths agreed to free the 165 hostages they had been holding on two oil rigs since Monday. The oil company said it would meet with representatives of the youths on Aug. 15 to discuss their demands, which included jobs. (Reuters)
 
NIGERIA: ISLAMIC LAW WIDENS
A sixth northern state, Jigawa, has decided to introduce strict Islamic law later this year. The move to extend Shariah has divided the mostly Muslim north from the strongly Christian areas in central Nigeria, and created political problems for President Olusegun Obasanjo, a Christian. (Agence France-Presse)
 
BURUNDI: CAMPS SHUT
Authorities have finished dismantling 30 "regroupment camps" into which 350,000 civilians were moved last year, according to the governor of Bujumbura Rural Province. Older camps in other parts of the country housing more than half a million people displaced by Burundi's seven-year-old civil war were not included in the operation. The government justified the camps by saying they would allow the military to better deal with the rebels, but international aid agencies said their aim was to cut off villagers from the rebels. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ERITREA, SUDAN: UNEASY BORDER
Eritrea's defense minister moved to calm tensions with Sudan during a visit to Khartoum, dismissing claims that Eritrean troops were massing at their common border. Relations between the countries have been tense in recent months after accusations by officials in eastern Sudan that Eritrea was sending troops to the border in preparation for an attack. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Doctor Says He Can Cure His Party's Ills

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
THE doctor will see you now. So will the only undisputed homegrown Democratic candidate for United States senator from New York.
Gosh, they're the same chipmunk-cheeked guy, and neither one oozes schmooze. They're operating out of the same Park Avenue war room, a minimal space with an ominous screen for viewing X-rays, a manila folder for keeping track of campaign promises and, in the tradition of doctors' offices everywhere, the sound of toilets being flushed as you cower in the visitor's chair awaiting news about that orthopedic surgery. 
 But no need now for Dr. Mark S. McMahon, 38, to drum up his bedside manner -- possibly a good thing, as rumor has it that this is not a strong suit with him, except when he's home tending to his three children. Two of whom -- honest! -- attend P.S. 6, one of the city's A-list public schools.
Our topic is the doctor's obsession: politics, apparently a moth-to-flame thing with him ever since he was elected homeroom president back in elementary school. And even if Hillary Rodham Clinton, wearing the party's halo, treats Dr. McMahon like a nebbish -- ignoring his debate invitations and pretending he's polling-place toast -- he's got news for her.
He's officially on the ballot and sticking around until the Sept. 12 primary; maybe longer. Sure, he thinks it's fishy that there are suddenly four other insurgents on the ballot, none of whom scraped up the required 15,000 signatures, all of whom could undermine his effort to monopolize the anti-Hillary vote.
But his mother, Eva, a retired nurse, and his father, Tom, a semi-retired dentist, didn't scavenge the malls and Home Depots of Long Island helping him collect those 44,107 signatures for nothing. So regardless of the decision on his court challenge to the validity of the other party-crashers, he's forging ahead with his no-frills, no-television-commercials, $200,000 (more or less) campaign to heal what ails the Senate by sending it a physician, not another lawyer.
He doesn't drink, smoke, curse, golf, or philander. (Does this fellow really meet the qualifications to be a Senator from New York?) He's never been arrested, and the closest he's come to the fast track is skipping the 8th and 11th grades at Fordham Prep in the Bronx.
"Maybe that's my problem a little," he says about being on the cusp of nerddom. "I may be just sort of, ah, insipid in that sense. I don't know. I just felt I owed it to my parents to lead sort of an exemplary life."
Meet candidate McMahon, the Harvard-educated doctor, vanity-published medical-thriller author and self-confessed goody-two-shoes who insists that not only is candidate Clinton not the people's choice ("I'm shocked at the level of anti-Hillary sentiment that exists") but that she's absolutely the wrong candidate to combat Rick Lazio ("My biggest gripe with Hillary is that because of her, this seat may end up in Republican hands. Giuliani is replaced by an understudy candidate of limited distinction, and now he's seven points ahead of the other candidate, the most famous woman on the planet, quote, unquote," he sputters.)
HIS handshake is a limp one, but don't hold that against him. Maybe he's saving strength to wield his scalpel -- he's already done six operations today and, like a savvy politician who blueprints names and faces, he demonstrates total, if a tad disinterested, recall. One carpal tunnel release, two tumor removals (benign), three knees scoped. The usual stuff. Frankly, after seven years in private practice, he'd rather be in the Senate making policy than renovating bone matter. He would, he says, be a leader in health care reform, but not a one-issue automaton, not with that 1985 degree from the London School of Economics.
The McMahon mission in a nutshell: expanded Medicare and services for the elderly; increased research on AIDS and cancer; gun control; capital punishment; rent control; higher minimum wage and teachers' salaries; the sovereignty of Israel's borders. He opposes prayer in public schools, school vouchers, late-term abortion, gay marriage, eliminating affirmative action.
He did not take a cram course on the issues: this is stuff he thinks about all the time.
So far his patients haven't rebelled at his alternate career: "But I could imagine somebody saying 'I want to go to someone who all he thinks about is scoping knees, not this guy who's running for Senate, too.' "
Dr. McMahon refuses to attack Mrs. Clinton's political platform (he's waiting for the debate that he says she owes the state's 4.9 million Democrats) and slyly says they even have something in common: "Neither one of us has held office." But he makes short work of Mr. Lazio: "He's the un-Hillary. What does he stand for? What's his rationale? For example, about Israel, where's he been on that? My sense of him is that there's no there there."
Enough air time for Rick Lazio. Let's talk about Mark McMahon. What do you do for fun? "Spend time with the kids," he says. "I can't understand parents who all they want to do is get away from their kids." His are 6, 5 and almost 1 and unaware that daddy is running for Senate. He is, he adds, opposed to "using them as campaign props." And his wife, Lynne, a radiologist at Bellevue Hospital Center, is "apolitical," so he expects no stumping from that quadrant, either.
"She'll probably vote for Hillary," he says. It's his first, and last, joke of the day.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Next Speech

 BODY:
When Gov. George W. Bush addresses the Republican Convention tonight, in the most important speech of his career, he will face an oddly difficult challenge of his own making. For four days Philadelphia has echoed with uplifting talk about diversity, inclusion, family values and "compassion." Last night the vice-presidential nominee, Richard B. Cheney, added a strong dose of partisan combativeness by turning Vice President Al Gore's 1992 attack line -- "It's time for them to go" -- back on the Democrats. But what is still missing is any discussion of the specific policies and programs that Mr. Bush intends to present to the country. Even Republican policies that the delegates hold dear -- tax cuts, distrust of government, privatizing Social Security -- have scarcely received mention from the podium. Mr. Bush's task tonight is to go beyond broad themes and begin to add some substance to this campaign.
To be sure, passionate generalities about leaving no child behind and restoring American military strength are part of an honorable tradition of political oratory, and it is heartening to hear a leading Republican emphasize government that cares. But after four days, one has a right to expect something more nutritious. One of the few speakers to make a clear policy point in Philadelphia this week was Gen. Colin Powell, who supported affirmative action for minorities -- a policy the platform rejects. Republican opposition to abortion, gun control, campaign finance reform and the rights of patients to sue health maintenance organizations are core items on the party's agenda. They have hardly been mentioned from the podium in Philadelphia. 
In shunting aside the party's traditional wedge issues in favor of pleasing banalities, Governor Bush's political strategists are no doubt confident in their political judgment. Even the seasoned movement conservatives who support Mr. Bush are withholding their criticism, apparently certain that hiding their positions in a fog of generalities is the right way to go this year.
But it should give Republicans some pause that the convention's television ratings have slipped sharply, perhaps because viewers have not encountered much in the way of ideas and policies. Mr. Cheney, for his part, did raise the energy level by showing how the Bush-Cheney ticket will use the attack-by-comparison to tie Mr. Gore to President Clinton and attempt to discredit both. Wheeling out what will probably be key words of the fall campaign, Mr. Cheney called Mr. Bush "a man of principle, a man of honor" who will "restore decency and integrity to the Oval Office." He also placed the lightly experienced Texas governor in a G.O.P. leadership pantheon of Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush.
The Cheney performance cut against Mr. Bush's assertions that he does not like attack politics, although he is likely to salt his own speech tonight with language designed to remind voters of the Clinton administration's ethical problems. But it is also time for Mr. Bush to begin leveling with Americans on what he plans to do. He could start by laying out exactly why the economy needs the proposed 10-year, $1.9 trillion tax cut that would start in 2002 and eat up the federal surplus. It may sound odd to say it, but the time has come for Republicans to stand up for what they believe.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Build Plant in Suburb Of Buffalo, Saving 600 Jobs

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
General Motors will build a $500 million high-tech engine manufacturing plant at its complex in the Buffalo suburb of Tonawanda, saving 600 well-paying jobs through the largest private-sector investment in western New York State in many years, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.
Had the company chosen to build the plant in another state or in Canada or Mexico, something state officials said G.M. had been considering, it would have been a major blow to the Buffalo area because the 600 blue-collar jobs would have been phased out from the Tonawanda complex's 3,800 existing jobs. 
 As it is, the Buffalo metropolitan area's unemployment rate was 5 percent in June compared with a 4.3 percent rate statewide. And as the economy has been booming, the Buffalo area has been adding jobs at a much slower rate than the state has over all. In the 12-month period ending in June, the number of jobs in the area increased by 2,300, or 0.4 percent, the lowest job growth rate in any metropolitan area in the state. The job increase rate statewide was 2.1 percent.
"The threat was very strong to move the 600 jobs," Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said in an interview. Among the other options, officials said, were the 10 other engine plants the company has in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
State and General Motors officials said the Tonawanda site was selected for the plant partly because of what Mr. Gargano called the state's incentive package, which included a commitment to spend $9 million to upgrade streets around the site and water and sewage facilities. They also cited an agreement permitting more flexible work rules that G.M. reached with the union.
The Tonawanda complex produces four-, six- and eight-cylinder engines, and Mr. Gargano said that G.M. planned to phase out some of the old production lines there. The plant to be added at the site is intended to produce a six-cylinder, all aluminum, inline engine that will be used in a wide variety of G.M. cars and light trucks.
Construction of the new plant is to begin later this year, and the plant is scheduled to begin operation in early 2003. Mr. Gargano said the construction alone would provide 600 jobs in the building trades.
The Tonawanda supervisor, Ronald H. Moline, said that the G.M. engine complex had been a "vital part of our industrial base for more than 50 years," in which thousands of area residents had been employed at well-paying jobs. "This expansion," he said, "will add stability to our industrial base and to the lives of thousands of families."

HEADLINE: 10th Anniversary of Iraqi Invasion Is Marked Quietly in Kuwait

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, Aug. 2

 BODY:
It took Iraqi tanks just a few hours to invade this small, oil-producing country 10 years ago. Since then, determination by Kuwait and its neighbors never again to be so vulnerable has changed the Persian Gulf's political landscape.
Shortly after a United States-led coalition liberated Kuwait in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the country signed a 10-year defense pact with Washington. Similar agreements followed with Britain, France and Russia as well as a defense agreement with other gulf states. 
 "I feel that Kuwait is one of the safest countries in the world," said Abdul-Mohsen Jamal, a member of Parliament, a decade after the day Kuwaitis call "Black Thursday" -- Aug. 2, 1990.
The day passed quietly with no official functions to mark the anniversary. Kuwait also does not mark the anniversary of its liberation on Feb. 26, 1991, out of respect for the families of the hundreds of people still missing since the days of Iraq's occupation.
Thanks to billions of dollars that Kuwait had stashed away from oil earnings, physical scars of the invasion have been removed. Blazes in oil wells that were set afire by retreating Iraqis were extinguished. Equipment looted from government offices, the university and hospitals has been replaced.
However, Kuwait's 2.3 million people, most of them guest workers, are still shocked that one Arab country would take over another overnight.
"Our wounds have not healed," said the editorial of a special issue of the daily Al-Anba to mark the anniversary.
Kuwait and other members of the Gulf Cooperation Council -- Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Bahrain and Qatar -- established a nucleus of a common army in a mutual defense pact. But it is clear they believe their real defense lies in their relationship with the United States.
Iraq's aggression led neighboring Saudi Arabia to allow in some 500,000 foreign troops, most of them American. The legacy of that decision is still felt politically and economically in the kingdom.
Western pressure helped edge Saudi Arabia's King Fahd to decree some limited political reforms, the $60 billion bill helped drain the Saudi kingdom's reserves, and the presence of foreign troops gave birth to a fundamentalist Islamic opposition.
In Kuwait, Abdullah al-Shayeji, a political scientist, said his government is spending 25 percent of its annual budget on security, in addition to some $12 billion earmarked for defense after Kuwait's liberation.
Muslam al-Barrak, a lawmaker and former union leader, counted additional costs: He expected his country to remain under American pressure to support the Middle East peace effort.
As for Iraq, Kuwaitis say enmity between neighbors cannot go on forever. Some predict a day when the two countries will reconcile and perhaps join economic forces.
Yet, Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, remains in power, and Iraq has not accounted for 605 Kuwaitis and citizens of other countries who disappeared during the occupation.
Baghdad says it has released all war prisoners, and in recent years has accused Kuwait of withholding information on the fate of 1,150 Iraqis who disappeared during the crisis. Kuwait says it cannot be held responsible for them at the time when Iraqi authorities ran the country.

California Short of Power In an Age of Deregulation
Four years after it led the nation into a deregulation of the electric industry, California is at the brink of a breakdown in its power supply. The nation's most populous state nearly ran out of power for the third consecutive day.
What disturbs California utility executives and regulators is that this week's crisis has come even though none of the state's power plants or transmission lines has failed, at a time when temperatures around the state have been hot but hardly extraordinary. The state's power supply simply can no longer keep up with peak demand, they warn. Page A1. 

Proxy Companies Plan to Merge
Georgeson Shareholder Communications, the world's largest proxy solicitation company, will announce today that it has acquired Corporate Investor Communications, the third-largest concern in the industry. C6.
 
Adviser to Celebrities Pleads Guilty
Dana C. Giacchetto, the money manager who promised Hollywood stars and other artists a safe investment haven, pleaded guilty to fraud and acknowledged that he misappropriated some of his clients' money. Mr. Giacchetto, 37, faces 46 to 57 months in prison and a fine of $10,000 to $100,000, as well as restitution payments to fraud victims. C2.
 
Nasdaq Falls in Flight to Blue Chips
The Nasdaq composite index slumped as skittish investors sought safety in blue-chip stocks or headed for the sidelines waiting for tomorrow's report on the job market in July. The Nasdaq composite fell 27.06 points, or 0.7 percent, to 3,658.46. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 80.58 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,687.53. And in a separate report, the Conference Board said its index of leading economic indicators -- a gauge of economic performance over the next six to nine months -- was unchanged in June, the third consecutive month without an increase. C7.
 
AOL Is Sued Over Blocked E-Mail
Harris Interactive, the online market research company, has filed a suit against America Online and other e-mail providers, contending those companies unlawfully blocked e-mail from Harris to its survey participants. C7.
 
 
Maybe the Market Can Be Beaten
In the 1970's, the efficient-markets hypothesis was an article of near-religious faith, arguing that financial markets processed new information about securities so efficiently that you couldn't beat the market. Now a growing number of economists argue that the financial markets do not appear all that efficient after all. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.
