HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA ON EDGE OF FAILING TO MEET ELECTRICITY NEEDS

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Four years after it led the nation into a sweeping deregulation of the electric industry, California is at the brink of a breakdown in its power supply.
Yesterday, as a heat wave caused electric demand to soar across the West, the nation's most populous state nearly ran out of power for the third straight day. To reduce the strain on California's electric grid, regulators ordered utilities to curtail supplies to big commercial users that have agreed to cut their electric consumption in times of shortage. 
 Still, the state was on the verge of imposing rolling blackouts of homes and businesses. That step has been taken only eight times around the country in the last 17 years, usually because of extreme weather or power plant failures, says the North American Electric Reliability Council, which supervises the Canadian and American power grid.
What disturbs California utility executives and regulators is that this week's crisis has come even though none of the state's power plants or transmission lines have failed and temperatures around the state have been high but hardly extraordinary.
In the last decade, demand for power surged along with the California economy. But utilities, fearing they would be unable to recover their costs as the state moved away from regulations that guaranteed them profits, stopped building power plants, leaving the state's power supply simply no longer able to keep up with peak demand.
California's electric industry has reached the "ragged edge" of failure, said Robert D. Glynn Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the PG&E Corporation, whose Pacific Gas & Electric unit delivers electricity to more than 13 million people in Northern California. "There's just barely enough supply to go around."
So far this summer, the California Independent System Operator, a non-profit state-chartered agency that manages the electric grid, has scrounged enough power each day to meet demand. So the lights have stayed on, except for a blackout in San Francisco in June related more to local transmission problems than the statewide shortage.
But with supplies exceptionally tight, the wholesale price of power has soared in the state. That has caused electric bills in San Diego, where the retail price of power now fluctuates directly with the wholesale market, to more than double, stirring consumer anger and calls for the industry to be reregulated.
The supply of electricity is also tight in New York State and New England, which have had spot shortages this year. Nationally, power reserves have steadily decreased since 1992, with the electric industry in the midst of a transition from a network of local monopolies with fixed prices and guaranteed profits to a competitive marketplace with prices set by supply and demand.
But a surge in plant construction -- in response to soaring market prices and projections of growing demand -- seems likely to ensure that supplies and reserves will begin to increase next year in most of the nation.
"The system is tight around the country, but there's been an enormous supply response," said Jeffrey K. Skilling, president of Enron, the Houston company that is the world's leading trader of electricity and natural gas. "In the next year or two, in most parts of the country, there will be surplus capacity."
Mr. Skilling said he believed the market would provide the reliable power supply once assured by regulatory fiat, with higher prices encouraging both construction of plants and conservation by users.
In the early 1990's, with deregulation looming and Southern California stuck in a recession, utilities stopped building new plants; none have been built in the state for more than a decade.
California's economy has surged in the last five years, a boom led by Internet and high-technology companies, which are voracious power users. And growth is even more vigorous in the Pacific Northwest, Arizona and Nevada, making it harder for California to import the power on which it has relied.
The California Energy Commission, a state agency that licenses new power plants and predicts the state's energy demand, says California has a 10 percent reserve margin for this summer's expected peak electric demand, assuming all plants and transmission lines are working perfectly.
But plants and transmission lines often run at less than their theoretical capacity. As a result, the state's reserve power margin has already fallen below 5 percent a half-dozen times on hot days this summer, prompting the Independent System Operator to declare a Stage 2 alert and begin cutting power to big customers like the state's big aerospace companies, that agree in advance in exchange for lower rates. On Tuesday, the tightest day this summer, the reserve margin fell to 3 percent at 3:30 p.m.
The state's reserve has remained above the critical 1.5 percent margin that would trigger a Stage 3 alert, in which the Independent System Operator orders utilities to begin rotating blackouts. How long the blackouts last would depend on how much demand needed to be curtailed, said Ron Low, a spokesman for PG&E.
Mr. Low said the utility would try to keep blackouts to less than two hours. As a general rule, utilities try to avoid cutting power to essential public services like hospitals and police departments, and attempt to give warnings of any blackouts to people with medical needs that could be affected by a loss of electricity.
In the control room of the Independent System Operator, in a heavily secured building in Folsom, about 30 miles northeast of Sacramento, the atmosphere was businesslike yesterday as two dozen operators tapped at their workstations, regulating the flow of power around the state. Above giant computer screens on the walls of the room, a digital readout displayed the total megawatts being consumed on the grid from moment to moment. It hovered above 42,000 megawatts, just below yesterday's peak of 43,500.
But the apparent calm was misleading, said Terry Winter, the agency's president and chief executive. Mr. Winter said the state's supply crisis has caused generators to defer needed maintenance, increasing the chances that a plant would fail -- which could plunge the grid into chaos.
California's supply crisis will not ease anytime soon, says the California Energy Commission, the state agency that licenses new plants. Four new plants are under construction in the state, with two expected to be online by the end of next summer. Several more plants are in development. But with peak electric demand predicted to rise at least 2 percent next year, the energy commission is predicting the situation will worsen before it improves.
"The squeaking gets tighter in 2001," said Daniel Nix, deputy director for energy information. If next summer is even slightly hotter than normal, he added, "there is a good chance we would have inadequate resources."
Already, wholesale power prices have shot up in California this summer. At the California Power Exchange, a nonprofit, state chartered company where utilities and power producers trade most of the state's electricity, prices this summer have regularly spiked above 40 cents per kilowatt-hour, more than 10 times normal.
Most power customers remain insulated from the price roller coaster. With retail rates fixed by regulators, the state's two biggest utilities, PG&E and Southern California Edison, which serves 11 million people in the Los Angeles area, have absorbed the summer price spikes, expecting to make up the difference when the wholesale price drops this fall.
But in just two years, California plans to deregulate retail prices for PG&E and Edison customers. And in San Diego, where retail prices have already been freed to match market rates, a doubling of electric bills this summer has prompted some politicians and consumer groups to call for price caps or reregulation of the industry.
John Bryson, chairman of Edison's parent company, Edison International, said that consumers and small businesses might never be ready for fully deregulated power prices. Electricity is such a vital part of modern life that most customers "are not going to order their lives and shouldn't be asked to order their lives looking at the meters all the time," Mr. Bryson said.
State Senator Steve Peace, an architect of deregulation who is calling for new controls on the industry, said tight price caps were necessary in the short run because generators of electricity had too much leverage to set prices. Producers "shouldn't be able to extort whatever price they can get at any moment," said Mr. Peace, a San Diego Democrat.
On Tuesday, the Independent System Operator, under pressure from Senator Peace and Gov. Gray Davis, voted to cut in half, to $250 per megawatt, the maximum price it can charge utilities for power purchased from the agency's pool.
But some experts warn that fiddling with a partly deregulated market can have unintended consequences. Because the agency's market has price caps, utilities in the state have leaned on it to meet demand, trimming their purchases from the much larger pool run by the Power Exchange, which has no price caps.
As a result, the agency's engineers have had to make a daily scramble for thousands of megawatts -- increasing the chance of a system collapse, said Camden Collins, who quit the agency's board last month to protest the caps.
"Manipulating the wholesale market, in my opinion, threatens the reliability of the entire western region," Ms. Collins wrote in a memorandum that accompanied her resignation.
Yesterday, Governor Davis asked the state's attorney general to investigate whether the wholesale market was being manipulated.
Other experts warn that price caps will discourage power generators from building the plants that California needs.
"We've started down this path of creating markets for this electricity, and if we stop, we'll be in the worst of all possible worlds," said Eric Hirst, a utility consultant in Oak Ridge, Tenn.
Meanwhile, with the threat of blackouts rising along with the temperature, there are shorter term fixes in the works.
In San Francisco, PG&E has asked regulators for permission to place a floating power station in San Francisco Bay with enough generating capacity to power 95,000 homes. Some environmental groups have posed objections to the plan; a decision by regulators is expected by the time the barge arrives in the bay next week.
If the station is rejected, PG&E has a Plan B for preventing power failures, the company's chief executive, Mr. Glynn, said, "Everyone will pray that the weather doesn't become extreme."

HEADLINE: Two Charged in '99 Stabbing Death of Student in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By SHAILA K. DEWAN and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
In a murder case that drew national attention but seemed to be growing colder by the month, the police have charged two men with the fatal stabbing of Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old graduate student, on a Brooklyn street a year and a half ago.
The man who police say did the stabbing, David Jamison, 27, admitted his role in the killing in a videotaped statement and was charged with first-degree murder, a senior law enforcement official said. 
 The other man, Felix Rodriguez, 20, was charged with second-degree murder because he helped Mr. Jamison rob Ms. Watkins and the robbery led to her murder, said Sgt. Elias Nikas, a police spokesman. Both men were also charged with first-degree robbery and weapons possession.
Mr. Jamison has a record of more than half a dozen arrests, mostly for petty crimes and drugs and once for robbery, the police said. He was arrested yesterday about 11 a.m. at his home, 126 Sterling Place in Park Slope, mere blocks from where the stabbing took place.
A third man, Pierre Antoinne, 26, an unemployed house painter, was being questioned by the police, his relatives said yesterday. In his statement, Mr. Jamison said that the two men were present during the robbery and killing, law enforcement officials said.
After the stabbing, on Park Place in Prospect Heights on March 9, 1999, the police were left with a highly publicized crime and few clues. There were no known witnesses, and because the killer had apparently concealed the large carving knife in a white plastic bag during the attack, no fingerprints were left behind.
More than six months after the robbery and killing of Ms. Watkins, who had moved to New York from Kansas to attend the Hunter College Graduate School of Social Work, investigators reported that despite thousands of hours of work, their leads had dwindled to zero. Their only hope was that the killer would turn himself in, commit another crime in front of witnesses or tell someone about the stabbing. A $10,000 reward went unclaimed.
The police said that hundreds of people had been questioned, but that Mr. Jamison's name had never come up. At various times, the police theorized that the crime could have been committed by a homeless man or someone who knew her, according to a senior investigator.
Finally, detectives got a break, an investigator said yesterday: in recent days, Mr. Jamison talked about the case, and word got back to detectives through an informant in another part of the city and a tip to the police Crime Stoppers hot line.
News of Mr. Jamison's arrest came as a surprise to Ms. Watkins's friends and family, many of whom said they had given up hope that the killer would be found.
"I think we'll have feelings of reawakened grief," said Lawrence Watkins, her father, a history teacher at the Dominican Academy on East 68th Street in Manhattan.
Adam Green, Ms. Watkins's boyfriend at the time of her death, said he had moved out of the neighborhood where she was killed. He said he had thought the police would never find a suspect. "A good part of me hoped it would stay that way," he said. "I was not in need of a name and a face, because that wasn't going to change anything for me."
In its brutality and apparent randomness, the killing of Ms. Watkins was the kind of homicide that had become increasingly startling with the declines in reported crime in New York City. That was one reason it drew national attention and tabloid headlines. Ms. Watkins's dedication to helping others, particularly women who were victims of violence, and the shock that the killing sent through the newly gentrified area near Prospect Park made the story even more compelling.
On that cold March night, Ms. Watkins, described by a classmate as "a soldier of social work," was on her way home from the Bronx Community Center where she worked with battered women. As she walked down her quiet street, neighbors heard two screams, and found her less than two blocks from her apartment with a knife in her back, surrounded by fallen groceries. Her purse was later found near Washington Avenue.
The police said their initial suspicion, that the motive was robbery, was borne out yesterday.
Detectives John Barber and Robert Rivera were able to draw the confession out of Mr. Jamison, an investigator said.
According to his statement, investigators said, he and the two other men were sitting in a luncheonette on the southeast corner of Flatbush Avenue and Park Place when they saw Ms. Watkins walk by laden with shopping bags and decided she would be "an easy mark."
Mr. Jamison approached Ms. Watkins from behind while, investigators believe, the two other men were in front of her. After Mr. Jamison stabbed her, the three fled in different directions.
Mr. Jamison apparently claimed to police that the stabbing was unintentional. "He's got some story that she moved backwards onto the knife," a senior investigator said, "which is inconsistent with the wounds."
Three relatives of the men who were waiting in the lobby of the 77th Precinct station house last night said the men had nothing to do with the murder.
Veronica Corea, 25, Mr. Jamison's sister-in-law and Mr. Rodriguez's sister, acknowledged that Mr. Jamison had been in trouble with the law -- he has prior arrests for robbery, petty larceny and drug-dealing -- but she said that he was not violent.
"Everyone makes a lot of mistakes, but he would never take it to that level," she said. "Just because a brother hangs out in the street and smokes a little weed, he's a killer? Come on."
Ms. West, a cashier at the Yankee Stadium box office, said that her brother was not capable of murder.
"He's an idiot and a moron, but he wouldn't be able to do that," she said. "If you knew my brother, he's a real coward. He doesn't have the heart to do that."
The police had said that Mr. Rodriguez, a warehouse worker who lives on Prospect Place not far from the murder site, was talking to investigators last night, but that Mr. Antoinne was not. Mr. Antoinne, a Haitian national, began serving a state prison term for an attempted drug sale in 1995. On Jan. 25, 1996, state records indicate, he was paroled to the United States immigration service. A police investigator said that Mr. Antoinne might have been deported to Haiti under a special program and then might have returned, on his own and illegally, to the United States.
When the stabbing occurred, it drew focus to a rapidly changing neighborhood. Some said that professionals who had recently moved to Prospect Heights had chosen to overlook the rougher areas of the neighborhood at their peril.
But old residents as well as new mourned the loss of Ms. Watkins.
Janet Abdelmegeed, 47, a waitress who has lived for 13 years in the building where Mr. Jamison was arrested, said yesterday that she was shocked to learn that a neighbor was a suspect in the killing. She said she had attended a candlelight vigil for Ms. Watkins. "I remember when that little girl died," she said. "Who couldn't cry over that?"

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS: IN CONTEXT;
Promises of Changes, But Unspoken Details

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2

 BODY:
It is all so murky, the rhetoric here, that you might think yourself back in the presidential campaign of 1952, when Dwight D. Eisenhower promised, "I shall go to Korea," but supplied no details about what he would do to end the war once he got there.
Or maybe 1968 or 1972, in the heyday of Richard M. Nixon, another campaigner often short on specifics. Confident that he was well ahead of Hubert H. Humphrey in 1968, he told the nation he would end the war in Vietnam, but he never bothered to say what he had in mind. Four years later, more confident, he stayed off the stump, running the first Rose Garden campaign. 
 This year, en route to nomination for president, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has hammered the Clinton administration's foreign policy, suggesting that it has been inept, ill-focused and lacking in priorities.
In a speech in Washington on May 23, he said that "the world has changed faster than United States policy" and called for a fresh approach to nuclear weapons and a more comprehensive missile defense system. At other times he has hinted he would spend less energy on humanitarian missions and more on dealing with great powers like China and Russia and on shoring up America's alliances.
But the first three nights of a Republican convention that Mr. Bush had promised would lay new ideas before the American people, including a night designated as an occasion to discuss national security, produced few details of what a Bush administration might do overseas. The speeches have been vague even by the lax standards of convention oratory, an art form that was tailor-made for bloviation.
Most of what has been said dealt with Mr. Bush's personal qualities, not with policy -- grist for People magazine, not Foreign Affairs.
"No specifics, no nuance," said the historian Michael Beschloss. "I think the lack of content may be unprecedented. They argue that Bill Clinton paid less attention to foreign policy than any president since Herbert Hoover, which may be fair. But they have given no example here of how they would lead or where they would go."
It may be that Mr. Bush himself will fill in the gaps when he appears before the convention on Thursday night. But if so, he will change the pattern that has emerged this week.
On Monday, Colin L. Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff during the war in the Persian Gulf, talked almost exclusively about domestic affairs, including the ills afflicting urban areas, the need to pay more attention to the education of the nation's children and the problems of minorities. Only at the end did he look overseas, assuring the delegates that Mr. Bush "will not repeat the mistakes of the past and let our insurance policy, our armed forces, fall into disrepair."
Tuesday's speeches consisted mostly of similar generalizations.
Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commanded American troops in the Middle East during the war, said that American military strength had withered since then. But he gave no prescription for rebuilding it, except to voice a wish for "another commander in chief named George Bush with Dick Cheney on his team." Mr. Cheney, nominated tonight as Mr. Bush's running mate, served as defense secretary during the war.
Senator John McCain of Arizona, whom Mr. Bush defeated for the nomination, said that Mr. Bush "knows well that there is no safe alternative to American leadership, and he will not squander this unique moment in history by allowing America to retreat behind empty threats, false promises and uncertain diplomacy" -- an indirect indictment of Mr. Clinton, presumably, but one unaccompanied by even shadowy proposals for policy initiatives.
Mr. Bush's main foreign policy adviser, Condoleezza Rice, was only slightly more forthcoming. She said that Mr. Bush would not regard the American military as "a global police force" without a clue as to where and under what circumstances troops should be used; she promised that Mr. Bush would move at the earliest possible date to institute "the deployment of effective missile defenses," without saying when that might be, and asserted that Mr. Bush "recognizes the challenge the Chinese government poses to our interests and values," without outlining how that challenge might be met.
Much of what she said sounded like cheerleading, as when she praised Mr. Bush -- "the George W. Bush that I know" -- as a man of "uncommonly good judgment" who is "focused and consistent" and knows "that we Americans are at our best when we exercise power without fanfare and arrogance."
Tonight, Mr. Cheney joined in the chorus, praising Mr. Bush in his advance text as "a man who has the courage and the vision and the goodness to be a great president." Big changes, he said, are coming to Washington, following eight years of "squandered opportunities." He did not name them.
Aside from promising, like almost everyone, to devote more resources to the military, Mr. Cheney concentrated on life at home. He talked about education and Social Security and working with Democrats to end the air "of bitterness and ill will and partisan strife" in Washington, but not about Europe or Asia.
Like Mr. Clinton eight years ago, Mr. Bush began the campaign with an inconvenient dearth of foreign policy experience. Like Mr. Clinton, and unlike Vice President Al Gore, his Democratic rival, he has no service in Vietnam to dwell upon with pride.
Early on, Mr. Bush surrounded himself with an impressive array of national security experts, most of them veterans of past Republican administrations, including Ms. Rice, Paul Wolfowitz, Robert Zoellick and Richard Perle. (The notable exception is James A. Baker, one of his father's secretaries of state, whose performance in his father's unsuccessful 1992 campaign the younger Mr. Bush has often faulted).
In a "coming-out" speech at the Ronald Reagan Library near Los Angeles on Nov. 19, George W. Bush won good marks for what most experts considered a polished performance. His choice of Mr. Cheney lent the ticket further heft on foreign policy.
But there remains a long list of issues on which the delegates, and those across the country following the convention in the news media, have so far heard little. Among them are strategies for dealing with the intractable problems of Russia and China, the issue of expanding NATO farther into Eastern Europe, the manifold complications of expanding free world trade and the doubts that surround the present requirement that the Pentagon be prepared to fight simultaneous wars in two different theaters of war.
There are divisions within the Republican party on issues like Kosovo that have yet to be resolved.
If Mr. Bush leaves too much unspoken for too long, he may hand Mr. Gore a significant opening. Mr. Gore, after all, has had broad experience in foreign policy matters, first on Capitol Hill, then in the White House. And while the Clinton administration has had its flops overseas, in places like Africa and Haiti, it has also recorded significant achievements, particularly in peace efforts in Northern Ireland and the Middle East.
But then, Mr. Bush may have decided that too much talk about foreign policy is bad business. He has talked often to friends and acquaintances about his father's loss to Bill Clinton eight years ago, when the elder Bush focused on foreign affairs and the Arkansas neophyte emphasized the economy.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bulldozer and Cash for Canadian Press Baron, but Hold the Sunset

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Aug. 2

 BODY:
So what is Conrad Black going to do with his bags of money now that he has sold most of the crown jewels of Canada's newspapers in one fell swoop?
"Do you remember that cartoon character, Scrooge McDuck?" Mr. Black said, answering a question with a question. "Do you remember how he used to get into his little bulldozer every morning and plow back and forth over his gold coins? Well, maybe I will just sit and look at it for a while." 
 Looking back to 1969 when he bought a tiny English-language paper in Quebec, Mr. Black, now 55, said, "I started in this business 30 years ago with an investment of $500."
Returning to the present, he said of the deal announced this week: "It was time in the history of my country, and time in my own history, to make things shipshape, to get rid of the debt, to get a bit of a cash box to work from, to enjoy life a little more."
Few pundits in newspapers today predicted an easy-chair life for Mr. Black, a Napoleon buff who has run his newspaper empire from a chair once owned by his military hero. As Mr. Black trims his sails in North America -- a sale of his community papers in the Chicago area is believed to be imminent -- Canadians believe he will turn his energies to Europe.
A holder of dual British and Canadian citizenship and owner of The Daily Telegraph of London, Mr. Black could seek out new European investments for the company that on Monday bought most of his Canadian newspapers, the CanWest Global Communications Corporation, now Canada's largest media company.
Commenting extensively about the deal for the first time since it was announced, Mr. Black said in a telephone interview Tuesday night that the sale to CanWest would leave his company, Hollinger Inc., on a solid financial footing. "We will go from $1.7 billion in debt to zero plus $500 million in cash, perhaps a bit better than that," he said.
Noting that Hollinger stock had bounced back from depressed levels in recent months, he said he was selling his newspapers "fairly close to the top of the economic cycle."
Mr. Black also justified his heavy sell-off here, saying he was "overexposed in Canada." In a separate interview with The National Post, his Toronto-based newspaper, Mr. Black added, "The reputation of Canada is not particularly great among American investors."
Although Americans have poured billions into the Toronto Stock Exchange this year, helping it to rise faster than the New York exchanges, Mr. Black said his pool of buyers was artificially limited by Canadian laws that discourage foreigners from buying Canadian newspapers. Noting that Canada is essentially off limits to American newspaper chains, he complained, "With these ridiculous foreign-ownership rules in Canada, you can't get much equity."
Israel Asper, the chairman of CanWest, has predicted that the editorial line of his newspapers will be "balanced," a word rarely found in the lexicon of Mr. Black, a crusty, conservative press baron who has been described by detractors as a thesaurus that walks like a man.
In response, Mr. Black snorted at newspaper characterizations of Mr. Asper as a "social democrat," saying that he and his new business partner see eye to eye on economic issues and recalling that he first met Mr. Asper 25 years ago when he was writing a personal tax column for The Winnipeg Free Press. Questioned further, he acknowledged having had "a bit of wrestling match with Izzy" over The National Post, which in less than two years has established an intellectual beachhead for conservative, free-market changes in Canada.
After the wrestling was over, ownership of The National Post was split 50-50 between the two business groups. Mr. Black, who is to be chairman of the newspaper for five years, says it sells 330,000 copies daily.
"Under our arrangement, he has no ability to change it," Mr. Black said of Mr. Asper and the editorial line of The Post, which has become a cheerleader for the Canadian Alliance, the nation's new tax-cutting party. Asked if the editorial line would change, he stressed: "Zero, nothing, not one millimeter."
But leaders of Canada's ruling Liberal Party, frequent target of criticism from the editorial pages of Mr. Black's newspapers, were elated at news of the purchase by Mr. Asper, a longtime centrist Liberal.
Calling the sale "the best news they had had in a long time," Lawrence Martin, a Southam News political analyst, wrote from Ottawa of the Liberals: "Even a measured neutrality will be viewed by the prime minister as a major plus over the treatment he felt he was receiving before the newspaper sale."
The government of Prime Minister Jean Chretien has not given the slightest hint that it will move to block the sale.
Toronto is home to one of the toughest newspaper wars in the English-speaking world, a three-way battle among The National Post, The Globe and Mail and The Toronto Star. On Tuesday, The Globe and Mail printed on the top of its front page a large full-color cartoon of Mr. Asper grinning and preparing to dine on a prostrate Mr. Black, who was depicted stuffed and spiced, with a sprig of parsley in each ear. The headlines read: "Asper: Mogul and a half" and "Black: Only half a mogul."
Despite its gloating, The Globe and Mail now stands alone, virtually the only major English-language Canadian newspaper that does not have ties to CanWest, which has a Canadian network of television stations broadcasting coast to coast.
After a day of reflection, The Globe and Mail came out today with an editorial salted with crocodile tears and headlined: "Black to fade."
"Since Canada does not have so many larger-than-life characters that it can afford to lose any of them cheerfully, the notion of a vanishing Conrad Black is rather affecting," the editorial said. In a service to readers, it warned that some Canadians "will experience the disorientation that follows the abrupt end of a toothache."

HEADLINE: General Motors Raises Stakes in Fuel Economy War with Ford

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 2

 BODY:
General Motors challenged Ford today to a battle over which company can deliver bigger improvements in fuel economy, particularly for sport utility vehicles, the least efficient vehicles of all.
Ford committed itself last week to improve the average mileage of its sport utility vehicles by almost five miles a gallon over the next five years. General Motors announced today that no matter how much Ford improved the energy efficiency of its sport utilities by 2005, G.M.'s sport utilities would average even more miles to the gallon by then. 
 The announcements affect half of all the sport utilities sold in the country -- about 800,000 by each automaker.
G.M. also upped the ante, saying that the overall fuel economy for all its light trucks -- a category including minivans and pickups as well as sport utilities -- would be better than Ford's in 2005.
"G.M. will still be the leader in five years, and in 15 years for that matter," said Harry Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman, at a news conference today in this Detroit suburb.
Ford vowed last week to raise its sport utilities' mileage by 25 percent, from a little over 18 miles a gallon now. Ford also said that it would improve the fuel economy of its minivans and pickups, and planned future announcements to give more precise figures, after performing additional engineering studies. Mr. Pearce's comments today effectively pre-empted Ford's next move, by committing G.M. to exceed in average light truck fuel economy whatever Ford does. The world's two largest automakers make nearly half the nation's minivans and pickup trucks.
Automakers have been trumpeting the occasional fuel-economy improvement in various models for years, but have typically offset these gains by making other vehicles more powerful and less efficient. The G.M. and Ford announcements are the first instances of big domestic automakers committing themselves voluntarily to significant increases in the average fuel economy of large classes of vehicles.
Why, after merely two decades of no significant improvement in the fuel economy of light trucks, are G.M. and Ford reversing course? Both companies said their market research had found growing interest in better fuel economy. Foreign automakers are stepping up their sales of sport utilities and showing that they do not have to be gas guzzlers, partly because the foreign brands are often based on lightweight car underbodies instead of cheap but heavy pickup truck underbodies. G.M. and Ford also worry that the government might require higher fuel economy; the automakers helped narrowly defeat such a plan in Congress two months ago.
But another big reason for G.M.'s declaration seemed to be a nervousness that last week's news conference by Ford had burnished Ford's reputation for environmental responsibility, which might help Ford sell more vehicles. "What annoys me is the perception that seems to come from that press conference that Ford is somehow the environmental leader," Mr. Pearce said.
Jacques A. Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said last week that the planned improvement in fuel economy would save the typical sport utility customer about 1,700 gallons of gasoline, or 80 trips to the gas station, over the first 10 years of vehicle ownership. The effect on the nation's overall oil imports and emissions of global warming gases, while small at first, would grow as the more efficient models gradually replace the behemoths now on the road.
DaimlerChrysler and Asian automakers declined to join Ford and G.M. in promising fuel-economy gains, saying that they already had better gas mileage, partly because they did not sell models as big as the Ford Excursion and the G.M. Chevrolet Suburban. "We'll let them do the tit for tat," said Michael Aberlich, a DaimlerChrysler spokesman.
Michael Love, Toyota's national regulatory affairs manager, said the Japanese automaker would focus on the gas mileage of individual models. "We'll try to have class-leading fuel economy in every segment we're in," he said.
Environmentalists hailed G.M.'s position. "That's huge -- Ford placed its bet and G.M. anted up and we've got a real race here," said Jason Mark, the transportation co-director at the Union of Concerned Scientists.
Like Ford last week, G.M. said today that it would improve fuel economy without resorting to the auto industry's favorite loopholes in the 1990's: building vehicles so heavy that they are exempt from federal fuel-economy rules, and claiming gas mileage credits for vehicles that have the capability to burn either gasoline or nearly pure ethanol, even though ethanol is not available in most of the country. G.M. also said that, like Ford, it would achieve almost all of its improvement through changes in conventional gasoline-powered engines, rather than by switching to potentially dirty diesel engines or introducing partly electric engines for which consumer demand is unclear.
G.M. provided more technical details than Ford, saying it planned to change all of its big V-8 engines over the next several years to use a technology tried in desperation and abandoned during the depths of the oil crisis that followed the Iranian revolution in 1979. The technology involves turning off four of the engine's eight cylinders except when maximum power is needed for acceleration or towing.
This approach was discredited when G.M. tried it in the early 1980's because the engine controls then were slow to sense changes in the driver's need for power, so there was a long lag when drivers tried to accelerate. The latest microprocessors adjust the number of cylinders in use faster than a human being can appreciate the change, said Stephen G. Poulos, a G.M. engineer.
G.M. also said it would introduce in some of its light trucks a technology known as a continuously variable transmission. This replaces a conventional four-speed automatic transmission, and is in use on a few very small cars, mainly overseas. But the technology, which allows gear changes that are undetectable to drivers, has been improving lately for use on larger vehicles.
Mr. Pearce also displayed a large pickup truck and a city bus that were each powered by a hybrid system of a gasoline engine and an electric motor. The hybrid pickup truck will be 15 percent more fuel efficient than current models and the hybrid bus will be 50 percent more efficient. Many electric vehicle enthusiasts say that even bigger efficiency gains will be possible, and that hybrid systems could someday reduce considerably the nation's energy needs.
But G.M. is concerned that customers may take a while to accept hybrids as household vehicles, and is not counting on hybrids to play more than a very small part in its overall improvement in light truck fuel economy by 2005, said Jeffrey Kuhlman, a G.M. spokesman.
Mr. Pearce said G.M.'s current sport utilities go 6 percent farther than Ford's on a gallon of gasoline, on average. He did not promise that G.M. would beat Ford by a similar percentage in 2005, raising the possibility that G.M. could keep the lead but improve its fuel economy by a little less than Ford's 25 percent.
Ford officials said they were unsure whether G.M.'s current sport utilities were ahead in fuel economy. In midmodel year reports to regulators on the 2000 model year, G.M. and Ford have both reported that their light truck fleets are averaging 20.9 miles a gallon.
But Ford welcomed G.M.'s overall willingness to compete on fuel economy. "It's good for the ecology; it's good for the customer," said Ken Zino, a Ford spokesman.
Mr. Pearce, who has overseen public policy and technology issues at G.M. for four years, mentioned repeatedly today his irritation at the attention that Ford had received for its commitment to greater fuel economy at a news conference in Washington last week. He chided Mr. Nasser, Ford's chief executive, for having flown to Washington to make his announcement at the National Press Club. "We've got them beat in S.U.V.'s and they know it, and maybe that's why they felt compelled to be in the Press Club," he said, speaking at G.M.'s Truck Design Center here.

HEADLINE: Chairman of Con Ed Blames Power Producers for Rise in Electric Bills

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
For customers in New York City and Westchester County, trying to get a candid explanation for a sharp increase in electricity rates has been a complicated game of who's to blame, with the parties involved pointing fingers at one another. The explanation was no less elusive yesterday as state legislators questioned regulators, power producers and Consolidated Edison.
One thing, however, was clear from yesterday's hearings: regardless of who is at fault, customers have made it clear in a flurry of complaints that they are fed up. 
 All told, the average electricity bill for New York City and Westchester County residents this summer is expected to be 30 percent more than last summer's average, officials said. The average June bill jumped 43 percent compared with last year, city officials said.
But Eugene R. McGrath, the chairman and chief executive of Consolidated Edison, pleaded with legislators to stop looking to his company for answers. Since deregulation began in New York State, Mr. McGrath noted, Con Edison has been forced to sell most of its power plants and no longer controls the cost of producing power, the part that he said has caused customers' bills to increase.
Blaming the new Con Edison, he said, was akin to getting upset with the delivery man when a farmer decides to double the price of milk.
"Our rates are going down," Mr. McGrath said, noting that Con Edison's part of the bill, which covers distribution of the electricity, has decreased 17 percent since 1980. "On the supply side, rates are going up, and I think we need to better understand what is going on in the market."
Legislators said they were concerned that businesses would soon be passing on the cost of higher electric rates to their customers. Officials from the National Supermarket Association said that those costs would be likely to show up on grocery bills.
"No one can absorb such a large increase in their electricity costs and not pass it on to consumers," said Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist for the National Supermarket Association, a group of independent grocery stores in New York.
Legislators expressed concern that the higher costs could mean the loss of electricity for poor, elderly and disabled people who are unable to pay. Yesterday, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, who last month called for the hearing, said in an interview that the "spike threatens the economic and physical health of New Yorkers."
While legislators grilled officials and tried to place the blame on Con Ed and the Pataki administration's oversight of deregulation, conspicuously absent from the hearing was the group that might be able to explain the increase in rates: executives from the companies that produce power. A legislative aide who insisted on anonymity said that the executives were invited only at the last minute, adding that the misstep was a sign of how even legislators were even struggling to grasp how the new system works.
Under deregulation, Con Ed was forced to sell most of its power plants to unregulated companies that could set prices based on market rates. Con Ed now makes money by transmitting power from the plants to customers. The higher costs are on the generation side, which is now virtually unregulated.
Mr. McGrath said that he did not know why power providers, who own the plants, had increased prices. He said it appeared that the higher costs of gasoline and oil, fuels used to run most power plants downstate, explained about half the rise. But it is unclear what is causing the rest of the increase, Mr. McGrath added.
Representatives of the power providers did not explain the increase other than to say that demand was outpacing supply.
Maureen O. Helmer, chairwoman of the State Public Service Commission, defended the Pataki administration's oversight of deregulation. She and Mr. McGrath said that the Legislature must encourage the building of new power plants.
"Just as increased supply reduces the price for milk, oranges or telephone service, the placement of power plants in New York City will reduce upward pressure on prices and increases the reliability of the city's supply," Ms. Helmer said.

HEADLINE: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS: THE NOMINEE;
BUSH-CHENEY TICKET NOMINATED AND THE ATTACKS ON GORE BEGIN

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Burning to reclaim the White House after eight years on the outside, the Republican Party tonight nominated George Walker Bush for president and sent forth his running mate with the most stinging and unabashedly partisan assault of the convention.
Dick Cheney, Mr. Bush's No. 2, said the election of Al Gore would perpetuate what he called the misguided policies of President Clinton. 
 "We are all a little weary of the Clinton-Gore routine," Mr. Cheney said. "But the wheel has turned." Excerpts, Page A28.
Then, appropriating Mr. Gore's 1992 campaign slogan as his own, he said, "It is time for them to go!"
In the ritual roll call, the 22 votes from Mr. Cheney's home state, Wyoming, cast at 10:04 p.m. gave Mr. Bush more than the 1,034 votes needed to grasp the nomination. The hall erupted in a prolonged ovation as jubilant delegates, many of them dancing, were awash in a sea of beach balls, confetti and balloons.
The delegates, who had heard three nights of sunny, even apolitical, speeches, roared in delight as Mr. Cheney directed full-throated taunts at the Democrats. But with Mr. Cheney's mild and even-toned delivery, his punch lines did not carry the same weight on television.
Casting aside the high-minded oratory that had marked this convention, Mr. Cheney portrayed Mr. Gore as mean-spirited by reviving former Senator Bill Bradley's pungent dismissal of him six days before the New Hampshire primary: "A thousand promises. A thousand attacks."
Mr. Cheney, defense secretary under former President George Bush, said he was lured back into public service because of his belief in Governor Bush and his fear that Mr. Gore's election would perpetuate everything that he believed was wrong with Mr. Clinton's stewardship.
Drawing a contrast with Mr. Bush's achievements as governor of Texas, Mr. Cheney contended that the Clinton administration had made no headway on Social Security, taxes or military readiness.
Mr. Cheney's address capped Mr. Bush's night of triumph, which had been honed for weeks, if not months. It was a political and emotional peak for the two-term governor, one-time baseball team owner and son of a former president who did not appear on the public stage until he first won election in 1994.
Just eight years ago, Republicans nominated Mr. Bush's father for a second term, only to have their president ousted by Bill Clinton. But tonight, Mr. Cheney told the 2,066 delegates that the era of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore had been one of dashed hopes and squandered opportunities.
Mr. Cheney depicted Mr. Gore as intimately connected to an administration mired in scandal, and he sought to turn Mr. Gore's attacks on Mr. Bush's "risky tax scheme" back against the vice president.
"In this election, they will speak endlessly of risk," Mr. Cheney said. "We will speak of progress. They will make accusations. We will make proposals. They will feed fear and we will appeal to hope. They will offer more lectures and legalisms and carefully worded denials. We offer another way -- a better way -- and a stiff dose of truth."
Mr. Cheney's comments left no doubt that despite his mild-mannered demeanor, the Bush campaign intended to employ him in the somewhat traditional role of running-mate-as-attacker. In his acceptance speech four years ago as Bob Dole's No. 2, Jack F. Kemp was far more restrained; he mentioned Mr. Clinton only once, and his sharpest words were casting Democrats as "elitist."
But Mr. Cheney picked up a mantle that has been carried in the past by Bob Dole and Mr. Gore himself.
The speech by the vice-presidential nominee is typically delivered on the closing night of the convention -- and is usually overshadowed by the one delivered by the head of the ticket. But by giving Mr. Cheney his own night, the campaign was able to showcase Mr. Bush's running mate.
And though Mr. Bush had planned the break with tradition well before Mr. Cheney was chosen, the move offered the public an opportunity to take a measure of a man who has been out of the public eye since leaving the Pentagon eight years ago after playing a crucial role in the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Cheney's speech provided delegates with yet another reason to revel in a quadrennial gathering that has been remarkably devoid of controversy, in public at least.
After his defeat to Mr. Clinton, former President Bush was shunned at many Republican events. But this week, delegates expressed supreme confidence that his son was their best hope to retake the White House.
For the third night in a row, the former president sat through the proceedings, logging more time there than many delegates. At the very end of the night, he smiled and sang along as Lee Greenwood appeared on stage to sing what had been Mr. Bush's campaign anthem, "I'm Proud to Be an American."
The one somber note on what was the most festive night thus far was the health of former President Gerald R. Ford.
Mr. Ford, who had delighted party loyalists on Tuesday night when he appeared on the floor as part of a tribute to past Republican presidents, was admitted to a hospital here today after suffering at least one minor stroke.
At the start of his speech, Mr. Cheney, who had been Mr. Ford's chief of staff at the White House, passed on his wishes for "a quick and speedy recovery." After serving with Mr. Ford, Mr. Cheney was elected as a congressman from Wyoming, rising to the rank of Republican whip.
While acknowledging that Mr. Cheney's speech was the most hard-edged of the convention, Mr. Bush's aides insisted that it did not violate their pledge to keep the discourse from Philadelphia largely high-minded and positive.
"The secretary's speech sets a new tone," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Mr. Bush. "It draws contrasts with Vice President Gore, but far more respectfully than typical politicians."
Mr. Bush had said to expect some barbs aimed at Mr. Gore. Yet some passages in Mr. Cheney's speech veered closely to the personal, especially those that linked Mr. Gore to Mr. Clinton.
"As the man from Hope goes home to New York," Mr. Cheney said, "Mr. Gore will try to separate himself from his leader's shadow, but somehow we will never see one without thinking of the other."
Then he added, "Does anyone, Republican or Democrat, seriously believe that under Mr. Gore the next four years would be any different from the last eight?"
Several delegates welcomed Mr. Cheney's speech as crucial to counter the Democrats. "After putting up with the president and his lies for eight years, this was a breath of fresh air," said John Enriquez, a delegate from California.
Carolyn Shinke, a delegate from Dayton, Ohio, put it this way: "Mr. Cheney had to say the things that had to be said tonight. We all know the details, and it is not easy to listen to. But the record had to be set straight at this convention; this aggressive message had to come out."
In the eight days since Mr. Bush named him as his running mate, Mr. Cheney has found himself largely on the defensive, fighting off attacks by Democrats that his voting record was too conservative for most voters. They concentrated on his opposition to the Head Start preschool education program and his votes against a ban on armor-piercing bullets.
Yet in his speech tonight, Mr. Cheney did not even allude to the controversy -- or his own ideology -- and instead took the opportunity to say glowing things about his former boss, then-President Bush, and about the president's son.
Governor Bush -- who arrived in Philadelphia today after a six-day tour through six states carried by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore in 1992 and 1996 -- took to the sprawling stage at the convention hall this afternoon to run through his acceptance address for Thursday night.
Expressing, perhaps, Mr. Bush's disdain of long-winded addresses -- and perhaps his own self-assuredness -- his aides said that his acceptance speech might well be the shortest in years.
Karen Hughes, the campaign's communications director, told reporters that, allowing for applause, Mr. Bush's speech would last roughly 38 minutes. In contrast, acceptance speeches by President Bush in 1992 and Bob Dole in 1996 each ran 57 minutes.
Beyond the effort tonight for Mr. Cheney to extol Mr. Bush's virtues, the program was intended to highlight the Republican Party's signature economic issue: tax cuts.
As throughout the convention, the focus was on portraying the party not as one of plutocrats -- as Democrats have long sought to label it -- but as a party of working people.
To drive home the point, speakers included a Hispanic small-business owner, Hector Barreto, who spoke of how Mr. Bush would help entrepreneurs by cutting the burden of taxation and regulation, and Kim Jennings, a single mother, who discussed how the tax plan would help her edge toward the middle class.
Democratic officials countered that the Republicans were trying to obscure the fact that Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposals would disproportionately benefit the wealthy.
And Mr. Gore's aides pressed their case that the Republican tax cuts passed this year by Congress and those proposed by Mr. Bush would both endanger the nation's newfound fiscal health and the economy's long-term prospects.
The very theme of the Republicans' evening, "prosperity with a purpose," contained a tacit acknowledgment that the economy is hardy, a fact that could ultimately be expected to help Mr. Gore.
When Mr. Bush arrived at the airport here this morning, he received a red-carpet welcome, replete with a fife and drum corps and a replica of the Liberty Bell, which he gonged. Then he was off to the Philadelphia Museum of Art for what was billed as a Hispanic welcome event.
Mr. Bush was introduced by his Hispanic-American nephew, George P. Bush, who asked the crowd, "Are you excited about electing a president who represents the diversity of our society?"
The governor and his wife, Laura, then appeared with Senator John McCain and his wife, Cindy. Mr. Bush praised his once-bitter foe -- who had paid tribute to him at the convention on Tuesday -- as a "living example of duty, honor and country."
He added, "Senator, I can't wait to campaign with you all across our country."

HEADLINE: Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam, 92, Is Dead

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

 BODY:
Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam, a Holocaust survivor whose gentle charisma nurtured the exuberant postwar rebirth of the Bobov Hasidic sect in Brooklyn and around the world, died at Maimonides Medical Center yesterday after a long illness. He was 92.
A regal-looking man with a great silver beard and horn-rimmed glasses, Rabbi Halberstam was known for his love of dancing with the Torah and for his artful way of sidestepping the internal squabbles that plague other Hasidic sects. 
 But his enduring accomplishment, Judaic scholars say, was rebuilding the Bobov sect, a group of Jews based in southeastern Poland that was nearly exterminated by the Nazis during World War II.
Under about 50 years of his consistently conciliatory leadership, the Bobovers became the leading Hasidic group in Borough Park, which is the most Hasidic section of Brooklyn. It is a neighborhood, city planners say, where the fertility rate is double that of New York as a whole, where families with eight children are not unusual and where Rabbi Halberstam convinced ultra-Orthodox Jews that they could thrive without compromising their way of life.
At his funeral yesterday, about 6,000 mourners crushed into Bobover Yeshiva Bnei Zion at 15th Avenue and 48th Street, with an additional 30,000 or so standing outside in steaming heat listening to loudspeakers. During the ceremony, many mourners wailed and ripped their clothing, signifying that the rabbi was like a father to them.
Rabbi Halberstam's two sons spoke at the service. Rabbi Naftali Halberstam, the eldest and the chosen successor in the Bobov sect, escaped the Nazis with his father and came to New York after the war. He spoke of his grandfather, the Bobover grand rabbi, who was killed by the Nazis. The second son, Rabbi Ben Zion Halberstam, said his father had picked up the ashes from the Holocaust and created the community that was now mourning him.
The Bobover Hasidim are part of an ecstatic religious movement of the late 17th century that broke from traditional rabbinical Judaism for reasons that included objections about materialistic excess. The various sects among the Hasidim share similar beliefs, with their differences owing to geographical origin, dress and style of leadership among grand rabbis.
The Bobovers, whose name derives from a village in southeastern Poland, tend to look to their grand rabbi more than most other sects for advice on business, marriage and family matters, according to William B. Helmreich, a professor of sociology and Judaic studies at the City University of New York.
"Bobover Hasidim is known for not emphasizing disputes," said Professor Helmreich, author of "The World of the Yeshiva" (Ktav, 2000). "They are considered very open and tolerant to other groups."
Several Judaic experts said that Rabbi Halberstam enjoyed extraordinary success in recruiting Jews in America to the Bobov sect because he was both nonconfrontational and charismatic.
"There is a market economy in America in religion, and whoever has the charisma attracts the most people," said Samuel Heilman, a professor of Jewish studies and sociology at Queens College. "Rabbi Halberstam was successful, and the numbers show that."
Professor Heilman estimated there are 20,000 followers of the Bobov sect, although some other Jewish leaders said the sect had more than 100,000 members who are concentrated in New York, Montreal, Toronto, Miami and London.
Unlike the Satmar and Lubavitch Hasidic sects, which are also prominent in Brooklyn, the Bobovers have flourished with little public infighting. A leadership squabble dating to the death 21 years ago of a grand rabbi continues to divide the Satmar sect, and the Lubavitch movement remains riven by a dispute over whether their late leader, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, was the Messiah.
Rabbi Halberstam years ago designated his oldest son as his successor, Professor Heilman said. At the funeral yesterday, he said the congregation enthusiastically welcomed the son as their new leader.
Rabbi Halberstam arrived in New York in the late 1940's, with only his oldest son. The rest of his family had been killed. During this time, according to Professor Heilman, he apparently had a crisis of faith, shaved his beard and lost his desire to be a rabbi. But he soon recovered and, Professor Heilman said, his crisis of faith proved inspirational to many Orthodox Jews reeling in poverty and psychological distress in the wake of the war.
"Many of his followers felt that if the rabbi can forgive God for the Holocaust, then we can, too," Professor Heilman said.
Rabbi Halberstam took great pleasure in dancing and singing. His dancing frames a recent documentary movie about the Hasidim called "A World Apart -- Hasidic Life in America."
Rabbi Halberstam is survived by his two sons and five daughters, along with many grandchildren and great-grandchildren.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: August 4, 2000, Friday August 7, 2000, Monday

 CORRECTION:
The obituary of Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam of the Bobover sect yesterday included an incomplete reference from family friends to the members of his family who survived the Holocaust. Although several relatives were killed, his mother, a brother and six sisters -- not just his eldest son -- survived.
An obituary of Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam of the Bobover sect on Thursday misstated the title of a documentary in which he is shown dancing. It is "A Life Apart: Hasidism in America," not "A World Apart: Hasidic Life in America."

HEADLINE: A New Caveat for eBay Users: Seller Beware;
Putting Your Family Heirlooms Up for Bids May Make You a Target for Credit Card Fraud

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
CONNIE BACON, a regular seller on eBay, thought that she had brokered an excellent deal. On behalf of a consignment shop in Charleston, S.C., she had sold a Rolex watch for $13,500 in an online auction, and everything had gone smoothly.
A man who identified himself as Kelvin Johanis had put the money in an escrow account, assuring Ms. Bacon that the payment was good, and the shopkeeper had shipped the package to a house specified by the buyer in Lynwood, Wash. 
 A few hours later, Ms. Bacon got an urgent e-mail message from I-Escrow, the company holding the payment. I-Escrow said the buyer was suspected of using a stolen credit card. Please, the message pleaded, do not ship the watch.
"I was shaking," Ms. Bacon said. "This was a $13,500 watch that wasn't mine."
She had good reason to be concerned. Online sellers are even more vulnerable to fraud than online buyers, experts say. Those who buy faulty or fake goods through online auctions or Web shops have some recourse; insurance programs and credit card companies will often come to their rescue and credit their accounts, at least up to a certain amount.
But individuals who are selling goods in online auctions have little protection. Stolen credit cards, fake money orders and bounced checks are risks they face. For them, the adage is turned on its head: Seller beware.
In Ms. Bacon's case, she was not the only Ebay seller who did business with the person who called himself Mr. Johanis. His real name was Michael Prime, according to court documents, and he turned out to be a 19-year-old unemployed high school graduate in Brier, Wash.
According to I-Escrow's investigators (informally known as the fraud squad), Mr. Prime had opened 25 accounts on the I-Escrow system and had been in contact with at least nine sellers. He had used stolen credit cards to get almost $20,000 worth of merchandise, including laptop computers, other Rolex watches and three remote-controlled scale-model helicopters.
When people worry about fraud in online auctions, they do not usually think about buyers like Mr. Prime. They assume that they are most likely to be deceived by sellers -- particularly by people hawking counterfeit or broken merchandise.
"That is really not true," said Dr. Audri Lanford, a sociologist and editor of an e-mail newsletter, Scambusters.org. "Fraud is a huge issue, but it is from the seller's perspective."
In fact, online sellers are 1O to 18 times as likely as bricks and mortar merchants to lose merchandise to people using stolen credit cards, according to a survey by the Gartner Group, a market research company. The survey, which was released in July and polled 166 retailers, showed that 1.13 percent of all online transactions were conducted with stolen cards.
Once online sellers accept a stolen card, they often find that the credit card company is of no help. Under federal law, the owner of the credit card would not have to pay for those items. The credit card companies do not have to cover the cost either; they are liable for the purchases only if the seller got a signature from the card holder. So the seller bears the cost and will never be paid.
A year ago, that might not have sounded like an issue for consumers to worry about. But now, with auction sites like those offered by eBay, Yahoo and Amazon.com, consumers can be sellers as easily as they can be buyers. Today, millions of people are selling goods online, with no background in running a business and none of the resources used by traditional businesses if things go awry.
Until recently, most individuals selling through online auctions have not been able to accept credit cards and have had to worry only about bounced checks. But this spring, the introduction of credit card services like Billpoint have made it possible for anyone -- even someone selling one item -- to take credit cards online. Now people who have no business savvy, and who may simply be selling miscellaneous items to clean out their basements, are vulnerable to the same credit card fraud that is plaguing online merchants.
Ms. Bacon, an antique-glassware trader who can often be spotted on eBay under the name GrayHorse, was an experienced online auctioneer when she decided to help a consignment shop sell the Rolex last summer. She had already run into a few problems, mainly with buyers who retracted their bids. But she was still not prepared when she heard that the sellers she was acting for had been defrauded by Mr. Prime. "I felt very violated," she said. "It made me very angry."
Mr. Prime, it turned out, was doing more than simply using stolen credit cards. Those involved with the case say that he is a whiz with computers, though he has little education beyond high school. His lawyer, Tim Tesh, described his client as "one of these self-taught kids who can just pick it up."
According to I-Escrow, Mr. Prime first registered for accounts using stolen cards in July 1999. But I-Escrow detected that the accounts were based on stolen cards and quickly canceled them.
So Mr. Prime tried to get around the system. According to I-Escrow, he told sellers that he wanted to use I-Escrow and would start the process of setting up accounts. But instead of completing the transaction through the escrow service, officials said, Mr. Prime would close the deal by pretending to be an escrow agent and sending messages from "I_Escrow@Hotmail.com," an e-mail address that looked a lot like I-Escrow's official messages, which end with "IEscrow.com." Using that disguise, he told sellers that the money had been deposited and that they should go ahead and ship their items.
The first person to be deceived, I-Escrow said, was a Bellingham, Wash., man who was selling a Macintosh Powerbook G3 in July 1999. According to I-Escrow's records, Mr. Prime purchased two remote-controlled helicopters and two Rolex watches a week later using fake e-mail messages.
But one other case involving a remote-controlled helicopter worked a little differently. The seller, Bobby DeRosa, was a Web designer in San Diego, and Mr. Prime did not try to use a fake e-mail address. Instead, I-Escrow said, he used a credit card that had not yet been listed by banks as stolen and then asked Mr. DeRosa to direct the shipment to an address that was different from the one on the card.
By the end of July, I-Escrow had been tipped off by the seller of the Apple computer, who had checked the company's Web site to view his account's status and had been baffled to find that the transaction was listed as "still pending." He forwarded to I-Escrow the fake message that included the real shipping address: 14501 Highway 99 in Lynwood, Wash.
I-Escrow officials called the sheriff's office there, in Snohomish County. A detective, Matt Trafford, drove to the address on Highway 99, a four-lane commercial road, and found what looked like an abandoned house that had been "sitting there rotting for years," he said.
Inside the house, Detective Trafford said, he found credit card receipts and registration papers for a nearby storage business.
Detective Trafford wanted to be waiting when the next shipment was delivered to the house. He asked I-Escrow if its records showed another shipment. Yes, it looked as though another Rolex watch was about to be purchased, from an eBay seller in South Carolina: Ms. Bacon.
This was the same week that Ms. Bacon received that urgent e-mail message telling her not to ship the watch. The minute she saw that message, Ms. Bacon had called the consignment shop but had discovered, to her dismay, that the watch had already been packed and delivered to the post office. "I called the post office," she said, and found to her relief that the package was still there. "I said: 'Oh thank you, Jesus. Please do not send that watch out.' "
Ms. Bacon then agreed to help I-Escrow and the sheriff's office. She found an old chipped soap dish that weighed about as much as the watch, wrapped it up and sent it to her buyer. Across the country in Lynwood, Wash., Detective Trafford was waiting, watching the abandoned house through the windows of a nearby store.
But the soap dish never made its way to the abandoned house. Mr. Prime picked it up at the Federal Express office instead and threw it into a gasoline station's trash can after he opened it. Detective Trafford, however, was still able to find Mr. Prime. By talking to witnesses at the Federal Express office, the detective learned that Mr. Prime rode a blue-and-white motorcycle and used a nearby storage business. On a visit to the site, the detective spotted the motorcycle and noted its license plate number. The number led him to find snapshots of Mr. Prime that were on file from a previous arrest. (Mr. Prime had pleaded guilty a few days earlier to stealing a computer.)
Soon, with help from I-Escrow and eBay, the detective had enough information to make an arrest. Mr. Prime was picked up at his mother's house, and the police said they had found a Rolex watch and two stolen credit cards there. Mr. Prime said he had taken the cards after finding them in automated teller machines. He was charged with theft and two counts of possession of stolen property. He denied the charges at first, posted bail and a few months later moved from his mother's house.
That move led to another visit from the authorities, this time from a probation officer who had been assigned to Mr. Prime after he pleaded guilty to the previous theft, in King County. The officer came to do a routine check of Mr. Prime's new residence. During a search of the apartment, he found a tin can in a cabinet. As soon as the officer opened the can, a firecracker rocket inside ignited, according to Mr. Prime's affidavit. The flame from the rocket was apparently intended to destroy the contents, but detectives were still able to identify them: another stolen credit card, a stolen debit card and fake identification cards.
Mr. Prime eventually pleaded guilty to five felony counts (the three earlier charges plus a count for possessing an incendiary device and a count of forgery), and he was sentenced to 22 months at the Airway Heights Correctional Center in eastern Washington. In the interview this week, he said he had learned his lesson and was hoping to take a computer-related job someday. "I was emotionally depressed and doing stupid things," he said. "I made a bad choice."
The case of Mr. Prime may sound more complex than most cases of credit card fraud, but officials at companies like I-Escrow and CyberSource, which provides verification services to online merchants, say they have been seeing more incidents like this recently. "The con artists today are getting much more crafty," said Vince Gottman, i-Escrow's senior director for customer support and the leader of the fraud squad.
I-Escrow, for example, recently caught a buyer trying to use a check stolen from his employer. CyberSource officials said they had seen an increasing number of international cases. A buyer will ask that goods be sent to a location outside the United States but will use a credit card with a billing address inside the United States. In many cases, they say, the credit card being used is a stolen card.
"One bad buyer out there can do a lot of damage," said Tom Arnold, chief technology officer at CyberSource.
Most businesses already know this. "You have to build that into the cost of business," said Janet Crane, chief executive of Billpoint, the credit card system used by many people on eBay. Ms. Crane acknowledged, however, that most eBay users did not have the business experience to protect themselves.
Billpoint works like most credit card companies and will not cover a seller's costs when a transaction has gone bad. But this week, the company started offering a new feature to give sellers more protection. The service, called Electronic Check, will let sellers receive money directly from a buyer's checking account, instead of through a credit card. But the service has a three-day waiting period so Billpoint can make sure that the check clears. If a fraudulent check goes through, the service will reimburse the seller up to $200.
A few services offer guarantees if a card is used and later determined to be stolen. I-Escrow, for example, gave refunds to the sellers who were defrauded by Mr. Prime. The company now asks its users to ensure that messages are legitimate by comparing the information they get in e-mail messages that appear to be from I-Escrow with what I-Escrow shows in their Web-based accounts. If sellers do everything that is asked of them and are still defrauded, I-Escrow says, it will cover the cost of any lost items.
Ecount, a service that enables people to use credit cards on the Web, also says that it will cover the cost of bad transactions and cover payments that are owed to a seller even if a credit card turns out to be stolen. PayPal, another payment service, also offers a guarantee, but only if users have completed a three-step verification process when setting up accounts. About 10 percent of PayPal's customers do so, said Elon Musk, chief executive of X.com, the company behind PayPal.
For the most part, experts say, sellers should not panic. Kevin Pursglove, eBay's spokesman, added that "99.997 percent of transactions have satisfactory buyers and sellers." Yahoo Auctions and other auction sites also stress that most sales are completed without a hitch.
In fact, Ms. Bacon said she had not been dissuaded from selling her glassware on eBay, and she is still using I-Escrow for high-priced items. And she probably would not have been held financially responsible for the loss of the watch because she was selling it for another shop.
But she has become more wary, and she warns sellers to review the procedures on auction and escrow services before using them. "Fully understand what the process should be," she said, "so you can't get fooled like I did."
 
Protecting Yourself
 
Sellers may be 10 times as likely to run into credit card fraud over the Internet as in the physical world. Here are some things online sellers should watch:
 
SHIPPING -- Ship the item only to the address listed on the credit card. People using stolen cards, of course, want purchases to come to them, not to card holders.
 
TIMING -- Don't sell to a buyer who appears anxious to purchase an item and offers a premium to buy it before the auction ends. A holder of a stolen card is usually in a hurry to use it before the theft is reported.
 
SHIPPING -- Be wary of any buyer who requests expensive overnight shipping and offers to cover the costs.
 
E-MAIL -- Be wary of buyers using free e-mail services like Hotmail or Juno.com. Many honest people use free e-mail, but these accounts allow senders to be anonymous.
 
PAYMENTS -- Don't let the buyer split up the payment for an item by making, say, 10 payments of $500 instead of one $5,000 payment. The buyer may be trying to stay under the radar of credit card companies, who pay extra attention to large purchases.

HEADLINE: Salomon to Buy U.S. Treasury Interest

 BODY:
Salomon Smith Barney offered yesterday to buy $94.5 billion worth of the interest portion of Treasury securities, known as strips, from institutional and retail owners.
Salomon said it wanted to combine the interest portions with bond principal to create whole bonds that would be eligible for sale back to the Treasury as part of the government's buyback program. 
 This year, the Treasury is expected to buy back as much as $30 billion of Treasury bonds with maturities of 10 years to 25 years remaining. The government is reducing borrowing amid growing budget surpluses.
Wall Street firms often break up the interest and the principal portions of a bond and sell them separately as zero-coupon bonds.
Salomon has an oversupply of the principal portions of existing bonds but a shortage of the interest-rate portion. And if the firm wants to take advantage of the premium prices the Treasury is paying to buy back existing bonds, it needs to reconstitute the two portions into whole bonds.
"This offer will allow us to continue to be actively involved in the Treasury buyback program," said Charles Parkhurst, co-head of the United States government bond department at Salomon.
The $94.5 billion is the face value of the interest portion of the bonds. But the bonds would be purchased at a discount to the price so that the total cost would be less than $94.5 billion. Salomon is offering investors cash for the interest portions of the bond, or would swap them for a principal portion.

HEADLINE: 2 Reports Show a Slower Pace of Growth

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Factory orders for goods other than aircraft were little changed in June and the pace of business outside of manufacturing slowed in July, government and industry reports showed today.
Manufacturer orders, excluding a record increase for aircraft and other transportation equipment, rose 0.3 percent in June after a 4.4 percent increase in May, the Commerce Department said. 
 A separate report showed business outside of manufacturing expanded in July at the slowest pace since January as new orders cooled. The National Association of Purchasing Management's nonmanufacturing business index fell to 55.5 in July from a reading of 64 in June.
"The decline helps to confirm a generalized slowdown in U.S. demand, perhaps even extending into the service sector," said Peter Kretzmer, senior economist at Banc of America Securities in New York.
In a third report, the number of workers filing new applications for state unemployment benefits increased last week. Initial jobless claims rose 2,000, to a seasonally adjusted 276,000 in the week ended July 29, after a decrease of 39,000, to a revised 274,000, the previous week, according to the Labor Department.
In addition, the four-week moving average for claims, considered a less volatile gauge of labor market conditions, fell to 295,750 last week -- the lowest level in almost two months -- from 300,000 the previous week.
The Commerce Department's report showed that total orders to manufacturers rose 5.5 percent in June after increasing 4.7 percent in May. June's gain was the biggest since a 7.3 percent increase in July 1991, when the United States was emerging from its last recession.
Orders for transportation equipment surged 42.2 percent in June, mainly because of a jump in demand for aircraft, the Commerce Department said.
Boeing, the world's largest maker of aircraft, reported 139 orders for June, including a contract to sell at least 94 jetliners valued at $4.5 billion to Southwest Airlines. That compares with 57 orders received for May. Boeing's year-to-date orders are above those for all of 1999.
June shipments of goods from the nation's factories rose 1 percent, while inventories increased 0.5 percent. The inventories-to-shipments ratio, a measure of the time goods sit at factories, fell to a record low of 1.25 months in June from 1.26 months in May.
Unfilled orders surged 4.3 percent in June, a sign manufacturers are having trouble keeping pace with demand.
The value of orders for nondurable goods, which includes clothing and food as well as petroleum, oil and paper, fell 0.1 percent.
Orders for chemicals, paper and tobacco products also declined during the month.
In May, orders for nondurable goods increased 1.6 percent.
