HEADLINE: Taiwan's Leader Considers Purchase of Updated Jet Fighters

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, said today that the island should begin considering new fighter aircraft purchases, warning that in five years China could threaten Taiwan's ability to control the skies over the Taiwan Strait, a key factor in repelling a mainland invasion.
That Mr. Chen, who spoke during an inspection of Taiwan's air force headquarters in Taipei, would make the politically charged suggestion during the Republican Party's convention suggested to some analysts that he hoped to interject the issue into the American presidential campaign. The United States is the most likely supplier of any advanced fighter jets to Taiwan. But such a sale would be hotly contested by Beijing, which regards the island as a province separated from the mainland by civil war. 
 "Chen may be trying to smoke out the United States and have some sort of bidding war on reassurances from both candidates," said Jonathan Pollack, a China specialist at the Rand Corporation in California.
Support for Taiwan is always an emotional issue in the United States, but this year it became particularly so with Mr. Chen's election, which drew threats of war from Beijing. China distrusts Mr. Chen because of his past support for Taiwan's formal independence from the mainland.
In the midst of the 1992 presidential campaign, President Bush decided to sell Taiwan 150 advanced F-16 fighter aircraft after it became clear that China had bought advanced Sukhoi-27 fighters from Russia. The F-16 sale, the last major American arms sale to Taiwan, infuriated Beijing and complicated already difficult relations between the United States and China.
Under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, the United States is obligated to help Taiwan maintain its defenses. But in a 1982 joint communique with Beijing, Washington pledged not to increase the quantity or quality of arms sold to Taiwan.
More recently, though, China has ordered as many as 40 advanced Sukhoi-30 fighters from Russia as part of a steadily growing arms procurement program intended to give China an edge over Taiwan.
One military official here said this week that air force personnel have been told to expect the first of the planes to arrive in China later this year. The Sukhoi-30 is capable of carrying air-to-surface guided anti-ship missiles and has a longer range than the Sukhoi-27.
China has already fielded 48 of the Sukhoi-27 fighters at bases around the country and first deployed them over the Taiwan Strait during war games last year. It has plans to assemble as many as 200 more with help from Russia.
Bates Gill, a military expert at the Brookings Institution, said it is natural that the reports of Sukhoi-30 purchases from Russia should inspire Taiwan's air force to look for a next generation aircraft itself.
"Given the aging of the F-16 and the lead times needed to get next-generation aircraft in fighting shape, these decisions need to be made within the next three to five years at the latest," said Mr. Gill.
Other analysts said Mr. Chen may simply be raising the issue generally to put the next American administration on notice that the shopping list will be longer than usual when the island makes its annual arms purchase requests in the spring.
For the time being, Taiwan enjoys clear air superiority over the 100-mile-wide body of water separating the island from the mainland, thanks to its F-16's and 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 fighters.
While China has the largest air force in the world with about 6,000 planes, nearly half of those date from the 1950's and only a few dozen of the rest are viable machines for modern warfare. Even with its Russian purchases, military analysts say China is a long way from dominating the skies over Taiwan because few of its pilots have received aggressive training in the advanced fighter aircraft. China is believed to have lost several Sukhoi-27 jets in training exercises already and Beijing is reluctant to push harder training for fear of losing more of the expensive planes.
The country also lacks the sophisticated battlefield command technology necessary to deploy its jets effectively. It had hoped to meet that need with help from Israel, which agreed to sell China a Phalcon advanced-warning and air-control system mounted atop a Russian jet. Israel canceled that sale last month in response to American pressure.
But Mr. Chen warned that Taiwan must not be complacent and should start planning for the next generation of fighters. He said Taiwan should look into fighters for 2010 to 2020 and upgrade its weapons systems. China's modernization drive will "dramatically boost the Communist Chinese Air Force's overall air combat capability, seriously affecting the military balance" after 2005, Mr. Chen said today.
The Pentagon evidently concurs. It told Congress in its annual report on the Chinese military this June that "if projected trends continue, the balance of air power across the Taiwan Strait could begin to shift in China's favor" after 2005, unless Taiwan enhances its air power.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Issues Bolstered By Federal Reserve Move

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose yesterday but ended well off their highs of the day after technology stocks recovered from an earlier slide and investors reversed a flight to quality into government securities.
While sliding stock prices early in the session were the main catalyst in lifting Treasury prices, the Federal Reserve also bolstered prices by staging a coupon pass, in which the Fed buys Treasury securities and adds permanent reserves to the banking system. Yesterday the Fed bought maturities ranging from Aug. 15, 2020, through Nov. 15, 2028. 
 The price of the 30-year bond, the onetime benchmark for Treasury rates, rose 11/32, to 107 9/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.74 percent from 5.76 percent on Wednesday. The closely followed 10-year note gained 5/32, to 103 31/32. Its yield dropped to 5.95 percent from 5.97 percent.
The government reported yesterday that factory orders surged 5.5 percent in June, the largest increase since 7.3 percent in July 1991. The report helped to cap Treasury gains. But, excluding a record increase for aircraft and other transportation equipment, orders rose 0.3 percent. The government also revised the gain in June durable goods orders down slightly, to 9.7 percent from the staggering 10 percent reported two weeks ago.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its July nonmanufacturing business index sank to 55.5 in July from 64 in June, while the Labor Department said jobless claims rose to a seasonally adjusted 276,000 in the week ended July 29, slightly less than forecast.
Expectations are that today's July unemployment report will show little job and wage growth, providing the central bank with more information as the Federal Open Market Committee heads toward its next meeting on interest rates on Aug. 22.
"The Federal Reserve is carefully perusing the continual flow of economic statistics in order to determine the best course of action at the upcoming F.O.M.C. meeting," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management. "Using real G.D.P. as a yardstick, the year-over-year trend rate of economic growth now stands at a prodigious 6 percent, so obviously the expectation of a slowdown in the economy's pace is not a particularly heroic assumption."
"What really matters," he continued, "is the extent, timing and sustainability of the slowdown, and most importantly, whether or not an impending slackening of economic growth will be enough to definitively forestall inflationary pressures in the eyes of the Fed."
In this regard, today's July labor market data will play a crucial role. Mr. Fine said that if the numbers were weak, the market would conclude that the Fed was finished raising rates, but if they were strong, the future course would be uncertain.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares End Broadly Higher To Recover From Early Skid

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks pulled out of an early skid and rallied to finish broadly higher yesterday, with the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index posting a hefty 2.8 percent gain after being down as much as 3.8 percent in the first half hour.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and Dow Jones industrial average traced similar but less pronounced patterns. 
 Analysts attributed the sharp reversal to a combination of bargain-hunting, Motorola's denial of a report that it had cut its estimate of cellular telephone production and a surge of confidence that the government's monthly report on jobs and pay, to be released this morning, would make the Federal Reserve less likely to raise short-term interest rates when it meets on Aug. 22.
"Money is still searching for technological investment," said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment officer at State Street Advisors in Boston. He cautioned, however, that the Federal Reserve will sooner or later succeed in curbing economic growth and that when it does, high-technology businesses will be hurt as well as traditional, more cyclical, companies.
Semiconductor stocks were under particular selling pressure yesterday morning after Kulicke & Soffa, a top maker of equipment for assembling chips, warned of deferred orders. Its shares slumped to 13 9/16 and recovered only to 16 5/8, down 5 1/2. Credence Systems was among other industry losers, falling 9 49/64, to 39.
But other technology stocks regained all their lost ground and then some, with Cisco Systems, the most highly valued company after General Electric, slipping to 58 1/2 before rallying to close at 64 3/8, up 3 7/16. Cisco is to report its quarterly results on Tuesday.
The Nasdaq composite index ended the day with a gain of 101.42 points, at 3,759.88. This shrank its loss so far this year to 7.6 percent.
The S.& P. 500 advanced 13.86 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,452.56, paced by Cisco, Oracle, Intel, Sun Microsystems, EMC and Nortel Networks.
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, many of whose components have been recent havens for investors fleeing technology, rose 19.05 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,706.58. The Dow is down 6.9 percent so far this year.
Banks and brokerage firm stocks joined technology among the day's biggest winning sectors. J. P. Morgan, up 3, to 135, was the best-performing Dow stock, accounting for 17 points of the 19-point rise in the blue-chip average.
Clorox reported a big profit gain but cautioned about prospects and its stock slipped 3 11/16, to 39 11/16.
Gap's profits disappointed Wall Street and the shares fell 7 11/16, to 30 1/4.
But Viacom beat expectations and rose 2 3/16, to 71 9/16, while Disney, reporting after the 4 p.m. close of the market, gained 2 points in late trading. The UnitedHealth Group also gained after reporting results. It closed regular trading at 84 15/16, up 15/16.
Motorola, which changed hands for as little as 33 1/2, ended at 36 1/8, down 11/16, while AT&T touched a 52-week low before finishing at 30 9/16, down 1/2.
Hilton Hotels eased 1/2, to 9 9/16, after announcing higher second-quarter profits.
Joseph Battipaglia, chief market strategist at Gruntal, was among analysts saying the Federal Reserve can still refrain from raising rates at this month's meeting despite mixed evidence that the economy's blistering pace has appreciably slackened. He predicted it would decide that the series of six increases since mid-1999 "is all we have to do for now."
Joe Sundeman, an analyst at Schaeffer's Investment Research, said that the market had rallied sharply on recent job reports that suggested inflation remained largely in check.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose yesterday to 1.1 billion shares from 994.6 million as 74 issues made new highs, compared with 57 new lows. But declines outnumbered advancing issues by 1,545 to 1,338, roughly reversing Wednesday's performance.
Nasdaq turnover was 1.83 billion shares.

HEADLINE: Citrus Canker War Fought Yard by Yard

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 3

 BODY:
For 40 years, more than half her life, Kitty Field nurtured her trees. There was one orange, one lime, one grapefruit, and the blossoms and fruit filled the yard with fragrance and color. It just looked like Florida somehow, and she and her husband, Ernest, grew old under their leaves.
"The leaves are green," Mrs. Field said. "The fruit is perfect." 
 What could be more harmless, she wonders, than her tiny grove?
But recently, state inspectors searching for the dreaded citrus canker disease came into the Fields' yard in North Miami Beach and painted a red "X" on all three trees, marking them for destruction.
"These trees are like our children," Mrs. Field said. "We have watched them grow."
Hundreds of thousands of citrus trees, mostly in commercial groves, in South Florida have already been chopped down to stop the spread of canker, a disease that threatens Florida's citrus industry, which is second only to tourism in the money it takes in. But it is the house-by-house eradication of the canker that seems to be causing the most pain.
Most people, like Catalina Leal, 86, of Miami and Elvia Perez, 69, of Hialeah, only wept in their yards as Florida Department of Agriculture workers chopped down old citrus trees. But others are more determined. Five times this year, South Floridians met state inspectors with guns or threats of guns.
The most recent was on Tuesday. The police said Carl E. Lawson, 62, fired his shotgun after two state inspectors approached his home. No one was hurt, but Mr. Lawson was charged with two counts of attempted murder.
The saddest case came in March, in the city of Tamarac in Broward County. State inspectors had already chopped down three of 95-year-old Nelson Edwards's grapefruit trees.
When they came for the last one, Mr. Edwards, who can barely see and does not hear well, came to his door with a rifle. It was not loaded, but he worked the rifle's bolt, once, anyway, to try and scare them off.
"I'm just an old man," said Mr. Edwards, when he was asked why he did that.
It did not save his tree.
"It's history," he said. "It's gone."
Such cases are an extreme. Most people here fire off letters, instead. "We have written our political representatives," Mrs. Field said. "We will do what is necessary to keep our trees."
But yard by yard through South Florida, where citrus trees had stood for decades, there are just stumps now. "They gave me shade," Mrs. Perez said of her trees. "They gave me happiness. Every morning, I would throw the leftover coffee grounds around the trees. Now, I just throw it in the garbage."
There have been three outbreaks of canker in Florida since 1913, and the most recent was detected in 1995. "That one tree has spread to 700,000," said Richard Miranda, public information director for the state's Citrus Canker Eradication Program.
When state inspectors find a tree with canker, they condemn all trees within 1,900 feet. Trees that show no signs of the disease still must be destroyed.
The state offers $100 to compensate the owners of the trees, to help offset the costs of planting new trees.
But what good will it do, some of the elderly homeowners ask, to plant a new twig in the ground this late in their lives? It will be years before the trees bear fruit, and decades before they grow tall and full enough to provide shade.
For people in their 70's and 80's, what good is that?
"For them to plant a new tree now won't help them much," Mr. Miranda conceded. But, he said, "if it actually gets into the groves, it can be crippling to the economy of the state."
Canker manifests itself on the fruit in raised, brown, corky lesions, surrounded by yellow rings. It attacks the immune system of a tree the same way that H.I.V. affects humans and eventually kills the tree.
While those whose trees have signs of the disease hate to see them chopped down, those whose apparently healthy trees are within the 1,900-foot kill zone are livid.
"The ones that were sick were next door, not mine," Mrs. Perez said. "My daughter tells me, 'Mami, get over it, it's just plants,' but I can't."
Mrs. Leal planted her trees, oranges and other citrus, 23 years ago. She pruned them with a machete, and used boards studded with nails to keep cats off them.
There was nothing she could do to keep the inspectors away, though she let them know how it hurt her.
"I cried in front of them, because I felt very bad," Mrs. Leal said. "But they went ahead and cut them down anyway. I figured I'd have to let them because they're the government."
She cannot get used to the sight of the stumps. Her trees were so giving, she said, of fruit, of shade. "I grew to love them."
The thing that some here will miss most is the simple act of reaching up and plucking a fresh orange or grapefruit or lime, and the taste -- as different from a store-bought fruit as a made-from-scratch meal is from a microwave dinner.
"In the mornings, we put on a pair of slippers and go out to pick oranges, and have them for breakfast," said Gil Muratori, 61, a pharmaceutical sales manager in Miami whose trees are under the state's death sentence.
It is part of being in Florida, of being Floridian. Chopping them up, to many people here, is as wrong as setting fire to a flamingo.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bessemer Trust to Acquire Two Units of a Rival Firm
Bessemer Trust, one of the oldest firms in the business of managing money for wealthy families, will announce today that it is buying the private client and institutional equity groups of a rival, Brundage, Story & Rose. 
 Terms of the deal were not disclosed. But executives said the deal would add $4.5 billion in assets under management and about 800 clients to Bessemer, which has $33 billion under management and 1,300 clients. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is buying Brundage, Story's institutional fixed-income division. Page C2.
 
Spirit of Silicon Valley Lives in China
Zhongguancun, a chaotic Beijing neighborhood, is both the site of some of China's best universities and the government's designated high-technology industrial zone -- its Silicon Valley -- where there are 500 to 600 recent home-grown Internet start-ups. A1.
 
Walt Disney Profit Increases 48%
Walt Disney reported a 48 percent rise in third-quarter profit, citing strong advertising sales at its ABC television network. The strong advertising market, buoyed by hit show "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," kept Disney well ahead of Wall Street's expectations. Before Disney announced its results, its shares closed at $42.3125, up $2.1875. C6.
 
 
Viacom said second-quarter profit fell because of good-will expenses for its purchase of CBS, but the results still beat expectations. C6.
 
Stocks Reverse Slide and Close Up
Stocks pulled out of an early skid and rallied to finish broadly higher. The Nasdaq composite index gained 101.42 points, or 2.8 percent, to 3,759.88. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 19.05 points, to 10,706.58, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.86 points, or 1 percent, to 1,452.56. C6.
 
Tom Clancy Defects to Michael Ovitz
In another sign of Michael Ovitz's return to power as a Hollywood deal maker, Mr. Ovitz has persuaded the thriller writer Tom Clancy to defect from his longtime agent, Robert Gottlieb at the William Morris Agency. C4.
 
No Gene-Altered Food for Novartis
Novartis, one of the world's leading agricultural biotechnology companies, said that it had eliminated genetically engineered ingredients from all of its food products. C4.
 
Rival Emerges to N.T.T. in Japan
Japan Telecom, one of this nation's largest telecommunications companies, plans to offer local phone service, which would put it into direct competition with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the former government phone monopoly. Haruo Murakami, president of Japan Telecom, said that his company had applied to N.T.T. for the right to tap into its local network. Japan Telecom could offer the new service in 2001. C3.
 
Law Firm Mergers Cross Borders
Pushed by globalization and a boom in corporate law involving mergers and acquisitions, law firms in Europe are undergoing combinations of their own. The changes are also affecting law firms in the United States, as links are forged across the Atlantic. C3.
 
Group Invests in Supercomputer
The National Science Foundation said it had made a $45 million award to the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center to buy from Compaq what the computer maker says will be the world's fastest nonmilitary supercomputer when it is completely installed next year. C5.
 
Retail Sales Gained 3.7% in July
Sales in stores open more than a year, a crucial figure for measuring the health of the retail industry, rose 3.7 percent in July. C18.

HEADLINE: Russians Join U.S. to Seek New Sanctions On Taliban

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
The United States and Russia have agreed to work together to draft and win support for expanded sanctions against Afghanistan, officials said today. The cooperation aims to force the ruling Taliban to end support of Islamic terrorists, the officials said.
The pledge to expand United Nations sanctions against the Taliban, who control about 85 percent of Afghanistan, was among several measures endorsed in principle by a senior working group of American and Russian officials after two days of talks in Washington. 
 According to a statement issued by the State Department, the talks focused not only on stemming the threat of terrorism emanating from Afghanistan and the Taliban's promotion of the production and trafficking of drugs but also on ways of creating "conditions for Afghans to establish a broad-based government for their country."
While the statement did not provide details of the "further measures" that Moscow and Washington have endorsed, one American official said that diplomats of both countries favored what he called "smart" sanctions. That is a term for actions that could be directed against leaders and their entourages rather than against Afghanistan's beleaguered civilians.
The official said that these were likely to include a ban on most international trade outside areas like food and medicines, air traffic to Afghanistan and perhaps an arms embargo.
Last October, the United Nations Security Council, led by Russia and the United States, passed a resolution demanding that the Taliban stop providing refuge to terrorists and that they expel Osama bin Laden so that he could stand trial on terrorism charges stemming from his alleged planning of the bomb attacks that destroyed two American embassies in Africa in 1998.
The resolution's sanctions, which took effect last November, curtailed international flights by the national airline, Ariana, and froze Taliban assets abroad until Mr. bin Laden and one of his chief aides were turned over.
The Taliban have refused to expel Mr. bin Laden, who supported their successful effort to expel Soviet forces in the 1980's. But Taliban officials in New York and Islamabad say that he is being closely monitored, is not permitted to give interviews and no longer poses a threat.
American diplomats said that Russian support of expanded sanctions is important to their winning acceptance within the Security Council, which is increasingly reluctant to impose sanctions that punish civilians for the misdeeds of their rulers.
While Moscow and Washington disagree on the administration's endorsement of a missile-defense scheme for America and many other issues, they have found common ground in the need to curb terrorism fomented by militant Islamic groups in South Asia. While the administration is trying to stop Mr. bin Laden from planning and financing terror aimed at Americans, both in the United States and abroad, Russia wants to stop the Taliban from supporting Muslim militants fighting Russian forces in Chechnya and from destabilizing neighboring states in Central Asia.
The talks this week grew out of a summit meeting in Moscow in June between President Clinton and the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin. This week's meeting was led by Thomas R. Pickering, under secretary of state for political affairs, and Vyacheslav Trubnikov, Russia's first deputy foreign minister.

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley's Primal Spirit Lives On, in a Part of Beijing

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
Anyone searching for the soul of China's Silicon Valley can find it here, up four flights of concrete stairs, past walls with peeling paint and ledges strewn with beer bottles, down a darkened hallway and inside what was once the student activity room at Qinghua University Dormitory No. 20.
It is here that a visitor will find the makeshift research and development offices of the fledgling company called Beijing East Doctors Information Technology ("doctors" as in Ph.D.'s, not medical doctors). 
 With the blessing of the administrators at Qinghua, China's leading technical university, six graduate students are sharing their pursuit of a legend borrowed from the opposite side of the Pacific Ocean, in the original Silicon Valley -- the birthplace of companies like Hewlett-Packard and Yahoo, whose roots lie deep in the student life of Stanford University.
As Yang Diange, a 27-year-old computer science student who is the chief executive of Beijing East, put it: "That is our dream -- to be just like a Cisco or a Sun Microsystems."
Like many of the best and brightest technology companies in Silicon Valley, Hewlett-Packard, Sun and Cisco were founded by students, faculty and staff members at Stanford.
Today, Beijing East, which is developing a Web site that will match technology experts with Internet users, is one of perhaps 500 or 600 recent home-grown Internet start-ups in Zhongguancun, a chaotic Beijing neighborhood that is both the site of some of the nation's best universities and the Chinese government's designated high-technology industrial zone.
Zhongguancun, in the Haidian district in northwest Beijing, is home to a fledgling Internet industry as well as better-known Chinese computer and telecommunications companies like Legend Computer Systems, Founder Computer Systems and Huawei Technology.
Although the Internet arrived in China only in 1997, Beijing students, when their experience is measured in "Internet years," have already weathered a boom-and-bust cycle. Many tiny start-ups here have gone out of business since the April decline of the Nasdaq stock market.
For the young founders of Beijing East, however, Zhongguancun is the perfect incubator. Next year the company plans to move off campus and commercialize its Internet computer support Web site.
And though they work half a world away from the world's better-known high-technology mecca, this group of graduate students is in many ways closer to the authentic entrepreneurial spirit that drives Silicon Valley than many of the ersatz Silicon Deserts, Mountains, Glens and Forests, which are most frequently the public relations products of overzealous economic development agencies.
"It has been remarkable to me how similar the entrepreneurial high-tech Chinese are to their American counterparts," said Kai-Fu Lee, an American-educated computer scientist who is director of a research laboratory that Microsoft has established in Zhongguancun.
Despite the oppressive humidity that visits Beijing each summer, the Qinghua students spend 15 to 18 hours a day packed into their dormitory room with six personal computers hooked to their campus network.
So far, the students have drawn no salaries and have raised about $36,000 from friends and family that was spent mostly on computers and the wages paid to some undergraduate students for programming help.
They are now adding the finishing touches to their Web site, which is intended to take advantage of the latest Internet trend, a peer-to-peer service and support network. In their case, it is meant to bring together China's best technology experts with what they hope will be tens of thousands of Internet and PC novices hungry for online help in everything from surfing the Web to questions about both the Windows and Linux operating systems.
Ultimately, Mr. Yang expects the company to need as much as $500,000 to start its business. Despite some concerns about a recent cooling in venture capital investment in China, he foresees no difficulties in raising the funds. Indeed, he feels the group needs to be picky even in choosing its investors.
"It is not very difficult for us to find an investor for our next stage," he said. "But we don't want to cooperate with common investors. We will grow faster with the help of famous investors such as International Data Group, Softbank, CMGI, etc."
Mr. Yang's confidence is echoed by other Zhongguancun start-ups.
"We have venture capitalists coming to our door every week," said Jia En Chen, general manager of eefind .com, a Chinese-language search-engine technology development company in an office park just south of the Qinghua campus.
Like Beijing East, eefind is a clear example of why the Chinese start-ups should be taken seriously.
Both companies have access to sophisticated software technology and bright programmers, and they are operating on a shoestring compared with their Silicon Valley counterparts.
Although eefind's extremely cramped two-room office on the top floor of the 10-story Qinghua Pioneer Park building makes even the most crowded Silicon Valley office or garage look spacious, the company has spent only about $130,000 so far in developing its search engine.
Moreover, eefind.com exemplifies a second significant aspect of the Chinese technology boom. Many entrepreneurs who are founding companies are technologists who are moving here because they see the Internet boom here as real. A sense seems to prevail that in the 21st century the Internet will increasingly be dominated by the Chinese.
Eefind's founder, Ming-Jer Lee, is a computer science graduate student from Taiwan who moved to Beijing to found the company.
"This is where the Internet market will be," he said.
Indeed, the recent growth of the Chinese Internet suggests that he may even be understating the future. July survey statistics reported by the China Internet Network Information Center show that the number of Chinese Internet users has almost doubled, to 16.9 million from 8.9 million, in just seven months. By one estimate, the annual value of e-commerce could pass $1 billion by 2002.
That the Internet is catching hold in urban China can be seen by even a casual visitor to Beijing. Many billboards that bracket the city's freeways now come equipped with Internet addresses.
One of the first American companies to realize that the spirit of the Zhongguancun Internet boom was a resource to be exploited was Microsoft. Nearly two years ago, it set up a research laboratory here and tapped as its director Kai-Fu Lee, who had previously served as a vice president at both Apple Computer and Silicon Graphics, where he worked on voice recognition and 3-D software.
The Microsoft laboratory, now well established, is beginning to contribute to Microsoft products under development. Mr. Lee has recruited a number of American-trained computer experts to lead the laboratory's research teams and has hired leading Chinese scientists, programmers and mathematicians.
Many of his research group leaders are ethnic Chinese who agreed to return from the West, or to move from Taiwan, to build the lab.
In summer, the laboratory, which occupies a single floor of a new office building in the Zhongguancun zone, plays host to 180 student interns who are developing software programs for Microsoft. The laboratory is scheduled to expand to a second floor of the building in August.
Yet, despite his optimism about the potential Chinese technologists, Mr. Lee is still cautious about the possibility that Zhongguancun could rival Silicon Valley for sheer entrepreneurial innovation. In a recent article in People's Daily, he asserted that cultural differences remain.
"I believe the 'real' differences between Silicon Valley and Zhongguancun are: culture, different types of talent, different definitions of innovation, different types of venture capital and different involvement of academic institutions," he wrote.
Silicon Valley has evolved a culture that is tuned to market-driven innovation, Mr. Lee noted, while in China, innovation is still largely driven by technology.
He also wrote that venture capital is not playing the same role in China that it plays in Silicon Valley, where investors are frequently an integral part of a company's day-to-day operations. Things are changing in China, but until recently investors had been used only as a source of financing.
There may be another crucial difference as well. Despite an intensifying housing shortage, highway traffic problems and declining quality of life in Silicon Valley, it still seems like an earthly paradise compared with the rapidly industrializing Beijing, with its chronic pollution.
At a recent lunchtime meeting at the Microsoft lab here, a visitor asked seven of the American-trained computer experts recruited by Mr. Lee what they missed most about the United States. In unison the group answered, "Fresh air!"

HEADLINE: Bessemer Trust to Add Key Businesses of Rival

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
One of the oldest firms in the business of managing money for wealthy families, the Bessemer Trust Company, will announce today that it is buying the private-client and institutional-equity groups of a rival, Brundage, Story & Rose, executives of the firms said yesterday.
Neither of the firms, which are privately held, would disclose the terms of the deal. But executives of the firms said the deal would add $4.5 billion in assets under management and about 800 clients to Bessemer, which has $33 billion under management and 1,300 clients. 
 Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said yesterday that it was buying the other of Brundage, Story's three units, its institutional fixed-income division with $3.3 billion in assets under management. The terms of that deal were also not disclosed.
With the transactions, the Brundage name will disappear from Wall Street 68 years after the firm was founded.
"This transaction is significant in that it allows Bessemer to gain size and scale," said Henry McVey, a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst.
"The reality," he said, "is that many of the large commercial and investment banks are now pushing into this market, and the independent players need to bulk up."
In January, Charles Schwab & Company said it would buy the U.S. Trust Company, and just last month Alliance Capital Management, which is controlled by the French financial services holding company AXA Group, bought Sanford C. Bernstein.
Guy Moszkowski, a financial analyst at Salomon Smith Barney said, "This is another manifestation of the need to be at a certain minimum scale to maximize your economics in an environment where more technology investment is needed every day."
Francis S. Branin, the chief executive of Brundage, Story, acknowledged that size was an issue. "We felt that longer term, it was probably going to be more and more difficult for medium-size firms like ours to compete across a broad range of services," he said.
Besides investing its clients' money in blue-chip stocks like General Electric, Intel and Home Depot, Bessemer also offers investments in leveraged buyouts, venture capital and real estate limited partnership funds. It also provides estate- and tax-planning services.
"Wealthy individuals want the services Bessemer has," said Mr. Branin, who will join the larger firm along with seven partners. Apart from managing the affairs of his former clients, Mr. Branin said, his position, and those of his old partners, in Bessemer have not been determined.
For Bessemer, the transaction was "an opportunity for us to add some very talented private-client services and investment professionals," said Donald J. Herrema, the chief executive of the larger firm.
Business has been booming at Bessemer, and it needed more employees quickly. Its assets under management have more than tripled over the last five years.
Bessemer was founded in 1907 as the family office of Henry Phipps, a partner of Andrew Carnegie in the Carnegie Steel Company. Its purpose was to invest the $50 million Mr. Phipps received in the sale of the steel business to J. P. Morgan. In 1974, the family decided to take on outside clients.
Bessemer added Miami to its New York and Palm Beach offices in 1981 and now does business in eight cities. It opened an Atlanta office last year and expects to open one in Silicon Valley in the next few months.
The minimum investment with Bessemer is $5 million. The average client's portfolio is worth $22 million, executives said, and there are several dozen with investments of more than $100 million. Brundage, Story's minimum was $1 million and the average portfolio was worth $5 million to $10 million.

HEADLINE: Study Backs Freight-Train Tunnel in New York Harbor

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A proposed rail-freight tunnel under New York Harbor that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has adopted as a favored project would cost up to $2.3 billion but would pay for itself through increased business along a revitalized Brooklyn waterfront, according to a city study.
The two-year study by the New York City Economic Development Corporation recommends that a tunnel be built connecting Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and either Staten Island or Jersey City, linking New York to the existing rail-freight network in the rest of the country. 
 The report also says that a harbor tunnel could reduce the number of large commercial trucks that enter New York City -- mainly over the George Washington and Verrazano-Narrows Bridges -- by almost a million a year.
Since such a huge project would take at least a decade to complete, the report suggests that barges be used to carry freight across the harbor to and from Brooklyn in the interim.
The report was completed in May, but it has been released only to technical advisers and elected officials.
Mayor Giuliani has been urging the construction of a tunnel under the harbor for years, and the idea has been around since the 1920's. Critics say the tunnel is too expensive and faces huge hurdles because of its cost and the layers of review by the federal and state agencies responsible for New York Harbor.
But the report by the Economic Development Corporation supports the project. "This two-year study confirms that a new, direct rail-freight link would have dramatic positive impacts," it concludes.
The proposal faces difficult political hurdles not directly addressed by the report. Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls how federal aid for transportation projects is parceled out around the state, said in January that he would not join Mayor Giuliani in pushing for a harbor tunnel until seeing the results of the city study.
Yesterday, Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the governor, said Mr. Pataki was "still reviewing the findings" and would not comment.
Supporters of the project say it would also hinge on the support of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which controls the shipping terminals in the harbor and the bridges that carry most truck traffic into the city. One recommendation in the report on financing a tunnel is for the Port Authority to impose a 35 percent surcharge on the tolls now charged commercial trucks coming into the city.
"Until we finish reviewing the whole report, we can't offer any conclusions," said Steven Coleman, a Port Authority spokesman.
Despite its detailed analysis of projected benefits, the city's report did not alter skepticism from some experts in transportation and economic development, who said a rail tunnel might be outmoded by the time it was built. They pointed to the heavy demand by freight carriers for existing railroad tracks in New Jersey and elsewhere, which may not leave enough room to divert much of the cargo now trucked to and from the city.
"You are making a very large bet on what the freight market will be like 10 to 15 years down the road, and if you guess wrong, you blow the money," said Hugh O'Neill, an economic consultant and co-author of a New York University report in December that argued against Mayor Giuliani's proposal for the tunnel.
Aides to the mayor, who has not discussed the report publicly and was attending the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia yesterday, said that the report remained under review at City Hall.
"We are reviewing it with an eye toward what would be best for the city," said Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the Economic Development Corporation, whose president, Michael Carey, declined to be interviewed.
But the report, paid for by a $3 million federal grant and $2 million from the city, seemed likely to encourage the elected officials, urban planners and others who staunchly back the tunnel project.
"This gives real substance and real empirical evidence" to the benefits of the project, said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, who has long been a proponent of a harbor tunnel as a means of reducing truck traffic and providing rail access to the Brooklyn waterfront.
He envisions the tunnel as a link to a re-energized port terminal in Sunset Park, with the deep water off the Brooklyn waterfront enabling the terminal to be used by a new generation of deep-draft cargo vessels that cannot navigate the shallower channels leading to ports on Staten Island and in New Jersey.
The two-year study, which the city said incorporated detailed analyses by several engineering firms, focused on two paths for the proposed tunnel, each linked to the little-used 65th Street freight yard in Bay Ridge. From there, the tunnel would be dug under the harbor to freight-rail links on Staten Island or in Jersey City. In either case, a tunnel would provide connections to the national freight-rail network.
Cost estimates in the study are provided for tunnels wide enough to accommodate one track or two. They range from $1.4 billion to $2.3 billion.
The cost projections include work that would be required to heighten overpasses and upgrade idle rail tracks in the city, enabling trains to travel from Bay Ridge to the Bronx or to make a connection to Long Island.
The report projected the cost of a new system of freight-carrying barges, which could cross the harbor from several docks in Brooklyn and New Jersey and on Staten Island, at $150 million.
Cargo handling by barge was common in New York Harbor until the early 1960's, but has since all but died away. The report said a new system was necessary as an "essential building block" to foster economic activity until the proposed tunnel was built.
While offering no direct recommendation on financing the project, the study said alternatives in which private investment paid the bulk of the cost should be explored. It said freight carriers would be charged a fee to use the tunnel and that space could be sold for use by electrical utilities, which would lay cables, or by fiber optics companies.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 718 words

HEADLINE: The Man From Midland

 BODY:
It will be 96 days before Republicans know if Gov. George W. Bush was right to bypass standard G.O.P. ideological fare and center this convention on the twin themes of inclusion and personal testimony. But in his well-crafted, highly autobiographical acceptance speech last night, Mr. Bush sought to incite a public appetite for change based on a claim of bringing a new style of leadership to the White House. With flashes of wit and biting ridicule, Mr. Bush derided Vice President Al Gore as the risk-averse partner in an administration that "has coasted through prosperity." Ending his embargo on direct attacks, he said: "They had their chance. They have not led. We will." The underlying invitation was for voters to take a leap of faith on the promise that Mr. Bush will develop into a more effective, resolute and likable leader and role model than Mr. Gore.
This presentation of an admittedly late-blooming candidate as a work in progress carries certain risks. Not since Jimmy Carter has there been a presidential candidate to whom the act of introducing himself to the American people -- of making himself known, trusted and familiar as well as simply famous -- was more important. The speech marked the toughest test the new nominee will face before the debates this fall. 
 The irony of Mr. Bush's situation right now is that, despite the renowned father saluted in the speech, he is actually not very well known even to many supporters. He characterized his six-year stint as governor of Texas as one in which he learned to make tough decisions and work with Democrats. But serving in Austin and having many of his father's advisers around him now will probably have less meaning to the voters than Mr. Bush's attempt to define himself as a man from a different political culture than the one he said was epitomized by Mr. Gore and President Clinton.
In raising two previously unmentionable issues, he affirmed opposition to abortion and support for enforcement of existing gun laws. But in vowing fervently to "tear down that wall" that traps the poor and minorities in prisons and failed schools, he fleshed out more of what he has meant by "compassionate conservatism," implying actual delivery on the "kinder and gentler" Republican policies promised some years ago by his father.
Running a campaign for change is complicated by the fact that Americans are satisfied with the economy, and the polls show them broadly supporting the Democrats' approach on budget issues, as well as education, health care and Social Security. The oratorical doorway for Mr. Bush has been to speak from, and about, his heart as a way of suggesting a more expansive governance without really altering the ideological straitjacket that his party requires its nominees to wear.
The glue that is supposed to hold all this together is his promise of personality suited to the office, yet free of historical baggage. In service of that theme, Mr. Bush invoked the values of Midland and boasted that he would come to Washington without inherited enemies and with "no stake in the bitter arguments of the last few years." He asserted that his would be an administration guided by convictions and character rather than polls and focus groups.
A world of difference lies between Mr. Bush and Ronald Reagan, the last G.O.P. nominee to stir the kind of hope among Republicans that could be heard last night. But like Mr. Reagan, Mr. Bush promised that if given a chance he would rise above expectations, and like Mr. Reagan, he is attempting to create a market for change in the summer convention and then cash in this fall. Also like Mr. Reagan, he promised a regime of homespun values in place of the policy sophistication or taste for legislative maneuvering of Mr. Gore.
In reality, this down-home emphasis is sharply at odds with the privileged educational and financial background of Mr. Bush and many of the delegates here -- a condition that has led some to say this ought to be known as the illusion convention instead of the inclusion convention. But Democrats should make no mistake about the themes laid down here or the stump performance of George W. Bush and even that of his running mate, Richard B. Cheney. They represent a considerable danger for Mr. Gore and his party this fall.

PUB-DATE: August 4, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1366 words

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Front and (Very Much) Center

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Close your eyes and Gov. George W. Bush tonight could have been Bill Clinton without the punch -- or Al Gore without the precision.
In fact, in his acceptance speech, the Texas governor and Republican presidential nominee sought to reorient his party to the center with passages that were strikingly similar to Mr. Clinton's speech at the 1992 Democratic convention. 
 His address tonight capped a four-day political production in which Mr. Bush deftly elbowed aside ardent conservatives in an effort to convince America that his party was much like himself -- approachable and open -- and that he is a candidate who can be trusted to safely lead the nation.
It was an ambitious attempt at re-introducing the Republican Party, akin to Richard M. Nixon's drive in 1968 to transform the once solid Democratic South into a Republican stronghold, or Ronald Reagan's "Morning in America" campaign for middle Americans in 1984.
By stressing "idealism and inclusion" and the "forgotten," Mr. Bush sought to give a gracious new twist to the Grand Old Party, moving beyond the battles over impeachment, abortion and culture that had given his party such a harsh face. Rather than invoke Newt Gingrich, Mr. Bush spoke of "a bipartisan approach to governing."
"I don't have enemies to fight," he declared. "And I have no stake in the bitter arguments of the last few years. I want to change the tone of Washington to one of civility and respect."
Even Democrats conceded that Mr. Bush had mounted an impressive start in setting out a general election campaign that excises the demons that have haunted Republicans by offering a nominee who often sounds very much like his foes.
And already, many Democrats expressed fear that the display here will force Vice President Gore -- whose campaign is entering a crucial phase with the selection of a running mate and then his own convention in Los Angeles -- to aggressively fire back and depict the convention as a masquerade that obscured the party's platform and rigidly rightward voting records.
"Hundreds of jaws are dropping of Democratic members of Congress around the country who are hearing of a Republican commitment to their building of schools, hiring of teachers, commitment to the environment and diversity of government," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey.
Will it work? "It has been skillfully done," Mr. Torricelli said. "The Republicans have succeeded in projecting an image that is not only at total variance with their record but in contradiction of their own platform."
That may be exactly what the Bush campaign wants. The calculation -- or at least the hope -- among Republicans is that they will box Mr. Gore in: The more he tries to portray his opponents as insincere the more the vice president risks appearing mean-spirited and political. That is an important reason that Mr. Gore foundered when he tried to lambasteMr. Bush after the primaries.
And that helps explain why a relentlessly upbeat Mr. Bush managed to topple a popular -- and increasingly defensive -- Gov. Ann Richards in 1994. "The axis upon which a lot of this turns is Bush's experience against Ann Richards," said Richard N. Bond, a former chairman of the Republican Party. "She got shriller and shriller and shriller -- and less believable. That's the experience in which Bush has based his strategy for this campaign and this convention.
In this most formal moment for a determinedly informal man, Mr. Bush allowed as to how he possessed the qualities to reach beyond his own party and unite the nation. He tried to make this most political of speeches appear decidedly apolitical.
"Now is the time," Mr. Bush said, "for Republicans and Democrats to end the politics of fear and save Social Security, together."
Beyond echoing Mr. Clinton, Mr. Bush went so far as to laud the president -- even as he was skewering him. "Our current president embodied the potential of a generation," he said. "So many talents. So much charm. Such great skill. But in the end, to what end?"
As did Mr. Clinton in his acceptance speech eight years ago, Mr. Bush trumpeted themes of compassion and inclusion as he sought to appeal well beyond the Republicans in the hall.
Tonight, Mr. Bush said that when he was growing up in Midland, Tex., "our sense of community was just as strong as that sense of promise." It was from the playbook of Mr. Clinton, who said in 1992, "We can restore our sense of unity and community."
And tonight, Mr. Bush said, "Each of us is responsible to love and guide our children, and help a neighbor in need." It was an echo of Mr. Clinton, who implored his audience eight years ago, "take responsibility for your children."
Beyond that his opponent sounds like a Democrat, there are other complications for Mr. Gore.
Mr. Bush had the enviable luxury of neglecting conservatives -- and reaching out to independents and even Democrats -- because Republicans of all stripes have eagerly embraced his candidacy. But in addition to competing with Mr. Bush for the swing voters, Mr. Gore at his convention will have to tend to restive Democrats who are not altogether content with their candidate.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said Mr. Gore faces a more perilous balancing act than Mr. Bush. "He's got a more difficult line to walk," Mr. Breaux said. "Our job is to make sure the base is comfortable and secure -- but be very aggressive in speaking to the moderate middle."
Mr. Gore also has to contend with the shadow of Bill Clinton.
In an interview on the eve of the convention, Mr. Bush went out of his way to say that there was little need to demonize Mr. Clinton. "The opponent is not President Clinton," he said. "The opponent is Vice President Gore."
Yet Mr. Clinton has been a subtext here all week. It started when Mr. Bush's wife, Laura, voiced the need for people "to respect the president of the United States of America." And tonight, Mr. Bush, by underscoring that "times of plenty" are "tests of American character," the governor left no doubt that he regards Mr. Clinton as a tantalizing villain -- and will truly (albeit subtly) try to make him an issue in this campaign.
To further complicate matters, Mr. Gore also has an interest in seeing Mr. Clinton hover over this campaign. While Mr. Bush's loyalists will try to remind voters of Monica S. Lewinsky, Mr. Gore's will trot out Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary who helped the Clinton-Gore administration preside over the most sustained economic recovery in American history.
While there was a dash of Mr. Clinton in Mr. Bush's address tonight, the Texas governor also capitalized on his opportunity to reach the largest audience that will likely hear him give a speech in this campaign to ply his charm on the public.
Republicans said they were confident that their thoroughly unobjectionable, even warm-hearted, message was carried enough on the news to penetrate the hall, even though most of the proceedings were not even carried by the network.
Mr. Bush's objective tonight was not entirely different from that of Ronald Reagan, who at his convention in Detroit in 1980 sought to convince Americans that beyond his affability, he was up to being commander in chief. Tonight, Mr. Bush remembered "Ronald Reagan's optimism" and -- not to neglect Democrats -- "Harry Truman's integrity."
The thinking of Bush operatives is that if Mr. Bush, like Mr. Reagan, puts to rest worries about his capacity to be president, and reassures moderates that he feels their pain, he can gain the edge by trumping Mr. Gore in the likability category.
"This is all about George Bush being, in essence, not a bad person and a well-meaning person," said William M. Daley, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman. "Therefore he will do what's right and trust me. There's got to be more to it than that."
Mr. Breaux put it this way, "This cannot be a popularity contest."
Republicans do not see it that way. To them, it is all about presenting a likable, inclusive candidate and a likable, inclusive party.
Perhaps they should update Mr. Reagan's wildly successful slogan from 1984, "It's Morning Again in America." Again.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
First Formal Charges Are Filed Against Suharto
Former President Suharto was charged with corruption during his 32 years in power in Indonesia. The charge involves only a small part of the corruption imputed to him, but illustrates the effort to overhaul the economy and political system. A6 

Sri Lanka Constitution Proposal
The governing coalition proposed in Parliament that a new Constitution be adopted to give greater political autonomy to the minority Tamil population, in an effort to help end the long war waged by separatist rebels for a Tamil homeland. Opposition members booed the president as she introduced the document. A4
 
Patent Shared to Fight Hunger
Monsanto, an agricultural biotechnology firm, said that it would make patent rights to genetically altered rice available in an effort to stave off malnutrition in poor nations. A11
 
Taiwan Warning on Jets
President Chen Shui-bian said Taiwan should begin considering new fighter aircraft purchases, warning that in five years China could threaten Taiwan's ability to control the skies over the Taiwan Strait. A6
 
Hong Kong Fire Arrests
The police arrested 15 immigrants in connection with a fire set in a city immigration tower by mainland immigrants whose requests for residency permits had been denied. Hong Kong officials also said they would immediately deport 1,000 mainlanders. A6
 
Barak and Mubarak Meet
Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel met in Alexandria with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to discuss peace negotiations with the Palestinians. Mr. Mubarak met with Yasir Arafat on Wednesday. A3
 
Canadians Board Ship
Canadian troops swung down from a helicopter to board an American merchant ship that for almost three weeks had held hostage on the high seas three Canadian soldiers and 10 percent of Canada's armored might over nonpayment of a shipping bill. A11

Alaska Air Grounds 18 Planes
Alaska Airlines decided to ground 18 of its MD-80 aircraft, the same model as the plane that crashed off the California coast in January when a part in the tail broke. The airline found that a measurement tool was producing inconsistent results. A12

Pollution-related beach closings and advisories increased by 50 percent nationwide from 1997 to 1999, an environmental group said. A12

HEADLINE: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "How Taxes Trickle Down," by Charles W. Kadlec (Op-Ed, Aug. 1): The classic division between Republicans and Democrats rests in the delicate balance between the benefits of social programs and the burden of taxes. In Mr. Kadlec's model, however, tax dollars simply disappear and wealth is equated purely with cash on hand. Any economic model that ignores Social Security, Medicare and education bodes ill for lower- and middle-class Americans.
 
GREGORY STROUD
Urbana, Ill., Aug. 1, 2000
