HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Major Market Indexes Rise On Slower Job Growth Data
After an early morning decline, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 61.17 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,767.75. The Dow is down 6.3 percent so far this year. Other markets also rose with the Nasdaq composite index rising 27.48 points, or 0.7 percent, to 3,787.36 and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbing 10.37 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,462.93. 
 Stocks ended higher after the Department of Labor reported that private job growth had been slower than expected last month. The data appears to make an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve later this month less likely. Page C3.
 
Aetna Reports 17% Drop in Profits
Aetna, the nation's largest health insurer, reported a 17 percent decrease in second-quarter profits as more people sought increasingly costlier treatment. But it said it was moving along on sweeping changes aimed at improving business. C2.
 
8 Wall St. Firms Settle Charges
Banc One Capital Markets and seven other securities dealers have agreed to pay a total of $13.5 million to settle the latest federal case accusing firms of overcharging municipalities for Treasury securities in a practice known as yield burning. C2.
 
Unilever to Split Into 2 Divisions
Unilever, the global consumer goods giant that has been on a buying spree in the United States, announced a major reorganization of top management. The move would reorganize the company into two divisions, one focused on food brands like Lipton Tea and Ragu spaghetti sauce and the other on consumer products like Dove soap and Elizabeth Arden cosmetics. The news revived speculation that the company planned a full split in two. C2.
 
N.Y.S.E. Sues Online Impersonators
The New York Stock Exchange filed a lawsuit against 10 unidentified people on charges of impersonating its chairman and chief executive, Richard A. Grasso, on a popular Internet message board. In the suit, lodged in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the exchange contends that the John Does, using aliases like RichAGrasso, impersonated Mr. Grasso on the Ragingbull.com Web site. C14.
 
Role Seems to Remain for Concorde
The July 25 crash of the Air France supersonic Concorde brought down a plane that by common measurements can hardly be profitable, given its high maintenance costs, daunting fuel bills, little passenger space and no cargo. Yet any decision to ground the Concorde permanently could have deep financial implications for Air France and British Airways, the two airlines that run it. Its loss would divert high-end corporate travelers to other airlines, notably in the United States, or to corporate jet travel. C2.
 
Alcoa in Deal to Expand in Europe
Alcoa said it had bought Baco Consumer Products of London for an undisclosed price to increase its sale of household plastic wrap and aluminum foil in Europe. The company is Britain's biggest seller of aluminum foil and plastic bags. C3.
 
Rio Tinto Wins Battle for North
Anglo American ended its bid to acquire North, the Australian mining company that is one of the world's biggest producers of iron ore. A rival, Rio Tinto, countered Anglo American's $1.8 billion bid with one that was 11 percent higher. C2.
 
G.E. to Get Air Force Contract
Lockheed Martin said it had selected General Electric to provide engines for an updated version of its Galaxy transport aircraft for the Air Force, a contract that could be valued at up to $2.6 billion. C4.

HEADLINE: With Phone Strike Near, A New Offer

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Verizon Communications, the nation's largest wireless and local phone company, moved yesterday to avoid a strike by more than 86,000 telephone workers from Maine to Virginia by submitting a proposal addressing some of its unions' main contract concerns.
Still, the possibility of a walkout may have increased after Verizon skirted other important issues like union organizing attempts among its wireless work force, the contracting out of some labor, and the loss or migration of jobs as a result of mergers in the last several years. 
 Unless the company and the unions agree on issues by 12:01 a.m. Sunday or extend discussions, leaders of 72,000 members of the Communications Workers of America and 14,700 members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers have promised a walkout at Verizon, the new name of the company formed when Bell Atlantic acquired GTE.
Efforts to win assurances from Verizon that would make it easier to organize employees in the wireless businesses into unions are at the heart of the dispute. Unlike their counterparts in traditional areas of the telecommunications industry, wireless workers are generally not union members.
Only a few dozen of the 32,000 employees in Verizon's wireless division are unionized, compared with nearly 80 percent of the 120,000 employees in the local phone operations. Labor leaders are concerned that the wireless division is growing much faster than the rest of the company.
If the unions do strike, the telephone network would probably not be disrupted, the company says. But about 25 million businesses and households in the East could be inconvenienced by delays in requests to repair or install phone service, make operator-assisted calls and have questions answered about phone bills.
Emergency services like 911 would not be disrupted in the event of a walkout, according to Verizon officials. The company also said it would give priority to communications for hospitals and other health care operations. It said it did not yet know if it would create hot lines or special telephone numbers for customers inconvenienced by any work stoppage.
Seeking to prevent a strike, Verizon made its proposal yesterday morning addressing wages, pensions and job security. Representatives from the two unions and Verizon discussed the proposal at length in Washington.
Under the proposal, Verizon would increase wages by 3 to 4 percent a year for union employees, improve pension plans for active workers and offer some job security, according to Eric Rabe, a spokesman for Verizon. The details about job security, though, were not clear last night.
In addition, the company plans to offer increased funds for day care programs, improved medical benefits for new employees and an adoption reimbursement.
But, according to the communications workers union, the proposal did not address concerns about forced overtime, the movement of work locations as a result of the merger, or the contracting out of some services to nonunion companies in areas including the installation of high-speed Internet lines.
"Because the company would rather farm out work," said Ed McGowan, a Verizon employee who installs digital service lines in Midtown Manhattan, "this means one company installs the line on the outside of the building, which is us, and another on the inside, which is them. This results in a big headache for the customer, who has to be at home for two days instead of one, and a loss of income to a nonunion company."
Neither side appeared optimistic about the chances of reaching an agreement before the strike deadline early Sunday, people close to the talks said. The involvement of senior company and union officials in negotiations, which could change their direction, is expected only on Saturday night.
The results of the talks between the unions and Verizon are likely to have repercussions throughout the wireless communications industry. Verizon Wireless, which Verizon owns in an alliance with Vodafone AirTouch of Britain, is the nation's largest wireless company, with 26 million subscribers.
Although the wireless industry is generally not organized into unions, some companies, like SBC Communications and BellSouth, which together operate the nation's second-largest wireless carrier, make organizing efforts easier by allowing employees to join a union if a majority at a given site agree to do so.
"If unions can tap into a key area like wireless," said Stanley Aronowitz, a sociology professor at the City University of New York, "it means much more than simple wage increases or better pensions. This is about questioning who benefits from wealth creation in the new economy."
Based on figures before the company became Verizon this spring, Bell Atlantic's wireless division outstripped its traditional land-line operations in generating revenue, according to the communications workers union.
For example, each wireless employee generates $325,000 a year in revenue, or 230 percent more than counterparts in regular telephone operations. And the company's wireless operations generate $532 a year in revenue from each customer, compared with $324 a year for each telephone company customer.
A Verizon spokesman said the company was wary of discussing the organization of its wireless work force into a union because Verizon Wireless operates as a separate company from Verizon Communications.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
The Republicans Call a Cease-Fire on Cities

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
The Republican Party signaled a shift in attitude toward cities when it chose Philadelphia for this week's national convention. The party in recent years has used big urban centers as metaphors of moral decay and examples of faulty Democratic stewardship. But the choice of Philadelphia revealed the G.O.P.'s intent to abandon an anti-urban rhetoric that had proved alienating to moderate suburban voters.
It also reflects a growing awareness among Republicans like Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey that urban centers are crucial to state economies and must be recovered, even if the up-front costs are great. In attempting to rebuild crucial city centers, Mr. Ridge and Mrs. Whitman have both moved beyond the traditional Republican gospel that views local control as sacred and intervention from above as political heresy. 
 The need for strong, state-level intervention has become especially apparent to Governor Ridge, who has been faced with some of the most stubborn redevelopment problems in the country -- not just in Philadelphia, which is rebounding after 40 years of decline, but also in the neighboring city of Chester, an industrial powerhouse in the 1950's and 60's that has gone largely untouched by the recovery and was until recently in danger of becoming a ghost town. I grew up in Chester during the boom years and went back to visit during this week's convention. The city has begun to inch forward, with new roads, housing and infrastructure, but only after heavy, heavy lifting by the state government in Harrisburg.
Chester was the site of William Penn's first landing in the new colony of Pennsylvania in 1682, and became a successful mill town soon afterward. It boomed in the 1940's, when the war-stoked economy spawned steel mills, shipyards, textile mills and a range of heavy industries that made Chester a magnet for the great migration of black people moving into the industrial North from the rural South. Chester's Sun Shipyard employed 40,000 people from around the region, in a city whose population totaled a mere 66,000. But the yard lost roughly 10,000 jobs per decade and then closed in the 1980's, with catastrophic effect on Chester and its surrounding municipalities. Skilled laborers fled as quickly as they could, leaving behind the poor, who turned in great numbers to the drug trade.
The decay was worsened by a corrupt and long-lived Republican machine that brought graft and administrative ineptitude to new lows. The machine's founder was the legendary Republican boss John J. McClure, a natty dresser in a vest and high buttoned shoes whose power in Chester and surrounding Delaware County rivaled Boss Richard Daley's in Chicago. McClure was a Republican kingmaker who helped to choose Pennsylvania governors and to whom even Richard Nixon paid homage as an aspiring president. McClure ruled, through patronage and punishment, from 1930 to his death in 1965.
His successor was Jack Nacrelli, a tough machine politician who led Chester as mayor from 1968 to 1979, when he was convicted of racketeering. He returned from jail to dominate the city into the 1980's. According to a 1991 report from the Pennsylvania State Crime Commission, which investigated organized crime throughout the state, Mr. Nacrelli exercised his most intensive patronage efforts through the school board, which quickly deteriorated.
The Republican machine was impervious to state intervention into the 1990's. But faced with enormous decay, mounting crime and a corrupt school system that has consistently ranked at or near the bottom in the state, Governor Ridge has led state intervention on several fronts. Once Chester was declared in distress, the state took over its fiscal affairs, including economic development, and has overseen everything from rebuilding city sewer systems to housing redevelopment to building new roads to actually buying a building for the Police Department and replacing its rundown cars.
Public housing projects have been torn down and replaced with the first new housing built in the city in decades. Chester has seen the first glimmers of post-industrial business, with one new high-tech park just opened and others on the drawing board.
The hollowed-out school system poses the steepest challenge of all. At the governor's instigation, the legislature has passed a radical new plan that allows the state to dissolve the school system if it wishes, replacing it with a charter system or any other system of its choosing. Results from the new legislation have yet to be seen. But the system is coming under close fiscal scrutiny for the first time in at least 50 years.
The giant cranes over the long-dead shipyard still stand rusting and unmanned, a testament to prosperity gone by. But redevelopment plans are under way for the first time in memory and there are other encouraging signs of revival -- police cars that actually run, sewers that drain the streets, and street signs in vast stretches of the city that had none. The irony of the moment is that the rebuilding effort in this city and others has fallen to Republicans, who have historically shunned this kind of intervention, leaving fallen cities like Chester to the mercy of the market.

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Bowing to the Middle, Keeping to the Right

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4

 BODY:
With his convention speech, Gov. George W. Bush created a synthesis new to Republican politics: conservative policies described in ways that his campaign believes swing voters will love.
So his $1.3 trillion, 10-year tax cut -- more sweeping than Congressional Republicans ever tried to push through -- became an effort to bring "common sense and fairness to the tax code." His plan to divert some Social Security payroll taxes to private investment accounts amounted to giving "American workers security and independence that no politician can ever take away." 
 The language was positively Clintonian, but as many conservatives were quick to note, Mr. Bush had not actually changed any of the Republican Party's core principles -- from its opposition to abortion, to its support for large tax cuts, to its backing of a vast missile defense system, to its search for conservative Supreme Court justices.
"He has packaged the traditional conservative positions with completely new covering," said Marshall Wittmann, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation. "It's not necessarily a new Republicanism in quite the way that Clinton was a new Democrat."
This synthesis is central to Mr. Bush's effort to assemble a winning coalition. The Bush campaign wants to hold its conservative base through its policy proposals, and then pick up the moderate middle through Mr. Bush's conciliatory language and willingness to speak about issues that Democrats long dominated.
The question for the fall campaign is whether Mr. Bush can convincingly keep up his balancing act as the Democrats try to home in on the details of policy proposals and his record back in Texas.
Where Mr. Bush describes a tax cut that helps people at the bottom of the economic ladder, the Democrats see a tax cut that helps the rich. While Mr. Bush promises to strengthen Social Security, the Democrats say he could reduce retirement benefits. For all the time Mr. Bush spent delivering policy addresses this spring, a number of his proposals lack specifics.
And Mr. Bush's record does not always square with his rhetoric. The man who showcased minorities all across his convention is, after all, the same candidate who, when he needed to recover from a defeat in the New Hampshire primaries, began his comeback campaign at a South Carolina university that banned interracial dating.
"An informed voter is their worst nightmare," Douglas Hattaway, a Gore spokesman, said of the Bush campaign. The Democrats have already begun a barrage of ads trying to challenge Mr. Bush's commitment on issues like the environment.
With the Democrats running against the high cost of prescription drugs, Mr. Bush's aides say they are already debating, for example, whether the Texas governor needs to draw up a plan to show how he would pay for prescription drug coverage. In his nomination speech, Mr. Bush said he would "make prescription drugs available and affordable for every senior who needs them."
But he has never said how he would do that and has never devoted a major address to the issue. All he has done is speak approvingly of one bipartisan plan floated in Congress that would allow Medicare recipients to choose a plan with a prescription drug benefit. And when House Republicans passed their own prescription drug plan, Mr. Bush avoided taking a position on it.
Or what about Social Security? On Thursday night, Mr. Bush sought credit for his willingness to take a stand on the issue. And he promised that he would strengthen the program "for the greatest generation and generations to come."
But while he has called for some portion of the Social Security payroll tax to be diverted to individual investment accounts for young workers, he has not said what percentage. And he has been silent on a host of related issues, as well.
He has not said whether he would raise the retirement age. Nor has he specified how much he would reduce the basic Social Security benefit to deal with the diminished payroll tax that would come into the system.
One group of experts at the New Century Foundation, in a study disputed by the Bush campaign, has said that a plan like Mr. Bush's could result in future retirement incomes 20 percent lower than the levels projected under the current Social Security law.
Mr. Bush's tax cut can also be portrayed in different ways. As he always does, Mr. Bush focused on how he would help the people at the bottom of the economic ladder. "On principle, those in the greatest need should receive the greatest help," he said Thursday night. "So we will lower the bottom rate from 15 percent to 10 percent and double the child tax credit."
What he did not say, but the Democrats do, is that like all tax cuts that sweeping, Mr. Bush's plan helps people at the top of the economic ladder the most. The Gore campaign, in a statement, calls Mr. Bush "compassionate for the rich and conservative for everyone else."
In one case on Thursday night, Mr. Bush's language was designed to keep conservatives from becoming alarmed over one area of policy where he is directly breaking with his party's past.
"One size does not fit all when it comes to educating our children," Mr. Bush said, "so local people should control local schools." That was a version of one of his biggest applause lines on the campaign trail -- his insistence that he does not want to be the federal superintendent of education.
But, in fact, he has proposed using federal funds as a lever to encourage states to give standardized tests in reading and math to all students in grades three through eight. Any state that refused would lose 5 percent of its education money.
In this period of economic prosperity, the voters may never pay that much attention to the issues and may simply hear Mr. Bush's inclusive rhetoric and make judgments about whether they like the man.
Indeed, Mr. Bush's advisers acknowledge that to some extent he is using issues simply to create the impression that he is a bold leader. The very fact, they say, that he has been willing to take stands that challenge the status quo makes voters think he is up to the job of president.
"The issues form a composite of the candidate that's bigger than the issues themselves," said one senior adviser to Mr. Bush. "We have and want to be seen as confronting the hard issues, not avoiding them, and doing so in ways that are innovative for a Republican to do."
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster, said that in recent focus groups, "people did not feel that on the level of issues there is a lot at stake in this election." He found -- just as the Republicans are counting on -- that the voters are focusing much more on the character of the candidates and their moral authority.
For now, at least, the Republicans are confident that Mr. Bush has made conservatism attractive. "I don't think that Al Gore can win this election," said Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin. "I think George Bush can lose it."

HEADLINE: Tacoma Journal;
Its Air Cleaned, Its Tech High, a City Rebounds

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 3

 BODY:
When EssentialMarkets.com was looking for a place to establish headquarters a year and a half ago, executives at the Internet start-up thought first of the better-known software capitals of the Pacific Northwest.
"We sat down and the general feeling was, I guess we should look in Seattle, or maybe Bellevue or Redmond," recalled David M. Boitano, chief operating officer of the company, which helps businesses sell their products online. "But the more we talked about Tacoma, the more we thought, Well, why not Tacoma? I mean, we're an Internet company. We can be anywhere." 
 The company's decision to locate here is just one piece in the much larger story of a renaissance for Tacoma, which long suffered from image problems as a gritty mill town living very much in the shadow of Seattle, its more glamorous sister 30 miles to the north. For years the noxious fumes from pulp plants here were so powerful that people in the region spoke of the "Tacoma aroma." The city even seemed a bit of an afterthought in the name of the region's major point of entry, Seattle-Tacoma International Airport.
But, lured by office rents and housing prices roughly half Seattle's, 100 high-technology companies have started up, relocated or expanded in the downtown area in the last two years, according to the city's Economic Development Department.
Tacoma's revival is evident not just in the new companies coming here. The Tacoma Art Museum is expanding into a new building, and a convention center three times the size of the existing one is rising downtown. The infamous smell is gone, a result of mill closings and cleanups, and the air is much cleaner, yielding spectacular views of Mount Rainier, the Olympic Mountains and Puget Sound that rival those in Seattle. And traffic congestion, a major complaint in Seattle and its high-tech suburbs to the east, is not a big problem here in this city of 187,000 people -- not yet, anyway.
"If you're in Tacoma, you can still choose whether you want to live in an urban, suburban or rural area, and it simply doesn't take long to get around," said Eric Cederstrand, a developer here who has built or renovated several downtown buildings that are now home to high-tech companies. "You can be out in the countryside in half an hour. In Seattle these days, it can take you half an hour to drive three blocks."
The revival can be traced in part to municipal officials' decision a few years ago to invest $100 million to stretch fiber-optic lines through much of the city, offering a high-speed data network attractive to technology companies. Tacoma's is one of the largest publicly owned telecommunications infrastructures in the nation, prompting the city to market itself with the theme "America's No. 1 Wired City."
Tacoma also has an impressive stock of turn-of-the-century and Art Deco buildings that were largely in disrepair or even abandoned in recent decades, lending a ghost-town air to parts of downtown. Many of those are being renovated, offering the kind of "fun, creative space," in Mr. Cederstrand's description, that lots of technology companies crave.
One of his clients, Y3K Inc., a sort of Internet mall that helps small businesses sell products over the World Wide Web, is taking a floor and a half in a 1910 building downtown that has exposed brick walls, high ceilings, sandblasted beams and impressive views.
Bill Cox, chief operating officer at Y3K, which will move from another Tacoma location to the renovated building this fall, said he discerned no problems in being a bit outside the Seattle-Redmond orbit that is home to giants like the Microsoft Corporation and Amazon.com, and to many lesser-known high-tech companies.
"I think there are advantages here," Mr. Cox said. "In Seattle, I think, there's a danger that a new company can feel lost in the shuffle. The feeling is, Well, it's just another Internet company. Here, it's a bigger deal. And there's a lot of support from the city."
Robert W. Grenley, chief executive of IDmicro, a 25-employee company based here that designs several kinds of wireless tracking devices, also said he saw advantages to being a "bigger fish in a smaller pond."
Mr. Grenley, who grew up in the area, said he would have "laughed out loud" if he had heard someone predict Tacoma's resurgence 15 years ago.
"Downtown was decayed, empty, bombed-out," he said. "Parts of it looked like Dresden or something. You were scared to be downtown. And it physically smelled bad. Today it's completely different. It's amazing what's happened here."
Mr. Boitano, at EssentialMarkets, which is planning to grow to 250 employees from 105 over the next eight months and is leasing new office space downtown, said attracting people to the area was not a problem.
"You put them in a car and drive them around," he said, "show them the mountains, the water, the quality of housing that's available, the recreation. It's not a hard sell."
And Juli Wilkerson, the city's director of economic development, said there was plenty of talent available locally, noting that 22 percent of the work force from Tacoma and surrounding Pierce County still commuted to jobs in the Seattle area. "They would love to avoid that commute if they could," Ms. Wilkerson said.
Nathan A. Wright, marketing director at IDmicro, moved from Seattle in February with some trepidation, but was pleasantly surprised. "Now I'd say, Why put up with the hassle? Here I've got a seven-minute commute. The views are great, there's a lot going on, but Tacoma's still got a small-town feel to it, too. I'd take this any day of the week."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE-PRESIDENT;
GORE FIRES BACK, HOPING TO DAMPEN CONVENTION SPIRIT

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
After suffering days of Republican barbs in silence, Vice President Al Gore returned from vacation today swinging back hard, accusing the Republicans of running a showy, but insubstantial convention and strongly claiming credit for having helped create the nation's roaring economy.
Mr. Gore had spent the week with his family on a North Carolina beach while the newly minted Republican ticket of Gov. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney used the stage in Philadelphia to portray the Clinton administration as timid, ineffectual and lacking vision. 
 The Republican nominees left Philadelphia today for a day filled with campaign stops in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Ohio. Mr. Bush showed a post-convention lift of his own while speaking to a crowd of hundreds along downtown train tracks in Pittsburgh. "I can't tell you how energized I am," he said.
In Chicago, Mr. Gore answered the Republican criticisms today by slinging arrows of his own. Without mentioning Mr. Bush or Mr. Cheney by name, he accused the Republicans of trying to paper over empty promises and harsh policies with a feel-good, slickly choreographed convention that offered little more than "confetti and klieg lights."
"When it comes to political pageantry, I've got to hand it to the other side," Mr. Gore told more than 3,000 members of the International Association of Fire Fighters. "But you and I both know that a slogan never put out a raging fire. A sound bite never saved a child from a burning building. And political positioning will never heal sick children who don't have health care."
Playing the role he seems most comfortable with, the counterpuncher, Mr. Gore appeared to relish reusing one of his own lines from the 1992 campaign that Mr. Cheney had appropriated in Philadelphia: "It's time for them to go."
"Two nights ago at the convention, we heard their view of what time it is," Mr. Gore told the firefighters. "That was a familiar line wasn't it? I remember that one. Well let me tell you what time it's not. It's not time to give in to the big drug companies. It is not time to give in to big insurance companies."
"And our opponents may not like to hear it, but it is not recession time in America like it was back in 1992," he continued. "It's not deficit time in America like it was in 1992."
Mr. Gore entered a Chicago hotel this morning looking like a gladiator on an adrenaline high, pumping his fists as he led a group of chanting firefighters dressed in yellow T-shirts emblazoned with the words, "Fire Fighters for Gore."
Inside, he spent nearly 10 minutes wending his way through the crowded aisle toward the stage, slapping high-fives, grabbing every outstretched hand, cradling an infant.
"I know we're starting out behind," he said. "I'm here today to serve notice: this is Day 1 of the fight for working families. And with your help, we're going to win it."
Mr. Gore's advisers are hoping to fill the next 10 days with events like the one today, first to dampen any post-convention bounce in the polls that the Republicans are likely to receive, and then to build enthusiasm for Mr. Gore's own triumphal entrance into the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles on Aug. 16.
Later today, Mr. Gore spoke here before more than 8,000 letter carriers, and on Saturday he will address a convention of the National Association of Police Organizations in Washington.
Today's speeches offered a preview of the themes Mr. Gore will emphasize in the coming week and at the convention.
He fired populist attacks against the Republicans, describing their convention as "a masquerade ball for special interests" and repeating the refrain, "They're for the powerful, and we're for the people."
He pledged to oppose tax cuts for the rich, bolster Social Security, improve public schools, provide tax breaks for the middle class, raise the minimum wage by a dollar and make it easier for workers to form unions.
And, as if to answer critics within his own party who contend that he has not done enough to reveal his personal side to voters, he salted his speech with more biography than usual, saying, "I also want the American people to know me for who I am."
He then dwelt heavily on his time in Vietnam as an journalist in the Army, offering an implicit contrast to Mr. Bush, who served in the Texas Air National Guard, never leaving the country.
"When I was in Vietnam, I didn't do the most or run the greatest danger," Mr. Gore said. "But I volunteered and enlisted because I loved my country, and I knew that if I didn't go, I knew that someone else from my home town of Carthage, Tenn., would have to go in my place."
Left out of that explanation are two other possible reasons for his decision to volunteer: his desire to help insulate his father, an antiwar senator from Tennessee, from Republican criticism, and his own interest in broadening his resume for a possible career in politics.
The vice president was accompanied by his wife, Tipper, who was expected to spend significantly more time campaigning for her husband in the coming weeks.
Responding to one of Mr. Bush's harsher attacks -- that the Clinton administration had coasted through eight years of prosperity, choosing "the path of least resistance" -- Mr. Gore said: "What planet have they been on?"
He then claimed partial credit for starting the nation's economic recovery by casting a tie-breaking vote in the Senate for the president's 1993 economic stimulus plan.
And he recalled the efforts of the Republican-controlled Congress, led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, to shut down the government in 1995, which polls showed to be highly unpopular with voters.
"I wish there had been less resistance," he said. "I broke the tie when every Republican voted no on the economic change that has brought about this prosperity. I wish there had been less resistance and that they didn't shut down the government twice."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE IMPRESSIONS -- NEW YORK;
A Sharp Student Split On G.O.P. Spectacle

BYLINE: By Jane Gross 

 BODY:
Political science students at New York University recognize obscure de Toqueville quotations and argue the merits of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty vs. the Strategic Defense Initiative. So when the Republican National Convention rolled around, they were an astute audience, eager to analyze what George W. Bush set out to accomplish and how well he succeeded.
The three doctoral candidates and four students from the undergraduate honors program differed on whether the convention was "brilliant marketing," in the words of one, or "insulting propaganda," in the words of another. But all agreed it was a textbook example of "median voter theory" and "triangulation," jargon for capturing swing voters by adopting the popular issues of the opposition and burying the unpopular issues of its own fringe, as Bill Clinton's Democrats did in 1992. 
 "Clearly, the theme of inclusion is a blatant plea to nontraditional Republican voters," said Ramsey J. Green, 20, as he watched a rainbow coalition of speakers cross the podium in Philadelphia. "It seems as though they have finally realized that their reputation as white, wealthy and Christian will not appeal to socially liberal suburban voters and therefore prevent them from enjoying the policies of a Republican president."
Mr. Green, who said he would most likely cast his first presidential vote for Vice President Al Gore, veered between calling the tactic a "sick Republican scheme" and saying that the convention had "gone extremely well" for the party. He argued with himself about whether the Republicans were "trying to pull the wool over my eyes" or "making a serious attempt to change the party's traditional ethnic and financial makeup."
Still, Mr. Green said that the tone of the convention was a healthy development for the party and the nation.
From the other side of the aisle, Costas Panagopolous, a doctoral student who ran unsuccessfully for the Massachusetts Legislature while a Harvard undergraduate, also saw the Republican show of inclusion as a plus.
Mr. Panagopolous, 28, who ran as a Republican but has since re-registered as an independent, said, "I do think it's a strategy -- for now. But if they win the election, they'll know it works, and this will have been a first step. It has to start somewhere. And there comes a point where perception becomes reality."
Mr. Panagopolous, with his experience as a candidate and a resume filled with jobs in marketing, seemed to unnerve other students with his unabashed admiration for the "re-branding" by the Republican party.
"It's no different than re-positioning Hush Puppy shoes," he said.
Sona Nadenicheck, a doctoral candidate devoted to academic research not the hurly-burly of politics, gasped, "But that's not who they really are!"
Ms. Nadenicheck's husband and fellow graduate student, Matt Golder, jumped in.
"The goal is to get elected," Mr. Golder said, soothingly, comparing the Republicans to the Labor Party in his British homeland. "It took the Labor Party 10 years to change their image."
The students, interviewed over the course of the four-day convention, were not equally engaged by the proceedings. Alissa Elliott, a 20-year-old with a bent for international relations, watched hours of C-Span each night, as she cooked dinner, ironed and answered e-mail and took detailed exception to the foreign policy positions of several speakers.
Mr. Panagopolous, also a nightly devotee, dissected the ramifications of Mr. Bush's proposed tax cuts and lamented the candidate's silence on international trade and domestic economic trends. Mr. Green seemed to have seen virtually every speaker, Republican National Committee video and mariachi or Motown band.
By contrast, Martin Wolf, 19, skipped the first night because a broken fish tank had shorted out his television set, and he considered Mr. Bush's speech, which he grudgingly watched, a "waste of my time." Ms. Nadenichek, 28, said she would have ignored the Bush speech and worked on a conference paper were it not for her husband.
"Matt had the TV on and we have a small one-bedroom apartment," Ms. Nadenichek said. She said the convention was more interesting than it might have been because Mr. Golder brought a fresh eye to this American spectacle.
All of the students noted, admiringly, the Republicans finesse at highlighting the improprieties, sexual and otherwise, of the Clinton White House and tarnishing Mr. Gore in the process. They also thought it deft to call attention to the nation's prosperity, the Democrat's crowning achievement in the past eight years, while characterizing it as an opportunity wasted.
"Bush tried to point out what is morally wrong with the executive administration today while pointing out what is right with the economy," Mr. Green said. "Theoretically, I guess this means all Bush has to do is win the election, move into the White House, do no harm to the economy and remain faithful to his wife. Sounds like a pretty easy job." Jane Gross

HEADLINE: Arabs Strive for New Consensus On an Israeli-Palestinian Treaty

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
On the face of it, Arab support for the Palestinian position has never been so unified. One after another, Arab kings and presidents have said they stand behind Yasir Arafat's claim to East Jerusalem and the right of return for Palestinian refugees.
But behind the uncompromising public statements, more pragmatic approaches to those thorniest of issues are being discussed seriously among Arab leaders for the first time. 
 There have even been signs of subtle shifts in the once monolithic Arab public opinion that Arab Muslims should have exclusive sovereignty over East Jerusalem.
In the 10 days since the Camp David talks broke down, on this and other previously taboo issues, Arab leaders have been absorbed in their most intense consultations ever on how to find a swift, workable deal that would combine both symbol and substance for both sides.
Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has shuttled around the region. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has received a string of Arab leaders at his summer palace in Alexandria, where Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel arrived on Thursday for talks.
And Edward S. Walker Jr., a former American ambassador to Egypt and Israel and now an assistant secretary of state, has gone to Saudi Arabia as part of his tour of Arab nations that rely to some degree on United States money or military backing.
A new Arab consensus on these issues could ultimately make an agreement between the Israelis and the Palestinians possible, analysts and diplomats say, if Israel also compromises at least in symbolic ways on viewing Jerusalem as its eternal undivided capital and on Palestinian refugees as a resettlement problem for the rest of the world.
"The Jews and Muslims are in a Catholic marriage with no possibility of divorce," said Kamel Abu Jaber, a former Jordanian foreign minister who led the first joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation to the Madrid peace conference in 1991. "Everyone realizes that the problem now is how to engineer arrangements to satisfy at least the minimum requirements of both sides to live together."
The concept of making "arrangements" along the way to peace is relatively new in the last 52 years of Arab-Israeli conflict.
For seven years since direct talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians began in earnest, negotiations have focused almost exclusively on step-by-step details that have allowed most Arab leaders to remain on the sidelines, talking of a comprehensive peace settlement in absolute terms.
But with the rush of expectation that came with the 15-day Camp David talks last month, Arab leaders are facing internal and external pressure to play a role in forging a final settlement. One reason is that both of the most contentious issues on the table -- Jerusalem and refugees -- carry implications for leaders other than Mr. Arafat and for peoples other than the Palestinians.
Jordan is home to more Palestinian refugees than any other Arab country. Egypt is a leading American ally in the region and is the only Arab state to have reached a peace agreement with Israel.
And the approval of Saudi Arabia, as the keeper of Islam's two holiest sites, is essential to any shift, no matter how subtle, in the Arab position on Jerusalem, which contains the third-holiest site.
"When Arafat is alone negotiating with the Israelis, he is too weak to make concessions," said Labib Kamhawi, a Palestinian-Jordanian political analyst. "But if a third party is involved, the third party is like a facilitator. So I think, ultimately, an Arab umbrella will be given to Arafat."
Another reason is that most Arab nations, if not impatient for a settlement, have become at least used to the idea that a settlement would bring needed economic benefits.
"There is a growing linkage in the region between having conditions of peace and the possibility of development," said Abdel Moneim Said, director of Al Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies in Cairo. "In addition, there is no one in the Arab world, except for some fundamentalists, who would deny any more the legitimacy of Israel. So we are all transferring from an existential conflict of 'us or them' to how we are going to be living with them."
Before the Camp David peace negotiations, reflections on how to finesse issues like Jerusalem were never seriously broached in Arab countries. But proposals for dividing administrative and religious control of the city, made at Camp David by Prime Minister Barak and President Clinton, have lifted a curtain.
"There are ways of dealing with it without saying that Israel is sovereign over East Jerusalem," Dr. Said said. "Certain things could happen de facto, if we have an agreement that settles the issue of East Jerusalem and left aside the question of the Old City."
Arab control over the Haram al Sharif, the man-made plateau in the Old City known to Jews as the Temple Mount that is the site of two of the holiest mosques in Islam, remains a fixed demand. It cannot be relinquished, Arab officials have said, without stirring the wrath of Muslim militants in the region and Muslims all over the world.
But a number of Arab officials and commentators, even in the most religiously conservative country of Saudi Arabia, have recently talked of the need to cool tempers over Jerusalem and of making a distinction between political and religious sovereignty.
"Jerusalem has a very important religious value, but its political importance is just as great," a Saudi official said. "Maybe both sides could agree on joint administration according to certain arrangements." Postponing either Jerusalem or further negotiations is not an option, he added.
"We have already wasted 52 years, and we do not need to waste more time," the official said. "We have to take what we can now -- anything that is possible or is the remnant of the possible."
From another quarter, Fahmi Howeidi, an Egyptian commentator with close ties to the Islamic fundamentalist movement, also suggested that Arabs were focusing too much attention on the mosques. Instead, he wrote recently in the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram, they should emphasize the refugee issue.
"The importance of the human being is more important than a place, even if this place is the Haram al Sharif," Mr. Howeidi wrote, adding that God would protect the Jerusalem mosques.
On the issue of the return of refugees, a number of Arab officials have also said an arrangement is possible if Israel accepts the principle that Palestinians have a right to return if they fled or were forced from their homes in 1948.
Until now, Israel has said only that it might accept some 100,000 refugees under a family reunification plan. About 3.2 million Palestinians are registered with the United Nations as refugees who fled or were forced from their homes at the time of Israel's creation in 1948 or are descendants of those who met that fate.
Another 300,000 are considered displaced persons from the Israeli occupation of the West Bank in 1967. Some of the more flexible statements have come from Jordan, where officials and others of Palestinian descent say they doubt that many people will take advantage of a right to return, which would mean accepting Israeli citizenship.
"Say you agree to theoretical language that refugees have the possibility of the right of return," said Marwan Dudin, a Jordanian senator who was born in Beersheba, in what is now Israel, and represented Jordan in multilateral talks with Israel about Palestinian refugees. "It could take two to three generations to implement. But you at least make something that smells like an acknowledgment of the right of return."
Dr. Kamhawi, the Jordanian political analyst, agreed. "At a minimum, Israel should uphold this right and then sit down and see if it's practical or not," he said. "First the principle, then the details."

The Arab nations have long contended that Palestinian refugees are the responsibility of Israel, not of the rest of the world. The article also misstated the number of peace agreements signed by Israel with Arab countries. It is two -- not just with Egypt but also with Jordan.

LENGTH: 1275 words

HEADLINE: A Year Out of Bankruptcy, Barneys Is Still Looking for Sure Footing

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
When the troubled retailer J. C. Penney announced last week that Allen L. Questrom would be its new chief executive, Wall Street was euphoric.
Penney has been dogged by disappointing sales at its department stores, but its stock rose 16.5 percent that day. And Mr. Questrom's credentials led 4 of the 12 analysts that cover the company to upgrade the stock, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. 
 "He's got to be a huge improvement at J. C. Penney," said George Strachan at Goldman Sachs, who raised his rating to "market outperform" from "market perform." "He's got a lot of charisma and is very decisive."
Investor enthusiasm stems in large part from the work that Mr. Questrom did while reviving ailing public companies like Federated Department Stores and Macy's, which Federated acquired under his leadership. But in the most recent chapter of his career, as chairman and chief executive of Barneys New York after it emerged from bankruptcy, it is less clear that the turnaround man has spun straw into gold.
Though Barneys has had robust sales growth, its cash flow and earnings have not been nearly as strong as the company predicted in documents filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court. This weakness, combined with a less-forgiving investor environment, has dashed any chance of a quick return to public ownership. In addition, the glitzy retailer has been hemorrhaging employees.
Mr. Questrom, 60, a flawlessly groomed executive, arrived in May 1999 at Barneys, which was famous for dressing men in the finest suits and their social X-ray wives in the newest European designs. The company had come out of bankruptcy in January, and he was not responsible for the plan filed with the court in November 1998. That was done by the retailer's majority owners, two vulture funds, Bar Harbour Management and Whipporwill Associates Inc.
Doug Teitlebaum of Bar Harbour and David A. Strumwasser of Whipporwill Associates say that the numbers in the filing were based on the projections of previous management, under the leadership of the chief executive, Tom Shull. When Mr. Questrom came aboard, the owners and Mr. Questrom formulated a more conservative plan, the owners say, and the company is exceeding its new targets, though they declined to disclose those numbers.
At the time of his arrival, Mr. Questrom was heralded as an executive who could generate dynamic growth -- growth essential for Barneys to pay off its substantial debts.
Jeffrey Tarkenton, a bankruptcy lawyer at Womble, Carlyle, Sandridge & Rice in Washington, said he had not studied the Barneys situation, but added, "Like any company that misses projections significantly, it is a sign that reorganization might be failing."
The idea that his yearlong tenure at Barneys has been anything less than spectacular makes Mr. Questrom's eyes flash. He says what really matters for a retailer just out of bankruptcy is to earn the trust of vendors, and that there he surpassed expectations. When he took the helm, 80 percent of vendors were asking to be paid on delivery of goods, he says, and today less than 8 percent do -- and those are mostly small suppliers who cannot afford to do otherwise.
Barneys stores have experienced double-digit sales growth since he arrived. In fact, much of the luxury market, including Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus, has benefited from a strong economy. Mr. Questrom, though, takes credit for helping Barneys partake in the boom by training the notoriously snooty sales force to be more friendly.
Despite these solid accomplishments, there have been troubling signs at the retailer, most notably executive turnover at Barneys flagship Madison Avenue store since Mr. Questrom arrived. In just the last three months, the company has lost six executives at the level of divisional vice president and above, a creative director, a vice president of communications and the Madison Avenue store manager, or roughly 9 out of 16 senior staff members.
The turnover would not be a concern at a large chain of stores. At a small, high-end operation like Barneys, though, experienced service people and discerning fashion buyers are vital.
A common theme among departing employees was that they did not like the change to Mr. Questrom's more corporate manner from the family-style management dating back to the Pressman clan that owned Barneys before bankruptcy. The executive was repeatedly described as "cold." He earned ill will, employees said, by demanding that employees pass basic retail math tests -- an exercise one former staff member described as "degrading."
Although Mr. Questrom's effort could be defended as needed professionalism for a famously highflying, high-spending operation, staff members said they felt his bottom-line emphasis was not in line with Barneys overall luxury shopping experience. For example, he shifted Barneys away from its traditional emphasis on the most cutting-edge designers.
"He was focused on business volume makers, not on nurturing the young and upcoming designers," said Emilia Fabricant, the former senior vice president responsible for the women's co-op and outlet division, who said she left because she was looking for a new creative environment. "I thought he was maybe losing the future."
Another possible reason for staff departures is that Barneys is in no position to make a public offering of stock anytime soon. Since Barneys emerged from bankruptcy with an estimated value of $240 million, the market valuations of public retailers have collapsed. Most now trade at less than their annual sales. The Neiman Marcus Group, a luxury retailer on solid footing, had 1999 sales of $2.6 billion and has a market cap of roughly 60 percent of that amount. Given sales last year of $365 million and its distressed history, Barneys might have a public value of less than $200 million now.
Even Mr. Questrom's decision to move on may relate to the probability of little short-term benefit in his staying. When he joined, his employment agreement called for him to be paid entirely in stock. The company now says that he will get an undisclosed sum of stock as well as a salary for the year he was the top executive. He will remain chairman after joining Penney.
Barneys' majority owners say they do not pay attention to short-term valuations and that theirs is a long-term investment.
Back in its 1998 filing with the bankruptcy court, the company projected a net loss of $614,000 for the fiscal year ending January 2000 and net income of $5 million for the year ending in January 2001. Instead, the company posted a $5.3 million loss last year and expects just to break even this year.
The shortfall is significant because Barneys has two important pools of debt that will start to come due in 2003. A person with knowledge of the balance sheet says the shortfall already endangers the company's ability to meet these obligations.
Mr. Teitlebaum and Mr. Strumwasser vigorously deny they will have trouble meeting their debts.
Mr. Shull, who saw Barneys through bankruptcy and helped build its cash flow from a loss of $2 million a year to gains of $20 million yearly, and who also knows the company well, says that if it does not start meeting the original recovery plan it will not be able to pay its debts.
"In order for them to make their financial commitments in two years, the company would have to achieve an EBITDA of over $70 million," he said, using the term that refers to earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. "At this stage, barring significant additional investment, that would seem to be a difficult challenge."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 23, 2000, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Aug. 5 reported on the performance of Barneys New York since its emergence from bankruptcy in January 1999. Critics of the departing chief executive, Allen L. Questrom, were quoted as saying that he had shifted the company away from its traditional emphasis on the most cutting-edge designers.
In fairness, The Times should have included a response from the company. In a statement, the company has since said, "Barneys today is every bit the fashion incubator that it has ever been."
Because of an editing error, the article also referred imprecisely to the company's prospects for raising money through a stock sale. Concerns about Barneys and the industry's stocks over all rule out a share issue any time soon. They do not rule out "a quick return to public ownership"; Barneys already has stockholders, although its shares are not traded regularly.
The article also misspelled the names of the two firms that own a majority share of the company and misstated the number of senior employees who have resigned in the last three months. The firms are Bay Harbour Management, not Bar Harbour, and Whippoorwill Associates, not Whipporwill. Eight senior employees, not nine, have resigned in the last three months.

HEADLINE: A Taste for Frequent-Flier Miles

BYLINE: By SUSAN SHEEHAN; SUSAN SHEEHAN is a staff writer for The New Yorker.

 BODY:
I AM my mother's daughter: I love the idea of getting something for nothing. In the 1960's, mother went from bank to bank, bringing home a new appliance each time she opened a $25 savings account. By the 70's, we were both collecting the green stamps grocery stores handed us with our purchases and redeeming them for toys for my young girls.
In the 1980's, with the advent of frequent-flier miles, getting something for nothing took a major turn for the better. I earned ample mileage (and subsequent free trips around the country) simply by flying a lot in the course of researching magazine articles and books. Later, with the felicitous appearance of airline credit cards, I charged everything possible to these plastic rectangles and flew to Europe free. 
 Last August, when one card offered double mileage for all purchases for a year, I forsook the others and paid every supermarket and department store bill, as well as all newspaper subscriptions, burglar-alarm maintenance bills and charitable donations with my Delta Optima. A biography of my life appears in monthly installments on the credit card statements.
I am also my mother's daughter in that I have spent most of my life chasing seven pounds up and down the scale. Last spring, while tossing a package of Healthy Choice macaroni and cheese into my shopping cart, I read on the box that I would receive 500 free miles for every 10 Healthy Choice products I bought before the end of the year. By Dec. 31, 1999, I had a collection of 110 proofs-of-purchase from 55 lunches of Colonial Chicken Pie and 55 dinners of Chicken and Vegetables Marsala. I had also lost 10 pounds from eating out of cardboard boxes.
I mailed them to Healthy Choice, received certificates valid for 5,500 miles on a number of participating airlines, and sent them to TWA, where they brought my mileage to just over the 25,000 miles required for a free round-trip economy ticket in the United States.
I paid my way to an assortment of cities this year, saving the California interviews for a new book until last. I knew that TWA flew there from our home in Washington by way of its hub in St. Louis. In June I called TWA and asked to fly to San Francisco on July 6. I was told I could go to Ontario.
"Thanks, not going to Canada," I said to the person at TWA's 800 number.
"Ontario, California," she said. "It's an airport 46 miles from Los Angeles."
I kept telephoning but TWA steadfastly declined to put me on a flight to San Francisco, where I had four interviews in four days. I also had an interview in central Los Angeles on July 11. TWA would let we fly out to Ontario on July 6 and then home on July 12 from Orange County Airport, 36 miles from Los Angeles International Airport. After 57 phone calls, I persuaded a person at TWA's 800 number to let me fly home from LAX, although not at a convenient hour -- I would have a three-hour layover in St. Louis instead of the hour layover available to paying passengers. But the basic arrangement would work.
I bought a United round-trip ticket with a flight from Ontario to San Francisco on July 7 and one from San Francisco to LAX three days later, for just over $100. Flying TWA to Ontario through St. Louis was fine, and a night at the Super 8 Motel in Ontario was more than fine. Some months earlier, I had discovered the charms of Super 8's -- firm beds, free Continental breakfasts and reasonable prices. In small towns like Le Mars, Iowa, there are no upscale hotel chains.
I arrived at Ontario Airport at 9 a.m. on July 7 for my 10 a.m. United flight to San Francisco. An agent could be heard telling another passenger that the 10 a.m. flight had been canceled because of fog in San Francisco. "My boyfriend says there's no fog in San Francisco," a woman waving a cell phone shouted to the agent.
"Well, if there's no fog, then there are high clouds over San Francisco," the agent retorted.
We were to be put on the 12:30 p.m. flight, but upon further questioning were told United would have no flight leaving Ontario for northern California until 4 p.m.
I asked a skycap if any other airline flew to the San Francisco area. Southwest did, he said. I sprinted a quarter-mile with my luggage to the Southwest terminal, bought a $100 one-way ticket to Oakland, and was there by noon. I didn't see any fog or high clouds over either Oakland or San Francisco. I later learned that a slowdown by United pilots had been disrupting flight schedules.
Three-hour layovers are regrettably frequent when planes experience mechanical problems or encounter bad weather. One sits and frets and doesn't dare leave the departure gate, even as projected delays escalate from 3 to 18 hours. This layover was different. I knew I would be in St. Louis from 4 to 7 p.m. on July 12 and decided to make the most or my time. I sent an e-mail message to my friend Pat, a knowledgeable St. Louis resident, with a string of questions.
I started with airport facilities. Any manicurists? (I had recently had my nails done at Reagan National in Washington.) Any interesting stores, like the Body Shop or the Gap? (I had once done my Christmas shopping at Pittsburgh airport.) "No manicure just yet, but by September you'll be able to get a back rub or foot massage," Pat answered. "No particularly interesting stores come to mind."
WELL, then, might the Cardinals be playing a home game on July 12? I would have liked to see Mark McGwire at bat. "No ball teams playing anywhere," Pat wrote. "It's the day after the All-Star Game, part of a three-day break for every team."
I asked her about a few of the city's celebrated attractions -- the St. Louis Art Museum, the zoo, the Missouri Botanical Garden, the Scott Joplin House and the Arch. "The last place I would go on a July afternoon would be the Arch, as there are HUGE lines all summer long to go up to the top in the trams," she wrote. "Of course, you could hang out under the Arch without having to stand in line for the tram, but you still would encounter MANY sweaty people."
To anyone who has grown up in Manhattan, huge lines and sweaty people are part of one's heritage. I spent a little over half an hour getting to the Arch on the MetroLink light-rail system and a glorious something-for-nothing hour marveling at Eero Saarinen's Gateway Arch, a stunning memorial to Thomas Jefferson and others who expanded the country westward. I MetroLinked back to the airport, and flew home.
When I returned, my husband reminded me of a long-ago Thanksgiving weekend he and my father had spent assembling a green-stamp made-in-Czechoslovakia bicycle for our older daughter.
Our daughter, the former bicycle rider turned business executive, extolled the merits of taking and paying for nonstop coast-to-coast flights. I spotted a picture of an American Airlines jet on a box of All-Bran on the breakfast table. Kellogg's is now offering 500 free miles on American for mailing in five pictures of the plane on boxes of its cereals. I took out the scissors.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 15; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1867 words

HEADLINE: ONLINE TEACHING;
The Battle in Cyberspace

BYLINE: By Abby Ellin; Abby Ellin writes the Preludes column for the Money & Business section of The New York Times on Sunday.

 BODY:
In the summer of 1997, Dr. Cyndi Wilson Porter, an assistant chemistry professor at Lakeland College in Sheboygan, Wis., was asked to teach a class online. She hesitated at first -- she loved the feel of a classroom, the camaraderie of live communication. She did not want to be an anonymous piece of software somewhere beyond the computer screen.
But she did it, and soon, she said, she fell in love with the interaction. "On the ground, some students respond and others don't; online, everyone does -- they have to," she said. "Online, the only way I know you're alive is if you participate, so we set goals of how many times a week students have to respond. It's very exciting." 
 Three years later, she is the assistant vice president for extended academic programs and the director of Universe Online, a nonprofit virtual arm of the University of the Incarnate Word in San Antonio. Universe Online is starting up this fall and will offer business classes for undergraduates, as well as courses leading to an M.B.A. The online teachers are faculty members and business owners.
Universe Online is one of the many so-called distance-learning programs hovering in cyberspace. According to reports from the United States Department of Education, at least one-third of the 3,500 colleges and universities in the United States offer distance-learning courses; within the next two years, four out of every five are expected to do so.
But neither faculty members nor administrators are sure about some of the issues raised about intellectual property, like who owns and who should control content that appears online. Does the university or the faculty member who created an online course own it? Who retains copyright to the material? The issue did not arise before cybercourses, because the material and the teacher were intertwined. But now many faculty members fear they will lose control over the courses they teach, that their lessons will be modified or prepackaged into a one-size-fits-all lecture by someone at an online institution.
How much freedom does a faculty member have? Professors typically design traditional courses, and decide which readings to assign and what information to deliver. But what happens with an online course, where the methodologies are different?
David F. Noble, a history professor at York University in Toronto, argues that distance learning contributes to the commercialization of academia and that it forces universities to be concerned only with turning a profit.
"Who owns the material you have placed on the Web site or e-mail?" he wrote in an essay called "Digital Diploma Mills: The Coming Battle Over Online Instruction," part of a series that, ironically, he posted on the Internet, at www.communication.ucsd.edu/dl.
"Without a clear and definitive assertion of copyright claims by faculty, the universities will usurp such rights by default."
Dr. Porter disagrees. Educators, she says, "are hired to impart knowledge, to help students learn. Even as a traditional academic, I have never understood the mindset of 'I own this so I should be able to sell it.' As a chemist, I share my knowledge. I didn't invent chemistry or chemical concepts." She added, "Since I am paid by my school to share my knowledge, they in effect are leasing me."
Some universities, on the other hand, are concerned that professors will rake in substantial sums by teaching classes to millions of people across the globe, and that they will not share the tuition with their institutions. They are also worried that some professors will branch out on their own and teach courses for nontraditional institutions like the Global Education Network, a company founded by Herbert A. Allen, a venture capitalist.
That is what happened with Arthur R. Miller, a Harvard Law School professor who provides video courses for the Concord University School of Law, a virtual school founded by Kaplan Inc., the test-preparation company. Professor Mil- ler, who markets many of his Harvard lectures on videocassettes, contended that he was not violating Harvard's policy of not providing course material to another school while still teaching at Harvard, without permission. Harvard said he was. According to Michael Chmura, a Harvard Law School spokesman, the university issued new guidelines last spring, after the conflict with Professor Miller arose, to make clear that it prohibited such online moonlighting. Professor Miller was out of the country and not immediately available for comment, an assistant said.
SOME universities are signing deals themselves. Unext.com, a virtual university backed by Michael Milken, the former junk bond king, and Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman of Oracle, has agreements with Columbia University, Carnegie Mellon University, the University of Chicago, the London School of Economics and Stanford University to receive course materials from them for use at an online for-profit virtual university, said Andrew M. Rosenfield, an economist and lawyer who is a lecturer at the University of Chicago Law School and the chief executive of Unext.com. The school also contracts with faculty members at other colleges to provide courses unique to Unext.
Western Governors University, a virtual college, will develop programs that provide academic credit for practical experience, and will utilize course work from institutions throughout the United States.
Still, while colleges and universities have long concerned themselves with patentable items -- inventions or medical techniques created in university laboratories -- many are unsure about how to proceed with online materials.
"Schools never cared about literary endeavors," said Dan Burk, professor of law at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, who is an expert on intellectual property law and cyberlaw. "There was never enough money expected from one." But now that the economics of ownership of academic materials is changing, he says, "the vast majority of universities don't know what they're doing. We have no guidance."
Because the multimedia arena of distance learning is copyrightable subject matter, some academics foresee a lot of money being generated by online courses. For the past three years, for example, Stanford's engineering school has taught 200 courses to students all over the world -- at 140 percent of the school's normal tuition. Duke University charges $95,000 for what it calls a Global Executive M.B.A., a 19-month-long program that mixes a month on campus and a month studying abroad with online study. That is considerably more expensive than tuition for the traditional two-year M.B.A. program, which is $28,200 per year.
Administrators at Penn State view their online World Campus as the 25th campus in the university system. Since it opened two years ago, there has been a jump from 70 students to 2,895.
At some schools, faculty members have protested the consideration of courses on the Web. Nine hundred faculty members at the University of Washington signed a petition opposing talk of a virtual university. Professors at Cornell have expressed discomfort with e-Cornell, a for-profit subsidiary to develop and market online courses, said Bill Steele, a university spokesman. Details of the program have not yet been completed.
Beyond the focus on ownership, Dr. Burk cites deeper, more complex issues that are at stake -- like career, competition, status and money.
If Harvard's Professor Miller took a sabbatical to teach at another bricks-and-mortar institution, "nobody would have cared," he said. But now, "what they're saying is that 'we don't want you to pull a paycheck from Harvard and also teach online.' Harvard's not happy to have its name affiliated with a nonaccredited school."
Mr. Chmura said that the issue was not the linking of names, but assuring that Harvard faculty members give most of their attention to Harvard students. There are also issues of ego and respect. Both came up when faculty members at the University of Chicago were asked by administrators to develop materials for Unext.com. "It makes them sound like they're working for a big corporation, where their bosses can give them an assignment," said Dr. Burk. "They wonder, 'Are we just cogs? Can my dean or department head tell me to create this course as part of my regular duties here? Can I say yes or no?' The real question now is: What's the role of the bricks-and-mortar university, and how is the relationship between the faculty and the university changing?"
Ultimately, the courses those faculty members develop count toward their required teaching load, but they do not earn any extra pay for creating them, said Larry Arbeiter, a University of Chicago spokesman. There is no consensus about many of the questions raised. Some schools have decided to use revenue from online courses as a way of paying faculty. Others are considering the model of the recording and entertainment industries; faculty members would own the rights to online instructional materials and would be allowed to sell material to online colleges. Some people expect professors to hire agents to broker deals for them.
In May, Duke University's Academic Council approved a policy allowing professors to retain ownership of all courses they create as individuals, but allowing the university to retain ownership of some courses created using university property. The University of Texas has a similar policy, which calls for joint ownership of courses created using the university's funds or personnel.
At the University of Minnesota, faculty members retain ownership of any Web-based courses they create, unless there is a prior agreement to the contrary. Dr. Porter said Universe Online pays a faculty member 5 percent of the tuition it receives for an online course for each of the first five times the course is offered.
She said, "There's no difference between online and on-ground teaching other than the actual method of delivery. Instead of standing up and talking, I now type. When I do an online class, I'm still just sharing my knowledge. When I teach a course on-ground, I get paid as part of my salary. When I teach a class online, I also get paid as part of my salary. But everyone wants a piece of the pie." But the issue of dividing the pie is more pressing when, unlike Dr. Porter, the faculty member whose course is offered online does not participate in teaching it, because then he or she will either be paid for assembling the content or not be paid at all.
The American Association of University Professors has drafted model contracts that give faculty members a financial interest in courses that are adapted to online presentations. Dr. Burk of Minnesota predicts that the debate will quiet down soon.
"Part of what's driving this is that these online courses are multimedia intensive, with video, graphics, music, and text," he said. "They're new and hot, and both the institution and faculty seem to think there will be a bunch of money out there. But the reality is that these blockbuster moneymaking gold-rush scenarios probably won't happen. I am hoping people will realize there's not a gold mine and come to their senses."
 
http://www.nytimes.com
