PUB-DATE: August 6, 2000

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 24; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 3467 words

HEADLINE: The One-Room Schoolhouse

BYLINE: By Jodi Wilgoren; Jodi Wilgoren is a national education correspondent for The New York Times.

DATELINE: Bloomfield, Mont.

 BODY:
SCHOOL doesn't start until the Mullets arrive. Today, they are late, so we wait.
Kenny Whitmer, age 7, is going 'round and 'round on the rickety pentagon that a local welder built out of $46 worth of pipes half a century ago. Julia Lindquist, a seventh-grade loner, is sitting by herself, contemplating the gaping sky and the wind pushing waves through the grassy field. The boys are shooting hoops, as usual. They let Monica Hostetler, 14, play to even out the teams -- first when there are only three of them, then again when there are five. In between, she hangs at the other end of the makeshift court, lobbing jumpers into the net. 
 It's 10, 12, maybe 15 minutes past 8 a.m. when the forest green 1998 Oldsmobile Regency pulls into the dirt driveway and the Mullets tumble out: Marshall, the eighth grader, Winston, a year younger, Merrilee, 11, and little Sterling, age 9. They live the farthest from the white clapboard schoolhouse, 11 miles down gravel roads across empty plains, so their lateness might be forgivable -- except that it holds up everybody else.
As the Mullets pull backpacks, musical instruments and lunch boxes from the trunk, the boys on the blacktop hurry to land one more basket. Linda Borntrager, the teacher, stands on the steps, one hand on the hip of her faded jeans, the other clasping the old cow bell, ready to ring. It's time to raise the flag, say the Pledge of Allegiance, start another day at Bloomfield School.
"If they're absent, we really have declined enrollment for the day," Mrs. Borntrager, 48, laughed about the Mullets. The family accounts for four of her 13 pupils, and two more are Mullet cousins. Children at Bloomfield "just have to learn how to be flexible," she added. "That's a good skill in life."
Bloomfield, which opened in 1908, is one of nearly 400 remaining public one-room schoolhouses in the nation, at once a nostalgic remnant of the past and a modern outlet for educational experimentation. Even as the number of tiny rural schools has plunged in recent years, the fundamental aspects of teaching inside them -- from multi-age classrooms and peer tutoring to interdisciplinary projects and keeping students with the same teacher for more than one year -- are being copied in large school systems across the country.
Small classes and, especially, small schools, are increasingly seen as crucial to students' success in the early grades, leading many urban educators to create islands within large school buildings that attempt to foster the intimacy and individual attention of places like Bloomfield.
And, with the Internet, long-held concerns about the narrow curriculum available in an isolated one-teacher school are fading. "One-room schools really represent, I think, the best model for training American children for the first through the eighth grades," said Andrew Gulliford, director of the Center for Southwest Studies at Fort Lewis College in Durango, Colo., who is the nation's leading expert on one-room schools.
"In terms of ego development, in terms of character, in terms of personality, in terms of the well-rounded individual fitting in with the group, country schools are very efficient -- they helped train generations of Americans," added Professor Gulliford, author of the definitive book on the subject, "America's Country Schools" (University of Colorado Press). "In a one-room schoolhouse, every child counts -- they've always counted, whether it was 1890 or 1990. How can you say that in most modern educational systems today? It's just not true."
IT is 10:50 a.m. on a Tuesday, a couple of hours after I've arrived here amid the cattle ranches and wheat farms, and Mrs. Borntrager is deep into an eighth-grade math lesson on symmetry, using a mirror and a book of drawings to show how even complex shapes can sometimes be divided exactly in half.
Kenny, meanwhile, is hunched over a first-grade reader. Sterling, the third grader, is copying contractions into his notebook. Brady Boese, 12, and Matthew Kanagy, 14, are suffering through a quiz on probability and percentages, while Brady's twin brother, Kirk, is pondering a work sheet titled "Remembering Details," based on the novel, "Where the Red Fern Grows."
Julia, a seventh grader, has her nose stuck in "The Call of the Wild," legs outstretched, ankles crossed, and Winston, age 13, is methodically computing fractions and decimals. Daniel Whitmer, six years older than Kenny, is tackling problems from a math text, and Keith Hall, 13, is "Drawing Conclusions" -- at least according to the paper on his desk -- from Red Fern. Clayton Unruh has his seventh-grade spelling workbook open to a crossword puzzle. Merrilee, 11, is in the back of the room, using a computer to type sentences she made up from a list of new vocabulary words.
It could be educational chaos, but all is quiet except for the ceiling fans spinning overhead and the teacher's low-voiced prompts to the two students at her half-moon table in the corner. Most of the children have pencils moving, pages turning. Julia or Keith or Daniel occasionally stare blankly out the large windows at the endless brown earth. And, every so often, one of the boys pops up from his desk, carrying a book or a paper over to Mrs. B. with a question.
Eyes searching behind his wire-rims, Brady, 12, wants to know which number should be the numerator as he forms an algebraic equation to answer the question: 18 is 30 percent of what number?
"It's a quiz, Brady, so you're going to have to figure it out on your own," the teacher says. "One thing is to try both and then use your sense."
By 11, it's time for a different math "class" -- Julia and Keith, seventh graders who lag behind, and Merrilee, a fifth grader a bit advanced for her age, stand at the chalkboard adding and subtracting fractions. Four reading groups have already cycled through Mrs. B.'s station this morning. At 11:15, the children race outside for calisthenics, led by little Kenny, as much the school's mascot as he is one of its students. They fold their legs into a pretzel stretch, then run around the wheat field that lies beyond the school's large yard in a haphazard training regimen for the coming track meet with nearby one-room schools. Today, the twins will have to wait until after lunch for math.
"We just do kind of a rotation," Mrs. Borntrager shrugged. "I think my goal is to try to make sure everybody's doing constructive work almost all the time."
Mrs. Borntrager, who is paid $26,000 a year -- twice what she made when she started at Bloomfield 17 years ago -- often has as many as 25 different lessons to prepare each day. This year, her 13 students are in six grades, but she sometimes subdivides the older students according to ability or interest. For example, "The Red Badge of Courage" and "The Call of the Wild" are novels of similar difficulty but appeal to different students.
At Bloomfield, students spend most of the day working by themselves at their desks, old-fashioned wood-topped tables with attached chairs. Mrs. Borntrager relies heavily on textbooks and work sheets she has collected over the years; she rarely lectures to the group, instead running mini-classes in her corner, most lasting no more than 10 minutes. A teacher's aide often helps the younger boys with reading or art projects, or stands by a student's desk, administering a vocabulary test in the most nonthreatening way.
"The kids who come out of Bloomfield have real good study stills," said Cindi Hostetler, Monica's mother, who teaches music and serves as a part-time aide at the school, earning the minimum wage. "They know how to go back to their desks and go to work."
Mrs. Borntrager does not assign homework, but students who fall behind must finish their work after school. At the high school in Richey, Mont., about 20 miles away, Bloomfield graduates often rise to the top of their classes. Last spring, alumni of the school won the top awards for freshmen, sophomores and juniors at the Eastern Montana Math Meet.
Statewide, students from elementary schools with fewer than 40 students tend to outperform their peers on standardized tests in every subject. During the 1997-98 school year, in both fourth and eighth grades, more students from Montana's small schools were rated "advanced" or "proficient" -- and fewer were "novice" or "near proficiency" -- than their counterparts in reading, math, language arts, science and social studies.
"What you're showing there is small class-size ratio and individual teacher contact with kids," said Lance Melton, executive director of the Montana School Boards Association.
ONE of the advantages parents and educators see in one-room schools is the natural tailoring of the curriculum to children's needs.
"Nobody gets left through the cracks," said Mrs. Hostetler, whose husband and two older children also graduated from Bloomfield. "If you're a smart kid, they take you where you can go. If you're struggling, you get the individual attention."
That is what brought Keith Hall to Bloomfield last spring. Growing up in the Portland, Ore., suburbs, Keith, now 13, bounced among nine different schools, including one with 3,000 students. He was learning very little, but getting into plenty of trouble. "They were just shoving him through," said Phyllis Mullet, his grandmother and guardian.
Keith spent the summer of 1999 on Mrs. Mullet's farm here, hunting and fishing and tooling around on the four-wheeler. After another year of fighting at home and at school, he returned to Bloomfield two weeks before school let out in May, upping the school's enrollment by 8 percent.
He reads at about a third-grade level, misspells even basic words like reason (reazer), other (outer) and touch (tuch). But Keith, one of two Bloomfield students who take Ritalin, is a sweet boy who stays after school to help Mrs. B. move furniture, a smart kid who is energized by tactile science projects like identifying bone fragments from owl pellets or building rockets out of soda bottles.
"The other schools were junk," said Keith, whose dark-brown buzz cut is a remnant of his city brashness. "This one, it's different.
"At my old school, it would take them half the year just to know you. There was, like, 32 kids in my class, so it was kind of hard to ask the teachers questions," he said.
"Here, they keep track and stuff. They tell you, 'do you have this reading or this done.' There, they never tell you."
IN 1917, there were 196,000 one-teacher public schools in the United States. At last count, in 1996, there were 380.
Spread throughout 28 states, one-room schools are concentrated in Nebraska, which has 128, and Montana, which has 81. But while schools throughout the rural Midwest and Mountain States have been consolidating, California has seen a 22 percent growth in the number of one-room schools in the past five years, fueled in part by flexible work schedules and telecommuting policies that allow families to pursue frontier living again.
At the same time, Amish and Mennonite communities, among others, have been opening private one-room schools, which total nearly 1,200; about a third of them are in Pennsylvania. Among the public schools, average enrollment in 1996 was 9.4 students, according to a study by researchers at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah.
Here in Dawson County, a 2,358 square-mile expanse of empty plains and badlands that was once called the gateway to Montana, there were 138 rural schools in 1919, according to a fading chronicle of their history. A ledger kept by the county superintendent shows that in 1955, the county had 47 teachers. That dwindled to 32 over the next decade, then to 21 in 1969. When Mrs. Borntrager arrived at Bloomfield in 1983, she was one of nine teachers in the county; today there are three.
The attrition is mostly about economics, as fewer and fewer families find they can survive farming the arid land. There are now 53 stops on the 44-mile postal route around Bloomfield; once, there were two routes, with 80 families each.
But Bloomfield, a one-gas-station outpost 247 miles from the Billings airport -- and 27 miles from the nearest McDonald's -- is also losing students to home-schooling, which is increasingly popular among the area's religious Mennonites, and to the schools in Richey, the nearest town, where students can play on basketball and volleyball teams. This fall, Marshall and Monica will start high school and the Boese twins and Clayton Unruh plan to enroll at Richey, leaving Mrs. Borntrager with just eight students. The next kindergartner on the horizon is Elizabeth Nissley, who will not enroll until the fall of 2001.
"That's probably why I'll stop teaching," Mrs. Borntrager sighed one afternoon during the eight-mile drive from school to her modest house, a double-wide trailer with an addition her husband built. "We're going to run out of kids."
Once, Bloomfield was packed with 40 students, and voters approved a special tax to create a second classroom. Now the two rooms are combined into a 35-foot by 60-foot space, filled not with children but with an upright piano, project tables for art and audio, three computers, and a library of 4,000 worn paperbacks running around the perimeter. In the basement, there is enough open space to hold gym class indoors.
The first Bloomfield School burned in 1918. Another fire felled the new one a decade later. This third building got electricity in 1948 (after years of running a wire from a 32-volt battery at the store down the road) and indoor plumbing in 1950, although the outhouse, with separate wood-lidded toilets for boys and girls, still stands out back.
"This, to me, doesn't look like a school," said Jeff Whitmer, 77, Kenny and Daniel's grandfather and the unofficial historian of Bloomfield. "This, to me, is just like a big living room."
Mr. Whitmer, a 1936 Bloomfield graduate, built the merry-go-round in 1954 or 1955, after the ladies of Bloomfield discovered that $46 would not buy them much playground equipment. He rode on the giant stride, a kind of swing made of a metal pole with chains hanging off the top, when it was built in the 1930's. Back then they rode horses to school, or sleds in winter. It would take a while for the coal furnace to warm up, so the water bucket in the hallway would be frozen solid each morning. There were no janitors; the children cleaned the classroom themselves.
"Our classroom had four rows of desks and a big bench at the front for the teacher," Mr. Whitmer said. "The teacher would holler out, 'Fourth Grade Arithmetic!' and you'd march on down. You were told to shut up about twice, and then you were hit upside the head, or hit with a book."
Today's discipline is somewhat softer. Occasionally Mrs. Borntrager will look up from her corner and say "Quiet, please, guys," or "People, there's too much talking in here," but there are not a lot of rules.
Mrs. Borntrager, who was born in Hebron, N.D., rode a horse four miles each way to Farmer's Valley, a one-room schoolhouse, through fifth grade. After attending the state university in Fargo, N.D., she worked as a waitress, then for the telephone company in Denver and in Arizona. After divorcing her first husband, she returned home to get an elementary education degree. When she fell in love with a farmer-rancher from these parts, the teacher's desk at Bloomfield was vacant.
"I don't know if I'd like teaching in a big classroom, with all the other things that go with it," said Mrs. Borntrager, whose three children are among the 28 students who have been graduated from the school since she arrived. "The teachers' lounge. The rigidity as far as the classroom timing.
"I'm probably like the kids in a sense," she added. "I like the ability to have that freedom."
In a community where the drivers of every passing car acknowledge each other with a half-wave, Mrs. Borntrager is surrounded by her successes -- and cannot walk away from students who are struggling.
"I don't have to spend two weeks in the fall figuring out where these kids are, and I can be, in the back of my mind, planning during the summer," she said. "We don't have to spend any time getting to know each other in the fall. We can get right on to it."
KENNY, his blond bangs almost hiding his ice-blue eyes, is paired with Monica, whose metal-filled mouth and experiments with eyeliner betray her entry into adolescence. They are planning their bottle rocket for the end-of-the-year launch.
"What color do you want?" the eighth grader asks.
"You can pick this time," Kenny says generously, then suggests that each name a favorite color to combine in the decorations.
Kenny picks yellow. Monica picks orange.
"Yellow and orange?" Kenny squeals. "Those are my favorite colors!"
Monica gets the construction paper. Kenny names the project The Rocketeer. She draws the lines, he tries the scissors.
"We're going to make it actually shoot up in the air," she tells him confidently, then adds: "I don't know exactly how."
Kenny concentrates, chews a lip.
"I can't cut straight," he says.
"It's a good thing I didn't draw straight, huh?" she responds.
"How'd you know I couldn't cut straight?" Kenny asks.
"I didn't know," Monica says. "That's good. That's what gives it character."
The rocket project is a classic one-room schoolhouse lesson. For Kenny, it is practice with shapes. For Sterling, the third grader, it is real-life application of the concepts of aerodynamics, thrust and lift-off in his science text. The older students have researched the space shuttle on the Internet. There will be fraction work as the students decide how much water to put in the bottles. And, it's all about teamwork.
The challenge of teaching at Bloomfield is finding things that are interesting to a boy of 7 and a girl of 14 -- and everyone in between. The peer tutoring, like pairing Monica and Kenny, often creates the most magical moments of learning. And while it can be lonely to be the only girl of a given age, the small, multi-age setting limits peer pressure; children have little choice but to get along.
Before moving to Bloomfield, "I got picked on a lot," said Julia, whose skull was malformed at birth and has required several surgeries, leaving a prominent scar on the top of her head.
Julia, 13, draws beautiful pictures of horses and is writing her 11th book in a series about mining, but, "for some reason, I kind of get along better with younger kids," she said.
"I like watching cartoons and playing with toys. Merrilee and Sterling and Kenny and I can really have conversations," she added. "Probably when I get into high school, I'll stay by myself a lot."
In gym, Cori Schultz, the teacher's aide, tries to separate brothers and create games where the eighth graders won't mow down the first grader. Instead of traditional kickball, they put a garbage can at home plate, and kickers score points according to what base they reach before the fielders land the ball in the bucket (I played to even out the teams, and triumphed with a home run).
After two days of designing and building the bottle rockets, with their ever-more elaborate noses and fins, it was time for the launch. We placed the homemade launcher around second base, and lined up. The eldest Mullet sat atop the swing set with a video camera, Matthew Kanagy stood ready to release the bottles, and Keith Hall primed the pump. The students scattered to see which rocket would fly highest and farthest, which would twirl and spin, and which would fall flat.
Keith's masterpiece, its two-foot cardboard cylinder festooned with a picture of President Clinton, floundered; too heavy. The Mountain Dewzy, by Winston and Matthew, performed a spectacular loop-the-loop before sputtering out. Monica and Kenny's Rocketeer looked pretty but had an unremarkable ride. The strongest rocket was the unlikely, simple design by Julia and Sterling, who filled their bottle half full and used the maximum amount of air.
Daniel's was the biggest disappointment. Its small orange wings and white cone head could not stand up to the stiff wind. He had planned to fill the bottle 5/8 full of water, but some spilled out. And Daniel only used four air pumps -- in retrospect, clearly not enough.
He moped around the field alone awhile, ignoring the other rockets as they flew overhead. If only he could try again. He would use maximum air, less water. Design a stiff cardboard cone to cut through the wind. Waste less time on the useless paper fins. And, definitely, not go first, before the kinks are worked out of the launching system.
"Did you say we're doing this again next year?" Daniel asked the teacher, hopefully.
"You want to do it next year?" Mrs. Borntrager replied. Well, why not?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 15; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 932 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00;
Evil Inc.

BYLINE: By Rob Walker; Rob Walker is a contributing writer for Money and Slate.

 BODY:
Over the past decade or so, Americans turned the tobacco industry into the great common foe, a true corporate villain. Sure, there were plenty of people who enjoyed a little tobacco, but Big Tobacco was an all-purpose whipping boy: big profitable companies, run by arrogant fat cats whose products were not just addictive and lethal but also smelly. The industry practically took the place of the Soviet Union: who wanted to be known as soft on cigarettes?
But the most recent in a long series of blows, a Florida jury's $145 billion punitive judgment against the industry, has brought a certain fatigue with this particular villain. These firms have already coughed up billions and been placed under all kinds of restrictions; they've been taxed and taxed again; their products have been banned from restaurants, offices, even parks. The companies will soldier on, but there is nothing left to argue about. Tobacco has been thoroughly bashed, and there is a blank space in the American discourse. The role of Bogeyman Inc. stands open. 
 There are plenty of contenders, but finding a true replacement -- one that can serve different segments of society's different needs in a villain -- is harder than you think. Some people decried second-hand smoke's threat to individual health. Others bemoaned the cost to the health care system. Still others loathed the firms' political clout. Some simply found smoke annoying. That's the sort of broad base that's necessary to build a new Bogeyman Inc. If the obsession with healthier living, for example, were enough, politicians would be railing against the power of Big Mayonnaise.
One early candidate has been the gun business, whose products are linked to actual deaths without a great deal of mental gymnastics. But despite all the lawsuits and diatribes, gunmaker-hating has had little traction. Partly this is because Americans disagree about gun rights. But it is also because those manufacturers are a dispersed group, some of them subsidiaries of foreign companies. It's hard to reduce the plot to the nefarious actions of a handful of men running mammoth corporations with obscene profits. There's a fat-cat gap.
Some efforts were also made to demonize the entertainment industry, but -- as with frequently annoying airlines and the possibly carcinogenic cell phones -- we're all too dependent on its product to sustain a grudge.
What about Microsoft? Or the dot-coms? Admittedly, there's nothing deadly about their creations, but surely we can all get angry together about the obscene fortunes of the tech industry's virtual robber barons, right? Well, no, not at the same time that we're snapping up their wares, totting up the latest changes in their net worth, fantasizing about joining their ranks and generally treating them as philosopher-kings. Besides, we just love tech stocks, which brings us to a final complication.
There was a time when tobacco stocks performed quite nicely for a lot of people. But only since the last presidential election has shareholder culture so decisively moved to the center of American public discourse. We have heard endlessly that half of the country has money in the markets, that Main Street and Wall Street are on the same side. By now we even seem to believe it. Consider Al Gore's efforts to villainize the "price gouging" pharmaceutical industry. Do drug companies not seem like prime targets for demonization? Yes, they make products that save lives, but like tobacco companies, they seem to be able to charge whatever they want, raking in profits and forcing elderly Americans (to borrow from Gore's rap) to eat macaroni and cheese to pay for vital medication.
But it isn't so simple. When Gore picks on the maker of the allergy drug Claritin D for trying to muscle special patent treatment out of Congress, he is picking on Schering-Plough, whose share price has risen from about 12 to 44, adjusted for splits, in the past five years. The No. 1 mutual-fund holder of Schering-Plough is Fidelity Magellan, one of the most popular funds in the United States; the No. 3 holder is the famous Vanguard 500 Index fund. Less than a month before he began tilting at Big Pharma, Gore set out on a "prosperity and progress" tour to remind us of the Clinton-Gore economic boom. Plenty of those whose prosperity progressed during the last eight years are investors in Magellan and the Vanguard 500.
Few fund holders would directly attribute their financial comfort to this or that industry. But the assumption that businesses should be out making profits for shareholders is far more popular now than when the assault on (publicly held) tobacco firms began. And this makes it entirely plausible that we will never have another Bogeyman Inc. -- or at least not until Main Street finds some reason to diverge from Wall Street. Until then, one man's "price gouging" remains another's "killer profit margin," or maybe more to the point, another's "shareholder value."
I am, of course, as opposed to price gouging as the next guy, and I applaud anyone who can force this issue into the open. But I recently noticed that a fund I have money in is a top owner of Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pfizer. Pfizer, the maker of Viagra, is up 500 percent in the past five years. So am I part of a nation of consumers, anxious to see corporate power checked? Or part of a nation of shareholders, anxious to finance a luxurious retirement? I suppose you can say that Al Gore has campaigned like a candidate who wants it both ways. But if so, there's no truer reflection of the current electorate.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2901 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Rock en Espanol Is Approaching Its Final Border

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER; Larry Rohter is chief of the Rio de Janeiro bureau
of The New York Times.

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
ROCK may have been born as American music, but at middle age it is also the music of the Americas, as quickly becomes apparent during an afternoon spent in a recording studio here with Aterciopelados, Colombia's most popular rock band. The duo is rushing to finish mixing tracks for its new compact disc before heading off for a summer tour of the United States.
Andrea Echeverri and Hector Buitrago, the group's founders, are putting the finishing touches on a song called "El Album," which has just the sort of mixed-salad of a sound that has made the band so successful throughout Latin America. The tune features a twangy rockabilly guitar, a repetitive piano pattern that would sound at home on any salsa record, the scratching of a hip-hop D.J., and a chorus in the accordion-driven Colombian folk style known as vallenato. 
 "We are rockers at heart, but we are Latin American rockers, and that means that our music feeds on a lot of different sources," Ms. Echeverri, who sings and writes for Aterciopelados (pronounced ah-TARE-see-oh-pay-LAH-dos), whose name means "the Velvets," said after the session was over. "We like to mix things from outside with what is indigenous because that is what makes the music so cool and unpredictable."
In studios and on stages all over Latin America these days, similar scenes are unfolding as a new generation of musicians, raised on rock in all its various permutations, topples the traditional stereotypes of what Latin music ought to be. If only for lack of a better name, the movement, which has been developing since the mid 1980's, has come to be known as rock en espanol -- and to be seen by its adherents as a powerful and energizing global force.
"Rock 'n' roll was born out of a cultural clash in the United States between black and white," said Gustavo Santaolalla, an Argentine who is the leading producer of rock en espanol records. "Now a new cultural clash is taking place worldwide between American culture and our indigenous cultures and the result, at a time when so much mainstream pop music sounds like it has been rehashed or recycled, is something that is new and fresh and exciting."
The term rock en espanol is all-purpose and all-inclusive, grouping musicians whose only real points in common are that they grew up admiring Anglo-American rock bands and that they sing in Spanish. Indeed, the movement is so wide-ranging that it comfortably embraces everything from Mexican rappers like Molotov, Control Machete and El Gran Silencio to melodic singer-songwriters like the Argentines Fito Paez, Charly Garcia and Andres Calamaro.
But as record companies have discovered in recent years, rock en espanol is a phenomenon that is as much commercial as aesthetic, which has created an interesting quandary for many Latin American rockers about their future directions as their music moves beyond their borders. Bands like the Mexican power-pop quartet Mana, to take the most prominent example, routinely fill soccer and baseball stadiums, arenas and bull rings with audiences of 25,000 or more and sell millions of records to Spanish-speaking teenagers all over Latin America and, increasingly, the United States.
The movement has been slower to make an impact in New York, whose Spanish-speaking population is predominantly Caribbean and thus more accustomed to tropical rhythms, than in Latin America or in cities like Los Angeles, Miami and Chicago. But over the next three weeks that situation may change, as a result of the Latin Alternative Music Conference, a three-day industry forum scheduled to begin next Sunday, and a series of showcase concerts sandwiched around it.
On Saturday, the Chilean pop quartet La Ley, the dance specialists Los Amigos Invisibles from Venezuela and the Argentine funk band Ilya Kuryaki and the Valderramas will be performing in a free open-air concert at Central Park Summerstage. Then on Aug. 23 the Watcha Tour, a package show that has become Latin rock's equivalent of Lollapalooza, arrives in New York for the first time, with Cafe Tacuba, Aterciopelados, Molotov and Animal playing at the Tunnel.
What is most striking about these and other popular rock en espanol bands is their eclecticism and flexibility. Like Latin American musicians from earlier generations, they have grown up listening to the whole gamut of styles that make up the region's common musical heritage: salsa, tango, merengue, bolero, cumbia, mariachi, samba, ranchera, mambo and so on.
But thanks to improved communications and economic conditions, they have also had more opportunities than their predecessors to become familiar and comfortable with the popular music of the English-speaking world. From Jimi Hendrix, Led Zeppelin and Bob Dylan to Nirvana, Oasis and Nine Inch Nails, they have heard -- and absorbed -- it all.
"We are amphibious," said Ivan Benavides, leader of the Colombian group Bloque, whose eponymous debut album made the top 10 lists of several New York Times critics in 1998. "We can play the music of the cultures we were born into, but it also feels natural to play the music of the broader cosmopolitan culture. That gives us an advantage over people who are ethnocentric, whether they are Anglo-, Euro- or Latino-centric."
At the time that Latin rockers, most of whom are in their 30's, were growing up, cultural discourse in Latin America was dominated by doctrinaire leftists who argued that rock was a decadent manifestation of American imperialism and that only folk-based indigenous music could be a valid form of expression. Given what they saw as a false dichotomy between Silvio Rodriguez and David Bowie, or Victor Jara and Kiss, the rockers quite deliberately chose both.
"People on the left tend to have very closed opinions and not to be very farsighted," said Flavio Cianciarulo, the bass player and a songwriter for Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, Argentina's most innovative band. "Rock is essentially pure rebellion, and always has been, but they couldn't understand that, so we just wrote them off and continued to do our own thing, always with honesty."
In their early days, admittedly, many rock en espanol performers sounded like copies of whatever Anglo-American bands first inspired them to pick up their instruments or sing. Mana drew heavily on the Police, La Ley emerged as a cross between Depeche Mode and Duran Duran, Los Fabulosos Cadillacs seemed like an Argentine version of the Specials and the Colombian singer-songwriter Shakira found herself being compared to Alanis Morissette.
But as bands and singers have gradually gained experience and confidence, that tendency has changed, and Latin American rock today can be just as adventurous and stylistically promiscuous as North American pop. One of the biggest hits in Latin America during the past year, for example, has been Shakira's "Ojos Asi," which fuses a Spanish-language lyric with a Middle Eastern melody and rhythms.
"I grew up in Barranquilla, which is a Caribbean port city where you heard every kind of music you could imagine, from cumbia and vallenato to rhythm-and-blues," recalled Shakira, a member of a Lebanese immigrant family whose full name is Shakira Mebarak. "Some of the first records I remember hearing as a little girl were Donna Summer and the Arab singers that my parents liked," such as the Egyptian singer Oum Kalsoum.
But if one place has been most influential in the development of the movement, it is Mexico. Even in the 1960's, Mexican bands were listening to the "border blasters," high-wattage radio stations broadcasting to the United States from Mexican territory and recording Spanish-language cover versions of American rock 'n' roll hits. By the mid 1980's, Mexican record labels were slowly waking to the commercial possibilities of home-grown rock.
"Rock en tu idioma," or "rock in your language," was the way they marketed the new sound. Based in Mexico City, bands like Cafe Tacuba, Maldita Vecindad, Caifanes, Santa Sabina and La Castaneda found small clubs in bohemian neighborhoods that were willing to let them play, developed followings that soon grew from the local to the national, and signed contracts with the Mexican branches of the main multinational record companies.
"It was important as an affirmation to sing in Spanish," said Ruben Albarran of Cafe Tacuba, the pioneering band whose recent activities have included a tour of the United States with Beck and recordings with the Kronos Quartet. "We had to define ourselves."
At the other end of the continent, in Argentina, a similar process was under way. A flourishing rock 'n' roll scene had emerged in Buenos Aires during the 1960's, but when a right-wing military junta seized power in the mid 1970's, the music was forced to retreat and only began to re-emerge after the collapse of the dictatorship following the Falklands War of 1982.
"It is no accident that we began around 1984," Mr. Cianciarulo said. Once civilian rule was restored, he said, "everything that had gone underground came out into the light of day, and freedom became the order of the day."
Though isolated from the rest of Latin America by language, Brazil saw its pop music evolve along the same lines. The tropicalists who first came to prominence in the late 1960's continue to flourish there, but groups like Paralamas do Suceso, Legiao Urbana, Titas, Skank, Charlie Brown Jr., Jota Quest, Barao Vermelho, Kid Abelha, Planet Hemp and Chico Science have forged an equally catholic, Portuguese-language variant of Latin rock.
Yet each nation's burgeoning rock scene might have continued in insularity were it not for recent advances in technology and more contacts between the local affiliates of multinational record companies. Perhaps the biggest factor in breaking down barriers, artists and managers agree, has been the explosive growth of cable television in Latin America during the last five years.
"MTV Latino and CNN en Espanol have been fundamental" in spreading rock en espanol, said Beto Cuevas, lead singer of the Chilean band La Ley, whose base is in Mexico. "They not only showed us what was happening in the United States at the same time it was happening, but also allowed us to see what was going on in Argentina or Colombia, countries that had their own rock tradition but hadn't been heard elsewhere because of a lack of communication."
But now, because of its very success, the movement, rebaptized Latin Alternative to make it more palatable to North American audiences, may be approaching a crossroads. Stimulated by the recent crossover success of home-grown Hispanic performers like Ricky Martin and Jennifer Lopez, interest in Latin American rock is growing in the United States, both among audiences hungry for new sounds and record companies eager for new profits.
THERE is now a Grammy award for best Latin Rock/Alternative performance, for instance, and several Latin rock songs have turned up in Hollywood films seeking an edgy tone, "Grosse Pointe Blank" and various Quentin Tarantino movies among them. College radio stations are adding rock en espanol to their playlists, Web sites and publications like Spin have begun to pay attention to the genre, and booking agencies like Creative Artists Agency have signed leading rock en espanol bands and sent them out on tour with established American pop artists.
"I know that I don't get calls from EMI Latino or Sony Discos anymore," said Tomas Cookman, manager of Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, Aterciopelados and other top groups, referring to the traditional Latin music departments of two big labels. "Now I'm more likely to be dealing with Maverick Records or Atlantic or Warners or Chris Blackwell. This is a wonderful moment, like the beginning of hip-hop, when Russell Simmons was just getting Def Jam together."
As a result, however, many of Latin America's most popular rock bands are facing a dilemma. Do they continue to focus on their loyal Spanish-speaking audience back home or do they shift more of their attention and energy to a potentially futile quest to break into the promising but unknown American market, at the risk of sacrificing what makes them authentic and perhaps alienating their original fans?
A hilariously sly new video by Los Fabulosos Cadillacs that has been in heavy rotation on MTV Latino in recent weeks makes it clear that at least one band recognizes the problem. The clip accompanying "La Vida" features an American image consultant, unable to speak Spanish and completely unattuned to the band's proudly grungy image and sound, trying to repackage them into a slick, dancing ensemble, a la 'N Sync or Ricky Martin.
Some artists, like Shakira, are convinced they can have it both ways. She recently signed a contract with the same management team that long guided Madonna's career and has spent much of the summer in the Bahamas, working on new material and translating some of her older songs for a projected English-language album.
"I want the chance to expand as an artist, and I'm curious," she said. "I want to know what's on the other side, how far I can take this thing. It's a challenge to sing in another language, but it's also an opportunity, and if I can have success in both languages, of course that will also bring credit to Colombia."
Julieta Venegas, in contrast, is a 29-year-old Mexican singer-songwriter who grew up in Tijuana, listening to California radio stations "with more a chance of seeing Iggy Pop or Oingo Boingo in San Diego" than hearing rock in Spanish. Though she speaks perfect English, the only suggestion of an accent being that of a Valley Girl, and recorded her latest disc in Los Angeles with American studio musicians, she insisted "it never occurred to me to write in English."
"I like having access to American music, but writing in Spanish is a big part of what I am and what makes my music interesting, even to someone who might not understand the language," she said. "We've been watching you people all the time, and now you're watching us. It's sort of funny, but it's true, and I think that's the way it's going to stay from now on, with everybody on both sides of the border exposed to a broader, richer range of influences."
 
To Try a New Sound
If the idea of Latin American rock and pop seems utterly foreign, here are a dozen records, chosen to display the diversity of the movement, that offer a good starting point for the beginner:
 
ATERCIOPELADOS -- "Caribe Atomico" (BMG 1998). Tropical punk? Psychedelic folk? It is hard to classify this eclectic collection from Colombia other than to say it never stops swinging, surprising or satisfying.
 
BLOQUE -- "Bloque de Busqueda" (Luaka Bop 1998). The group started as the back-up band for the vallenato star Carlos Vives, then made this record showing the darker side of Colombian pop, with acerbic lyrics and harsh heavy metal guitars over a driving Afro-Caribbean percussion section.
 
LOS FABULOSOS CADILLACS -- "Vasos Vacios" (Sony 1994). This Argentine ensemble has shown jazz leanings on its most recent records, but this early best-of compilation highlights its reggae-ska-dub-punk origins and includes the Brazilian-influenced "Matador," still its signature song.
 
CAIFANES -- "La Historia" (BMG/Ariola 1997). A two-disc set that traces the evolution of one of Mexico's most important groups from a clone of the Cure to a tight and deft ensemble proud of its Latin American origins.
 
CHARLY GARCIA -- "Obras Cumbres" (Sony 2000). A two-volume career retrospective from Latin America's foremost singer-songwriter, a disciple of Bob Dylan and the Beatles who has inspired a generation of younger artists. It includes "No Voy en Tren," perhaps the first rock en espanol anthem.
 
LOS AMIGOS INVISIBLES -- "The New Sound of the Venezuelan Gozadera" (Luaka Bop 1998). Dance music as self-referentially playful and goofy as anything the B-52's have ever recorded.
 
JAGUARES -- "El Equilibrio de los Jaguares" (BMG 1996). If rock en espanol has a guitar virtuoso, Mexico's Saul Hernandez is the man, and this brooding but beautiful collection of songs allows him to show off all his chops.
 
MANA -- "Suenos Liquidos" (WEA Latina 1997). The best-selling rock en espanol record ever, by a Guadalajara-based quartet that has parlayed a melodic, power-pop sound into unparalleled commercial success.
 
MOLOTOV -- "Donde Jugaran Las Ninas?" (Surco/Universal 1998). Bilingual rap from a binational quartet (three Mexicans and one gringo) that is by turns angry, scatological and humorous.
 
SHAKIRA -- "Donde Estan Los Ladrones?" (Sony 1998). At 23, this Colombian singer and songwriter has barely entered adulthood but already shows a striking talent for the polished, well-made pop tune, the most appealing of which here is probably the Arab-influenced "Ojos Asi."
 
CAFE TACUBA -- "Reves/Yo Soy" (WEA Latina 1999). A challenging two-disc collection (one of quirky instrumentals, the other of more conventional but stylistically diverse songs) that may be the crowning achievement of Mexico's most consistently adventurous and experimental rock band.
 
VARIOUS ARTISTS -- "Reconquista! The Latin Rock Invasion" (Rhino 1996). A chronicle of rock en espanol's early, punk-inspired years, with an emphasis on the Mexican pioneers of the movement but also including a pair of key cuts by Los Fabulosos Cadillacs. LARRY ROHTER

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/West Islip, Long Island;
Waterside, With a Range of Prices

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
RISING on a high tide of economic good times for Long Island, the generously proportioned, traditionally middle-income hamlet of West Islip on Suffolk County's South Shore has experienced an upward surge in housing prices that surprises veteran real estate professionals.
As surprising, they said, was how quickly homes listed for sale moved in this community of single-family Cape Cods, split-levels, colonials and ranches. 
 "Everything is up, across the board," said Geoffrey S. Matherson, the owner of a real estate agency in West Islip that bears his name. "But anyone who puts a sign on the lawn sells very quickly."
With its wide range in prices -- from more than $1 million for prime waterfront locations on or near Great South Bay to less than $200,000 in well-inland neighborhoods north of Sunrise Highway -- the community caters to a broad range of buyers, including young families priced out of more expensive but in other ways similar South Shore communities a few miles west in Nassau County.
Many new buyers come to West Islip, brokers and residents said, because of highly regarded local public schools. The school district line largely defines unincorporated West Islip, giving shape and form to an area without a downtown or identifiable center.
Lately, West Islip has had attention as the boyhood home of Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican candidate for United States Senate. Mr. Lazio, who speaks in campaign advertisements of his deep New York roots and lazy schoolboy days clamming on the bay, grew up on a quiet street south of Montauk Highway in a modest Cape, where his mother, Olive, still lives.
Mr. Lazio, a 1976 graduate of West Islip High School, returned there in June to deliver the commencement address to the class of 2000. "He's a hometown boy, and he has always been very concerned about this community," said Nancy Donohue, a West Islip resident for 27 years and the president of the West Islip Symphony Orchestra.
The 50-member orchestra holds three major concerts a year. Tickets are $5.
For others, it is what lies near but not in West Islip that adds much of the hometown feeling. The hamlet has a convenient entrance onto the Robert Moses Causeway, and ocean beaches and fishing are minutes away.
Getting to the city is not quite so simple. Without a railroad station of their own, city-bound West Islip commuters must drive about 10 minutes west to Babylon village, where an assortment of private lots provide parking.
"We have a lot of wives that run their husbands to the train," said Carl W. Riese, president and owner of Segal-Riese Realtors in West Islip.
Major shopping is a 10-minute drive away at the 1.3-million-square-foot Sunrise Mall in East Massapequa and the 846,000-square-foot South Shore Mall in Bay Shore. There are also stores and restaurants locally along Montauk Highway, Union Boulevard and Sunrise Highway.
In an indication of rising real estate prices that some brokers said were just now leveling off, a three-bedroom, one-bath ranch in the Concord Village neighborhood recently sold for $225,000. Houses there frequently sold for less than $200,000 a few years ago.
HOUSE rentals, when they can be found, are also getting more expensive. A three-bedroom, one-bath house recently rented for $1,700 a month. Rents are lower at the 15-unit Keith Garden Apartments, the hamlet's only rental complex, where two-bedroom units are about $900 a month. But there are no vacancies, Mr. Matherson said.
Mr. Matherson said there were also no vacancies at the hamlet's two condominium complexes. They are the 15-unit Sunrise Garden, where a two-bedroom unit sold for $160,000 in March 1999, and the recently completed South Country Estates, with 14 two-bedroom town houses that sold for about $250,000.
People tend to stay, and children come back. Virginia Bonfiglio, whose parents moved to West Islip from Queens in the early 1950's, now lives down the street from them and not far from her grown daughter. "That's three generations in a two-block radius," she said.
So many young families have moved here in recent years that the 5,800-student West Islip Union Free School District will reopen an elementary school in September, bringing the number to six. The high school had 307 graduates in the class of 2000, more than 90 percent of whom are going on to college, but enrollment in the bulging sixth grade exceeds 500.
In March 1999, district residents approved a whopping $52.9 million bond issue for more classrooms and renovations to all schools and the reopening of the Captree elementary school. There are two middle schools for grades six through eight.
Nearly 70 percent of June graduates earned Regents diplomas. Thirty-seven graduates scored more than 1,300 on the College Board examinations. Class averages of 497 in verbal and 507 in math were slightly above the state averages.
The high school offers advanced placement courses and extensive opportunities to use computers and is one of the few schools on Long Island to teach introductory Chinese. There is a specially designed classroom for students with special needs, half of whom are from outside the district. A partnership with Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center, which is in West Islip, teams students with medical professionals. A new global communications center is scheduled to open this fall.
THE center will employ computers, a satellite dish and Internet hookups to allow language students to tap directly into other cultures for audio and visual material -- newscasts, for example, or virtual tours of the Louvre given in French. Students will also be able to converse in real time with students in other countries. The classroom teacher will have computer capability to track students individually and send messages that appear on their monitors. The district said Mr. Lazio obtained the $176,000 federal grant to finance the center.
West Islip is also the home of St. John the Baptist diocesan high school, which draws 1,000 students in grades 9 through 12 from many parts of Long Island. Almost all of the 238 graduates in the Roman Catholic school's class of 2000 plan to go to college. Tuition is $4,375 a year for all students.
The school has a range of programs for its students, including the academically gifted and those with learning disabilities. An advanced placement program allows students to earn 32 college credits through St. John's University and New York Institute of Technology.
Boys' soccer teams have been standouts in the school's full athletic program, winning a national high school championship four years ago and league championships in two of the last three years.
There are five computer labs and all classrooms are linked to a school computer network. Internet use is integrated into course instruction. Students in the communications program produce a 22-minute program each weekday entitled "Good Morning St. John's" that is shown on the school's closed-circuit television system. The school also has an AM and and FM radio station.
THE school strives to create a Catholic community atmosphere. Non-Catholic students, whose numbers have been rising, make up less than 5 percent of the student body.
Students are required to wear blazers, dress shoes, oxford shirts and, for boys, ties. Hair cannot be too long, too short or faddish, and earrings are prohibited for boys, who must also be close-shaved. "If a major corporation does not allow orange hair, a goatee and five earrings, we don't allow it either," said the Rev. Jim Vlaun, the school chaplain.
A Catholic elementary school, Our Lady of Lourdes, has 375 students in prekindergarten through the eighth grade. Tuition for the half-day prekindergarten classes is $85 a month, rising to $200 a month for kindergarten through the eighth grade. Nonparishioners pay $25 a month more.
The Town of Islip's 14.5-acre Casamento Park, the largest outdoor recreation area in West Islip, has ball fields, a picnic spot and courts for tennis, basketball and handball. Season permits for the park's swimming pool complex, which is opened from mid-June to Labor Day, are $125 for a family and $80 for an individual.
There are 134 boat slips, and a two-year waiting list, at the Town of Islip's beach and marina. The docking fee is $34 a foot. There is also a boat ramp.
The original inhabitants of the area, the Secatogue Indians, lived along the bay and on Sumpwams Creek and what is now called Willetts Creek. They sold the land to Thomas and William Willetts in 1692. The area remained a fishing and farming enclave until wealthy estate owners arrived more than a century later.
By the mid-1800's, the railroad had arrived in nearby Babylon, and lumber and charcoal industries were prospering. Ukrainians arrived early in the 20th century, and by 1930 there were 734 residents.
The eastward-rolling suburbanization of Long Island struck in the early 1950's and peaked by the early 1970's, the 20-year period in which most homes were built. The population by 1970 was slightly higher than it is today.
But school enrollment hints that new peaks may lie ahead. "We are experiencing a population boom here," said Nancy M. Lenz, a school district spokeswoman.

NONSTOP FAIR: Twenty-five years ago, a small group of West Islip residents met to discuss doing something to mark the nation's Bicentennial celebration in 1976. They settled on a crafts fair that proved so popular that the West Islip Bicentennial Committee still stages it annually. So on Sept. 24, the 25th annual crafts fair, the year's major event in West Islip, will bring 400 artisans, four bands, assorted magicians and clowns, plus pony rides and a petting zoo, to the grounds of the West Islip Library at Montauk Highway and Higbie Lane. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Developers Meeting Demand for Warehouse Space

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WAREHOUSE distribution buildings, some as large as city blocks, are sprouting across New Jersey. Hoping to lasso the state's bullish industrial market, developers are constructing such buildings with -- or without -- specific tenants in place.
Two projects illustrate the different approaches developers are taking to meet what they say -- and commercial brokers agree -- is an unmet demand for modern warehouses with high ceilings of 32- to 38-feet, to accommodate racking systems. "Businesses change, and a 1930's warehouse can no longer serve the needs of a year 2000 company," said David T. Houston, the president of Colliers Houston, a commercial real estate brokerage and services firm in Teaneck. 
 The demand, Mr. Houston added, is coming from tenants who are expanding into new buildings or consolidating operations to increase efficiency.
In the Secaucus section of the Meadowlands, Hartz Mountain Industries will start driving piles next month for a 338,850-square-foot industrial building for the Lantis Eyewear Corporation, a designer and distributor of sunglasses, based in Manhattan. Lantis will consolidate its warehouse, distribution and administrative functions, which are now in three different locations in Bergen and Hudson Counties.
The new building on Secaucus Road is expected to be completed next summer. Lantis will lease the building, which will provide the growing company with an additional 100,000 square feet of space, for 15 years. The project's estimated cost, including the value of the lease, is over $40 million.
Hartz, which is one of the largest property owners in the Meadowlands, is also in negotiations with another tenant to build a second 300,000-square-foot building on the same 35-acre Secaucus Road site.
Heller Industrial Parks is taking a different tack in Edison, where it has begun work on a speculative project. Its two buildings, one with 171,411 square feet and the other with 958,446 square feet, will rise on 52 acres in the company's 410-acre industrial park at the end of Mill Road. The $34 million project will include a $1 million 8,937-square-foot children's day-care center, which will replace a smaller center that will be razed to make way for the new buildings.
The 1.3-million-square-foot development follows two earlier speculative projects, with one with one million square feet and the other with 1.25 million, that Heller, which is based in Edison, has built in the last five years at the park. The two new buildings, expected to be finished in the next 12 months, will complete the park, which will eventually contain nearly eight million square feet of space.
The Secaucus and Edison buildings are part of a spate of projects totaling 5.2 million square feet now under construction in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market. The current pace of construction is consistent with that of the last two years, when 12.5 million square feet was completed, brokers said.
But the focus of the new construction, they added, has increasingly been on speculative projects. Tenants often want warehouses to be ready when they decide to enter or expand in markets, Mr. Houston of Colliers Houston and other commercial brokers said.
MUCH of the new space continues to go up in the central part of the state. Such traditional magnets as Edison and the area around Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike are particular hot spots. The activity is also moving farther south on the turnpike to Exit 7A in Mercer County but is limited in northern New Jersey by the lack of suitably zoned land.
Despite the addition of new space, "the rate of construction has not exceeded demand," Mr. Houston said, adding that large blocks of space of 200,000 to 500,000 square feet are difficult to find. Strong leasing activity and the conversion of older industrial buildings to technology centers has kept the lid on supply, he said.
In the second quarter the industrial vacancy rate in the northern and central parts of the state dropped to 3.2 percent from 4.4 percent in the second quarter of 1999. At the same time, average rental rates have hovered around $5 a square foot a year, according to Grubb & Ellis, the commercial brokerage firm.
Joel M. Orenstein, a senior vice president of Grubb & Ellis, noted that the new buildings were often substantially leased before they were completed. An example is the 300,000 square feet of space that Anixter, a Chicago-based distributor of data communication products and electrical wire and cable, has leased in a 501,400-square-foot building under construction at the 150-acre Cranbury Business Park, three miles from Exit 8A. Mr. Orenstein, who represented Anixter in the transaction, said the company would be expanding from a smaller space elsewhere in the 8A area.
Most brokers said the overall industrial market was expected to remain healthy through the rest of the year. Mr. Orenstein, for example, said that he knew of five prospective tenants who were looking for buildings of one million square feet or more in New Jersey, and four others who needed 200,000 to 400,000 square feet. He would not name them.
Tenants' demands for larger blocks of space is what Heller Industrial Parks is banking on to fill its two new buildings in Edison. Jeffrey J. Milanaik, the company's president, said that despite the risks involved in so large a speculative project, which the company is financing itself, "it enables us to achieve an economy of scale."
The smaller 171,000-square-foot building will be divided in half, and two prospective tenants have expressed interest in the space, Mr. Milanaik said. He said the larger 958,446-square-foot building has been designed for tenants needing 200,000 square feet or more, but the space could be divided into areas as small as 70,000 square feet.
T HE current project, like the earlier ones at the industrial park, has received a five-year tax abatement from the Edison Township Council. "We needed a little help because the cost of constructing on the site is more expensive" -- costs have gone up and the soil is softer than usual, Mr. Milanaik said. But with the abatement, rents can be kept competitive at $5.25 a square foot, he said.
Mr. Milanaik said if the "market holds steady until next year," he expected his company to move into the Interchange 8A market with a 202-acre project in South Brunswick that will have up to four million square feet in five buildings. He said the first 1.25-million-square foot building would be built on speculation.
Commercial brokers said the Meadowlands region continued to draw attention from tenants that want to be near Manhattan. That area, which covers parts of seven communities in Bergen and Hudson Counties, has a vacancy rate of 3.2 percent and average rents of $5.80 a square foot, the highest in the state, according to Grubb & Ellis.
"Until the inventory of existing space was absorbed over the last five years, the cost of constructing new buildings was still greater" than renovating existing ones, said Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz Mountain Industries, which has enough vacant sites in the Meadowlands to accommodate buildings totaling one and half to two million square feet. "Now we're seeing the demand for space push into our developable land."
Hartz had originally planned to build a 300,000-square-foot outlet mall on the Secaucus Road site where the Lantis Eyewear project will rise. "While the market for outlet malls has not been hot, the industrial market here is hopping," Mr. Stern said, explaining why he dropped the plans for the mall.
While Mr. Stern said his company "toyed with the idea of building a speculative ware-house" on Secaucus Road, the deal with Lantis Eyewear surfaced.
The deal ends a yearlong search for new quarters for Lantis, which has grown to 750 employees in the last decade, 450 of them working in the three New Jersey locations. "We are totally jammed in and hungry for space," said Lon J. Moellentine, the company's president and chief executive.
Mr. Moellentine said his company looked at speculative buildings in "the middle of cornfields as far as 7A on the turnpike," before opting to join with Hartz at the Secaucus site. "We were driven by labor," he said, noting that "while rents are significantly higher in northern New Jersey, that will be offset by the benefit of continuity." He said he expected all of his New Jersey employees to make the move to the Secaucus property, which will "give us room to grow."

HEADLINE: The View From/West Hartford;
Once a Home for Milk Trucks, Now a Theater in the Round

BYLINE: By PATRICIA WEISS

 BODY:
WEST HARTFORD, virtually equidistant between Boston and New York, has long capitalized on its proximity to more live culture than a lifetime supply of yogurt. Now, with construction under way on the Park Road Playhouse, the town is about to gain the first live theater of its 146-year-old history.
"It's long overdue, and I think we have the infrastructure and the demographics to support it," said the town's mayor, Rob Bouvier. "West Hartford has had a longstanding tradition of embracing and supporting the arts." 
 The theater, scheduled to open next winter, has already gained support. More than $375,000 of its $500,000 budget has been raised, including a $200,000 grant from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, $100,000 from the State Office of Policy and Management and $27,000 from the town's community development fund. An additional $50,000 has come from individuals.
"But the support, I think, is even above and beyond dollars and cents," said Barry Feldman, the town manager who is so enthusiastic that he submitted himself to public ridicule last spring at a roast to benefit the project. "That's evidenced on almost a daily basis," Mr. Feldman said, "by hundreds if not thousands of volunteer hours, from people who serve on the board of the theater to interested residents who donate their time to help do some demolition work in the building in which the theater is going to ultimately be housed."
That building is the former A. C. Petersen Farms dairy on Park Road, a terra cotta structure adjoining a 1939 Art Deco ice cream parlor still popular for its sundaes topped with hand-whipped heavy cream. In a garage where 48 milk trucks once revved up for their rounds, the curtain will soon rise on a theater in the round.
Mr. Feldman and other community leaders hope that the playhouse will be a kind of catalyst for development along the avenue, where $5 million has just been spent on improvements such as lighting and paving as well as burying power lines under a completely rebuilt roadway.
"This is something that's going to be very important in the future of West Hartford," said Rob Rowlson, who is in charge of business development for the town. "I think from this other things will grow, such as opportunities for artists in residence who will come here, do work and perform and expose our community to creative efforts we don't normally see otherwise."
"This thing could spiral," said Angelo Faenza, a restaurateur and president of the Park Road Merchants Association, noting that "when I first got involved in it, I had artists from Bridgeport and New Haven call me wondering if there would be studio space available for them in the building." Mr. Faenza said he thought that a busy theater might attract new businesses such as restaurants and boutiques, as well as generate other attractions. "Once you have the staging and the lights set," he said, "and you get a marquee out there, this place could be used every night, whether it be for a comedy show or jazz."
No one is as eager for the playhouse to open as its artistic director. The venture may be a major first for the town, yet for Howard Hirsch it is very much part of a second chance.
Mr. Hirsch, a 63-year-old advertising executive, once aspired to a life in the theater. But that ambition was overridden by the need to feed a growing family. Although he remained active in local theater (as artistic director of the Mark Twain Masquers), his dream of running a theater was relegated to the list of things he hoped to do someday. That changed abruptly five years ago when Mr. Hirsch said he "woke up and realized I'd almost run out of somedays." Mr. Hirsch had entered the hospital for an angioplasty, but there were complications and he was put on a list for a heart transplant. The doctors summoned his family; that's when they got word that a heart suitable for transplant had been found. And Mr. Hirsch said he knew just what to do with his revival.
Virginia Woolf once said a writer needs a room of her own. For a community theater troupe to thrive, Mr. Hirsch said, it too needs a permanent space.
"It's terribly important from an economic standpoint," he explained. "If you have your own theater, the lights, seats, working space and sound equipment are all installed. If you're performing at a school, church or other borrowed facility, you have to rent all those things and pay a crew to install them. That can cause production costs to double."
Having space to call home, he said, is also essential in attracting a faithful audience. "People like to feel comfortable knowing where they're going," he said. "Imagine if you subscribed to a six-show season, and each time you had to find a new place."
When a company has its own stage, the audience arrives with a different attitude. "They walk in expecting more, a higher level of both performance and production," he said. "It allows the company to reach higher. You can choose subject matter and plays that are more thoughtful and far-reaching."
That is what Mr. Hirsch hopes to do on Park Road. "I've worked in community theater now for about 40 years," he said, "and the reason I want to start my own theater company is to stretch further and to do plays that, while entertaining and exciting, can also be thought-provoking and informative."
The first season is expected to include "The Real Thing," by Tom Stoppard, and Arthur Miller's work "The Price." He considers each one ideal for the space, which will have just 168 seats.
Park Road, of course, is way off Broadway. It isn't even Main Street. This will indeed be community theater, although Mr. Hirsch said that doesn't mean acting that is amateurish.
"When I had my ad agency, I used to go into New York to cast commercials. You'd have a cattle call, and who came? People from Albuquerque, Buffalo and Hartford. They'd been in the city for 60 days, signed with an agent and suddenly they were 'New York talent.' It didn't take me long to realize that talent is all over the place. You find it in every walk of life -- doctors, teachers, salespeople, postmen, housewives, plumbers."
The organization's directors, by design, also come from other fields. "This theater had to have a business sense," he said, "as well as an artistic one."
Among the board members he recruited are business owners, community leaders, engineers and academicians.
"When you have theater people on a board," Mr. Hirsch said, "their primary concerns are which plays are you doing that I like, which ones have parts for me, and which have parts for my friends."
One of Mr. Hirsch's most ardent volunteers is Plato Karafelis, the principal of an elementary school, who became involved on the condition that the playhouse have an educational component.
Mr. Karafelis said he would like the theater to offer children's plays performed by adults, as well as scripts written and performed by children, student playwriting contests, poetry slams and excursions to Broadway shows.
"There is no comprehensive children's theater program here," said Mr. Karafelis, "and boy, if there's a town that's ripe for it, that would be West Hartford."
It is an idea that Mr. Hirsch readily embraces.
"Most kids have no idea what live theater is about," he said, and with television, movies, CD's and the Internet, "theater is in competition for the young mind, and it's a battle it could actually lose."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Manhattan Market;
Office Rents Are Up Sharply in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
OFFICE rents, which have been rising steadily for several years, spiked upward in the second quarter of this year, leading some real estate executives to express concern that vital service providers, such as smaller law and accounting firms, may be driven out of Manhattan.
According to figures compiled by the Williams Real Estate company, the average annual asking rent for office space in Manhattan increased 16.9 percent in the three months that ended in June, to $54.44 a square foot. Asking rents have increased 28.1 percent since the beginning of the year; the year-to-year increase was 35.3 percent. 
 The increase in rents is directly linked to the shrinking amount of space available for occupancy. Williams calculates that the overall vacancy rate for all office space in Manhattan is 5.1 percent, a decrease of 14.2 percent during the second quarter and a drop of 47.7 percent from June 1999.
And the averages understate the actual shortage of space available at what many consider affordable rents. In the Midtown market, 53.5 percent of the space on the market had an asking annual rent under $50 a square foot at the end of the second quarter of 1999. By the end of June this year, only 9 percent of the space was under $50 a square foot.
"A plausible Midtown business address is going to cost at least $55 a square foot and more likely $60 or $70," said Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams. "For a while the financial district was the last refuge for companies priced out of Midtown, but it's not a refuge anymore. The space has been absorbed, and the rents spiked again in the last quarter."
The downtown business district had a 12 percent availability rate at the end of the second quarter of 1999 and an average annual rental rate in the low $30's a square foot. By the end of June this year, the availability was under 6 percent and the average rent over $40 a square foot.
"The vacancy rate is at the lowest point in 20 years," said Steven A. Swerdlow, senior managing director of the New York office of CB Richard Ellis, a real estate services company. "And rents have eclipsed the highs of the early 1980's on an inflation-adjusted basis."
The strength of the market is all the more remarkable because of the recovery from the financial crises in several parts of the world in the fall of 1998, said Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, a brokerage and property management company. "People were very concerned there would be no liquidity, but now with the economy healthy and growing, everybody needs space."
Once again the averages mask some of the high points in a market where prosperous companies needing space to grow compete with one another for the limited amount available. "I am negotiating rates that start at $115 a square foot," said Tara Stacom, an executive director at Cushman & Wakefield, a large brokerage and real estate services company. "My father Matthew J. Stacom, also an official at Cushman & Wakefield predicted we would see rates of $100 a square foot by the end of the century, and people told him he was crazy. Well here we are and here they are."
Mr. Cohen said he was concerned that Manhattan would become home to an elite, with only the biggest, richest companies able to pay the rent to stay at prime locations. He said it would be bad for the city in the long term, and bad for his business as well.
Medium-size law firms, those with fewer than 100 lawyers, and moderate-size accounting firms are coming under intense pressure as a result of the rising rents. He said that one law firm that is his client -- which he would not name -- recently agreed to a rent increase before the expiration of its current lease to avoid being pushed immediately to the market rate when it rolls over.
"You like to think of New York as a land of opportunity, with a quilt of entrepreneurial companies of different sizes," he said. "But if only the big, rich companies can afford to stay, that thins out the city's economic base and leaves it vulnerable in the long term."
IN addition to the big picture, Mr. Cohen said he had strong little-picture fears as well. "I am a purchaser of legal and accounting services and I get better quality services when there are many firms competing for my business," he said. "If high rents thin out the ranks of local services providers, that works to my disadvantage."
Mr. Swerdlow said he also saw that as a danger. "There will be haves and have nots," he said. He said that Internet and new-media companies say they cannot afford to wait for new construction, such as the million-square-foot building Forest City Ratner Companies is planning at its Metrotech complex in Brooklyn, and so they increase the pressure in the existing market.
If only the richest companies can remain in Manhattan, "it changes the fabric of city life," said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, a real estate brokerage and services company. "It will be different if only the top knowledge workers and their immediate support staff remain, and the effects will ripple out to the stores and restaurants."
Real estate executives said they saw nothing on the horizon to dampen the office market in Manhattan and said it would continue to drive tenants to look for alternatives such as Jersey City and the rest of the New Jersey coast facing the city. Many say they expect more building in downtown Brooklyn and in the Long Island City section of Queens.
And the remaining fringes of Manhattan are expected to be renovated for tenants who cannot overcome a reluctance to cross a river.
"We are going to see a lot of activity on 11th and 12th Avenues between 30th and 59th Street," said James S. Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a brokerage specializing in representing tenants.
This area is one of the last sections of Manhattan that is primarily industrial, with garage, warehouses and distribution centers. But the successful conversion of old factories farther south in Chelsea to offices for new media and Internet companies makes it likely there will be demand for office space farther north.
The high rents for office space are forcing companies to decide how many people they actually need in Manhattan, and how many might be just as well based in less costly boroughs and suburbs, real estate executives say.
Regardless of the effect it may have on the ambience of the city, economics are forcing tenant companies to look hard at their Manhattan operations. "Every business has to consider why they are here," Ms. Tighe said. "They have to determine what kind of work has a profit margin that justifies housing a person in Manhattan."
As companies split their operations, with only the high-value-added jobs staying in Manhattan, the boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens should benefit, she said. "Queens is going to be hopping and downtown Brooklyn is going to be active too," Ms. Tighe said. "These areas have not shared in the job growth because, at least in the past, people wanted Manhattan addresses."
But even soaring rents are not a deterrent to companies that are lacking an even more precious commodity: skilled workers to operate the business.
"I have two clients who moved out and are trying to move back in," Ms. Stacom said. "They couldn't find the labor they needed and they're trying to come back because New York still has the right labor supply."
