HEADLINE: On Stage, a Dancer's Busy Life

BYLINE: By E. KYLE MINOR

 BODY:
FRANK ROOT can breeze through Fairfield, his hometown, without being recognized, but there is hardly a Broadway dancer who doesn't know him. He has worked steadily as a supporting actor and director for more than 20 years, including choreographing as many as 7,000 dancers in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Currently, Mr. Root is performing in "George M!" at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in the supporting role of George M. Cohan's father, Jerry.
"I've played George 15 years ago and I've played Jerry before, too," Mr. Root said after a recent performance. "I'm more like Jerry Cohan than George. Jerry was polite, sedate. He didn't like getting in people's way." 
 On stage, Mr. Root is hardly sedate and yet never in people's way. Other than John Scherer in the title role, Mr. Root has the busiest feet in the production. He takes part in 18 of the 29 musical numbers, which is more than many of the company members nearly half his age. There aren't many middle-aged hoofers who can handle the load eight performances a week. "Frank is a wonderful performer and a wonderful person," said Greg Ganakas, director of the musical. "It is a demanding role, but Frank is a tireless worker."
One reason Mr. Root can handle the rigors of his role is that he has been dancing since his childhood in St. Louis. His mother, a dancer, started Mr. Root in classes when he was 7, along with his three sisters. By the time he was in his early 20's, Mr. Root had developed into an accomplished dancer, specializing in tap.
Mr. Root has performed on Broadway and in national touring productions of "42nd Street," "Mack and Mabel" and "Pirates of Penzance," to name a few. He has also directed and choreographed roughly a dozen other professional productions. Not strictly a song and dance man, Mr. Root also acts in straight plays, such as the Off Broadway production of "Dealer's Choice" a few seasons ago. He also teaches acting at New York University.
In 1977 his dance training introduced him to more than just work. He met Marianne Challis, a singer and actress, during a production of "Follies" at the Milwaukee Melody Tent. The two never parted and married a few years later. The couple worked together often, which is not easy in a business that offers more than enough unemployment for single people. Mr. Root has in fact worked so much that this is his fifth production of "George M!," a relatively obscure musical in which few of today's young actors get a chance to perform.
"George M!" was originally produced on Broadway in 1968 with Joel Grey in the title role. The show vaguely chronicles the life of the original "Yankee Doodle Dandy" from his youthful days in the family act, "The Four Cohans," through his last hurrah in the 1937 musical spoof of F.D.R., "I'd Rather Be Right."
Written by Michael Stewart and Francine and John Pascal, "George M!" features the best of Cohan's popular music, from his romantic "Mary's a Grand Old Name" to his banner-waving "You're a Grand Old Flag." The musical is based on both Mr. Cohan's autobiography and the 1942 film "Yankee Doodle Dandy," in which James Cagney won his only Oscar in the leading role. Considering that "George M!" opened during the height of the Vietnam war, it was a solid hit with its 437-performance run. "The show is fairly honest in its portrayal of Cohan," Mr. Root said. "He was pretty egotistical and not the most popular person in the business."
Mr. Root said that his favorite moment in the show is when Mr. Cohan shows his vulnerability. "It's right before George opens his first big hit, 'Little Johnny Jones,' " he said. "The curtain's about to go up when George tells Jerry he's afraid to fail. That relieves Jerry, who tells him that now he's ready to be a hit."
This is Mr. Root's first show at Goodspeed. He said he enjoyed working close to home so he could spend time with Ms. Challis and their two children, Lonnie and Abigail.
"Marianne and I have lots of friends who have worked here," Mr. Root said, "so we've come up to see shows. I really like it. It's beautiful. The town is so quaint." But, he added: "The best thing is the work. Although I really enjoy teaching and directing, my first love has been performing. This show is a lot of work, but I'm enjoying it."
"George M!" is at Goodspeed Opera in East Haddam through Oct. 7. (860) 873-8668. Tickets $20-$42.

HEADLINE: From Suitcases on Wheels To Tear-Free Onion Slicers

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
THEY all laughed when Edison recorded sound," Ira Gershwin wrote in 1937. They also laughed at Bernard Sadow and the funny-looking suitcase on wheels he tugged into Macy's one morning.
Mr. Sadow and his prototype were ridiculed and rejected by a buyer for Macy's, which carried the conventional luggage Mr. Sadow's company, U.S. Luggage, made. 
 But this was 1972, and no one knew from luggage on wheels. Soon, the glum luggage manufacturer found himself wheeling his idea right back out.
"They said, 'No one's going to pull a suitcase on the end of a strap,' " Mr. Sadow recalled.
But two weeks later, he got an appointment with a Macy's vice president who was soon doing just that: towing the suitcase around his office, giggling with glee. He called in the naysaying buyer and, smiling broadly at him, asked: "So, Jack, what do you think of my new idea?" recalled Mr. Sadow. "He looked at me and then back at the boss, and he said, 'Great, I love it.' "
The executive told the buyer to buy, and that was the start of wheels on luggage. Mr. Sadow, 75, recalled it all recently in the well-furnished living room of his sprawling Chappaqua home. Besides getting the last laugh, Mr. Sadow still receives licensing fees from manufacturers selling bags using his 1972 patent on rolling luggage.
"I know they're still selling because I watch the royalty checks coming in," Mr. Sadow said.
Westchester has had a long tradition of inventors. Most of the large corporations in the county, like International Business Machines, keep a stable of inventors on staff to develop technologies and processes. But more and more independent inventors are springing up, setting up shop in basements and garages around the county.
The county is still known for buttoned-down bankers and lawyers catching the 6:58, not eccentric shock-haired geniuses crying "Eureka!" from their workshops.
But, according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office, about 600 inventions a year are dreamed up in Westchester and patented. In New York State, only Monroe County, where Rochester-based Kodak is situated, had more patents last year at 1,549. By comparison, Manhattan had 533 and Nassau 351.
Inventors proliferate in areas with large corporations and high-education levels, said Richard J. Apley, director of the office of independent inventor programs for the Patent and Trademark Office.
Inventing is on the rise for a number of reasons, said Joanne Hayes-Rines, editor and publisher of Inventors' Digest magazine in Boston. The economy is booming, and the Internet provides a marketplace for inventors to sell their devices, as well as an information resource.
For Mr. Sadow, inspiration came one day in 1971 when he was lugging a large suitcase through customs and a man breezed by towing heavy machinery on a dolly.
"I said, 'Now that's what we need, wheels on luggage,' " recalled Mr. Sadow, who took the heavy casters from a large trunk and fastened them to the bottom of a suitcase. He tied a rope to it, "and it worked like a charm," he said.
Since then, his inventions include air-cushioned carrying cases for laptop computers, electric toothpicks and training wheels for tipsy suitcases. His latest innovation, a spray dispenser for holy water, now sells for $19.95 at the gift shop at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.
Of course, not every inventor is as successful as Mr. Sadow.
So far, Vince and Patrice Cacciatore of Yonkers have not made any profit from their inventions; not from their toothpaste tube key, nor from their cough drop lollipop for children.
They are devout Catholics and say they invent in the name of the Lord. They hope their latest inventions hit big, so they can use the profits to rent billboard space for biblical quotations.
Mr. Cacciatore, who owns a copy machine repair service, invented a cardboard platform for take-out pizza boxes, to keep the pies from getting soggy by letting air circulate under the crust.
Mrs. Cacciatore invented memorial picture frames for owners of deceased pets. The pet's photo goes in the front and its crematory ashes go in the rear. The frames, which come in mirror and black acrylic finishes, have just gone on the Internet at a starting price of $18.99. Larger containers for human remains are coming.
On average, it takes 18 months to get a patent approved. Most applications are prepared by lawyers, who charge an average of $5,000 an application. Costs vary enormously to build a prototype and market it to manufacturers.
Inventing and then successfully marketing a product are very different things, said Stephen I. Mayo of New Rochelle, who owns Artistic Office Products in the Bronx.
"Some of your best inventions don't sell," he said, "and the least patentable turn out to be best sellers."
Mr. Mayo recently patented two items but wound up marketing only one -- a simple wire device he made to fit as a coat hook over an office cubicle partition. But his innovative retractable wall hook, an idea he got from a clothes hook in an airplane bathroom, never appealed to customers, so he shelved it.
Nowadays, he said, independent inventors find it more difficult to persuade retailers to carry their products.
"There's less interest in product innovation because the stakes are huge, and buyers don't want to take chances," Mr. Mayo said. "It's hard to introduce a new item unless you have big money behind you. Buyers don't want a product that's not backed by national advertising."
Rachel Kaminsky, a third grader from Ardsley, has not yet sought national advertising for her invention, a device for cutting onions without crying, but she did get national recognition and she is preparing an application for a patent.
Her "Dry Eyes" onion slicer helped her win a $5,000 savings bond in a national contest held this spring by Sears, Roebuck & Company and the National Science Teachers Association, becoming the only finalist from a region that includes New York and several other states (and the youngest in the country).
Rachel, 8, took an inventing class last fall at her school, the Concord Road Elementary School. She devised the slicer after her mother asked her to help in the kitchen by chopping onions. With her tears came a vow to solve the problem.
She made a dome out of a clear plastic bowl, attached a circular apple cutter to the bottom and a cloth screen to the top with an attached pouch of baking soda to absorb the onion odor.
Her mother said Rachel had long created inventions out of household items, like the view-finder she made to teach her little brother left and right.
As for the slicer, "We use it all the time," Mrs. Kaminsky said. "She thinks it should be in Lechter's."
Despite stories of Nobel Prizes and comfortable fellowships, inventing is tough, tedious work and rarely lives up to its sometimes romantic image.
"You hear about flashes of brilliance, that's the sexy part," said Neil Baldwin, author of "Edison: Inventing the Century" (Hyperion Books, 1995). "But stamina and persistence are as important as creativity."
Edison filled 3,000 notebooks with his ideas, Mr. Baldwin said, and he once spent 100 nights in his workshop, staying away from his family at home. His wife often complained about his absence from the dinner table.
The family of Richard J. Maiaro, an inventor from New Rochelle, knows the feeling. When he is on the verge of a breakthrough idea, he said, "it weighs on your brain till you come up with a solution."
"Sometimes I'll be at the dinner table with my kids, and I'll be in another world," he said. "The next thing I know, my 10-year-old son's looking at me, saying, 'Daddy, Daddy, where are you?' "
Mr. Maiaro had trouble with his earlier inventions. His idea for an alarm system operated by a remote key-chain switch was rejected by Cadillac. Discouraged, he never patented the idea, which has since become standard in the automobile industry. Then he designed a pen that was easier and cheaper to assemble than the competition's designs, but his silent partner began showing off the design and another manufacturer beat him to the patent and to market.
Now, Mr. Maiaro is trying to market two machines he recently invented. One is a machine that prints two colors simultaneously on promotional pens or pencils.
Printers have long had problems aligning pens correctly to add multiple layers of color, but Mr. Maiaro's machine marks the pen with invisible dye, which is then sensed by a scanner when positioning the pen for additional layers. His machine can print logos on 20,000 pens in eight hours, and he has sold two so far, for $70,000 apiece.
Last march, he patented a safety apparatus for a weight-lifting bench. The unit extends above the bench press, lifting the barbell with a winch if the user becomes too fatigued.
The Patent Office said one of the largest groups of applications involves exercise equipment.
Brian M. Dugan, a patent lawyer from Tarrytown, developed with one of his professors from Yale, Dr. Robert D. Grober, a device to teach golfers proper swing tempo.
The device is slipped onto the shaft of a golf club, and using an accelerometer, the device emits an even tone when the user is swinging smoothly.
Mr. Dugan has also patented another exercise feedback device, a hand-held computer game based on the user's exertion level during exercise. The more strenuous the workout, the better the computer character kickboxes his way out of captivity.
But "you don't have to be a technical genius, or come up with some breakthrough in computer technology to patent a succesful product," said Richard C. Wingate, a marketing lawyer for Sony Electronics.
Mr. Wingate, from Scarsdale, invented a wireless headphone set with a retractable microphone, which allows the user to answer the phone while listening to the stereo and television.
Looking for a headlight for night jogging, he fastened a small halogen penlight to his radio headphones and patented it.
"It's about having an idea that's useful and that nobody's thought of before you," Mr. Wingate said.
While many part-time inventors dream of doing it full time, some who work in research and development departments for large corporations complain that the patents, and most of the profits, go to the company.
Joseph R. Infantino worked 30 years for AMF, the sporting goods manufacturer, in its Stamford laboratories as the chief plastics chemist. He regularly met with athletes like Ben Hogan, Guillermo Vilas and Arthur Ashe, discussing the products they endorsed for AMF.
Mr. Infantino, 67, a lifelong Chappaqua resident, developed equipment like tennis rackets, skis and swim fins. His inventions for bowling alleys brought bowling into the modern era, where perfect games have become commonplace.
In the late 60's, he used a hard plastic called Surlyn to coat bowling pins, making them livelier and more durable. He also developed the urethane bowling ball, which had superior traction and could be hooked by bowlers to get consistent strikes.
He patented the inflatable interior used in Head ski boots, a concept now widely used in sneakers, and he patented a florescent bowling pin, now used by alleys for rock 'n' roll bowling.
In all, he had 16 inventions for AMF, most of which got him a handshake and a $100 bonus, he said.
"You sign your life away to these big corporations," he said, adding that if he had shared in the profits, "I'd be on the Italian Riviera right now."
Now he applies for his own patents and sells licensing rights to AMF.
In the cramped basement boiler room, crowded by boxes of pasta and cans of Campbell's soup, he works on improving bowling pins. He recently patented an improved method to adhere hard covers to the pins, which he is licensing to AMF for a six-figure payment.
Another corporate defector is Steven Linder, the self-proclaimed "king of inflatable furniture" and a former executive with the Ethan Allen furniture company.
Seeing inflatable cushions and seats that "were more like blobs," Mr. Linder designed a fully inflatable armchair and patented it in 1994, starting an inflatable furniture fad that pervaded college dormitories, tailgate parties and the living rooms of armchair quarterbacks.
Mr. Linder's Purchase-based Sterling Promotions company sells the chairs, which usually bear the logos of professional sports teams or beer companies.
His Dallas Cowboys ottoman, that doubles as an ice chest, and the Britney Spears armchair, are both evidence that inventions need not be groundbreaking contributions to modern science to sell.
With nine patents for inflatable furniture, Mr. Linder, 52, proudly boasts, "I've taken inflatable furniture to another level."
 
A Stable Full of Chemists, Physicists and Scientists
Most companies that deal in intellectual property keep large stables of inventors. Three of the state's top four patent recipients -- I.B.M., Xerox and General Electric -- have large offices in Westchester.
I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center, the company's largest laboratory, occupies three buildings in Yorktown Heights and Hawthorne. Many innovations in information technology have come from the Watson labs, from semiconductor technology to the first "super computers" to the software that runs E-commerce systems.
The center's research and development staff includes 1,400 inventors -- chemists, physicists and computer scientists -- said Paul M. Horn, chief inventor for I.B.M.
The company spends roughly $6 billion annually on research and development worldwide and last year earned $1.3 billion from licensing fees. It has produced five Nobel prize winners and more patents than any other company in the world, Mr. Horn said.

HEADLINE: IN SEARCH OF...;
It's Colonel Mustard in the Kitchen

BYLINE: By JOSEPH D'AGNESE

 BODY:
YOU can call him Paul Fischer. Or you can call him Paul. Or you can call him Mr. Fischer. But if you really want to get to heart of the matter, call him Mister Mustard. Really. He doesn't mind. Everybody calls him that.
For 28 years the Mr. Fischer, a 69-year-old Franklin Lakes resident, has owned and operated House of Herbs Inc., a Passaic company that puts out jars of a spicy condiment called Mister Mustard. It's a quirky brand that sports a retro image of a chef with a luxuriant mustachio and a dreamy look in his eyes. 
 "How shall I describe it?" said Mr. Fischer. "We make a mustard that's better in quality than the run-of-the-mill, but we're not a Grey Poupon."
Ah, but it's a Jersey mustard, and that's got to count for something.
More sophisticated than ketchup, more daring than mayo, mustard is the king of condiments, and the condiment of kings. King Louis XI of France traveled everywhere with his mustard pot. He would always have a supply on hand -- and he neatly sidestepped nasty poisoning plots. During the 14th century Avignon Papacy, Pope John XXII named his nephew Chief Mustardeer to the Pope. And Thomas Jefferson, who was consumed as much with perfecting the gardens surrounding Monticello as he was with nailing down inalienable rights, planted mustard seeds after sampling a good Dijon during his French ambassadorship.
Travel the nation in this season of beaches, ball games and cookouts, and you'll find millions slathering yellow or brown paste on their dogs and sausages, their pretzels, knishes and bratwursts.but historically, Americans have preferred not to mess with eye-watering, nose-running mixtures consumed with such, well, relish in the rest of the world. When the upstate New Yorkers George and Francis French introduced their classic yellow mustard in 1904, they softened the mustard seed's kick and added turmeric for coloring. The result was a mild (some would say bland) yellow mustard that has become the No. 1 mustard in North America, forever duking it out with the slightly spicier (though not by much) brown mustard first concocted by Charles Gulden on Elizabeth Street in Manhattan in 1862.
Mustard sales hit $300 million last year, a 10 percent rise over the last five years, and New Jersey tosses its fair share into that fray. Numerous food companies call the Garden State their home. There is French's (with headquarters in Wayne), Gulden's (Parsippany), Hellman's (Englewood Cliffs), and A&P (Montvale). Even Grey Poupon is distributed by Nabisco in East Hanover. This doesn't mean the mustards are made here. French's, for example, produces its condiment in Springfield, Mo. But scan the label on these products and you come up Jersey.
So in that sense, New Jersey brings mustard to the masses.
But faceless national brands don't exactly inspire local loyalty. Heck, in Cleveland, baseball fans alone are torn between two hometown brands -- Bertman's Ballpark and Stadium Mustard -- which have slugged it out for years. Things don't get that heated in Jersey. But if there is passion to be found, it could lie with the state's few small mustards.
One of the oldest is Pulaski Stone Ground, produced by family-owned Pulaski Products in Carlstadt. It is a strong, yellow-brown mustard that has graced shelves in Polish-American homes since 1934. According to Stanley Mazepa, who bought the company in 1977 from its founder, John Warren, the mustard is still popular in towns with a large Polish community: Garfield, Clifton, Linden, and Wallington.
As a youngster, Mr. Mazepa recalls slathering his grandmother's own homemade Old World mustard. "I wished I'd gotten that recipe," he said wistfully. "It had a kick."
When he wasn't eating that, his family enjoyed one of two types of Polish mustard: Pulaski or its rival, Chicago-based Kosciusko. Both came packed in a glass mug. The Pulaski label bore the image of Gen. Casimir Pulaski, the Polish-born hero of the American Revolutionary War.
Today, the glass mug is gone, but the general lives on, with his own delicate mustachio and presiding over a condiment that, thanks to a touch of horseradish, takes no prisoners.
"A few years ago we did kick it up a few notches," said Mr. Mazepa, 54. "We made it a little stronger, and people called saying they liked it. It's not bland. You could have it on a kielbasa and it stands out."
Another standout -- and maybe even hotter -- is the Original Hot Mister Mustard. According to Mr. Fischer, the pungent recipe was first conceived as a specialty mustard by the brand's originator, a man he knows only as Mr. Frank, of the Frank Tea and Spice Company of Cincinnati. "He liked mustard but he could never find one that he liked when he went out to dinner," said Mr. Fischer. So, like King Louis XI, Mr. Frank packed his own. "He'd walk into restaurants with this mustard pot and people would say, 'Here comes Mister Mustard.' "
Mr. Fisher bought the Mister Mustard brand, recipe and customer list from the Durkee company 20 years ago. Using the original recipe and label, he began grinding mustard seed with a stone mill at his Ann Street operation in Passaic, and introduced two more varieties: Sweet Hot Mister Mustard and a Mister Mustard with Honey.
Predictably, he could not escape picking up the monicker, too. "I started walking into my country club and people call me Mister Mustard," said Mr. Fischer. "I have a house down in Florida, and when I go down there, the same thing happens."
He has accepted the mustard mantle with pride. When in Florida, Mr. Fischer tools around Boca Raton in a sports Mercedes with an unofficial license plate that reads -- what else? -- MR. MUSTARD.
In the teeming world of condiments, Pulaski and Mister Mustard are scrappy supermarket sellers that consistently earn the love of their fans. They stand outside the realm of flashier brands competing in the same market. The Silver Palate, a specialty foods company in Cresskill associated with the "The Silver Palate Cookbook," produces five mustards and two mustard sauces. Jars are topped with a dainty red-and-white cloth tied with a bit of string. A 7.5 ounce jar of Mister Mustard retails for $1.39, tops; a 7-ounce jar of Silver Palate green peppercorn garlic mustard runs $3 to $4.
Customers pay for the product, and they also pay for the cachet.
Or the story. Like the one about Ed and Doris Simpson, high school sweethearts who grew up in Irvington before World War II. He was a mechanical engineer, she was a home economist with an interest in colonial recipes. In 1974, they opened Muirhead, a restaurant in their historic 14-room colonial home in Ringoes. They kept an herb garden and mixed their own dressings and condiments. Patrons often left asking for a bottle of the vinaigrette. In time, said Mr. Simpson, now 73, the couple decided to shift gears. In 1994, they closed the restaurant and devoted themselves to managing their growing food line, Muirhead of Ringoes. Their signature product, pecan pumpkin butter, is now sold through Williams-Sonoma.
Muirhead makes three mustards; the two best are the honey mustard and horseradish (the other is a Dijon). The operation is decidedly small: family members and employees still gather in the kitchen to mix small batches. A national company acts as distributor, and Mr. Simpson himself delivers jars to stores like Delicious Orchards in Colts Neck. He also fills orders placed through muirheadfoods.com.
A member of the World Mustard Association, Mr. Simpson can attest to the expanding challenges and headaches of the market. With so many mustards out there, how can customers find yours? And for all the market growth, not everyone is a mustard nut. A jar can last six months in most refrigerators. He chuckled when a wiseacre recently suggested that he approach the Meadowlands.
"Ballparks and stadiums in this country use about 15 million pounds of mustard a year," said Mr. Simpson. "Would one be able to corral that market, you'd be talking thousands of pounds. To them it becomes a price picture. If they can buy it for a penny cheaper, they will."
But the thought lingered in his head.
"Volume would enable me to lower the price," he said. "Let's just say it's available."

HEADLINE: THE LAW;
Waterfront Fire Safety Is Examined

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Less than a decade ago, a section of waterfront here known as Harsimus Cove, a 40-acre expanse of trucked-in sand, lay like a bizarre, man-made Sahara amid the skyscrapers that had risen in the 1980's.
But high-rise buildings have been sprouting like dune grass in Harsimus Cove in recent years, as well as along other formerly barren stretches of Hudson River in Hoboken as well as here, irrigated by economic good times and the urge to be a PATH stop from Manhattan. Farther north along what is called the Gold Coast, town houses and condominium clusters are mushrooming at the base of the Palisades. 
 While the growth has generally been applauded by state and local officials, it has also increased the burden on firefighters, who say high-rise fires are labor intensive and demand knowledge of a building's intricate electrical and ventilation systems. They can also involve large numbers of residents with limited routes of escape.
"Obviously, any high-rise fire, depending on the type of fire that you have, is going to tax anybody's department," said Chief Frederick G. Eggers of the Jersey City Fire Department. "We had a certain amount of high rises up until this point, but ever since the Gold Coast has taken off, they're popping up every day."
Officially, high rises are buildings seven stories or higher. In the past 10 years, 20 of them have gone up here -- most on or near the waterfront -- for a total of about 120 buildings, officials say. Eight more are under construction, and more are planned.
Hoboken, a much smaller city, has about 40 high-rise buildings, officials there say, with construction at a similarly brisk pace. As a result, fire departments in the region have been designing training and prevention programs, seeking more firefighters with the tax revenue generated by the new buildings, and even planning new fire houses financed by developers.
Moreover, a plan is being developed by the fire director here, Armando Roman, who is also on the State Fire Safety Commission, requiring that high-rise buildings have fire personnel on duty around the clock.
Mr. Roman said that in a fire's crucial early stages, the managers could use a building's intercom system to communicate with residents and help firefighters by shutting down the power and turning off the heating, ventilation and air-conditioning, which can spread smoke and fire.
Officials said that is what happened last month in a new 26-story apartment building in the Harsimus Cove section, where four people suffered smoke inhalation. "At that particular fire, had there been a fire manager, that person could have gotten on the P.A. system and as soon as he assessed the situation, could have told people, 'There's no need to evacuate the building, stay in your apartment,' " Mr. Roman said.
William Kramer, deputy director of the State Division of Fire Safety, said Mr. Roman's proposal would be the first such measure mandating safety managers. Mr. Kramer declined to comment on the proposal, which Mr Roman said he might offer at the next commission meeting Sept. 13.
Tom Gallagher, chief of staff for Mayor Bret Schundler, said Mr. Roman had briefly discussed the proposal, although the mayor had not decided whether to support it.
For now, state law requires that fire safety managers be on duty in Atlantic City casinos. In New York City, such personnel must be stationed in high-rise office buildings, whose wide floors make them more vulnerable to the rapid spread of fire.
At least one of Mr. Roman's fellow commissioners, Deputy Chief Richard Blohm of the Hoboken Fire Department, said he would support such a requirement, which -- if recommended by the commission -- would have to be approved either as legislation or as a regulation of the State Department of Community Affairs, which includes the Division of Fire Safety.
But the necessity, cost effectiveness and the potential benefit of requiring fire safety managers are far from certain. Deputy Chief Blohm said last month that he had begun surveying high rises and would then develop plans for each building.
Aside from last month's fire, in which no one was seriously injured, firefighters said they could not recall a major high-rise fire along the waterfront in recent years. But even supporters of such a requirement acknowledged that it would probably be opposed by most developers. Joseph Barry, president of the Applied Companies of Hoboken, which operates several high-rise builings there and in Jersey City, said the annual price tag could come to as much as $250,000 a building, a cost that would ultimately be passed on to tenants. In a building of 250 apartments, that would amount to $1,000 a year for each tenant, or $84 a month added to the rent.
"It's a very big burden," said Mr. Barry, who suggested that the money could be better spent elsewhere.
But Ed Cortese, a vice president for the Lefrak Organization, which has a dozen high-rise office and apartment buildings in its Newport complex, said the company already had the equivalent of round-the-clock fire safety managers. "We think it is an excellent idea," Mr. Cortese said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Huntington's Housing Plan: Too Little or Too Much?

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
HOUSES that moderate-income families can afford have become elusive in the Town of Huntington, where the median price in the resale market is $338,000 and the price of new houses is often half a million dollars or more.
Concerned about the lack of modestly priced housing, town officials have prepared legislation that would require that developers who are granted a zoning change set aside some units for moderate-income buyers. The Town Board is expected to vote on the proposal on Aug. 29. 
 Town officials say that the prices on these units should not exceed $125,000. This amount, they say, is the maximum that families with annual incomes of $60,000 or less can afford. The $60,000 figure is 80 percent of Long Island's median, a measure often used to define "moderate income."
All new subdivisions of 10 or more lots requiring a zoning change would be affected. Developers who are granted a higher density would have to set aside 20 percent of the additional units for moderate-income residents. A public hearing on the measure, which Frank P. Petrone, the town supervisor, and Steve A. Israel, a town councilman, are sponsoring, was held July 11.
"This is the start of a very, very aggressive housing program, probably the most aggressive of any of the towns on Long Island," said Mr. Petrone, a Republican.
While praising some aspects of the proposed law, housing advocates are sharply critical that it would not be retroactive, which means that it could not apply to one of the largest vacant tracts remaining in the town, on which a rezoning application is already pending.
The 380-acre parcel was formerly occupied by the Long Island Developmental Center, a state-owned children's psychiatric hospital. The site, part in Melville and part in Dix Hills, borders the Northern State Parkway and Carman Road just north of the Long Island Expressway. The current owner, SBJ Associates, bought it from New York State in October for $16.1 million. The state retains one children's hospital building and 34 group homes on 78 acres.
The zoning now in effect for the former hospital site would allow only one house on a two-acre plot, or fewer than 190 houses on the 380 acres. SBJ is proposing to build up to 1,375 housing units. Of these, 1,225 would be for sale: single-level condominiums, town houses, and semidetached and detached houses around a private 18-hole golf course. The remainder would be rentals.
Only 75 of the larger detached houses on half-acre and one-acre lots would be offered for sale to all age groups, and they are expected to sell for $500,000 and up. The remainder, including the rentals, would be restricted to families in which at least one member is 55 or older.
That provision has stirred the most controversy. Critics contend that property that once was publicly owned should now include housing for young families and for residents with moderate incomes.
SBJ is taking the position that it is meeting another important need: housing for older residents. "This property cannot solve all the town's housing needs," said John A. Harras, a partner in Morton Weber & Associates, the Melville law firm representing SBJ. "We are providing a project that meets a housing crisis for seniors, who are the fastest-growing population in the town."
In its rezoning application, SBJ, which is a partnership formed by two development companies, Benjamin Development of Garden City and Jobco of Great Neck, has offered to sell 100 of its proposed 400 condominium apartments for $145,000, which represents a $30,000 discount. State and county subsidies could further reduce the price to $125,000, Mr. Harras said.
Under an earlier proposal, SBJ wanted to build 150 assisted-living apartments. It is now offering to build 100 rental apartments under a federal program that subsidizes the rents of low-income elderly tenants.
SBJ has also said it would donate $2.5 million to a housing trust fund that the town could use for such purposes as subsidizing mortgages or providing grants for down payments for needy families. "There is no way that anyone can criticize this project for not having an affordable component," Mr. Harras said.
O NE of the two partners in SBJ, Benjamin Development, also owns an eight-acre tract on Ruland Road in Melville, where it is proposing to build 120 one-bedroom and studio garden apartments open to all age groups and selling for no more than $125,000 each. That would help provide badly needed starter homes for young couples working in the Melville area, Mr. Harras said.
But critics say regardless of all these proposals, moderately priced housing for young families should still be part of the mix at the former hospital property.
Jim Morgo, the president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group based in Hauppauge, called the SBJ plan a "missed opportunity."
"It perpetuates the idea that seniors only want to live with seniors and be segregated, and it misses the chance to do a visionary community with various housing types," said Mr. Morgo, who served as a consultant on the proposed legislation.
The Rev. John A. Jurik, the pastor of St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Huntington Station and a member of a coalition known by the acronym Lican, which stands for Long Island Congregations, Associations and Neighborhoods, said: "There is a crying need both for affordable housing for seniors and for affordable housing for families with children. Surely, out of 1,375 homes, 150 could be set aside for families."
The idea of developing the former hospital site largely for age-restricted housing was first proposed in 1996 by a task force formed to come up with a plan for the site when state officials first announced they would sell it. The 12 task force members represented the state and county governments and local residents.
The concern was that building housing for all age groups would bring an influx of children into the Half Hollow Hills school district, said Mr. Petrone, the town supervisor. He said that about 1,500 new homes have been built in the district in the last few years, and if the number of children continued to grow, new schools would have to be built. School taxes could rise by as much as 30 percent, he said.
"We understand that there is a need for affordable housing for families, but you also have the practical problem of crowded schools," he said. "So balancing all that, we came out with a senior housing program, for which we have now negotiated 100 affordable condominium units and 100 affordable rental units."
The remaining housing on the former hospital property would be 350 three-bedroom town houses expected to sell for $250,000 to $270,000 and 400 semiattached and detached three-bedroom houses on the golf course selling for around $350,000.
The Long Island Association, a nonprofit business group with offices in Commack, is also opposed to the SBJ plan, because it views high housing costs as a threat to the region's ability to keep or draw workers. "The issue of affordable housing on Long Island is more important than the effect on any individual school district," said Mitchell Pally, the group's vice president for legislative and economic affairs.
Although the town officials appear to bestanding firm on the SBJ proposal restricting housing at the former hospital site mostly to older residents, critics of the plan have won concessions on the pending legislation. It now specifies that developers cannot impose age restrictions on any of the units they are required to offer at reduced prices, and units must have at least two bedrooms.
But critics are pushing for another change. As now written, the proposal would permit developers to reduce the 20 percent requirement to 10 percent by contributing to the housing trust fund instead. The amount to be paid into the trust fund would depend on the density the developer is granted under a rezoning. A fee of $75,000 per house would apply where lots are 15,000 square feet or less; $150,000 per house for lots of 20,000 square feet and $200,000 per house for lots of one acre.
Opponents of that provision say that with so little land still available for development within the town, building housing is more important than building a trust fund. "Once the land is gone, the opportunity to build more affordable housing is also gone," said Mr. Jurik, the Lutheran pastor.
But Mr. Israel, the leader of the Town Board's Democratic majority, said he was unwilling to concede that point because the trust fund could serve a broad base of needy families and first-time buyers. "Housing advocates feel the entire 20 percent should be used for housing built on site, and I think that's very shortsighted," he said.
To guarantee that the housing will remain moderately priced, the proposed law would require deed restrictions to limit profits when owners resold their houses.
Although critics of the town plan say that it falls short, they also praise the town for proposing any program at all. "It's a town doing something," said Mr. Morgo of the Long Island Housing Partnership.
Mr. Jurik said the need now was for all groups to work together. "If reasonable people sit down around a table and talk about this," he said, "we won't end up as a fractured society."

LENGTH: 1358 words

HEADLINE: Near Asheville, Biltmore Is Building a 213-Room Inn

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
A hundred years ago, shortly after George W. Vanderbilt built a 250-room French Renaissance country estate outside this western North Carolina city in the Blue Ridge Mountains, he carefully sketched out plans for a 50-room inn on the property.
His list began with $3,200 for 449 doors and windows. It ended with a total: $17,509.29, excluding wallpaper, plumbing, heating and electrical work. 
 Today, on a hill on what remains of Mr. Vanderbilt's estate, some two miles from the country home he called Biltmore House, a 213-room inn is taking shape. The Biltmore Company, led by Mr. Vanderbilt's great-grandson William A. V. Cecil Jr., will spend $31 million on an inn designed with the intent of giving guests a glimpse of what it was like to stay on the lavish estate about 1900.
Last year, 900,000 people visited Biltmore House and its outbuildings, including a conservatory and a winery. As a tourist destination, Biltmore now employs about 1,100 people, and it served as a location for several movies, including "Richie Rich" and "Being There."
Richard T. Pressley, the chief financial officer and executive vice president of the Biltmore Company, said that market research showed that 60 percent of the visitors to Biltmore House stay in local motels, and most stay in midpriced chains with room rates of about $100 a night. Most visitors are between 35 and 54 years old, he said.
"We've looked at this project for 20 years," Mr. Pressley said. Once convinced it was sound financially, company officials spent 18 months interviewing architects and contractors. They selected Thompson, Ventulett & Stainback Associates of Atlanta as its architect, along with the Design Workshop of Aspen, Colo., landscape architect; Hughes Design Associates of McLean, Va., interior designer; and the W. G. Yates & Sons Construction Company of Philadelphia, Miss.
The designers took some of their cues from the work of the distinguished team that designed Biltmore House before the turn of the century. Richard Morris Hunt, architect for the center part of the Fifth Avenue facade of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, designed the house. Frederick Law Olmsted, who designed Central Park with Calvert Vaux, created the landscape plan.
In designing the hotel, to be called the Inn on Biltmore Estate, "the intent was partially to create a building that didn't compete with the house but gave guests a sense of staying at the house," said Scott Sickeler, the project's lead architect. "What caught me by surprise was Olmsted and the influence he had over the estate," he added.
The designers sought to give guests the same sort of experience when driving up to the inn that visitors get on the three-mile approach road to the house, a road that meanders through five different North Carolina landscapes. The house is not visible until visitors get right up to it. In a similar manner, guests will be given only small glimpses of the inn as they wind their way up the hillside.
Landscaping, influenced by Olmsted's work, has already been done to allow a year's growth before the inn's opening, scheduled for March 1.
The inn faces Mount Pisgah and Mount Pisgah National Forest. "It is 270 degrees of uninterrupted wilderness," Mr. Sickeler said. Other views are of Biltmore House itself, framed by woodlands and mountains, and of downtown Asheville, several miles in the distance.
The Biltmore Company decided to manage the inn itself, rather than contract with a national chain, because corporate officials wanted direct control over quality, Mr. Pressley said. The company hired as general manager Michael Chaffin, who previously managed the Stephen F. Austin Hotel in Austin, Tex., and the Omni hotel, also in Austin. Biltmore's hospitality division is managed by Thomas B. Ruff, a senior vice president of the company who previously worked with Marriott Hotels and Resorts and the Hyatt Hotels Corporation. Mr. Chaffin and Mr. Ruff say their goal is to create an inn that will win top ratings from guidebooks like those from AAA and Mobil.
In-season room rates will range from $160 to $195 a night. Nine suites will be available, ranging from $900 to $2,000 a night. The $2,000 suite has 1,400 square feet with a sitting room and one bedroom with an optional second bedroom. Discount packages will be available, but prices have not been set, Mr. Ruff said.
The inn can accommodate small corporate functions, but not conventions. Its largest meeting room will be the 1,800-square-foot Vanderbilt Room, and it will also have two smaller meeting rooms and two banquet rooms.
The lobby will have a large fireplace that mimics the huge fireplaces of Biltmore House. Mr. Vanderbilt was a book collector, and so the inn will have a library, an unusual feature for a hotel. The restaurant will be called simply the Restaurant at the Inn on Biltmore Estate. Guests will also be able to eat in the more casual restaurant at the estate's winery, just down the hill. Admission to Biltmore House -- $32 for adults -- will not be included in the room rates, and the inn will have a gatehouse, meant to keep out the merely curious.
The company has incorporated some of the signature features of Biltmore House in the inn's design. Limestone, used on the exterior of the house, will cover the lobby floor. The roof will be slate, and oak for the library came from trees on the property, as did the black walnut floors for the private dining room.
The inn will compete with two other venerable Asheville hotels, the 510-room Grove Park Inn, which is now building a $27 million 40,000-square-foot spa, and the 36-room Richmond Hill Inn. The area also has a number of upscale B & B's as well.
The company will begin taking reservations for the inn in October, and group events scheduled after April 15, 2001, are already being booked.
The Vanderbilt connection with the Asheville area began when George W. Vanderbilt, a grandson of the steamboat and railroad industrialist Cornelius Vanderbilt, visited the North Carolina mountains in the late 1880's. The area was known for its healing mineral springs and fresh mountain air. In 1888, Mr. Vanderbilt decided it was the place for his country home. He began buying land, eventually assembling an estate of 125,000 acres, and commissioned designs for the house and its landscaping.
The house took six years to build. It covers four acres and included many amenities unusual for its time: elevators, electric lights and telephones. The first major event held there took place on Christmas Eve in 1895, when Mr. Vanderbilt, then a 33-year-old bachelor, entertained dozens of guests who had arrived in five train cars from New York and Newport, R.I. Through the years, Mr. Vanderbilt and his wife, Edith, entertained many celebrities at Biltmore, including Henry James, Edith Wharton and John Singer Sargent.
Mr. Vanderbilt died in 1914 during an emergency appendectomy in Washington, and Mrs. Vanderbilt returned to the estate, where the couple's only child, Cornelia, grew up. Over the years, Mrs. Vanderbilt donated and sold off much of the estate. Some 87,000 acres were deeded to the federal government for what is now Pisgah National Forest. Another chunk became Biltmore Village, a commercial area now just outside the Biltmore House gate.
But the house and 8,000 acres have remained in the family through four generations. It was opened to the public in 1930 at the request of Asheville city officials who hoped it would bolster an economy reeling from the Depression. It closed during World War II and was reopened in 1945.
By 1959, Biltmore House was losing $250,000 a year. William A. V. Cecil, a grandson of Mr. Vanderbilt and then a New York banker, returned to the family business shortly thereafter and began a turnaround that many people told him could not be achieved. The house was placed on the national Register of Historic Places in 1963, and almost a decade later, Biltmore made a profit: $16.
"The best money I've ever made," Mr. Cecil, now chairman of the Biltmore Company and the father of the current chief executive, is reported to have said.

HEADLINE: Move Over, Fire Island, Here Comes Asbury Park;
Urban Gays Lead Way in Reviving This Run-Down Resort

BYLINE: By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK

 BODY:
ON MOST Saturdays in summer, Anthony Perrotta awakens to the clatter of breakfast dishes, the slamming of screen doors and the ceaseless chatter coming from the first floor of his four-bedroom 1920's stucco home overlooking Sunset Lake. The weekly ritual has begun: friends and neighbors drop in to discuss where everyone will be for lunch, whether it's a beach day, who will be host of a cocktail or dinner party, and what time they'll stop by the club at night.
Another activity that frequently dominates Mr. Perrotta's weekend agenda is arranging tours of the northern section of the city, with participants seeking "for sale" signs on houses, some of which may have stood vacant for so long it is hard to tell where the yard ends and the front porch begins. In the last several months there has been a growing -- and unfamiliar -- interest in real estate in this faded shore resort to a degree that realtors and city officials say they have not seen in almost 20 years. 
 While officials like to attribute the resurgence to the long-anticipated, ever-looming redevelopment of the city's decaying waterfront, those in the real estate business and those moving in say it is being driven by the market, which at the moment is largely made up of urban, professional gay men and women.
"Five years ago, a house might sit on the market for two years," said one realtor, Bruce Donaldson. "A year ago it would take six months, now they're on the market for an average of two months, and many are being sold privately before they even get listed," Mr. Donaldson added, noting that the asking prices had doubled over the last five years, and jumped by close to 50 percent in the last year alone.
Mr. Donaldson, who is also chairman of city planning board, said he had sold as many houses in Asbury Park in the first few months of this year as he sold during all of last year, with about 80 percent of his current buyers being gay.
Cheaper than the Hamptons, more relaxed than Fire Island, easier to get to than Miami Beach or Provincetown (or, for that matter, the Hamptons and Fire Island), this oceanfront city -- just an hour from Manhattan -- is seen by some as the next gay enclave. Those buying homes here either as weekend getaways or permanent residences cite several appeals: affordable houses, beautiful architecture, an almost private beach, plentiful entertainment and a certain "seediness" that has its own charm. And as their numbers grow, the gays moving in are increasingly finding a sense of community in this city of 17,000.
"It's not the Hamptons, where it's all about who's fabulous and what you're wearing," said Mr. Perrotta, 28, a Manhattan interior designer who with his partner, an attorney, bought two houses in Asbury Park in the last 10 months. "It's not the muscle boys and sex and parties of Fire Island. We all have the same bohemian mentality here: anything goes and nothing matters. It's the gay ghetto, and it's only going to get better."
Janice Gutloff, a 47-year-old guidance counselor for the New York City Board of Education who bought a 13-bedroom home with her partner here last November, said she had already made new friends since spending the summer here this year. "There's an acceptance here, a feeling of community, and there are a few gathering places for gay and lesbian people," said Ms. Gutloff, whose house also overlooks Sunset Lake. "There are lots of things going on here."
Probably the biggest draw are the bargains, where a large single-family house can be scooped up for about $150,000, about a third of the price for a similar home in such neighboring shore towns as Deal, Loch Arbour or Interlaken, and close to the cost of a seasonal rental on a prime place in Fire Island or the Hamptons. Of course, the reason real estate is so affordable here is that this 1.5-square-mile city has been impaled on hard times for more than two decades.
Founded in 1871 by James Brady, a visionary developer who also began neighboring Ocean Grove, Asbury Park was designed to be the premier resort destination on the Jersey Shore, with avenues 100 to 200 feet wide, two lakes and a mile-long oceanfront boardwalk. By 1890, the city boasted a 1,200-seat opera house, a dozen grand hotels, 1,000 guest cottages, and several large mansions owned by some of New York's finest families. A fire in 1917 wiped out many of the city's buildings, but that only made way for an even bigger building boom in the 1920's, which included the Convention Hall and the Casino, two Art Deco waterfront gems that have long since fallen into disrepair, as well as hundreds of other Victorian and Colonial-style homes.
The waterfront amusements drew hundreds of thousands of visitors annually in the 1940's and 50's, but by the 1960's the city had begun to look frayed around the edges. Businesses moved out of the downtown commercial district in favor of nearby malls, then race riots in 1969 dealt the downtown its final blow. Despite Bruce Springsteen's attempt to put the city back on the map with his 1973 album "Greetings from Asbury Park," the city continued to decline until a promise to revitalize the waterfront in the mid-1980's by a Connecticut developer, Joseph Carabetta, brought another surge of interest in Asbury Park. But Mr. Carabetta's financial failure left the waterfront in a state of abandonment, as it remains today.
Homeowners fled, leaving many properties in the hands of the city or absentee landlords who divided most of the larger homes into multi-unit rental properties. According to the latest figures supplied by the city, of the 7,692 housing units, 1,730 are single-family homes and only 1,584 are occupied by the owner.
Interestingly, however, some of the factors that have driven away other potential home buyers -- the blighted and sparsely visited waterfront, the multiracial population, and the deteriorating housing stock -- are precisely what the urban gay population finds most attractive.
"I love it the way it is now," said Bernard Figueroa, speaking about the vast, dilapidated amusement buildings that line Ocean Avenue. "It's very particular and very intriguing. I think it's beautiful."
Moreover, Mr. Figueroa, who is French, also dislikes Americans' attitudes about race and finds a perfect antidote in Asbury Park.
"People in America are so racist and prejudiced," said Mr. Figueroa, a 39-year-old shoe designer from New York who expects to close on a house on Third Avenue this summer. "They think if a neighborhood is more than 20 percent black it's a bad neighborhood. Between the gay people and the black people here, it makes an anti-yuppie atmosphere which I love."
His partner, Ted Scheffler, also says the multicultural aspect of Asbury Park was a deciding factor on where to raise the son he adopted in China four years ago. Mr. Scheffler, who teaches English as a second language, hopes to teach in Asbury Park in what many call a substandard school system that discourages families from living here. But for gay couples with children, Asbury Park again offers the best of both worlds.
"I was brought up in a house, and I wanted my son to have that same experience, but it needed to be in a community that accepted his parents as well," said Mr. Scheffler, 42, who admitted he was still weighing options on where to send his 4-year-old son, Matthew, to school. "That's usually not so easy to find in suburban setting, and in most city settings, you're not going to find a lot of gay couples with kids."
Nor is Mr. Scheffler the only gay family man in town. Morgan Mulford and his partner, Doug Palumbo, were among the first couples to buy a home in Asbury Park six years ago when they purchased a four-bedroom Craftsman-style house for $70,000. Mr. Mulford's 8-year-old son and 10-year-old daughter spend Christmas and summer vacations here with their father, and live with their mother in Florida the rest of the year.
"Because it's a town that's coming back, everybody is very open-minded," said Mr. Mulford, 39, a director of annuity sales for New York Life. "It's introduced the kids to a lot of different people, and if our goal is to expose them to and be accepting of a lot of things, then this is a good place for them to be."
Mr. Palumbo, who grew up here but moved in the early 1970's with his family in what he refers to as "the white flight," said that historically, Asbury Park had always been friendly to gays. He remembers the dozen gay bars that lined Ocean Avenue in the early 1980's, before many of the buildings were condemned by Mr. Carabetta. For the last six years, New Jersey Gay Pride Day has been held here on the first weekend in June, drawing thousands from New Jersey, New York and Philadelphia. So when the couple was looking for a weekend retreat, Mr. Palumbo thought of his hometown.
While Mr. Palumbo and Mr. Mulford may have been pioneers at the time, they now estimate that almost 50 percent of their block is gay, evidenced by the rainbow flags that fly outside many of the homes. Several rainbow flags also fly on homes on Locust Drive, where two longtime Greenwich Village residents, Deborah Walsh and her partner Carla Simpson, bought a five-bedroom colonial on Deal Lake for about $100,000 two years ago. Ms. Simpson is currently trying to get pregnant through artificial insemination because, as Ms. Walsh puts it: "It's a good place to raise a family. There's space and acceptance here."
Throughout the northern section of the city, multifamily homes are being converted back to single-family houses and restored to their original beauty. Speculators like RDR Properties are buying dozens of places, rehabilitating them, and putting them back on the market at a tidy profit. They say the problem is no longer a dormant real estate market but not having enough supply to fill the demand.
Houses in the most sought-after sections of the city -- a four-square-block area bordered on the north by Deal Lake, on the south by Sunset Lake, on the east by Park Avenue and on the west by Main Street, plus the northwest part of the city near Deal Lake -- often exchange hands privately, never making it to market.
"I just wish I had more listings,," said Georgia Burns, who has been in the real estate business here for 40 years. "There's not much left here to sell." Acknowledging that many of the interested buyers are now gay, Ms. Burns calls her current client crop "the best buyers I ever had."
"They're wonderful people," she added. "They love the old houses and they're restoring them."
There are even signs of life at the Asbury Park beach, which, despite a recent sand replenishment program and the reasonable $20 seasonal beach tag charge, is usually all but deserted. Two weeks ago, more than 500 black and Hispanic lesbians spread their blankets on the white sands of the city's north beach. The women were holding their sixth annual beach party, this year choosing Asbury Park over Fire Island because "it was a little more hospitable," said the event's organizer, Tracey Pridgen.
"The town council was very warm, said Ms. Pridgen, a Jersey City resident who also caught the home-buying fever after coming here in April. "We really felt very welcome and it's going to be our new home from now on." Since then, she said, she has checked out 15 houses.
Some savvy buyers aren't waiting for a house they like to go on the market. Mr. Perrotta, the interior designer from Manhattan, and his partner spent the Martin Luther King weekend knocking on the door and leaving notes at a house on Sunset Drive that they had their eyes on, asking the owners if they were interested in selling. On Monday they saw a police car at the house and found out the owner had died over the weekend. They contacted her relatives in New York and worked out a sale privately.
Others are pushing the borders of what is considered a stable neighborhood in Asbury Park, anticipating gentrification to continue to march southward. Jerry Scarano of Manhattan bought a 12--by-40-foot, two-story cottage on Second Avenue in April for only $20,000. Mr. Scarano spent another $12,000 replacing the bathroom, kitchen and roof, and adding siding and Victorian gingerbread to the outside. In July, his house was awarded the "Beautiful House of the Month" by the city's zoning board. Although his house is in a neighborhood that realtors like Mr. Donaldson would call transitional at best, Mr. Scarano is unfazed by the loud rap music that pours out of neighbors' windows and the frequent loitering in the streets. Instead, he has befriended the neighbors, who consider him something of an anomaly.
"While I was cleaning the place out I developed a network of contacts," said Mr. Scarano, 45, who hopes to be able to sell his house and double his investment so he can buy a larger house for himself here. "Everyday people in the neighborhood came by and asked me if I needed any help. I was able to hire them as day workers for about a third of the price that contractors were asking."
The newfound interest in homes here is beginning to have a spillover effect on other aspects of life. A few artists are moving back into some of the loft spaces along Cookman Avenue downtown. Activity has picked up at the Emeralds and Pearls cafe and gift shop on Bangs Avenue, particularly during the pre-dawn, post-club hours. Billy Meisch, who owns the retro furniture store, House of Modern Living, on Cookman Avenue, said he had been seeing a lot of new clients.
"They may need a new couch or a chair, and it's a lot easier buying it here than carting it down from Soho," said Mr. Meisch, who moved to Asbury Park in March after living in neighboring Ocean Grove for 20 years.
Mr. Meisch said Ocean Grove, which also has a large gay population, had become "too family-oriented."
The year-and-a-half-old alternative newspaper, triCityNews, has become a popular source for what's happening in the city, including news from the active night life that floats among the city's four gay bars.
With renewed talk of creating a state-controlled redevelopment authority to press forward on the proposed $780 million waterfront revitalization, Asbury Park's currency may go even higher. But for some who distrust the decisions of the current government, getting a foothold in the political arena is the only way to guarantee that the city continues to move in the right direction.
Last month, Robert DeSanto, who is a student and tends bar at Club Paradise, said he organized a "meet and greet your neighbors" event at the club, in part to "get everyone in to one place so we can see what our numbers are." While only about 50 people turned out, many who did joined the homeowners' association and filled out forms to switch their voter registration to Asbury Park, Mr. DeSanto said.
In a city where fewer than 10 percent of the residents typically turn out to vote, every vote counts. John Loffredo, president of the Asbury Park Homeowners Association, ran for City Council in 1997 and lost by a few hundred votes. Mr. Loffredo plans to run again next May, and, while he says he is not running as "the gay representative," he believes "the outcome will be different" based on the current makeup of voters.
"Right now there's no gay representation on the council, but hopefully we're moving in that direction," said Mr. DeSanto, who ran for the school board last April and lost by a small number of absentee ballots. "We're homeowners here, and it's important for us to keep our property values up."
For now, the political establishment may be a bit wary of the shifting demographics of Asbury Park. While acknowledging the increased presence of gays and lesbians in Asbury Park, Deputy Mayor John Hamilton does not see turning the keys to the city over to them any time soon.
"While I'm open to anyone moving here, I'm certainly not going to try to have Asbury Park designated as the gay mecca of New Jersey," Mr. Hamilton said. "If we do gear ourselves toward an entire gay and lesbian population, will we end up discriminating against straight people?"

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
College Tuition On Rise

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS

 BODY:
As students get ready for the start of the college year, they -- or their parents -- will find that the cost of higher education in the state is getting higher. All of the public and private four-year colleges in New Jersey are raising tuition this fall.
Increases range from a high of 10 percent at Rowan and Montclair, both public universities, to a low of 3.2 percent at Princeton University, which is already the state's most expensive institution of higher education, according to the Commission on Higher Education. 
 Still, the increases should come as no surprise. "Most schools raise tuition every year," said Janice Gams, associate director of public affairs for the College Board in New York City. "People should be prepared for that."
The average increase nationally last year was 3.4 percent for public colleges and 4.6 percent for private ones, according to the College Board, a nonprofit education association of schools and colleges that administers the SAT tests.
"College tuition rates regularly increase at more than the rate of inflation because colleges are labor-intensive and technology-intensive and both are expensive," Ms. Gams said. "It is unfair to compare tuition increases to the Consumer Price Index because consumers have a lot of different kinds of things to buy that don't apply to schools."
Most colleges cite the costs of new buildings and equipment, particularly computers, and salaries as the chief reasons for the rise in tuition costs.
Rowan University in Glassboro, where tuition will be $4,140 for the coming school year -- a 10.4 percent increase -- is in the fifth year of a five-year program that called for 10 percent tuition increases each year.
"Students, faculty and administration all wanted to do this," said Jose Cardona, director of university relations for Rowan. "We increased faculty, added six new master's programs, improved other academic offerings, added computers and increased financial aid for students."
He said he did not know if tuition at Rowan, where enrollment was capped at about 9,300, would increase again next year.
The second highest increase will be paid by students at Montclair State University, where tuition will go up 10 percent, to $3,470.
"The need for additional academic programs and facility renovations forced the increase," said Phyllis Miller, a university spokeswoman. "Technology costs and salary costs are increasing."
Montclair State is buying land in Little Falls to build additional housing for 600 students because of growing enrollment, which went up 20 percent last year and will grow another 6 percent this fall to about 13,500. The school anticipates that enrollment will increase by another 2,500 within three to four years, she said.
"We used to have the lowest tuition in the state and we are still the second lowest, even with the increase," Ms. Miller said.
The lowest rate will be paid by students at Richard Stockton College of New Jersey in Pomona, where the third largest increase -- 9.8 percent -- will bring tuition to $3,375.
However, two factors could reduce that cost. The college recently started its most ambitious fund-raising program to date by holding a contest to win the right to name the college gymnasium. So far $250,000 has been raised toward the $1 million goal.
An additional $1 million that had not been included in the budget was obtained from the State Legislature on the premise the money would be used to help hold down tuition costs for the 6,300 students at the school. The board of trustees will meet later this month to decide the final tuition cost, said Tim Kelly, college spokesman.
The state's oldest and largest public college, Rutgers University, with 48,700 students, will raise tuition 5 percent. As at most of the institutions, room and board and some fees will also go up this fall.
Rutgers and other public colleges receive substantial financing from the state, although not as much as in some other states, college representatives say. At Rutgers, 60 percent of operating costs are paid by the state, while Montclair and some other schools receive 50 percent or less of their operating revenue from the state.
Public universities and colleges in general would like two-thirds of the costs to be covered by the state, according to the Chronicle of Higher Education.
This year the state is increasing aid for operating expenses for public schools by 6.2 percent, to $1.2 billion. Aid to private colleges and to the 19 community colleges was also increased.
Tuition at all the public colleges except Stockton and at 8 of the state's 14 private colleges last year exceeded the national average, which was $3,110 for public schools and $13,392 for private schools, according to the Chronicle of Higher Education.
With a 3.2 percent increase in tuition rates, a year at Princeton will cost $25,430. Costs at Drew University, $23,472 for a 4.5 percent increase, and Stevens Institute of Technology, $21,900 for a 4.8 percent increase, are not far behind.
County colleges announced earlier this summerthat tuition would hold steady at 11 schools and would actually decrease by 7.1 percent at Sussex County Community College. Increases at the remainder range up to 3.4 percent. The state is in the third year of a four-year plan to increase the state subsidy for county colleges to one-third of the operating costs. The state now pays for 29 percent of the costs.
The Commission on Higher Education, which does not set tuition rates, encourages schools to keep rates as low as possible, said Judy Savage, commission spokeswoman. But "we also recognize keeping institutions strong requires an ongoing investment."

LENGTH: 647 words

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS;
Yonel Letellier and Nadia Khalilpour

BYLINE: By LOIS SMITH BRADY

 BODY:
THE tango aficionados of New York -- a small but passionate group -- say that the tango can change your state of mind, the way you walk and how you dress. Women who once wore jeans and T-shirts start tango dancing and convert to gowns with slits and fishnet stockings. In a way, fishnets are the perfect metaphor for tango -- it is the dance form in which you reveal the most. Partners dance close, to music of grief, homesickness and hope.
Yonel Letellier, 43, is a lover of tango. He wears stylish suits and polished shoes, kisses people on the cheeks when he meets them and speaks comfortably about uncomfortable subjects. He grew up in Trujillo, Peru, and was politically active against the military government during his days at the National University of Trujillo. In 1982, he moved to New York, driving a cab while studying English and economics. Eventually, he became a vice president for financial services for small businesses at the Chase Manhattan Bank. 
 "For so many years, I was just studying and working, studying and working, 16 hours a day," he said. "I was very lonely. When I started to tango, I started feeling human warmth again."
In 1998, he met Nadia Khalilpour at a Halloween tango party in Manhattan. Ms. Khalilpour, who is 34 and grew up in Tehran, Iran, was then a live-in baby sitter in Manhattan for a couple from Iran. The mother of the children, Nasim Alikhani, a tango devotee, took Ms. Khalilpour to the party.
"Nadia has a very gentle manner," Ms. Alikhani said. "She's always smooth, never abrupt. Living with her, I never heard her footsteps. She was always floating about. At the same time, she's a very strong and clearheaded woman."
At the party, Ms. Khalilpour was sitting in the shadows, not knowing how to tango and trying not to be noticed, when Mr. Letellier saw her. "Just looking at her, I felt something strange, very, very strange, and I asked her to dance," he remembered. He led her around as she floated tentatively along. "She was so different, extremely sweet, extremely feminine, so delicate," he said.
Their courtship was also delicate, a slow accumulation of quiet conversations, at first on the telephone, then over dinner and in time in his Flushing, Queens, apartment, with tango music playing in the background. "He's very romantic," said Ms. Khalilpour, who is now an assistant administrator at Hunter College. "He likes red roses. He listens from his heart."
Soon, their tango friends could tell they had fallen in love by their body language on the dance floor. "I had a Christmas party at my apartment and invited them," said the Rev. Gerald Wagner, a nondenominational minister who tangos seven nights a week. "Yonel came a little later than she did. When he walked in, I happened to be dancing with Nadia, and she just softened and melted in my arms. I knew he was in the room."
On July 27, a Thursday, the couple were married at La Maganette, a restaurant in Manhattan that has a tango dinner-dance every Thursday night. As the guests stood close around the dance floor, Mr. Wagner, who officiated, began the ceremony by saying: "Tonight, love brings together a former student revolutionary from Peru, now a banker, and an expatriate from Iran, now a college administrator. And they were brought together by the Argentine tango."
Afterward, guests celebrated by dancing, the women kicking their legs out of slit skirts, the men dancing with eyes closed like pianists in a reverie. Sometimes, two partners would pause and lean against each other momentarily, waiting for one to suggest a move.
"Tango is about giving yourself to another person but keeping your own balance at the same time," said Deborah Winner, a guest. "It's so characteristic of a good relationship, having your own strengths and stability and independence, yet being able to ride the horse in the direction it's going."
