HEADLINE: Essay;
Exegesis of Acceptance

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The well-accepted acceptance speech of George W. Bush is worthy of an exegete's eye.
Most moving and evocative passage: In his visit to a jail for juveniles in Marlin, Tex., when a 15-year-old inmate asked him, "What do you think of me?", Bush perceptively interpreted the question to mean, "Do you, a white man in a suit, really care what happens to me?" He drew on John Donne's no-man-is-an-island philosophy to decry the imprisoning wall of indifference separating rich and poor, ambitious and despairing. Bush had alluded earlier to the Berlin Wall that had come down "with the leadership of Presidents Reagan and Bush." He then connected the metaphor of the jailed juvenile to Ronald Reagan's words in cold-war Berlin: we must "tear down that wall." 
 Most subtle play on discomfort of many Democrats with the current president: He quoted Robert Frost, the poet older Americans remember speaking in the cold at John F. Kennedy's inauguration, of the dream of the nation's founders "to occupy the land with character." That reminder set up Bush's observation that "a president himself must be responsible," significantly followed by his pledge to "uphold the honor and dignity of the office," which most voters believe Clinton failed to do.
Most adept plays on phrases of previous presidents: Although Al Gore now leads F.D.R.'s party, "the only thing he has to offer is fear itself." Bush had already improved on Clinton's phrase "the tyranny of low expectations" with his own "the soft bigotry of low expectations" and drove it home again in his acceptance.
Most useful verb to deride the opposition's misuse of only-superpower status and economic boom: "Instead of seizing this moment, the Clinton-Gore administration has squandered it." This word, of unknown origin but more mouth-filling than "waste," should become a staple of Bush rhetoric.
Most unexpected use of a code phrase to take an unequivocal stand: "I will lead our nation toward a culture that values . . . the life of the unborn." This definition of the fetus as alive, which is unequivocally anti-abortion, showed the depths of his pro-life belief and the nonpolitical reason for his refusal to modify the G.O.P.'s extreme anti-abortion platform plank. It also gave millions of Republican women clear reason to vote for his opponent, which I suppose shows his confidence in holding his lead.
Most uneven credo: This series of sentences beginning with "I believe," summing up the speaker's core beliefs, both soared and stumbled. "I believe in a God who calls us, not to judge our neighbors, but to love them" was especially welcomed by gays, and there was tasteful eloquence in "I believe in grace, because I have seen it, in peace, because I have felt it, in forgiveness, because I have needed it." But to cap this with "And I believe this will be a tough race, down to the wire" was demeaning.
On the debit side, more on substance than style:
Running against Washington. The Yale graduate and child of privilege assumed, Jimmy Carter style, a hardscrabble pose to assert that his "background may lack the polish of Washington." And then, following a focus-group distaste for controversy, he dissociated himself from all investigations into Clinton-Gore scandals, including illegal fund-raising: "I have no stake in the bitter arguments of the last few years." Republicans on the unpopular ramparts of the rule of law were coolly informed he preferred "civility and respect."
Oversimplifying foreign and defense policy. "When America uses force in the world, the cause must be just, the goal must be clear and the victory must be overwhelming." This is the old Weinberger-Powell doctrine, and had it been applied in the Balkans would have awarded Kosovo to Slobodan Milosevic. If Bush becomes president, that all-or-nothing policy sentence -- denying limited intervention -- will come back to haunt him.
Feeble labeling. "It is a time for new beginnings. . . . I believe America is ready for a new beginning." We are readier for new sloganeering; Bush's "New Beginning" will go over as thunderously as Clinton's "New Covenant."
Gore has put out word that he is composing his own acceptance. Welcome to the world of speechwriting, Al; the nonpartisan blades of exegesis go snicker-snack. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: VERIZON WORKERS FORM PICKET LINES AS TALKS CONTINUE

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Thousands of workers fanned out to picket sites throughout the East yesterday as negotiators for Verizon Communications and its unions pressed forward with efforts to end a strike by about 86,000 telephone employees.
While hardly affecting routine services, the labor dispute at Verizon, the nation's largest local and wireless telephone company, disrupted operator-assisted services, repairs and installations for 25 million residential and business customers from Maine to Virginia. More broadly, the strike, over issues including the outsourcing of work and the unionization of employees in the wireless business, may help define the role of organized labor in some of the most rapidly growing high-technology industries. 
 "This could open the door for unions to move not only into wireless but into other high-tech parts of the economy as well," said Paul Osterman, professor of management at M.I.T.
Verizon was able to limit the immediate impact of the strike by deploying about 30,000 managers to cover tasks normally performed by the striking employees, who walked off the job at 12:01 a.m. yesterday. Automated services on Verizon's network and wireless services were not disrupted. But delays in repairs and operator-assisted services could become more common as the workweek begins.
While members of the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers picketed at several hundred Verizon facilities in several Eastern cities, there was progress in the talks in Washington.
Late Saturday night, Verizon offered concessions that would allow the unions to organize more easily in the company's fast-growing wireless division, a central bargaining issue that could have a substantial effect on labor relations in the entire wireless communications industry, said people close to the talks.
Verizon (pronounced va-RISE-en) was formed by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of GTE and its venture in wireless communications with Vodafone AirTouch. Though it operates the nation's largest wireless carrier, only a few dozen of the wireless company's 32,000 workers are union members, compared with 80 percent of the 120,000 employees in Verizon's local telephone division.
But even as the company and the unions approached compromise on the wireless issue, on job security and on Verizon's practice of outsourcing work in fast-growing areas like the installation of high-speed Internet lines, they appeared to be far apart on other issues last evening.
According to a spokeswoman from the Communications Workers of America, the unions and the company remained most divided over forced overtime and job stress.
Neither side appeared optimistic that an agreement could be reached late yesterday, although the unions and Verizon said they were ready to continue negotiations into the morning if necessary.
Meanwhile, striking workers in 13 Eastern states and Washington, dug in for a walkout.
"My wife and I figured it out: three days," said Roger Doucette, 53, when asked how long he could afford to be on strike from his job as a trainer at a Verizon service center in Braintree, Mass.
But he said he was ready to strike as long as necessary, given his particular concern over the company's policy of outsourcing work in the installation of high-speed Internet lines.
In New York City, only a scattering of union members could be found at Verizon facilities, perhaps because of the progress in the talks. At the company's headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, six protesters, clad in red for union solidarity, stood behind police barricades.
"We're not trying to sabotage. We just want more money," said Shirley Harris, 33, an administrative assistant. "It's very expensive to live in New York."
In other cities, the strike generated greater tension between workers and management.
In Pennsylvania, striking employees blockaded entrances to Verizon's main switching facility in Philadelphia, effectively keeping managers from entering the building. In Delaware, some strikers also blocked access to facilities. The company was seeking court injunctions to deal with these cases, said Eric Rabe, Verizon's spokesman.
Only about 740 union workers out of 3,100 scheduled to work in the strike region yesterday showed up. Most of those were in New Jersey and not covered under the same contract as the striking workers, according to Verizon.
Managers were expected to work 12-hour shifts to provide stopgap service while the strike continued.
"After a while I'll probably get tired of this," said Stephenne L. Bell, who normally does budget tracking analysis in Verizon's marketing and communications department. On Sunday, she was working a 5:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. shift at a customer service center in Washington.
In the Bronx, where about 2,500 telephone lines were put out of service yesterday because of a cut line, Verizon said repairs could be delayed because of the walkout.
In New York City, Verizon deals with an average of 2,600 requests for telephone installations and 4,500 requests for repairs each day, said Steven Marcus, a spokesman for the company.
As the company moved to handle potential service problems and talks continued, the negotiations were of particular interest to employees in Verizon's largely nonunionized wireless division.
"I'm tired of being treated like a second-class citizen within the company," said a customer service representative from a call center in Woburn, Mass. She declined to provide her name, she said, because Verizon had told employees at the call center that they would be fired if they discussed joining the union on work premises.
"With a union contract, I'd have chances for better pay," she said.
According to the union, customer service representatives at Verizon's wireless unit who are not union members in Massachusetts make about a third less than unionized employees who do virtually the same job in other parts of the company. The company says pay differences are much smaller than what the union contends.
The union is seeking assurances from Verizon that the company will not interfere with or actively discourage organizing activities at the wireless division, making it easier for the union to sign up employees. Because Verizon Wireless controls nearly 30 percent of the wireless market, the outcome of the strike could affect labor relations throughout the wireless industry.
"If labor can't penetrate the new economy, they will be assigned to its margins," said Stanley Aronowitz, a sociology professor at the City University of New York. Mr. Aronowitz compared the situation to union efforts in the 1930's to organize in the automotive and steel industries.
"They are going after the biggie with the idea that the others will fall in line," he said.
Nearly all of the striking workers are from former Bell Atlantic divisions. Employees at old GTE units are not involved in the walkout, although the communication workers' union said the strike might prompt walkouts by 1,200 workers at former GTE operations in Kentucky and North Carolina, where separate contracts have expired.

HEADLINE: When Ivy and Dollars Intertwine

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Universities in New York certainly need to be more aggressive in licensing and selling their intellectual property, following the successes of Columbia University (news article, Aug. 2). Yet there is a larger strategic goal for our region as a whole, and it's one that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio need to emphasize. The region should exploit its scientific and technological assets far more effectively than it does in order to achieve real economic growth. 
 New York, New Jersey and Connecticut can be competitive in national and global markets only when their universities see themselves as part of the regional economy. Evidence from around the world shows that academic excellence and entrepreneurial verve must be fused to accelerate economic development.
RODNEY W. NICHOLS
President
New York Academy of Sciences
New York, Aug. 3, 2000

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
It Takes a World Wide Web to Raise a Village

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Overlooked in last month's Group of 8 discussions about the challenge of a growing "digital divide" between the information rich and the data deprived was the work of Bernard Krisher, a 69-year-old former journalist who is trying to bring the Internet to one of the poorest regions in Asia.
Most recently, Mr. Krisher's nonprofit group, American Assistance for Cambodia, has been toiling to create a permanent Internet connection to a primary school in the village of Robib, a cluster of six rural communities in north central Cambodia, more than a nine-hour drive from Phnom Penh. On Monday, the group plans to announce that it has succeeded. 
 The Internet link is being provided at no charge by Shin Satellite in neighboring Thailand. By placing the village directly on the Internet, Mr. Krisher, an American who worked as an Asia correspondent for Newsweek for decades, says he hopes to assist in the economic transformation of a region of Cambodia in which the average per capita income is about $37 a year.
In addition to providing computer education and Web access to a village school attended by 400 young students, the Internet project is supporting the creation of a small woven-silk industry in the village, which plans to sell silk scarves and table runners on the Internet. Once production begins, Mr. Krisher said, it might be possible to generate as much as $2,000 a month in revenue.
"We're trying to show that the Internet can really help a single village," said Mr. Krisher, whose nonprofit group is based in Tokyo, where he lives. "If this is copied elsewhere around the world it might help eliminate the digital divide."
Though the effort is on a small scale, Nicholas Negroponte, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology computer scientist who is also engaged in the effort to aid Cambodian villages, said the project demonstrated that the global impact of the Internet could ultimately serve to reverse the disparity between urban wealth and rural poverty.
"The Net will reverse urbanization," said Mr. Negroponte, director of the M.I.T. Media Laboratory. "The past 150 years of development have been one of urbanization. To be rural has meant to be poor. The Net could bring some of the same opportunities to the rural world and maybe even turn being rural into being rich."
The e-commerce effort has been created with the help of the Hotel Okura, a luxury hotel in Tokyo that has agreed to process credit card purchases made from the village's Web site, whose server computer is in Phnom Penh (www.villageleap.com). The plan is to ship the products by express mail through Cambodia's postal service, with the intention of reaching customers anywhere on the globe within two weeks.
A number of the Robib villagers are now being trained in the once traditional weaving skills of the region -- skills that atrophied under the brutal reign of the dictator Pol Pot in the 1970's and the years of strife afterward, isolating the country and disrupting traditional trade patterns.
A satellite dish provides a continuous 64,000-bits-a-second connection to a small group of computers in the village, which are powered for part of each day by a small solar power system. The hookup is also being used for a simple experiment in telemedicine that American Assistance has organized.
A group of doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston has agreed to answer health-related questions from villagers via e-mail, as well as offer general guidance on diseases like malaria and H.I.V.
"This is not what we usually think about when we talk about telemedicine, where a doctor may transmit an X-ray to a colleague for a second opinion," Mr. Krisher said.
Part of the challenge of Mr. Krisher's effort lies in helping recreate the social structure of the village, which was disrupted by the Khmer Rouge military under Pol Pot.
"It was a nice, traditional Cambodian village," Mr. Krisher said. "They had some old, dilapidated schools, and the Khmer Rouge arrested all of the teachers."
Mr. Krisher's commitment to Cambodia grew out of his years as a foreign correspondent for Newsweek. While many of the magazines' other reporters were drawn to Vietnam alone, Mr. Krisher traveled widely in Asia during the 1960's and 1970's. He became close with the Indonesian leadership and through those relationships was introduced to Prince Sihanouk of Cambodia.
Although the two men initially had a mercurial relationship, they ultimately became good friends, and Mr. Krisher kept in touch while the prince was in exile when the Khmer Rouge were in power.
When Mr. Sihanouk returned to Cambodia in 1990, he asked Mr. Krisher to help the struggling country. In 1994, Mr. Krisher founded and became publisher of The Cambodia Daily, a small English-language newspaper in Phnom Penh. He also raised money for and helped found the Sihanouk Hospital of Hope, in Phnom Pehn, which is now the nation's largest hospital.
Mr. Krisher set up American Assistance for Cambodia in 1990, running it with his wife, Akiko, and his daughter, Deborah Krisher-Steele.
 The hope is to construct 200 rural schools in Cambodian villages, under a program in which donors contribute $14,000 to build small school houses, with matching funds from the World Bank.
Mr. Krisher said he thought the Internet added a powerful lever to his small village-level projects. He said he received three or four e-mail messages from children at the Robib school each day, asking questions about his home in Tokyo.
"This is it," Mr. Krisher said. "You have to do things in a micro way that doesn't require a vast amount of money. My basic philosophy is to build a small sample and make it work and then just copy that."

HEADLINE: Sharing the Wealth

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Charles W. Kadlec ("How Taxes Trickle Down," Op-Ed, Aug. 1) supports the repeal of the estate tax and the lowering of income taxes because he thinks the poor, not just the rich, will benefit. 
 However, the wealthiest 1 percent of Americans doubled their share of our country's wealth between 1976 and 1997 (from 19 percent to 40 percent), while the share of the bottom 90 percent plunged from 51 percent to 27 percent.
Furthermore, the estate tax is paid by only a tiny minority of people, those lucky enough to be born in wealthy families. Why shouldn't they share their good fortune with the rest of society?
 
GEORGE LEVINGER
Amherst, Mass., Aug. 1, 2000
 
The writer is professor emeritus of social psychology at the University of Massachusetts.

HEADLINE: Affordable Housing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The plan for affordable housing presented at a recent New York City Hall news conference (news article, Aug. 3) should form the basis for a larger, urgently needed plan.
Recent census data show that 25 percent of New York renters pay more than half of their income for rent, and that there is a shortage of close to 400,000 affordable apartments for the city's poorest renters. And in June, the number of homeless people in shelters exceeded 24,000 for the first time since 1996 and included more than 10,000 children. 
 A recent Coalition for the Homeless report outlines the challenge facing New York City: rising population, declining housing production and a widening affordability gap.
A multiyear capital commitment of $750 million a year is needed to develop new housing for low- and middle-income New Yorkers. In a time of economic prosperity, nothing less will reverse the growing shortage of affordable homes for all New Yorkers.
 
PATRICK MARKEE
New York, Aug. 4, 2000
 
The writer is senior policy analyst, Coalition for the Homeless.

HEADLINE: Credit Bush Doesn't Deserve

BYLINE: By Lani Guinier and Gerald Torres; Lani Guinier and Gerald Torres, professors of law at Harvard and the University of Texas, respectively, are authors of the forthcoming "The Miner's Canary: Rethinking Race and Power."

 BODY:
At the Republican Convention last week, Colin Powell boldly challenged his party to be inclusive and follow the leadership of George W. Bush in Texas. As a model of inclusive reform, he touted Texas' 10 percent plan, which grants automatic admission to the flagship public colleges to all state students graduating in the top 10 percent of their high school classes.
Governor Bush calls this plan, which has been remarkably successful, an example of his compassionate conservatism. But this claim would be more convincing if his oratory about the program today had been matched by action when it was being debated. The Texas Legislature adopted it in 1997, after a federal Court of Appeals ruling, the Hopwood decision, had outlawed affirmative action at the University of Texas. Black and Hispanic state legislators conceived and advocated the plan. Governor Bush's contribution? He didn't veto it. 
 During the debate over the bill, Mr. Bush "never publicly supported the idea," says Irma Rangel, the Democratic chairwoman of the higher education subcommittee in the Texas House and the plan's sponsor.
Texas has about 1,500 high schools. But before the program's inception, the University of Texas at Austin, the most selective state-supported Texas college, filled 75 percent of its freshman seats from about 150 economically privileged suburban and private schools. Under the 10 percent plan, several poor white counties in rural West Texas sent graduates to Austin for the first time. Moreover, about 300 African-American freshmen were enrolled last year, a 50 percent increase over the year immediately after the Hopwood decision ended affirmative action. The number of Hispanic students has also increased, to more than when affirmative action was the official policy. (It is worth noting that the plan ensures integration at the university level even if the high schools remain segregated. But as some national Democrats point out, the plan is not a panacea for educational reform, especially in states without the extraordinary racial and economic segregation of Texas.)
Contrary to the fears that they would be unqualified, the 10 percenters exceeded expectations; their collective grade point average in their first year of college was higher than the freshman average for all students before the Hopwood decision. Part of their achievement comes from the university's efforts to make the school itself smarter. The university created more small classes for freshmen and allocated full scholarships to high schools with large numbers of poor and working-class students.
Despite these successes, and despite the high regard in which Governor Bush professes to hold the plan, there are rumblings among Republicans about trying to change it in the next legislative session. They want to restore a requirement that applicants take the SAT, which rewards those who can afford coaching and test preparation and does not predict the qualities of leadership and achievement that the university values. And Governor Bush is notably quiet about these proposed overhauls. "Hopwood required forward thinking, and he's been passive," Michael Olivas, a professor at the University of Houston who specializes in higher education law, says of Mr. Bush.
The 10 percent plan has worked in Texas to spread educational opportunity to those who have had too little of it. It never would have happened without leadership of people of color. Governor Bush should be bold enough to credit the black and brown leaders who gave him the opportunity to crow about its success today. That would be inclusiveness.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 1422 words

HEADLINE: Shoplifting on a Grand Scale: Luxury Wear Stolen to Order

BYLINE: By GUY TREBAY 

 BODY:
From the look of it, a person with identity issues had done some heavy shopping. Tossed on a bed in a Brooklyn apartment were a $600 Vuitton Broadway satchel, two $600 burgundy quilted polyester nylon skirts from Chanel, a $545 scarf with the block-lettered Chanel logo worked into the weave and two pairs of blunt-toed $425 Prada Nero shoes for men. None of the garments matched. But that did not matter. The apartment was a way station on a convoluted route of distribution, and the clothes did not yet have owners. Unless, that is, you count the retailers they were stolen from.
"These are going right out to Manhattan," said Angie E., a transgendered person who pilfers clothing for a living. The apartment is hers. "I use this fence in the diamond district," Ms. E said. "There's two brothers. They're the ones that sell it. I just mop the stuff and get my little cut." 
 Mopping, or shoplifting, is no new development on the retail scene. But large-scale shoplifting of luxury goods to order may be. Although criminal law does not distinguish between shoplifting and other kinds of larceny, law enforcement officials say that theft to order of luxury brands appears to be a growth sector. "They're going for the upscale stores," said Joe Morrash, a detective assigned to a stolen-property task force with the Alexandria, Va., police. "They're stealing in volume and selling to fences and underground boutiques." At one drab single-family home in Queens, Detective Morrash said, the New York police uncovered over $500,000 in stolen clothes in 1998. "The inside looked like Macy's," he said.
But Macy's isn't the only target of enterprising thieves. As label culture signals social arrival, even crooks are getting into the act. "It's a society where everybody's got their Fendi and their Chanel and their Vuitton," said Gerald Dupree, 39, a Brooklyn maintenance worker who said he left a career as a semiprofessional shoplifter when he broke a longtime heroin habit four years ago. "You've got to keep pace."
It is a breathtaking pace. In a survey conducted by the University of Florida, retail "shrinkage" -- as shoplifting is euphemistically called in the business -- was shown to have caused losses exceeding $8.9 billion in 1997, the last year for which figures are available.
Recently, police officials say, an increasing number of semiorganized crime syndicates, many of them South American, have been operating along the Eastern Seaboard, in urban centers and at upscale suburban malls. "It's not normal shoplifting anymore, where they're stealing one or two items," said Andrew McColl, a Washington-based agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who heads a task force on property crime. "They're going for the leather coats, the luxury items. The last arrest we made at Tysons Corner mall here, they had $100,000 in goods."
It is not hard to imagine running up a total like that when you consider the tagged prices of what the thieves are now after. "You can order a Chanel suit in size 10, and there are people who can mop it and fences who have the goods," Mr. Dupree said. Such suits typically cost around $4,000.
Angie E. is a thief whose audacity has led her, by her own account, to steal satchels from Louis Vuitton, baguette bags from Fendi, shoes from Prada and scarves from Hermes, things that are often kept in glass cases or under lock and key. She is, as Mr. Dupree said, "one of the ever-famous fierce girdle bandits of New York," a term referring to the practice of stuffing stolen goods into underclothes. "One thief I know put a whole mink in a girdle," Mr. Dupree asserted. Another, he said, would "go into a jewelry counter and, you know how they have chains hanging on display racks?" He paused. "She could just lift the chains up all at once and drop them down her sleeves."
At Saks Fifth Avenue last week a salesman said, "If you don't nail it down, they're going to take it." He was recounting an episode in July, when a woman grabbed six $200 Coach bags from a counter near the main Fifth Avenue exit and bolted. Although the bags were equipped with acoustomagnetic sensors, designed to trigger an alarm, that did not serve as a deterrent. "Do you think they care about the sensors?" asked the salesman, who, like most of the retailers I interviewed, did not want to be identified. "They're in, they're out, it's fast. Who's going to chase them for the bags? The bags are insured."
The subject of shoplifting is an abiding taboo. Only one of a dozen luxury store managers in Manhattan I spoke to would consent to discuss shrinkage on the record. The response of Ellen Hopfinger, manager of the Versace store on Fifth Avenue, was typical. "It's not something we would ever talk about," Ms. Hopfinger said. "I used to work at another luxury store, Armani, and no one talks about it, ever."
The reasons are various, explained Bruce Van Kleek, a member of the Loss Prevention Advisory Council at the National Retail Federation. "It points to internal problems, high turnover, people coming and going all the time," he said. Public admissions about shoplifting problems can also, of course, give potential thieves a heads up.
"It's sick that you have to write about these things," said Stephanie Greenfield, a retailer who attributes a low level of shrinkage at her two Scoop stores in Manhattan to security guards posted at every entrance. Still, she said: "It's going to happen. Look at the economy. Everybody wants stuff. I don't think it's only people who can't afford it. I think there's a prejudice that people don't steal on all class levels, all income levels. There's a mistake people make only looking at one type of crowd."
Mr. Van Kleek added that shoplifters "come in all shapes and sizes, from the 10-year-old stealing a comic book to sophisticated criminal gangs." The innovation, Detective Morrash said, is that inroads are being made on the luxury goods trade by professional gangs with greater levels of sophistication and, yes, of taste. "The South Americans are only doing upscale stores now," he said. "The Limited, Nordstrom, Lord & Taylor, Bloomingdale's."
Goods obtained by one Chilean syndicate, the Washington police reported, were later used to stock a "legitimate" Los Angeles boutique. "We had six guys who'd stolen $150,000 in three days," Detective Morrash said. "They move around the major cities like L.A., New York, Washington and Chicago."
They rent hotel rooms and getaway cars. They use sophisticated signaling methods as they go into department stores, to rake designer clothes into bags. One group compiled a written manual for its "contractors," advising them on the fine points of shoplifting both on and off the sales floor. "Never wander around with any of the pieces you are planning to take," read a copy of these guidelines that I obtained, "because not only will the salespeople want to help you or hold them for you or put them in a dressing room for you, all of which defeat your purpose, but it gives security a chance to count how many you have."
For all that, the method remains simple. "Why worry about alarms going off or electronic tags or radio tags?" Detective Morrash asked. "Speed is what makes them successful. They can get in and roll the merchandise up and run before anyone knows."
By the time an alarm sounds, most professional thieves are gone. In Manhattan particularly, where shoppers are made uneasy by excessive security and surveillance, shoplifters often have preferred exits from their favorite stores. "The Madison Avenue side of Barneys," Ms. E. said, citing an example. "The Fifth Avenue entrance to Saks. I did a job at Pink's," the London shirtmaker with a branch on Madison Avenue and 53rd Street. "They had $165 Sea Island shirts and a side door with nobody around," she continued. "I got six. Everybody's always complaining that they can't find anyone to wait on them. I say: 'Thank you. Let's keep it that way.' "
An assistant manager at Pink, who would not give his name, responded, "That's sad, but that's New York."
Shoplifters have been known to line shopping bags with foil or duct tape to thwart sensors. But Mr. Van Kleek of the retail federation said that the spate of successful theft owed less to cunning than to new levels of brazenness.
It is a view that Mr. Dupree, the former thief, confirmed. The secret of success, he said, is a formula that rings of business motivational seminars: "You go in there thinking, 'This is mine and I'm taking it with me.' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
British Airways Reports 65% Drop in its Earnings

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
British Airways reported a 65 percent decline in quarterly earnings today, attributing the poor performance to the effects of the strong British pound and the rising price of jet fuel.
The results for the March-June quarter were reported as the airline is trying to break out of a prolonged slump, partly through a proposed deal to acquire KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V. But there were increased signs today that those negotiations, which began in early June, had not advanced very far. 
 While both airlines are still in exclusive talks, concerns over regulatory approval from both the European Union and the United States have cast doubt over the deal. Executives close to the talks have said that the two sides are not yet close to an agreement on a price for KLM. The chief executive of British Airways, Rod Eddington, said today that it remained unclear whether the talks would result in an agreement.
The regulatory obstacles are high for a deal with KLM to receive approval. British Airways encountered regulatory problems when it tried to form an alliance with American Airlines. A deal with KLM was expected to face tougher antitrust scrutiny in Europe because the combined routes of both airlines would cover a large share of the market.
For British Airways, which last year reported its first full-year loss in its history, the pressure to complete the deal and to push profit higher is enormous. The airline dismissed its previous chief executive, Robert Ayling, because of the company's continued downward spiral and hired Mr. Eddington away from Ansett Holdings, the Australian airline company, to strengthen management and help British Airways return to profit.
The airline said pretax profit before one-time items dropped to 8 million, or $12 million, from 23 million a year earlier. Sales rose 4 percent, to 2.3 billion.
Nonetheless, British Airways posted a loss of 50 million after the charges were accounted for, compared with a profit of 200 million a year earlier. Mr. Eddington acknowledged the problems. "These results reflect the scale of the challenge we face in a highly competitive and price-sensitive market," he said. "However, we are also beginning to see the benefits of the investment we have made in every section of the aircraft. The growth in premium traffic has been strong and yields throughout the airline are up."
Indeed, British Airways said business-class traffic during the first quarter rose 8.2 percent, which the airline said equates to a 2.9 percent rise in revenue per passenger.
The airline said the rising price of jet fuel and the strong pound were largely responsible for the financial results. Fuel is one of the largest expenses for airlines, and a strong currency translates into fewer profits when overseas earnings are repatriated. "The effect of a persistently strong pound on British manufacturers and the high cost of fuel give cause for concern," said Lord Marshall, chairman of British Airways. However, he said, "We remain encouraged by the generally favorable economic climate which prevails in most of our key markets around the world."
Analysts said today that there was nothing surprising in the earnings results.
"We remain cautiously optimistic," Andrew Light, an analyst at Solomon Smith Barney, wrote in a note to investors. But, he said, the uncertainty of the KLM deal remains a big risk for the stock.
Shares of British Airways dropped 3 pence, to 388 pence, or about $5.82. KLM stock rose 5.9 percent, to 30.39 euros, or $27.50.

HEADLINE: Bail Reduced for Man Accused of Leading Philadelphia Protests

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

 BODY:
A man accused of being the ringleader of the illegal street protests during the Republican National Convention had his bail reduced from $1 million to $100,000 yesterday, as defendants contended that the Philadelphia police were guilty of jailhouse brutality and city officials maintained there was a criminal conspiracy to shut down the city.
During an appeal hearing, the million-dollar bail on misdemeanor charges was ruled excessive for John Sellers, the 33-year-old leader of the Ruckus Society of Berkeley, Calif. He denies leading a conspiracy and insists that he only trained demonstrators in the techniques of nonviolent civil disobedience. 
 At the same hearing, Common Pleas Judge Lisa A. Richette rejected a request for bail reduction for about 150 defendants still in jail who are protesting their arrests by refusing to give their identities to city authorities. Most of the defendants are charged with misdemeanors, with bail of $20,000 or less. They would probably be released with no bail once they properly identified themselves, said the district attorney, Lynne M. Abraham.
As more defendants from a total of 391 arrested returned to freedom with complaints about their detention conditions, the American Civil Liberties Union of Pennsylvania cited "credible stories concerning serious injuries inflicted" in jail, and urged anyone who was injured to file complaints with the city Police Advisory Commission.
Larry Frankel, executive director of the A.C.L.U., accused city authorities of overreacting to the provocations and relatively petty crimes of some demonstrators.
"We believe that vandalizing property, turning over trash cans, assaulting persons and shutting down the city by blocking traffic are not activities protected by the First Amendment," Mr. Frankel said, summarizing the main street incidents that occurred last Tuesday. "However, they are not the kind of crimes that justify treating the defendants as if they were dangerous urban terrorists."
The main demonstration group, R2K Network, protests the "corruption of democracy" through the power of Wall Street and the globalized economy. Network leaders accuse the city of "criminalizing dissent" by pre-emptively arresting some protesters and seeking high bail, amounting to preventive detention. Network members noted that some of the same demonstrators arrested in April in Washington during a similar protest were eventually fined $5 for jaywalking.
A network organizer, Beka Economopoulos, said some defendants had been brutalized, denied medication and "hog tied" ankle-to-wrist in jail.
The police denied the accusations and said defendants were creating their own problems by offering fanciful identities, staging hunger strikes and, in some cases, stripping off their clothes to hinder identification from videotaped street protests.
Mayor John F. Street has accused the protesters of "a very well-thought-out, well-planned conspiracy to shut down the city." And the police commissioner, John P. Timoney, maintained that protest leaders had far more than nonviolent dissent in mind.
"I call them conspirators and criminals and cowards," he said on Friday in detailing some charges, including what he said was the stringing of piano wire across Market Street in an attempt to injure police officers on horseback and bicycles.
The gravity of that charge was conceded in an interview by Bradley Bridge, an assistant legal aid lawyer with the city's Defender Association. But Mr. Bridge complained that 70 defendants were being held for a far less suspicious incident -- being present in a factory raided by the police where street puppets and other protest materials were made.
"I was there negotiating and saw the puppets," Mr. Bridge said. "It's appalling those guys are still in jail."
City officials contended that, with the police widely praised for exercising restraint during the protests, the demonstrators were deprived of bloody encounters and now sought to create an issue with allegations of jailhouse brutality.
Protest leaders argued that the city was bent on detaining defendants beyond the Democratic National Convention next week in Los Angeles. But they vowed that demonstrations planned for that convention would be stronger because of the arrests in Philadelphia.
With bail appeals continuing, the court did not reduce the $500,000 bail set for Darby Landy, 20, who is accused of a felony assault on the police in a street fracas with bicycling officers led by Commissioner Timoney.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russia Asks U.S. to Reconsider Steel Limit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The Russian government has asked the United States to reconsider an agreement that limits Russian steel exports into this country.
A Commerce Department spokesman said today that the Clinton administration was working with the Russian government to confirm a date in September to discuss the request. 
The Russian request immediately met strong opposition from representatives of United States steel companies, which are suffering earnings drops this year.
Russia and the United States signed the so-called suspension agreement in July last year after the Commerce Department found that Russia was selling steel in the United States at prices below the cost of manufacturing, and threatened retaliatory tariffs.
As a result, Russian steel exporters have diverted about five million tons of steel products, worth about $1 billion, from the United States market over the last year.
Under the accord, Russia agreed to a 64 percent cut in its exports to avoid tariffs of as much as 185 percent on hot-rolled steel, a product that is widely used in cars and appliances.
The agreement was reached on the day the United States was to have set final duties on Russian hot-rolled steel and other products.
When Russia's economy collapsed two years ago the country's steelmakers began selling steel at below-market prices on the United States market, according to the Commerce Department. American steelmakersasked the United States government to intervene and impose the duties.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Broad-Based Rally Extends to a 3rd Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks climbed for a third day yesterday on optimism that the economy is slowing enough that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again in 2000.
Nortel Networks, Wal-Mart Stores and EMC led the Standard & Poor's 500 index higher. 
 "Investors are coming to the realization that the underlying market fundamentals are in really good shape," said Phil Orlando, chief investment officer for Value Line Asset Management, which oversees $7 billion. "The economy continues to decelerate nicely, yet corporate earnings are still in decent shape."
The Nasdaq composite index climbed 75.63, or 2 percent, to 3,862.99. The S.&. P 500 rose 16.39, or 1.1 percent, to 1,479.32. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 99.26, or 0.9 percent, to 10,867.01. The Nasdaq advanced for a third day, while the Dow and S. & P. 500 climbed for a sixth.
A report on productivity today is expected to underscore the premise that the economy can continue to grow without setting off inflation.
Still, some investors see concern about rising rates preventing a sustained rally. "I don't infer anything from the Nasdaq going up a few days in a row," said Larry Smith, chief investment officer of Credit Suisse Asset Management, which manages about $200 billion. "The risk of a tightening will remain with the market."
Nortel gained 4 7/16, to 79 3/8; Wal-Mart advanced 11 5/16, to 55; and EMC climbed 41 1/16, to 90.
With today's gains, the Nasdaq year-to-date loss is 5.1 percent, while the S & P 500 has risen 0.7 percent. The Dow has lost 5.5 percent.
Internet stocks like Ebay, Safeguard Scientifics and Quokka Sports fell after Henry Blodget, the Merrill Lynch analyst, lowered ratings on those stocks and eight others.
Mr. Blodget said his downgrades were needed because "the tide is no longer rising fast enough to lift all boats." He also cut ratings on eToys, 24/7 Media, Buy.com, iVillage, Pets.com and Webvan Group.
Ebay lost 3/4, to 50, Safeguard fell 2 3/8, to 29 9/16, and Quokka dropped 15/16, to 6 1/16.
I2 Technologies Inc. soared 17 5/16, to 143 3/8. The company, which makes software that lets manufacturers and suppliers swap information on the Internet, joined with Citigroup and three others to create a new company to make it easier for buyers and sellers to pay on line.
Citigroup rose 3/16 to 73 11/16. Ariba, which makes software to help companies buy and sell goods on the Internet, rose 105 9/64, to 135. Ariba signed an agreement with Sabre Holdings, the world's largest travel-reservation company, in which Sabre agreed to use Ariba software in its corporate travel-management system. Sabre fell 1/8, to 28 3/4.
Financial stocks fell after gains last week on the expectation the Fed would not raise rates when it meets Aug. 22. Banks, personal-loan companies and savings and loans were the best-performing groups in the S.& P. 500 last week. American Express declined 11/16, to 58 3/8, and J. P. Morgan lost 15/16, to 141 15/16.

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasuries fell yesterday after a wave of buying dried up and market participants made room for $25 billion of new government supply due this week.
 "The market has really discounted any kind of tightening from the Fed at this point," said David Gottlieb, governments trader at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
 Friday's employment report, which showed easing in the tight job market, lessened concern that the Fed would raise rates for a seventh time since June 1999 at its Aug. 22 meeting. But dealers said trading volumes dried up yesterday as the euphoria that swept the market on Friday failed to carry through.
 The 10-year Treasury note fell 13/32, to a price of 103 31/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.95 percent from 5.89 on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 23/32, to 107 1/32. The yield rose to 5.75 percent from 5.71 percent.

HEADLINE: Oakland Joins the Bay Area Boom

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The construction cranes and cement trucks are taking over the downtown here, like the artillery of a conquering army.
Smack in the middle of the commercial district, a brick's throw from the falling-down houses that have symbolized Oakland for a generation, is the growing behemoth of an office tower -- the first to be built in the city in more than 10 years -- that promises to alter the landscape here for decades to come. 
 All around that project, dot-com businesses are plowing down old walk-ups for shiny new headquarters or swooping down on boarded-up, sad-sack buildings and restoring them to the proud, handsome office complexes they once were. In short, downtown Oakland can boast that it is within striking distance of 1.6 million square feet of offices and stores, built over the last three years.
That Oakland has become so popular, already facing the same space shortage, skyrocketing rents and gentrification battles that plague the rest of the San Francisco Bay Area, is an extraordinary testament to the new economy.
The last hot property within commutable distance of Silicon Valley has long been the plain Jane cousin to San Francisco's prom queen, never noticed except for its missteps (remember Ebonics?) and flaws. From its slums, which rival the toughest in the nation, to its reputation for high crime (a reputation not always deserved, but hard to shake) to its poorly performing schools and deteriorated housing, save for a few choice neighborhoods that prefer to call themselves something other than Oakland, the city has had a bad rap for so long that Mayor Jerry Brown likes to say it has stagnated with "diminished expectations."
Now, largely because it is -- or was -- the last affordable bastion in the Bay Area, and because it has courted new residents and businesses, Oakland is feeling the ups and downs of a boom. Those celebrating include Ask Jeeves, the $1 billion Internet search company, which is one of dozens of dot-coms that have staked a claim here, with a commitment to moving at least 700 employees into its new space from the nearby city of Emeryville.
The Port of Oakland is getting in on the action as well, with a $727 million modernization. Forbes magazine is impressed enough to rank Oakland as No. 12 on its list of the top cities in the nation to do business, ahead of San Francisco (No. 42) and Silicon Valley's unofficial capital, San Jose (No. 29).
But the pressure is building along with the boom. Oakland, always considered a Bay Area haven for the poor and dispossessed, has also become the last refuge for the middle class. Nonprofit organizations, renters and house buyers alike have been leaving the overpriced, overcrowded city of San Francisco in droves. They are coming to this city of 400,000 people as their best hope for an affordable place in the Bay Area. Soon, a real estate agent said recently, "all that will be left is the wishbone."
All this new money gives Oakland an odd feel. In a scene from the new Oakland, dot-comers with Palm Pilots are sitting in Starbucks while homeless panhandlers who have lived here forever stand outside waiting to ask them for spare change. The hot real estate market is also creating a panic among members of the working class, who have made up the backbone of the city, as rents rise and renters are evicted, legally and not.
Nancy Nadel, an Oakland City Council member whose district includes much of the prime development zones, said that real estate speculation had led to a housing crisis for the poor as landlords evicted longtime tenants and, sometimes illegally, raised rents. "As new owners acquire properties at higher prices, they are raising prices higher than our somewhat weak rent control laws allow, and evicting people illegally," Ms. Nadel said.
Oakland still has a lot of its old problems, too. Its crime rate, which has been dropping steadily, recently took an upturn. Poverty and homelessness, drug dealing and AIDS, all plague the city.
And now, there are the new worries: skyrocketing rents, the condemnation of old buildings that have given refuge to the very poor and a growing sense of uneasiness on the part of many longtime residents, many of them African-Americans, that their city is now for sale.
"I don't think we're getting enough attention focused on the housing needs going on here," said Linnie Cobb, a 62-year-old homeowner who has lived in Oakland most of her life. Ms. Cobb, who is co-chairwoman of the local chapter of Acorn, the national community advocacy organization, says she hears complaints all the time from people who wonder what is happening to their city.
"It's bad when you have a whole community up in arms except for the yuppie types or the middle class or the rich," Ms. Cobb said. "We're seeing a migration of yuppie types moving in, and blacks and minorities are being pushed out."
The newcomers are the city's biggest cheerleaders. John Dolby, marketing director for the Shorenstein Company, which is building a 20-story office tower downtown, said the falling vacancy rates for prime office space -- down to 1 percent (almost as low as San Francisco's) from 9 percent last year -- reflected a changing perception among wealthy companies.
"There was a perception of Oakland that it was crime-ridden and dilapidated, which is not the case," Mr. Dolby said. "And then Jerry Brown came in and the perception is changing for the better, blocks getting cleaned up, not only downtown but surrounding neighborhoods."
Sam Nassif, owner of the Waterfront Hotel on Jack London Square, was vice president of the city's Convention and Visitors Authority when it sputtered to a close in 1998. Now, as chairman of a revived bureau, he leads a 24-member board that can boast that Oakland's 2,000 hotel rooms are near capacity in peak times. An additional 630 rooms are slated to open in the next two years.
A growing problem for the city is sparked by its war on decades of blighted housing. Since the city strengthened its antiblight laws two years ago and urged citizens to file complaints, it has issued 14,000 summonses for ugly nuisances, including trash cans left at the curb too long and building code violations. "This is a very self-conscious effort at social engineering to get us on the train of economic revival," said Claudia Leed, a deputy city attorney.
For some residents, the enforcement goes too far, punishing poor people who cannot afford to repair their houses to code. Slapped with fines that start at more than $700 and quickly climb, old homeowners may be pushed out of their only option at housing. This, a growing number of ministers and community organizations say, is a part of the consequence of Oakland's newfound popularity with the rich and middle class.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An Effort by U.S. to Change the I.M.F. Is Set Back

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Poor countries are fighting a proposal by the leading industrial nations to increase the cost of borrowing from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, dealing a blow to a campaign by Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers to change the lending agencies.
The differences emerged today when Horst Kohler, the I.M.F.'s new managing director, chided Group of Seven finance ministers for announcing their desire to charge more for loans instead of working within the fund to build consensus on the issue. Several big nations that vote on loan decisions at the I.M.F. and the World Bank oppose the changes. 
 "The direction the G-7 have set up, I think, is right and should be considered carefully," Mr. Kohler said here, addressing a plan that had been endorsed by the wealthy nations in advance of their meeting of top leaders in Japan last month. "But it is now a problem because a big group of countries within the fund feels itself lectured by the presentation of these ideas. It makes things not easy."
Mr. Kohler's comments came after the fund's board rejected the proposal from the Group of Seven in an unpublicized, informal tally late last month, a board member said today. Only about half the board members, by voting power, sided with the Group of Seven, with 70 percent support required to change lending rates.
The board's decision was a setback for Mr. Summers, who has tried to change the way the I.M.F. works and has persuaded the Group of Seven -- Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, in addition to the United States -- to endorse an increase in lending rates as an important element of his plan to overhaul the international agency.
The treasury secretary, responding in part to heavy criticism in Congress, has tried to change some of the fund's practices to address concerns that it has made mistakes while expanding its role in recent years.
The I.M.F. has repeatedly lent to a growing number of poor and modest-income nations, fought financial crises, helped the West transform Russia, and attached sweeping conditions to loans in an attempt to turn borrowers into efficient capitalists.
There appears to be broad agreement, especially among wealthy nations, that the fund should streamline its activities. But developing nations, which make up a substantial voting bloc on the fund's board and double as borrowers, do not want to pay more for their loans or to agree to apply for help less often.
Some board members from poor countries also disagreed with the reasons the Group of Seven gave for wanting to raise rates. The industrial nations said higher rates could make more money available for new lending and the forgiveness of debts of the poorest countries.
"This is a case of them asking the poor to help the poor," a board member said.
Speaking at the National Press Club, Mr. Kohler said he personally supported the idea of raising loan rates, but disagreed with the rich nations' decision to push for the changes outside the fund. He said the job of winning support had now become harder.
Mr. Kohler became managing director three months ago, after a protracted struggle that pitted the United States and several other nations against Germany. The Clinton administration effectively vetoed Germany's first choice of a candidate to head the I.M.F. before settling on Mr. Kohler, who is a former German government official.
Mr. Kohler used his speech today to preview other elements of a plan he is working on to change the I.M.F. As he has signaled in the past, he said he intended to focus the fund primarily on broad economic management and to reduce overlapping activity with the World Bank, whose mandate includes fighting poverty and overhauling the way poor countries manage their economies. His ideas are broadly similar to those of Mr. Summers.
Some in the Group of Seven had expressed hope earlier that the I.M.F. and the World Bank would endorse pricing changes during their annual meeting in Prague late in September. But several fund officials said that was unlikely now. An official at the World Bank said that its board was also discussing lending rates but that there was no consensus to increase rates at this time.
A Treasury Department spokeswoman said the Group of Seven often agrees on changes to I.M.F. and World Bank policies among themselves before presenting them to the boards of the two institutions. She said the Clinton administration still hoped that the changes would be made. "We are glad that the managing director supports pricing reforms," the spokeswoman said. "It will be an important test of the I.M.F. to forge a consensus."

HEADLINE: Murder Rate In New York Sliding Back

BYLINE: By ELISSA GOOTMAN

 BODY:
New York City's murder rate, after a surge that alarmed the Police Department and brought about an expensive and aggressive street enforcement campaign, has begun to slide back down.
The upturn in homicides, which by the end of last year was 6 percent above the count from 1998, had put the department on the defensive and loomed as a potential political liability for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had made crime reduction his most important accomplishment. 
 But recent department statistics show that the homicide rate has flattened, with this year's murder count, which was 413 as of yesterday, an even match with the corresponding period in 1999.
The numbers looked even better just last week, with homicides down 1 percent for the first seven months of this year, compared with the same period last year, but the rate edged up slightly this weekend, when the city had one of its most violent nights of the year, with six people fatally shot or stabbed throughout the city late Saturday night into early Sunday. By the end of July, there had been 392 murders, compared with 396 by the end of July 1999.
The emergence of a flat murder rate belies a more marked decline, given that at the beginning of the year, the police were still facing a rise in homicides. By the end of March, the city had 13 percent more murders than in the first three months of last year. That the weekend's onslaught of slayings did not push this year's homicide count over the total from last year at this time illustrates that, blips and spurts aside, the situation is stabilizing.
"The crime rate," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, "is down all over the city, even with the violence over the weekend, which occasionally, unfortunately you deal with."
"There is a sense of relief that we've turned the trend around," said Garry F. McCarthy, the deputy police commissioner of operations. "Although it's not the bellwether crime -- the bellwether crime is robbery -- it's obviously the most important."
The police credit the drop to Operation Condor, an antinarcotics program begun in late January. The program has come under intense criticism for its high cost, for saturating neighborhoods with narcotics teams and for increasing the number of arrests for petty offenses. The police say they have since broadened the program to take aim at crimes against drivers of taxicabs and livery cabs and to add uniformed street patrols focusing on quality-of-life offenses like jumping subway turnstiles and peddling without a license.
So far, at least $41 million has been spent on the program; police officers working under its banner have made 53,933 arrests in the course of about 100,000 overtime shifts. In its latest, broadest incarnation, the police say, Operation Condor is not so much a new strategy as a redoubling of the department's regular enforcement efforts in the neighborhoods that need it most.
Critics are reluctant to credit the program for the decline in homicides, saying the numbers are small, the downward curve is new, and the murder rate could simply be fluctuating based on forces that have little to do with law enforcement.
"I think the Police Department has done a lot to reduce crime, but I'm not sure that they can take all the credit," said Karim Ismaili, an assistant professor of criminal justice at St. John's University in Queens. "If the economy goes on a slide and if some other drug market or underground economy flourishes, we're going to see an increase."
One problem in attributing the drop to police work alone is that in the Bronx, where Operation Condor has been as active as it has in any other borough, the murder rate was 57 percent higher in the first seven months of this year than in the same period of 1999. The Bronx was the only borough that had a decline in the number of murders last year, but through July, there were 124 murders there, up from 79 in the first seven months of 1999. The Bronx recorded one of those homicides during the weekend, when one person was shot to death at a block party at which seven other people were wounded by gunfire.
Police officials said they were puzzled by the Bronx statistics. "Whatever we've done there, it has not succeeded," Mr. McCarthy said, "so it's time for us to change gears there and try something else."
The department says the drop is still a powerful piece of evidence that the city remains safe. While overall crime was down 8 percent last year, the 6 percent rise in killings took center stage, illustrating the extent to which grim homicide figures can eclipse favorable trends in other types of crime. A body count is as solid a figure as exists, and no other number is as incontrovertible or as closely watched.
The police also mentioned a possible broader pattern. Officials say that as the murder rate in New York has declined 70 percent in the last decade, to levels last seen in the 1960's, the patterns of murder have changed, restoring the classical understanding of the crime as personal, not random.
The gradual return of past murder patterns marks the end of a time when drug-related street violence bucked conventional thinking about the context and circumstances of homicide, criminologists and police officials say.
"If you look at the long-term picture, it becomes obvious why the city of today barely resembles the New York City of 10 years ago," Police Commissioner Howard Safir said. "Ten years ago, innocent people were being killed in gun battles right on the city's streets." Mr. Safir is expected to announce today that he is leaving the job by the end of this month, officials said.
According to the police, only one bystander was killed during the first half of this year, a figure that includes both people caught in cross-fire and victims whom a killer mistook for someone else. In the first half of 1990, 101 bystanders were killed, the police said.
There has also been a decline in the proportion of homicides that take place on the streets: 39 percent during the first half of this year, down from 55 percent in the same period in 1990, the statistics indicate. And the percentage of murders that took place inside private homes (as opposed to public housing projects) rose slightly, to 29 percent for the first six months of this year from 27 percent in the first half of 1990.
The experts generally concur that the statistics reflect a real trend. "I think it's fair to say that murder today is less random than in the past," said Jeffrey Fagan, a professor at Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health. "Whether that's because of changes in the drug markets or in the way people conduct their everyday life or because there's a fear of police, no one knows."
Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, said he had no doubt that the overall portrait of murder had changed, becoming "much more diffuse, much less concentrated in a small number of places" than a decade ago. "It may well be time," he said, "to rethink the tactics for dealing with the kinds of homicides that are left, which are in many cases tougher to deal with but may call for a different set of approaches."

HEADLINE: As Japan Deregulates, Quality-of-Life Laments;
Mom and Pop Do Battle With Discounters

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: MACHIDA CITY, Japan

 BODY:
Sales started sliding at the Katos' small sake shop here a decade ago, when trucks began coming into the neighborhood and selling cut-price beer and other alcoholic beverages off their tailgates.
Now the trucks have been put out of business by convenience stores, supermarkets and discount shops, but Yoshiro Kato and his wife, Mitsuko, soldier on, determined to resist forces that could turn shops like theirs into quaint memories of a Japan that no longer exists. 
 "It's deregulation," she said. "People in government say Americans have deregulation, so we should, too, but those saying that don't understand the feelings of people like us who are just struggling to survive. It's like they're telling us, just hurry up and die, would you."
Mrs. Kato has suppressed her anger many times as once-loyal customers walk past the shop in this Tokyo suburb, lugging heavy bottles of alcohol from the supermarket nearby. She does not blame them for the shop's waning business. Her own children, she said, frequent discount stores, drawn by ample parking space, late hours and low prices.
Roughly 10 years have passed since Japan began to dismantle the list of licenses, permits and other regulatory approvals that were long part of breaking into business here. Under deregulation, competition has grown, the number of stores has increased and Japanese consumers now enjoy many of the same benefits as Americans in areas ranging from convenience banking to the purchase of gasoline. But the endangered shotengai, or local shopping district, has become a rallying point against deregulation among Japanese worried that they are destroying something precious.
In some isolated cases, the forces opposing deregulation are prevailing. Neighborhood groups have banded together to fight incursions by big store chains. And in a throwback to a more regulated era, large retailers must now get permission from local committees to open stores.
"Deregulation has been accepted without any criticism in Japan as a great measure for reviving the economy," said Shoji Muranuki, leader of a citizens' group that won concessions from a retail chain seeking to open in the neighborhood. "But how can we say that deregulation is helping the economy when so many local shopkeepers and merchants are hurting because of it?"
Groups like Mr. Muranuki's and business associations that sat by quietly as the effects of deregulation spread are now increasingly vocal about drawing the line somewhere. Breaking up a telephone monopoly like the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation is one thing, they say, but destroying the livelihoods of local shopkeepers is going too far. This sympathy for local shopkeepers has given them a powerful means of defense that N.T.T. does not have.
"The difference is like the difference between an elephant and an ant," said Hiroshi Yamada, the mayor of Suginami ward in Tokyo, when asked to compare the power of small shops with that of N.T.T., the telecommunications giant that is under heavy political pressure to accept further deregulation. "N.T.T. bows to the politicians, but the politicians bow to the local shopkeepers."
Shopkeepers have traditionally been the backbone of the Japanese neighborhood. They organize festivals that make the long, sticky summers here tolerable. They are active in school affairs and community sports. They hang out in front of their shops, chatting with patrons and handing out candy or small toys to children.
"They might be feeble in terms of their sales power, but they have a big say in what happens in local areas," Mr. Yamada said. They lack the financial resources of big corporations like N.T.T, he said, "but the local shop owners can collect something even more valuable -- votes."
As a young member of Parliament a few years ago, Mr. Yamada was a strong proponent of deregulation. But as a local politician, he has pressed for passage of an ordinance to restrict the discount stores in the interest of protecting his constituents from the traffic jams, even the motorcycle gangs, that some say will blight their neighborhoods.
"Now that I have come to the front line, I have learned that just legislating deregulation does not make deregulation fruitful," he said. "I realize that many conditions need to be imposed to make deregulation work in society."
That may be, but the shotengai are one of the biggest drags on Japan's sputtering economy. According to a new study by the McKinsey Global Institute that attributes Japan's economic troubles to low productivity, traditional shops like the Katos' are far less productive than their counterparts in the United States.
Many shops stay in business in part because of high tax penalties that discourage them from selling their property. Government loan guarantees and subsidies also make it easier to survive.
But the McKinsey study discloses another important source of the traditional shopkeeper's power: mom-and-pop shops account for 55 percent of retail employment here, while the entire retail industry accounts for 12 percent of total employment and 5 percent of the gross domestic product.
Kabun Muto, a senior member of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, is making a name for himself as a champion of small liquor-store owners like the Katos, and as a critic of deregulation in general. He has submitted a bill to postpone any further deregulation that could hurt neighborhood stores.
Mr. Muto and the 220 representatives who support him also oppose the relaxation of rules on taxicab licensing. Mr. Muto contends that looser rules have given organized criminal groups a toehold in the taxi business.
"There is less intervention by the bureaucracy now," said Mr. Muto, whose family owns a sake brewery. "But in creating such an open environment, we have weakened society, and people would have different opinions about whether that's a good thing or not."
So Japanese are grappling with the question of whether the social costs that concern Mr. Muto -- the loss of livelihood by shopkeepers who are often pillars of their communities and a potential increase in troubled youth -- offset the benefits of deregulation.
In the fiscal year that ended in March 1998, the Economic Planning Agency estimated that deregulation had created 8.6 trillion yen, or $83 billion at current exchange rates, in consumer benefits.
The agency also concluded that growth was notably strong that year in deregulated businesses like telephone services, electricity and gasoline, even as the overall economy shrank. "The progress in the last few years has been marvelous," said Yoshihiko Miyauchi, chairman of the government's Regulatory Reform Committee.
He regards Mr. Muto's campaign and the lobbying of the All-Japan Liquor Merchants' Association -- whose officials paid 300 visits to politicians last year and contributed nearly $400,000 to the ruling party -- as a sign of how far deregulation has penetrated the economy. "One reason we have these types of movements is because the efforts we have made are having an effect," he said.
Yet Japan is falling behind the other big economic powers, as Mr. Miyauchi sees it. "We are walking in the right direction at a very leisurely pace," he said, "congratulating ourselves for our progress, while other countries are running this race like Olympic athletes."
Those pressing for fast-paced regulatory change here seem more like, well, Don Quixote -- which happens to be the name of a discount store chain that has become the bane of the groups opposing deregulation. The Don Quixote store in the Suginami district has become a cause celebre on both sides of the argument, with its extended hours, big parking lot and cut-rate prices.
Neighborhood residents and local merchants united last year and gathered 6,271 signatures in their campaign to keep Don Quixote out. The group argued that the store would increase traffic and worsen pollution. They said some merchandise -- in particular, sexually explicit toys and videos, as well as knives -- would end up in the hands of youngsters.
Plus, "if the store operated 24 hours a day, regular shops could not compete," said Mr. Muranuki, a retired salaryman who leads the group. "Already, our shops are suffering from large-sized retailers like supermarkets."
The group extracted some concessions from Don Quixote. The store agreed to close from 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. daily, to avoid flashy advertising and handouts that might lead to litter, and to keep the risque merchandise and the knives off its shelves.
Moreover, the Suginami local legislature passed an ordinance early last month allowing the mayor to block the opening of stores larger than 500 square meters -- almost 5,400 square feet -- if he thinks the owner has not addressed local concerns.
The ordinance revived restrictions on retailers that had recently been abolished by the Japanese government. "Now, the entire nation is focusing on what's happened here," Mr. Muranuki said proudly.
Takao Yasuda, the president of Don Quixote and a passionate proponent of deregulation, contends that the citizens group won a Pyrrhic victory. His store did open, and its sales are running 30 percent above expectations. "We are closed in hours when few customers would visit the store anyway," Mr. Yasuda said, "and if the store is closed, we can do preparatory work like straightening up the cash registers and shelves."
Members of the group that opposed the liquor store acknowledge that their worries have proved unfounded -- and they take credit for that. They still watch the store, patrolling the parking lot between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. and making spot checks of the merchandise.
"Right now, the shop isn't causing any trouble," said Kyoko Hashiguchi, the group's secretary. "Traffic jams outside the store are much less than we expected because local people seem to ride their bicycles to the store."
But Mr. Yasuda says he is concerned about the precedent the fight in the Suginami district has established. The citizens' appeal to quality-of-life concerns has resonated in the news media and with politicians in a way that complaints solely about the economic impact of deregulation have not.
Their ability to enlist local officials in their cause is also alarming, he said, adding that the ordinance's vague command that retailers must "protect the environment" leaves plenty of room for government interference.
"The ordinance itself is not so strong," Mr. Yasuda said, "but I worry that it is rather arbitrary and fuzzy in its meaning." Then he added, "In a uniquely Japanese way, the local government can exercise its own power of interpretation, and that worries me."
