HEADLINE: The Little Museum That Could;
Dahesh Tries to Shake Founder's Mystical Image and Move Into the Mainstream

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
When the mystical Lebanese writer Salim Moussa Achi died in 1984 at age 75, he left an eclectic legacy of unfashionable art and devoted disciples who told tales of his miraculous powers to "cleanse" leprosy or pluck a live bird from a painting.
To true believers, he was a beloved prophet with some 2,500 "spiritual revelations" to his credit. He restored shattered crystal with a glance. He transformed losing lottery tickets into instant winners. And, as a young man, he cheated death by an Iranian firing squad by sacrificing one of six look-alike celestial personalities. 
 Today, however, this globe-trotting collector's most visible achievement is a museum housed in a former nail salon, two floors below the Fine Art of Hair Replacement.
At Fifth Avenue and 48th Street, the cramped gallery, papered in royal-blue damask, carries the name the collector preferred for himself, Dr. Dahesh. (The word means "inspiring wonder" or "astounding" in Arabic.) And the five-year-old Dahesh Museum is trying mightily to live up to its name by lifting itself from obscurity.
Some city guidebooks label it a "jewel box," and certainly it is one of New York's more unconventional museums. As it tries to distance itself from the spiritual roots of its founder (and his assorted personalities), the Dahesh Museum has amassed an endowment of more than $30 million, putting it in a class with art-world heavyweights like the Guggenheim Museum. It is also expanding its collection of 2,700 artworks and striving to stake out a more visible location with a bid to buy the former Hartford Gallery of Modern Art, a nine-story building at 2 Columbus Circle designed by Edward Durell Stone.
Most exotic of all is its quaint practice from bygone days: It doesn't charge admission.
The Dahesh Museum's mission is to shape a thoroughly mainstream and secular institution from its exotic beginnings as the whim of a passionate collector with a fondness for the supernatural and for the Rodney Dangerfields of high art.
The museum's core is Dr. Dahesh's personal collection of more than 2,000 19th- and 20th-century academic paintings created by students and teachers under a rigid training system at European academies. These bucolic landscapes and historical scenes are rendered in a realistic style that for years was scorned and overshadowed by Impressionism.
In much the same way, the new museum has faced scorn and suspicion because of the unconventional background of its founder, a self-taught art aficionado who dropped out of school at age 11. The museum strenuously distances itself from any religious connections, avoiding discussions of miracles and referring to Dr. Dahesh as a "philosopher."
"We admire him as an art collector and a connoisseur and a person who had the foresight to see that this academic art had value," said the museum's director, John David Farmer, whose own early training incorporated disdain for the kind of academic paintings he is now eager to buy at greatly increased prices. "When I was in art school," he added, "we didn't even look at this stuff."
Not surprisingly, the museum's cautious stance on its intellectual founder has stirred grumbling among Daheshist followers, who have no central organization to track their numbers, estimated by some devotees in the thousands.
But there is really not much they can do beyond complaining that Dr. Dahesh's image has been air-brushed of religious overtones. That is because Dr. Dahesh's legal heirs, the members of the Zahid family, command the rights to shape his legacy through ownership of his artworks, book collection and the copyrights to his writings.
"I could care less about all the materialistic things, like the art and museum and books," said one Daheshist, Mounir Murad, owner of a Virginia electronic-imaging company and author of a self-published book, "Daheshism and the Journey of Life." "My main concern is that there is a spiritual mission, and they've been shoving it under a carpet. Anything that would tie the museum to a spiritual mission is taboo."
The Zahids, a wealthy Saudi family with severed roots in Lebanon, inherited 2,000 artworks when Dr. Dahesh died in Greenwich, Conn., where the Zahids live. Longtime friends of Dr. Dahesh, the Zahids helped move the collection out of Lebanon during the civil war in 1975. Later they established the museum and nurtured a separate publishing company in Manhattan to produce and distribute Dr. Dahesh's writings. The museum says that a few of the paintings are still pocked from bullets that struck them while they were hanging in Dr. Dahesh's cluttered Beirut home, which functioned as a private salon.
Amira Zahid, a lawyer and one of five Zahid relatives who serve on the Dahesh Museum's seven-member board, said that as a girl she recalled sitting in the salon and listening to the conversations of Dr. Dahesh and his supporters. She said that Dr. Dahesh had wanted to create a museum in Lebanon. But when the family members inherited his estate years later, they preferred Manhattan because "New York is a challenge, and if we can make it in New York City we can make it everywhere," she said. "We are very serious about this."
With the multimillion-dollar inheritance from Dr. Dahesh, Ms. Zahid said that her mother, Mervat, proposed to her the idea of starting a museum with little more direction than, "You figure it out." The Dahesh Museum was incorporated in 1987 and formally opened in January 1995 with that seed money, the younger Ms. Zahid said.
The endowment has grown from $6.4 million in 1989 to more than $30 million in stock investments, which have increased over the years with regular contributions from Zahid family members. Last year alone, Amira Zahid donated $59,000 in cash and stocks valued at more than $2 million. The Zahids have also been active in acquiring new works for the museum, participating and bidding in auctions.
The endowment has helped nurture the Dahesh Museum's ambitions. Currently, with just 2,500 square feet of gallery space, the museum can offer only condensed exhibitions of Dr. Dahesh's collections of works by artists like Rosa Bonheur and Adolphe William Bouguereau, or loan exhibitions like its current one, "In the Footsteps of Goethe."
But the museum is determined to break out of its confines. In May it submitted a second, sweetened bid for the former Hartford Gallery building. Its earlier bid was rejected, as was a proposal from the developer Donald Trump, apparently because the amount, which the museum declined to disclose, was deemed unsatisfactory. An official with the Economic Development Commission said that the Dahesh Museum's second bid was still under review.
With a successful bid, the museum predicts that it could reopen in about 18 months at Columbus Circle, which would have a sizable impact on its annual attendance of about 20,000 people.
"It's a museum with enormous potential that can't be realized because it's ridiculously small," said Robert Rosenblum, a professor of fine arts at New York University and a curator of the Guggenheim exhibition "1900: Art at the Crossroads." "Everything depends on what's going to happen. If they're still cramped in this little space, they can't do much."
"They have an exceptional director and an excellent staff," he said. "Their background is a little bit like the problem of lots of other museums that have transcended the character of their founders. When you think of Albert C. Barnes and the Barnes Foundation -- he was a total lunatic. But with the money coming in, the personality of the founder is something that essentially gets buried, and what's relevant is the potential of the place."
The Dahesh Museum is one of very few institutions in the United States that exclusively promote 19th-century academic art. Polly Sartori, who oversees 19th-century paintings at Sotheby's in New York, said that the museum had also reassured collectors about the value of such works. "Collectors are very aware that when they go into major museums that most of the space is devoted to Impressionist paintings," she said.
Dr. Dahesh started collecting art in the 1930's, well before he faced persecution by the Lebanese authorities and temporary exile in 1944 for his religious beliefs. The key tenet of Daheshism is the universality of major religions and their embrace of the same core teachings and the same God. Miracles, Dr. Dahesh told some of his followers and his biographer, Salim Onbargi, "strengthen the bond of faith and belief in God."
No one is quite sure why Dr. Dahesh bought academic paintings, but the works were certainly more affordable than the Impressionist paintings that his friends said he also relished. Academic paintings sold for as little as $275 in the 1940's.
Followers like Fares Zaatar, who is completing a book about Dr. Dahesh, said that the collector amassed his acquisitions with help from supporters and earnings from the sales of his own books. The books, which offer spiritual lessons, include a 20-volume series about the global wanderings he undertook after he left Lebanon permanently in 1976.
"His extraordinary spiritual power enabled him to discern the great art," said Ghazi Brax, the editor of Dahesh Voice, a magazine for followers. "He was a genuine connoisseur. He believed in the power of great art in sublimating the instinctive drives and enhancing spiritual awakening."
Mr. Brax described the Zahid family as some of Dr. Dahesh's "favorite followers." His magazine is published by the Daheshist Publishing Company, whose president is listed as Amira Zahid's mother, Mervat.
But Amira Zahid is so careful about building a wall between the museum and religion that she declined to say whether she was a Daheshist. Mr. Farmer, the director of the museum, added that since the founding of the Dahesh Museum, the family had never espoused any religious views.
"I couldn't speak for my family," Ms. Zahid said. "I can only speak for myself. I have my own personal beliefs, but I don't think this is the forum to talk about it."
At the museum, nursing coffee from a cup emblazoned with Jules Breton's sketch "Le Gouter," she expressed frustration that the family had been scrutinized for years as if they were almost "criminals" because of suspicions about their motives.
"Dahesh is a person with many gifts, and so people can take from them what they want," Ms. Zahid said. "We're lucky to have known him, and this collection really is a gift from him to the city of New York."
"We are here to promote nothing but art," she said, adding, "Why can't we just accept the museum for what it is?"

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
For Richer, for Poorer

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
After working hard for many years, you and your husband have retired with a decent income from pensions and investments. Then, sadly, he dies. Is it fair that you should suddenly face higher tax bills, because your deductions have been cut in half and you are now in a higher tax bracket? In 1969 widows didn't think so.
Thanks in large part to their complaints, Congress decided to increase the deductions offered to single adults, and raise the incomes at which they entered higher tax brackets. Married couples in which the husband was the dominant earner -- the norm 30 years ago -- still paid lower taxes than they would have if unmarried, but their advantage was reduced. Nowadays, however, there are enough married couples with two comparable incomes that this tax break for widows is denounced as a "marriage tax," though even more couples receive a "marriage benefit." 
 The moral of this story is that the legislation Bill Clinton vetoed last week, which would have reduced the taxes of married couples, was not a clear move in the direction of "fairness." Widows, widowers and single people in general can justifiably claim to have been unfairly neglected -- especially since it turns out that most of the benefits would have gone to couples who already pay lower taxes than they would if they were unmarried. And the vetoed tax cut would -- surprise! -- also disproportionately help couples who are already very well off.
So is this just another example of trickle-down economics, of tax cuts for the affluent that are supposed to benefit the rest in some indirect way? No: it's worse than that.
You see, in the good old days conservatives used to argue that the really important thing was to reduce the marginal tax rate, the share of an additional dollar of income paid to Uncle Sam. If people got to keep more of any extra money they made, so the argument went, they would be motivated to work harder, save more, and so on. Of course, that also meant big tax cuts for the rich -- but increasing incentives was supposed to be the point of it all.
The bill eliminating the "marriage penalty," however, doesn't reduce marginal tax rates for its biggest beneficiaries. A married couple earning $100,000 a year would have gotten a tax break of around $1,700 -- seven times as much as the benefit for a couple with half their income -- but any additional money they earn would have been taxed at the same 28 percent rate as before. And because the marginal rate hasn't changed, the couple have no incentive to work harder, invest more, or any of those other good things that tax-cutters usually promise. So this isn't even supply-side economics; it's just a gift package for upper-middle-class couples.
Still, isn't it a good thing to encourage marriage, the bedrock of our society? Any tax expert could have told Congress that the really serious marriage penalty in our tax code involves the earned-income tax credit, which supplements the income of the working poor: when low-earning workers marry, their benefits are sharply reduced. Congress did vote a token increase in earned-income tax credit allowances, but not nearly enough to solve the problem. You might think that strengthening families trying to work their way out of poverty is more important than persuading affluent professionals not to live in sin. But I guess not.
I never thought that I would miss the days of the Laffer curve, when right-wingers used to say that lower taxes would mean higher revenue. But back then tax cuts were rationalized by ideas, however silly. These days the anti-tax movement seems driven only by a carefully selective sentimentality -- one that weeps for children of multimillionaires who don't get their full inheritance, but tells poor mothers to go out and get a job.
And it's a funny thing, but though the rationale for tax cuts seems to have changed, the distribution of the rewards -- who gets nothing, who gets the big benefits -- always ends up being the same. You might think that just once, for the sake of appearances, Congress would pass a law that provided more benefits (at least as a percentage of income) to those earning less than $50,000 a year than to those earning more than $150,000. But these guys are nothing if not consistent.

HEADLINE: Productivity of Workers Rose At 5.3% Rate in 2nd Quarter

BYLINE: NYTimes.com/TheStreet.com 

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers increased sharply in the second quarter, pushing labor costs down, the government said yesterday. The report bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates later this month.
The Labor Department said that worker productivity rose at a 5.3 percent annual rate in the latest quarter, higher than economists' expectations and nearly triple the revised rate of 1.9 percent for the first quarter. 
 With the gains in productivity, unit labor costs, a broad measure of how much businesses pay for unit of output, fell a surprising 0.1 percent in the second quarter, after rising 1.9 percent in the first quarter.
Productivity -- workers' output per hour -- has risen steeply in recent years as computer technology and other innovations have allowed businesses to press workers to do more tasks in the same amount of time. The productivity gains have also allowed businesses to absorb wage increases without raising the price of goods and services they produce, or to increase their profit margins.
Indeed, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in recent Congressional testimony that increased productivity was helping to restrain inflationary pressures, and that much of the gain in productivity could be nonreversible. Federal Reserve policy makers meet on interest rates on Aug. 22.
In a year-over-year comparison, productivity rose at a 5.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the biggest increase since the third quarter of 1983. And compared with the second quarter of 1999, unit labor costs fell 0.4 percent, the first year-over-year drop since the first quarter of 1984.
Hourly compensation rose 5.3 percent in the second quarter, compared with 3.9 percent in the first quarter. But adjusted for inflation, compensation rose only 1.6 percent against a flat reading in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: The Politics of Adulthood

BYLINE: By Jedediah Purdy; Jedediah Purdy, a student at Yale Law School, is the author of "For Common Things: Irony, Trust and Commitment in America Today."

 BODY:
America wants to grow up. Underneath the barbs and platitudes, that is the theme of this presidential campaign. Maybe it came out of polls. But probably not. It has the ring of an unexpected truth, the kind of thing a speechwriter, or even a candidate, sometimes intuits and finds a way to express.
The theme got under way with Bill Bradley's candidacy, which was about the idea that a prosperous America could afford to pursue higher goals through politics. Mr. Bradley proposed that self-interest left people cold in the end, and that economically comfortable voters were looking for ways to reduce poverty, create equality of opportunity and address racial division. We'd had our good times, and now was the time to act like adults. 
 The growing-up issue survived the Bradley campaign. Karenna Gore Schiff, a visible spokeswoman for her father, has made her trademark a call to her peers to surrender their "ironic detachment," the emblematic adolescent attitude, and dare to get passionate about presidential politics. Worldly wise indifference can be fun for a while, but no one knows better than a recent Harvard graduate, like Ms. Gore, that it's kid stuff.
George W. Bush has defused questions about his own maturity by appearing front and center in the campaign for national adulthood. His acceptance speech at the Republican Convention took over Mr. Bradley's theme wholesale. Governor Bush, who by several accounts finished his adolescence some 20 years after many of his peers, couched his "prosperity with a purpose" theme in an exhortation to his generation to prove itself, to "reclaim some essential values, to show we have grown up before we grew old."
His generation "tested limits" in its youth, he said, but is now coming to "a responsibility era." That phrase animated the final minutes of Mr. Bush's speech and captured his idea that individuals, religious organizations, corporations and presidents must temper their appetites and self-interest with a sense of duty to children, neighbors, the needy, the nation, the natural world. Everyone must begin acting like a grown-up.
Yesterday, Mr. Gore seemed to answer Mr. Bush's challenge by naming a running mate who is more associated with positions of moral responsibility than almost any other politician today. In fact, if there has been a criticism of Senator Joseph Lieberman this week, it is that he becomes sanctimonious about higher purposes.
The politics of adulthood is resonant for more than one reason. The most obvious is the adolescent behavior of the Clinton administration. These eight years have seen undisciplined appetites, ceaseless experiments with looks and attitudes, and a desperation to please that sometimes reverses itself into towering arrogance. People learn to expect these irritations from their children, but not from their leaders.
A deeper reason is the widespread perception that, indeed, prosperity is not enough. People who have provided for themselves and their families are looking for ways to contribute to larger communities, to give back and to put new meaning in their work. Others are noticing that, as the country's wealth increases, its inequalities grow more stark and unsettling. People worry that "They got rich and threw a lot of parties" is not history's highest benediction.
Many young voters take personal maturity and responsibility seriously. Children of divorce, now coming to adulthood in force, object to both hasty marriages and self-indulgent departures. Even anti-sweatshop activists and youthful union organizers read up on personal investment and build accounts for retirement, their children's education, or just security. Thirty years ago this would have seemed premature middle age. Today it has become common-sense behavior. It is always reassuring to hear politicians echo common sense.
Yet there is a risk for candidates in too loudly enunciating the politics of adulthood. Personal responsibility is as desirable in citizens and leaders as in friends and family. But the main work of politics is not to produce virtue, and personal virtue does not of itself produce good politics. Saying that corporations must be "responsible to leave the air and waters clean," as Mr. Bush did in his acceptance speech, is a reason to pass strong and efficient environmental laws, not a substitute for them.
Politics matters because government enables us to do things together that none of us could do alone: protect the environment, keep the workplace safe, guard public health, and address poverty and inequality on a national scale. Leading decent, successful lives may not, by itself, make a good society.
That is precisely why so many people now feel that prosperity is not enough. When politicians only urge us to lead better lives, and promise to do the same themselves, they may end up amplifying the discontent that they set out to solve.

HEADLINE: FirstEnergy Acquires GPU in $4.5 Billion Cash-Stock Deal

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
The FirstEnergy Corporation, an Ohio-based utility company, agreed yesterday to acquire GPU Inc. of Morristown, N.J., for $4.5 billion in cash and stock.
The acquisition would make FirstEnergy the sixth-largest energy concern in the United States, based on customers served. Its increased size and scale would also give it the potential to produce and distribute electricity more efficiently, industry analysts said. 
 The deal, approved by the boards of both companies, could save the combined company $150 million the first year, a FirstEnergy spokesman said.
FirstEnergy is based in Akron, Ohio, and primarily serves the Cleveland, Akron and Toledo markets and western Pennsylvania. GPU, best known for its past ownership of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, provides power to central and coastal New Jersey, as well as the northwestern part of the state and eastern and central Pennsylvania.
The deal allows FirstEnergy, which generates electricity, operates a transmission grid and servesclients, to double its customer base to about 4.3 million and to establish itself firmly on the East Coast. GPU, for its part, will receive a significant premium on its equity as part of the deal. FirstEnergy is offering $36.50 for each share of GPU common stock, which rose 75 cents yesterday, to $31.4375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
GPU, which divested itself of nearly all its power plants, would have access to FirstEnergy's power generation and would also be able to buy power more cheaply as part of a bigger company, changes that could translate into lower rates for its current customers in western New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania.
Together with last week's announcement of a union between the FPL Group of Florida and Entergy, based in New Orleans, the FirstEnergy acquisition may signal the start of another round of consolidation in the electric utility industry, which was reshaped last year by more than two dozen mergers.
Share prices of many utilities have risen substantially since the start of the year, increasing the temptation for management to find buyers for their companies. Utilities also realize that in the wake of last year's mergers, bigger companies have more opportunities to cut costs, to market their electricity more aggressively and to negotiate better deals for the purchase of power.
"They need to be big to implement the most efficiencies and have the economies of scale," said Barry M. Abramson, senior utility analyst at PaineWebber.
Consumer advocates in New Jersey expressed guarded optimism over the sale of GPU. Blossom Peretz, the ratepayer advocate for the state of New Jersey, a position appointed by the governor, said rates charged by GPU and other New Jersey utilities were relatively high, but that GPU had built a solid reputation as a company that cooperates with customers and regulators. The state ratepayer's office said it wanted to find out if GPU would be able to buy cheaper energy as part of a larger company with better purchasing power. Ms. Peretz also said her office expected FirstEnergy to share with its customers any savings made from the merger.
"We're also concerned that none of the merger-related costs go to ratepayers," Ms. Peretz said, "and that there be no rate shocks due to the deal."
The market, however, had a negative reaction to the deal. When word of a possible acquisition leaked out Monday, most analysts downgraded their ratings of FirstEnergy, citing the burdens the company will have to take on in purchasing GPU. Both companies are growing at a rate of 4 percent to 5 percent a year, lagging behind many other utilities that show double-digit growth.
FirstEnergy, which has no current debt on the parent company level, will have to incur debt to make the acquisition. "Financing for the cash portion of the transaction is going to come from a combination of public debt and bank financing," said Richard Marsh, the chief financial officer of FirstEnergy, during a conference call with analysts.
Moreover, FirstEnergy will assume GPU's $7.4 billion in debt, which the latter acquired through a series of overseas investments that are faltering.
GPU entered the retail energy field in Australia at the height of the market, but sold its venture recently for a loss. It also bought into the British market at a time when industry observers felt that utilities would be hit by a rate cut -- which is what happened. And GPU sold its generation business before power generators began making hefty profits because of high demand.
Because it shed most of its generation capacity, GPU is also short of power in Pennsylvania, a gap that FirstEnergy, whose own capacity is stretched in summer, will have to address.
Shares of FirstEnergy closed down 0.3 percent, or 6.25 cents, closing at $25.3125 yesterday.

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Sister M. Isolina Ferre, a Catholic nun from a wealthy family in Puerto Rico who was awarded the Medal of Freedom by President Clinton last August for over half a century of charity and peacemaking, died on Thursday in her native city of Ponce. She was 85.
"Armed only with her faith, she taught gangs in New York City to solve their differences without violence," President Clinton said in a statement last week. "In Puerto Rico, her community service centers, the Centros Isolina Ferre, transformed ravaged neighborhoods by operating clinics and helping residents to empower themselves." 
 Sister Isolina won the Medal of Freedom, the highest honor the government can give a civilian, for establishing charitable centers in New York City and Appalachia, in addition to Puerto Rico.
A friend and fellow nun in Sister Isolina's order, the Missionary Servants of the Most Blessed Trinity, said that Sister Isolina successfully mediated a conflict between warring Puerto Rican youth gangs in Brooklyn in the 1950's and 60's while she was the director of a Catholic charitable center there.
The friend said Sister Isolina's success as a peacemaker was the result of her interpersonal skills, her training in sociology at Fordham and the insights provided by her Puerto Rican heritage.
She also worked with Portuguese immigrants in New England and black youths in Brooklyn.
She won a Rockefeller Public Service Award in 1980 for her work in revitalizing communities and neighborhoods and organizing local groups to serve the unemployed, underskilled, delinquent, sick and handicapped.
Sister Isolina was born into a Puerto Rican family that owns two leading newspapers. Her brother, Luis, was a governor of Puerto Rico, and established the ruling New Progressive Party. She employed her family's influence in establishing charitable organizations.
In 1935, while on a trip to Havana, she decided to join the Missionary Servants of the Most Blessed Trinity. She studied at St. Joseph College for Women and at Fordham University. Her work in Puerto Rico included founding a vocational school in Ponce.
She is survived by her brother.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Sex appeal still overpowers sports skill when it comes to the marketing of female athletes.

BYLINE: By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
THE lightning struck first in 1996, when the United States women's soccer team won the gold at the summer Olympic Games, a traditional generator of sports heroes. Then it happened again, a year ago. After a month of matches, the United States women's soccer team -- composed largely of Olympic athletes -- beat China in a spectacular finale and captured the 1999 Women's World Cup. Before, during and after, the nation watched, rapt, as it rarely had for any women's team sport. Players like Mia Hamm became media darlings, their names known to all. And Madison Avenue sat up and paid attention.
Or did it? 
 "With their great success on the field, it should have been a given that great commercial success would have come to all of these women," said Nova Lanktree, whose Lanktree Sports Celebrity Network in Chicago has been matching athletes and endorsers for 15 years. "But it hasn't."
One year after the triumph of Team USA and with the start of the 2000 summer Games only weeks away, prospects are indisputably better than they once were. But it seems that when it comes to women and product endorsements, sex still sells better than athletic prowess on the playing fields.
Exhibit A: Anna Kournikova, the pretty 19-year-old tennis player whose looks have earned her an estimated $11 million to $15 million in endorsement contracts despite a lackluster record on the professional circuit.
While Ms. Kournikova is only ranked 19th in the world, her earnings are about equal to those of the top-seeded player, Martina Hingis, who has won millions in tournament money. Ms. Kournikova, in fact, came in just behind Ms. Hingis in income among female athletes on the Forbes Celebrity 100 list. Indeed, her endorsement contracts put her ahead of more accomplished athletes like Monica Seles ($7.5 million in annual income) and Venus and Serena Williams ($5 million and $6 million, respectively).
Even Ms. Kournikova could not come close to earning what the men did, like Tiger Woods ($47 million), Michael Jordan ($40 million) and even the 70-year-old Arnold Palmer ($19 million).
Why?
Simple economics. "For an advertiser, the most important element is visibility," Ms. Lanktree said. "And in sports, women are just not as visible."
The problem is one of marketability, according to Ms. Lanktree, not sexism, Ms. Kournikova's obvious use of sex appeal to get endorsement contracts notwithstanding.
"There are not a lot of women's sports that are on par with respect to attendance and money," said Jackie Thomas, the director of women's marketing at Nike in Beaverton, Ore., which uses many female athletes to promote its footwear and athletic apparel.
"Endorsement payments are based on market value," Ms. Thomas said, "whether it's a man or a woman."
That does not mean, of course, that no woman athlete has achieved success in advertising on par with men, or that women cannot go beyond the sports clothing endorsements to which most have been limited in the past. Nike, for example, uses Ms. Hamm, the soccer player, to promote products that "transcend the gender line," as Ms. Thomas put it, and has in fact named one of the buildings on its Beaverton campus headquarters in her honor. And Gatorade, sold by Quaker Oats, recently introduced a campaign titled American Woman, with a television spot featuring Ms. Hamm; Chamique Holdsclaw, a star of the Women's National Basketball Association; the tennis legend Billie Jean King; and Marion Jones, the champion runner.
The Gatorade campaign is aimed at all consumers, not just women, as are other ads for Gatorade that feature male athletes like Derek Jeter, Peyton Manning and Mr. Jordan.
But that commercial is still the exception. Usually, advertisers who use female athletes do so because they are seeking to reach women. For instance, General Mills for its Multi-Grain Cheerios cereal just signed a three-year sponsorship deal with the Ladies Professional Golf Association because the market for the product is "women over 25," according to a General Mills spokesman, Greg Zimprich, who are a "perfect fit demographically" with the women's golf tour.
And then there is the ballyhooed case of Ms. Kournikova. She has endorsement contracts with Charles Schwab and Adidas, among others, and was the subject of a cover article in Sports Illustrated in June. The cheesecake layout accompanying the article led to criticism of her for perpetuating the stereotype of women as sex objects to the detriment of other female athletes who may be better at their sports but not as conventionally attractive.
But Ms. Kournikova has her defenders. "One of the beauties of being a woman today is that you can be a lot of different things," said Ms. Thomas at Nike, who said she believed that glamour was one of the many options that should be afforded to female athletes.
Nancy Lieberman-Cline, coach of the W.N.B.A. Detroit Shock and president of the nonprofit Women's Sports Foundation, agrees.
Though she called the Kournikova example an "isolated situation," Ms. Lieberman-Cline said that if "playing off her looks" is what Ms. Kournikova wants to do, she has the right to "project her image any way she wants."
Despite lingering inequalities, Ms. Lieberman-Cline said, things are "absolutely better than they were before." She ought to know: a member of the United States women's basketball team that won a silver medal at the 1976 Olympics, she was at the time one of only a few women athletes to obtain nationwide recognition and substantial product endorsements from companies like Johnson & Johnson and Jordache.
"In my day, it was Nancy or nothing," Ms. Lieberman-Cline said, adding: "That's really changed. Now I could rattle off the names of dozens of female athletes who are highly marketable."
"It's very empowering to be a woman in sports these days."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
After Andersen War, Accountants Think Hard About Consulting

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Now that the Andersens are finally splitsville, are accountants going to forsake everything but the single life, limiting themselves to poring over a company's books and offering tax advice?
Not if they can help it. 
 A day after an arbitrator freed Andersen Consulting from Arthur Andersen, the tax and auditing firm, attention shifted to some of the other accounting and consulting marriages that are on the rocks. Though the world's largest accounting firms are eager to sell their existing consulting businesses for a variety of reasons, they will probably continue to offer a wide array of services -- unless regulators place new limits on them.
In the long run, "all the public accounting firms will be in consulting," predicted Robert K. Elliott, the chairman of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and a partner with KPMG.
Consulting has fueled much of the firms' growth over the last decade or so, said Jon McKenna, the executive editor of the Public Accounting Report. "It would be foolish to sell off a goose that golden," he said.
The international arbitrator brought in to settle the bitter Andersen dispute, which had dragged on for three years, essentially gave Andersen Consulting its freedom for a paltry $1 billion, although Arthur Andersen got the right to the Andersen name.
But the other firms moving toward split-ups expect to get a lot more than $1 billion given the high valuations on the consulting businesses. Ernst & Young sold its consulting unit earlier this year to Cap Gemini S.A. for some $11 billion, and KPMG plans to spin off the bulk of its consulting operations in an initial public offering that could raise nearly $3 billion. PricewaterhouseCoopers is also considering divesting itself of its consulting unit by the end of the year.
Selling at least a part of the business to another company or the public makes sense, according to Mr. Elliott. "I think it's driven by the economics," he said. Some firms are worried about the retirement needs of their partners, while others simply want to put the cash to other uses, offering stock to the partners or investing more in the traditional accounting side of the firm.
If money is why these firms are getting out, money may be the reason these firms get back into consulting, even after they sell off a large stake in their existing businesses. Arthur Andersen, for example, started another consulting business even after it decided to part ways with Andersen Consulting. "There's a natural desire to have consulting in one of these firms," said Kenneth A. Merchant, the dean of accounting at the University of Southern California.
What might change is the type of consulting these firms do. They may move away from management or information technology consulting to other areas that are either in demand or somehow related to their expertise in giving outsiders faith in the numbers and representations that companies make. "The challenge is what does business assurance mean," said Rocco J. Maggiotto, the global leader of markets and strategy for PricewaterhouseCoopers.
There is also some anxiety among these firms that the Securities and Exchange Commission might eventually give them little choice in the matter. Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the S.E.C., has expressed concern over the perception that auditor independence has been hindered by consulting services offered by the same firm, a perception strengthened when companies like Pinnacle Holdings and its auditor come under investigation for questions of independence, as happened yesterday. While accounting firms are already prohibited from offering some of those services, the S.E.C. is proposing to bar companies from using the same firm to provide both internal and outside audits and using a firm that provides information services consulting to them as their auditor.
Even if Mr. Levitt does not prevail, or reaches a compromise that allows many of the consulting services to still be offered, the need to reassure investors and clients of their independence may force firms to stay away from certain businesses. "Whether Levitt is there or not, they've opened the box up," said Tom Rodenhauser, an analyst with Consulting Information Services, who expects the relationship between accountants and consultants to fundamentally change to avoid potential conflicts of interest.
After the firms rid themselves of their consulting units and become smaller, there is also the possibility of futher consolidation, even as the firms once known as the Big Eight have shrunk to the Big Five. Without the consulting unit, Arthur Andersen has become a much smaller player, and Ernst and KPMG had once expressed interest in combining.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Advances 109.88 on Easing of Inflation Worries

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks moved higher for the seventh consecutive session yesterday as tame inflation data drew investors back to interest-rate-sensitive shares, like retailers, at the expense of the technology sector.
But Microsoft rose 4 1/8, to 74 1/8, after the company introduced free software for electronic books. That was not enough, however, to counter pressure on the technology-heavy Nasdaq market from investors who cashed in on recent gains. 
 Lifting the broader market in early trading was news that nonfarm productivity jumped 5.3 percent in the second quarter, exceeding Wall Street's expectations for a 4.3 percent gain.
"Those numbers were really positive for the market," said Charles Payne, head analyst at an independent research firm, Wall Street Strategies. "Investors are not ready to get out of the market and whenever they get a little concerned, they jump back into the safer Dow stocks."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 109.88 points, or 1 percent, to 10,976.89, its highest close in more than three months. It finished at 11,125 on April 25.
Besides Microsoft, other big Dow gainers were two retailing names. Home Depot rose 2, to 57, and Wal-Mart added 2 1/2, to 57 1/2.
Another Dow component, Eastman Kodak, rose 2 3/8, to 60 1/2, after positive remarks on the company's United States film sales by Salomon Smith Barney.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 3.48 points, or 0.2 percent, at 1,482.80.
The Nasdaq, meanwhile, shed 14.44 points, or 0.4 percent, to 3,848.55, after gaining more than 75 on Monday.
"The Nasdaq has had a hard time putting together back-to-back winning streaks," said Bryan Piskorowski at Prudential Securities.
Cisco Systems eased 3/4, to 65 1/2, ahead of its earnings, released after the close, which topped Wall Street's expectations.
In other economic news, second-quarter unit labor costs fell 0.1 percent, below Wall Street's estimate for a 0.6 percent gain. The numbers raised hopes that the Federal Reserve's policy committee, which meets on Aug. 22, will not have to lift interest rates to keep inflation in check. Higher productivity data lowers the risk of wage inflation because it is an indication that fewer employees can do more work.
"All the numbers to date have really indicated moderation of growth, and this does the same thing," said Pierre Ellis, senior economist at Primark Decision Economics.
Verizon Communications dropped 51 3/16, to 42 1/16, after the local telephone company posted higher, but disappointing, profits and trimmed its growth outlook for 2000. The company, formally known as Bell Atlantic, is in talks to settle a strike by union workers. It said it planned to merge its high-speed Internet access business with the NorthPoint Communications Group. NorthPoint fell 3/4, to 14 1/4.
Staples, the office products retailer, rose 2 1/4, to 17 9/16, after saying it would beat second-quarter profit estimates.
America Online Latin America rose 7/16, to 8 7/16, in the initial public offering of the venture between America Online and the Venezuelan media conglomerate Cisneros . The offering raised $200 million -- far below original expectations of $425 million. The shares of America Online advanced 1/2, to 53 3/8.
Active Power, an electrical equipment manufacturer, rose 35 3/4, to 52 3/4, in its initial public offering.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Cisco Sales Rise 61% in Quarter as Company Continues to Gain From Internet Growth

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Cisco Systems Inc. reported a 61 percent gain in sales for its fiscal fourth quarter today, as the company continued to be the leading supplier of the necessary hardware for the build-up of the Internet. It was the company's 10th consecutive quarter of accelerating year-over-year revenue growth.
Excluding acquisition-related charges, Cisco earnings exceeded analysts' published estimates by a penny a share. 
 Separately, Cisco said its No. 2 executive, Donald J. Listwin, was resigning to lead an unnamed company in which Cisco is a minority shareholder. Mr. Listwin, whose title was executive vice president, is leaving after 10 years with the company, where he was responsible for Cisco's New World business strategy and led its service provider and consumer businesses as well as corporate marketing.
Cisco reported its results after the close of the market. Cisco shares closed at $65.50, down 75 cents, in Nasdaq trading.
For the quarter ended July 29, Cisco reported earnings of $796 million, or 11 cents a diluted share, up 32 percent compared with $605 million, or 8 cents a share, for the period a year earlier. Sales rose 61 percent to $5.72 billion, compared with $3.56 billion in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1999.
Cisco said its pro forma net income, which excludes the effects of acquisition charges, payroll tax on stock option exercises and net gains realized on minority investments, was $1.20 billion, or 16 cents a diluted share, for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2000, compared with $710 million, or 10 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of fiscal 1999, increases of 69 percent and 60 percent, respectively. Analysts had expected Cisco to earn 15 cents a share, according to First Call.
"The quarter, as expected, looks very strong," said Greg Geiling, an analyst with J. P. Morgan. Revenue growth of 61 percent year over year, and 16 percent over the immediately previous quarter, "are tremendous numbers for a company this size," he said. "And it looks like very balanced growth across all the business lines, which is just what you like to see."
During the quarter, Cisco completed the acquisitions of Atlantech Technologies Ltd., JetCell Inc., PentaCom Ltd., Qeyton Systems and Seagull Semiconductor Ltd. for a combined purchase price, including assumed liabilities, of approximately $1.39 billion, and took one-time charges of $461 million, or approximately 6 cents a share, on an after-tax basis, as write-offs of purchased in-process research and development. Additionally, Cisco completed the acquisitions of ArrowPoint Communications Inc., the InfoGear Technology Corporation and SightPath Inc., which were accounted for as poolings of interests.
"We predicted five years ago that we were in the midst of a second Industrial Revolution that would determine the prosperity of companies, countries, and individuals. Today, the Internet continues to drive the strongest U.S. economy in history," John Chambers, Cisco's president and chief executive, said in a statement. "We see no indications in the marketplace that the radical Internet business transformation in practices like customer service, supply-chain management, employee training, empowerment, and e-commerce that is taking place around the world today is slowing -- in fact, we believe it is accelerating globally."
But Mr. Chambers also said that Cisco is experiencing some of the problems that come with explosive growth. Particularly in new product areas, the company has been constrained by shortages of crucial components, and is taking steps to increase order volume with its major suppliers. Lead times on its own products reached what Mr. Chambers called "an undesirable peak" in June, but he added that he expected improvements in manufacturing management to return these times to normal by the end of the calendar year.
For the year, Cisco reported earnings of $2.67 billion, or 36 cents a diluted share, compared with $2.02 billion, or 29 cents a share, for fiscal 1999. Sales rose 55 percent, to $18.93 billion, compared with $12.17 billion for fiscal 1999.
Cisco's pro forma net income was $3.91 billion, or 53 cents a diluted share, for fiscal 2000, compared with pro forma net income of $2.52 billion or 36 cents a share for fiscal 1999, increases of 56 percent and 47 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: McCaffrey Voices Confidence in Mexico's Anti-Drug Efforts

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8

 BODY:
In one of his last official visits here as the United States director of drug policy, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, praised the transition team of President-elect Vicente Fox and said he shared Mr. Fox's opposition to the American drug-certification program.
But General McCaffrey, who has long expressed misgivings about the program, said there was no chance that Congress would end it in the near future. "Zero," he said, to a question at a news briefing. At most, he said, the program might die a kind of natural death as the Organization of American States begins drawing up plans next year for multinational drug evaluation that would open all member governments' drug programs to scrutiny. 
 "I actually believe," General McCaffrey said, "that the certification process is slowly disappearing under the evidence that multinational cooperation better serves the interests of the American people than confrontation."
Under the program, created by Congress in the 1980's, the State Department evaluates other countries' interdiction efforts and can impose economic sanctions on countries that do receive certification. Most Latin American governments view the program as interventionist and lopsided, because it does not allow for scrutiny of American efforts to combat consumption.
General McCaffrey, who arrived on Monday for a series of meetings, including visits with Mr. Fox's chief security and law enforcement advisers, praised the president-elect for seeking greater cooperation among countries in the fight against drugs. He said he was confident that Mexico's efforts would not be weakened by Mr. Fox's plans to limit the military's role gradually.
General McCaffrey has long praised the Mexican military as a crucial element of the battle because of its successes in destroying marijuana crops and in confiscating drug shipments that travel through Mexico on the way to the United States. At least 60 percent of all cocaine that enters the United States is widely thought to pass through Mexico.
"My judgment is that President-elect Fox and this team that we are working with are pragmatists," General McCaffrey said to reporters at the United States Embassy. "They are determined to go down in history as Mexican patriots. I cannot believe they will do anything that doesn't make sense to them. They have got large new visions. And what we are going to do is listen to what they say and be supportive of their emerging strategies."
Soon after his election on July 2, Mr. Fox announced plans to reorganize the justice system to resemble United States agencies. At the same time, he announced plans to lobby Washington to end the drug-certification program. That will be among the topics to be discussed this month when Mr. Fox travels to the United States to meet President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and the Republican presidential candidate, George W. Bush.
A member of Mr. Fox's transition team said even though ending certification seemed unlikely, Mexico was determined to stop it.

HEADLINE: New York: Phone Strike Epicenter

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Call it a New York state of mind.
Three days into the strike by more than 86,000 employees of the nation's largest local telephone company, spanning the region from Maine to Virginia, the most strident and sometimes violent front lines of the walkout have been in New York City and its suburbs. 
 Yesterday, the company, Verizon Communications, said it had reported 455 strike-related incidents of assault, harassment and vandalism to the police in 12 states and the District of Columbia -- with more than half of them in New York State.
The first two strike-related arrests were made in New York yesterday. And last evening, New York State Supreme Court Judge Louis York, in Manhattan, granted the company's request for a temporary restraining order, effective through next Monday, that bars picketers from preventing managers or replacement workers from entering their offices or carrying out work assignments.
The flare-ups, ranging from egg throwing to arson, have come amid a scorching spell of heat and humidity that descended on the New York metropolitan area on Sunday, shortening tempers just as the strike began. The weather may help explain why the city, which lately has prided itself on a steep drop in crime, was rocked on Sunday night by a wave of violence, including 20 shootings and 4 murders, that had nothing to do with the strike,
But experts say outbreaks along picket lines and evidence of strike-related vandalism in New York point to broader, farther-reaching factors in the nation's largest city and communications capital, where a rapid technological new-economy shift into nonunionized wireless and Internet communications jobs is running head on into a long tradition of union activism.
"This is the place where the unions will have their impact," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban studies and a telecommunications expert at New York University. "The density of the city means that a small disruption can have an enormous effect.'
Last night, the company declined to estimate how many of several thousand residential phone lines in New York City were still out of service because of vandalism that had occurred since the strike began early Sunday. Union leaders have denied member involvement in any network vandalism.
Mr. Moss said the unionized Verizon workers, many of them schooled in strike tactics through years of employment at AT&T and Nynex (which merged with Verizon's predecessor, Bell Atlantic in 1997), hold a particularly potent weapon in New York because of their knowledge of the intricacies the city's telecommunications wiring -- and because of the wide publicity they are assured if the network is disrupted.
"They know the infrastructure because they built it," he said. "And since this is the media capital of the world, you get more sympathy from other union workers than you would anywhere else."
That logic was apparently not lost yesterday on a striking Verizon worker, who gave his name only as Jerry, and who was involved in a confrontation outside a Verizon maintenance garage on King Street in the SoHo section of Manhattan. Accounts varied, but the incident resulted in a maintenance truck's being battered and stuck under a electronic gate that witnesses said had been lowered by strikers, who had access to the gate's remote control box. A nonunion Verizon contractor, who was in the truck, was not injured. No arrests were made.
"Every now and then it gets tense," said Jerry, a member of the Communication Workers of America. "But we know that a large majority of jobs in this industry will go wireless, and it is only the union that can give us a future."
Besides winning the court injunction, the company responded to union violence by increasing a $10,000 reward it began offering on Sunday for information leading to convictions for strike-related vandalism. The new bounty is $25,000.
"We certainly have evidence the our management workers have experienced abuse from the pickets, sometimes dangerously so," said Eric Rabe, a Verizon spokesman. Similar injunctions had been issued by state courts in Pennsylvania and Rhode Island on Monday, the company said.
In one of yesterday's arrests in New York, a picketing worker was charged with disorderly conduct outside Verizon's Manhattan headquarters at 6th Avenue and 42nd Street, after the police said he refused to remain behind a barricade.
In the other incident, the police department said a striking worker was charged with petty larceny after removing lug nuts from the wheels of a Verizon maintenance truck on West 15th Street.
Verizon said yesterday that it had received reports of 143 incidents of vandalism or harassment involving its employees or equipment within New York City since the strike began, and believed at least 115 might have involved criminal activity.
But a spokeswoman in Washington for the Communications Workers of America, Candice Johnson, said Verizon might be exaggerating the disruption caused by the strike.
